abstract: Three technology titans — Amazon, Google and Microsoft — will be reporting their quarterly financial results on Thursday.
lead_para: It’s three times the fun with tech titan earnings on Thursday.
headline: Daily Report: A Trio of Earnings From Tech Behemoths

abstract: Tech earnings season is going into full swing, with companies including Yahoo, IBM, Google and Microsoft set to report quarterly results this week. Their financial data may offer insight into which companies are gaining the upper hand in some tech battles.
lead_para: The technology industry’s financial data is set to go on full display this week.
headline: Daily Report: Tech Tussles Take Center Stage in Earnings

abstract: The new show from Amazon finds Mr. Esmer as a tennis pro at a country club in the summer of 1985.
lead_para: Ennis Esmer might not be the next Rafael Nadal, but he gives it a good shot. In the new Amazon series “Red Oaks,” set at a country club in the summer of 1985, Mr. Esmer plays Nash, a flirtatious tennis pro and questionable role model to his protégé, David (Craig Roberts), an assistant tennis coach struggling to figure out his postgrad life.
headline: Ennis Esmer of ‘Red Oaks’ Talks Tennis and Comedy

abstract: Walmart is giving away some cutting-edge software to make it easier to switch cloud suppliers. Walmart’s retail nemesis, Amazon, is also the No. 1 cloud company.
lead_para: Walmart, the retail giant, has become an Internet powerhouse, employing more than 2,200 engineers today in Silicon Valley alone. They are working mainly on the cloud-based commerce technology behind the big Walmart and Sam’s Club shopping sites.
headline: Walmart Takes Aim at ‘Cloud Lock-in’

abstract: Amazon Web Services is starting to offer capabilities that compete head-to-head with longtime business computing giants like Oracle and IBM.
lead_para: LAS VEGAS — There is a famous story from the early days of Google that goes something like this: When a group of New York media big shots heard about the huge efficiency of search advertising, which could hurt their own businesses, the memorable reaction of one of them was a more vulgar take on “You’re fussing with the magic!”
headline: Amazon Messes With Billions in Corporate Computing Dollars

abstract: Amazon Web Services is building a global method of creating software quickly that could become a standard for how business computing systems are put together.
lead_para: LAS VEGAS — Amazon Web Services doesn’t just want to dominate the global business in selling computing online. It also wants to be the rarest thing of all in the technology industry: a long-lived company.
headline: Amazon Building a Tech Business for the Long Haul

abstract: This new comedy manages to be of the ’80s rather than about them, a startlingly authentic evocation rather than a satire or a dissection.
lead_para: “Red Oaks,” a new Amazon comedy, pulls off a neat trick: Set in 1985, it manages to be of the ’80s rather than about them, an affectionate and startlingly authentic evocation rather than a satire or a dissection. Whether it’s a trick that needed to be pulled off at all is debatable, but the result, while uneven across its 10 episodes (all of which debut on Friday on the streaming service), is undeniably charming.
headline: Review: Amazon’s ‘Red Oaks’ Aims for ’80s Affection, Not Satire

abstract: An article published in The New York Times two months ago, detailing Amazon’s work culture, drew a lengthy response on Monday from the company’s senior vice president for global corporate affairs.
lead_para: In an unusually public tussle over a prominent article, a senior executive from Amazon and the top editor of The New York Times clashed on Monday over the details in a Times article about the Internet retailer’s work culture.
headline: Amazon Spars With The Times Over Investigative Article

abstract: In recent years, low-cost booksellers have proliferated on the web. But how does a company that’ll sell you a book for a penny make a profit?
lead_para: Ever since a university gave me a literature degree certifying that I have read Chaucer in the original Middle English, my taste in books has reverted to very specific, lowbrow stuff. I like murder mysteries, heist books and spy books, preferably from the 1950s through the 1980s. These titles can be hard to find; many of them are out of print, unavailable on Kindle, and their presence in the New York Public Library is hit or miss.
headline: A Penny for Your Books

abstract: The retail giant forecast lackluster sales growth for this year and a steep profit dip for next, in part because costs are climbing sharply as sales are flat.
lead_para: He is the consummate Walmart company man.
headline: Walmart Chief Defends Investments in Labor, Stores and the Web

abstract: “Patriot,” “Good Girls Revolt,” “Edge,” “One Mississippi,” “Z” and “Highston” are the streaming service’s latest original TV programs.
lead_para: Since 2013, Amazon has released a batch of original TV pilots several times a year for the public to review and vote on. Our TV critics take a look at the latest crop, which will be available beginning on Thursday.
headline: Reviews: Amazon Pilots Include a Revolt and the Supernatural

abstract: The retailing giant announced that it would give fathers up to six weeks of paternity leave and more than double maternity leave. It is also opening a small bookstore in Seattle.
lead_para: Amazon, which prides itself on being surprising, is doing two predictably unpredictable things this week.
headline: Amazon Adds New Perks for Workers and Opens a Bookstore

abstract: A look at Do Not Track technology in web browsers, and how to use Google Cardboard effectively.
lead_para: Q. Do all web browsers have the anti-tracking feature? How do I turn it on in Firefox and does it actually work?
headline: Covering Your Browser Tracks

abstract: Setbacks Cast Harsh Light on Manhattan Prosecutor | A Rocky Quarter for Hedge Funds | Marriott’s Deal to Buy Starwood Hotels
lead_para: THE ECONOMIC COST OF TERRORISM  | After the horrific attacks in Paris, it is an issue that policy makers are grappling with,Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column.
headline: Morning Agenda: The Economic Cost of Terrorism

abstract: Jeff Bezos bucked the trend of seeking short-term results to create an addictive shopping experience few can match. And his newer enterprise is a blockbuster, too.
lead_para: To study the graph of Amazon’s stock performance in 2015 is to witness a series of stepwise lurches toward commanding new heights. Over all, the stock market has been flat this year, and technology companies, as a group, haven’t fared much better.
headline: How Amazon’s Long Game Yielded a Retail Juggernaut

abstract: Voters’ defeat of a measure that would have imposed restrictions on Airbnb rentals spurs a discussion on the company’s approach to setting up shop in a city.
lead_para: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.
headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Airbnb Takes San Francisco

abstract: The technology research firm IDC predicts the pace of digital transformation of business is going to accelerate and increasingly hit every industry.
lead_para: It is the time of year when the big technology research shops gaze into the near future to identify trends that will have the most impact on corporate America and the tech industry over the next few years.
headline: Digital Transformation Going Mainstream in 2016, IDC Predicts

abstract: American Made, a venture introduced in 2013, was intended to be eBay’s answer to Etsy, the pioneer in the online handmade goods market.
lead_para: Martha Stewart has ditched eBay, taking her American Made store to Amazon’s Handmade marketplace, as the e-commerce giant flexes its muscle in the burgeoning online market for handcrafted goods.
headline: A Martha Stewart Store Makes a Leap to Amazon

abstract: Total online sales are expected to generate $2.6 billion on Black Friday, a 14 percent increase compared to the same day last year.
lead_para: In shops across the country, including the empty malls of Georgia and the “not too crazy” crowds at struggling J. Crew, the relative calm that accompanied Black Friday shopping this year belied a frenzy for deals — many of them on the web.
headline: Black Friday Shopping Shifts Online as Stores See Less Foot Traffic

abstract: This new Amazon series envisions a postwar America occupied by triumphant German and Japanese forces.
lead_para: What if Hitler had won?
headline: Red, Reich and Blue: Building the World of ‘The Man in the High Castle’

abstract: Groups representing thousands of authors, agents and independent booksellers are calling for the Department of Justice to examine Amazon.
lead_para: This is a triumphant moment for Amazon.
headline: Accusing Amazon of Antitrust Violations, Authors and Booksellers Demand Inquiry

abstract: A reason for the company’s success has been its cloud computing division, Amazon Web Services, which generated $1.82 billion in revenue last quarter.
lead_para: We have reached Peak Amazon, or perhaps Prime Amazon, David Streitfeld reports.
headline: Daily Report: Amazon Shows Profit for a Change

abstract: The dream of consumer drones may be one step closer to reality, as Facebook announces that its unmanned aerial vehicle is ready for in-flight tests.
lead_para: In about a year and a half — ever since Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive, unveiled one — drones for consumer use seem to have proliferated everywhere. Quentin Hardy and Vindu Goel wrote this year about how Facebook is building a V-shaped unmanned vehicle called Aquila to help connect people to the Internet. In China, a drone maker, DJI, has been valued at about $8 billion. New funds are being formed to invest in the flying machines. Even pranksters are using them to cause trouble.
headline: Daily Report: That Facebook Drone is Ready for Takeoff

abstract: Mr. Clarkson, a popular TV personality whose contract with the BBC ended in March, said on Twitter that he would film a new show with his former co-hosts.
lead_para: Jeremy Clarkson, a popular British TV personality and the former host of BBC’s “Top Gear,” said on Twitter on Thursday that he would film a new car-themed show for Amazon.
headline: Jeremy Clarkson, Former ‘Top Gear’ Host, Announces Deal With Amazon

abstract: The group Authors United details their case against Amazon.
lead_para: The group Authors United details their case against Amazon.
headline: The Authors United Position Paper on Amazon’s Book Selling Practices

abstract: The Authors Guild, the American Booksellers Association and Authors United have sent letters and statements to the Justice Department calling for an investigation into Amazon.
lead_para: The Authors Guild, the American Booksellers Association and Authors United have sent letters and statements to the Justice Department calling for an investigation into Amazon.
headline: Documents: Authors and Booksellers Call for Amazon Inquiry

abstract: The American Booksellers Association is calling for the Justice Department to investigative Amazon for antitrust violations, contending that the company’s sales tactics threaten authors and publishers.
lead_para: The American Booksellers Association is calling for the Justice Department to investigative Amazon for antitrust violations, contending that the company’s sales tactics threaten authors and publishers.
headline: American Booksellers’ Letter to the Justice Department

abstract: The Authors Guild is urging the Department of Justice to investigate Amazon for what it calls “anti-competitive behavior” in book sales.
lead_para: The Authors Guild is urging the Department of Justice to investigate Amazon for what it calls “anti-competitive behavior” in book sales.
headline: Authors Guild’s Call to Investigate Amazon

abstract: The investigation is the latest hurdle for Amazon and other American tech giants as European policy makers pursue antitrust, tax and other inquiries.
lead_para: In the digital world, things change in an instant. One minute you are the people’s champion. In the next, perhaps a villain.
headline: Amazon’s E-Books Business Investigated by European Antitrust Regulators

abstract: Amazon on Tuesday afternoon joined other major retailers such as Walmart, Sears and eBay and banned the sale of merchandise bearing the Confederate battle flag.
lead_para: The debate over the Confederate battle flag has spilled into the world of commerce as major retailers including Walmart, Sears and eBay have banned the sale of merchandise bearing the Civil War symbol.
headline: Retailers Ban Sale of Merchandise Bearing Confederate Flag

abstract: As the marquee sponsor, the online behemoth’s fashion division aims to attract more high-end brands to its primary website.
lead_para: The click-clack that echoed through the loftlike fashion photography studio was the same click-clack that can be heard in fashion offices around New York City: Manolo Blahnik high heels on polished floors.
headline: Amazon Gears Up for New York Fashion Week for Men

abstract: The much-ballyhooed 20th anniversary discount event is awash in complaints of lackluster products and interminable waiting.
lead_para: Has Amazon Prime Day been everything it was advertised to be?
headline: More Fizzle Than Sizzle on Amazon’s Prime Day

abstract: Plus, Amazon’s ascent, Costume Institute stats and more from the week in style.
lead_para: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.
headline: Limited Too 2, Project Runway’s Record and R.I.P. Elio Fiorucci

abstract: An iPhone case that looks like a handgun could be too easily mistaken for a real weapon, officials say, and a United States senator moved Tuesday to ban its sale.
lead_para: An iPhone case that looks like a handgun is drawing warnings that it could be too easily mistaken for a real weapon.
headline: Gun-Shaped iPhone Case ‘Is a Terrible Idea,’ Police Officials Warn

abstract: Even Black Friday is getting lost in the blur of perpetual discounts as some of the biggest retailers go head-to-head Wednesday in a new midsummer event.
lead_para: Rollback. Doorbuster. Blowout prices. Do those words mean anything anymore?
headline: Amazon Dreams Up a Sale in a Calendar Bursting With Them

abstract: Groups representing thousands of authors, agents and independent booksellers are calling for the Department of Justice to examine Amazon.
lead_para: This is a triumphant moment for Amazon, David Streitfeld reports.
headline: Daily Report: Writers and Booksellers Seek U.S. Antitrust Inquiry Into Amazon

abstract: The film, about gun violence in Chicago, was acquired by Amazon Studios, which hopes to create a dozen movies a year.
lead_para: Amazon has landed Spike Lee’s new film, “Chi-Raq,” about violence in inner-city Chicago, as its first original movie production, seeking to make a splash with a well-known filmmaker, a controversial title and a well-known cast.
headline: Amazon Lands Spike Lee’s ‘Chi-Raq’ as Its First Original Movie

abstract: Despite derision in social media, the one-day sale appeared to achieve the company’s goals: more sales, and a big bump in subscribers to its Amazon Prime service.
lead_para: Despite a much-derided  product lineup and clunky wait-lists, Amazon said on Friday that it sold more products during its Prime Day sale this week than Black Friday last year, and that more new members tried its Prime subscription service than on any single day in the retailer’s 20-year history.
headline: Amazon Says Prime Day Beat Black Friday in Sales Numbers

abstract: Between series like “Transparent” and deals with Woody Allen, Spike Lee and the car-show host Jeremy Clarkson, Amazon is nurturing its original programming to build its subscription service.
lead_para: Roy Price, the vice president of Amazon Studios, stood onstage before a roomful of television critics in Los Angeles about a year ago and instructed them on how to sign up for the retailer’s Prime subscription service, which — along with two-day shipping — offered access to its budding lineup of original series.
headline: Amazon Pushes to Deliver More Prime Time

abstract: A reason for the company’s success has been its cloud computing division, Amazon Web Services, which generated $1.82 billion in revenue last quarter.
lead_para: We have reached Peak Amazon, or perhaps Prime Amazon.
headline: Amazon Reports Unexpected Profit, and Stock Soars

abstract: Mr. Delaney brings his biting relationship comedy, which ran earlier this year in Britain, to Amazon.
lead_para: Rob Delaney is onstage at the Bell House in Brooklyn, telling jokes about deviant sex acts with a car commercial smile.
headline: Rob Delaney, a Hit on Twitter, Turns to Television With ‘Catastrophe’

abstract: As companies like Walmart, Amazon and Sears were moving to discontinue sales of products tied to the Confederate battle flag, sales of them were soaring.
lead_para: Entering a debate that has played out for years mostly in the political realm, many of the nation’s largest retailers abruptly decided this week to stop selling merchandise tied to the Confederate battle flag.
headline: Confederate Flag Sales Soar as Retailers Pull Stock

abstract: In this comedy, Sharon Horgan and Rob Delaney play a couple brought closer together after an unexpected pregnancy.
lead_para: “Catastrophe,” a bittersweet British television comedy making its American debut on Amazon Prime, is the product of an unlikely artistic union. One of its creators, Sharon Horgan, is a veteran sitcom writer and star who could be fairly called the Tina Fey of British TV, in stature if not style. The other, Rob Delaney, is an American comedian best known for having more than a million Twitter followers; he’s headlining a TV show for the first time.
headline: Review: ‘Catastrophe,’ on Amazon Prime, Shares a Special Comedy Relationship

abstract: Google is becoming more public about its data centers, talking about its network and how much fiber it owns. The idea is to show off assets that Amazon, Microsoft and IBM cannot match in the competition for cloud customers.
lead_para: Google is wielding a new weapon against Amazon and Microsoft for cloud computing customers: itself.
headline: Google Is Its Own Secret Weapon in the Cloud

abstract: Founded in Montclair by the former journalist and author Donald Katz in 1995, Audible has been making itself heard at ever-increasing volume since moving to Newark from Wayne in 2007.
lead_para: On a gray April morning in Newark, Jonathan Davis, an actor, sat in a conference room and paused to consider the value of his work.
headline: At Audible, Work Speaks Volumes

abstract: Amazon beat Google to the acquisition of a popular gaming video service. Now Google is responding with a new YouTube Gaming application.
lead_para: About a year ago Google tried to acquire Twitch, the popular video game streaming site, but lost out to Amazon. Now it will try to build its own gaming portal.
headline: YouTube Takes On Amazon With New Gaming App

abstract: So-called software containers got backing from companies including Cisco Systems and Google, while another group of companies detailed plans to automate certain aspects of cloud computing.
lead_para: An unusual combination of big and small tech companies are working on ways to accelerate the development of cloud computing technologies.
headline: Tech Companies Line Up Behind ‘Containers’ and the Cloud

abstract: Amazon is by far the largest e-commerce player. Six hundred smaller fry gathered in Chicago this week to work out strategies for competing against or even cooperating with the Seattle giant.
lead_para: For all of the noise and hype — drones! one-hour delivery! get more toilet paper painlessly! — e-commerce is showing the first signs of maturing as a business. Figures from the research firm eMarketer show the rate of domestic growth falling from 16.5 percent in 2013 to 14.2 percent this year to 11.6 percent in 2018. By that point, e-commerce in the United States will still be less than 10 percent of all retail. The death of the physical store, so widely anticipated in the last few years, is nowhere in sight.
headline: Selling E-Commerce While Avoiding Amazon

abstract: The Amazon Echo is an artificially intelligent personal assistant answering to the name Alexa. It’s not yet heavy on the “intelligent,” but could one day be useful.
lead_para: THIS week, I asked a friend for help: “Alexa, can you write this review for me?”
headline: Amazon Echo, a.k.a. Alexa, Is a Personal Aide in Need of Schooling

abstract: Trailing Amazon in e-commerce sales, Walmart is starting a new online shipping program, hiring tech employees and pledging to invest $1 billion in online operations.
lead_para: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. — In the world of brick and mortar, Walmart is a titan, ringing up more than $1 billion of sales a day.
headline: Walmart, Lagging in Online Sales, Is Strengthening E-Commerce

abstract: Amazon has given a welcome boost to the beleaguered United States Postal Service.
lead_para: The giant e-marketeer Amazon may not have delivery drones in the air yet, but it does have letter carriers from local post offices busy delivering its packages to customers. In an innovative venture into e-commerce by the hard-pressed United States Postal Service, letter carriers in major cities have been making deliveries since October not only of the usual Amazon products but also of fresh milk, eggs, fish and other perishable commodities as Amazon continues its insatiable spread into the nation’s commercial aisles.
headline: Neither Rain Nor Snow Nor Gloom of Night Stays Amazon Deliveries

abstract: Is the company’s culture one of a kind, or a sign of the workplace of the future?
lead_para: The best thing about Jeff Bezos, the founder, chairman, president and chief executive of Amazon, is that he doesn’t give a hoot what anybody else thinks. The worst thing about Jeff Bezos is that he doesn’t give a hoot what anybody else thinks.
headline: Jeff Bezos and the Amazon Way

abstract: Perhaps nowhere is the inequality gap created by the latest technology boom as evident as in San Francisco’s Tenderloin neighborhood, a longtime low-income area that is now increasingly populated by tech start-ups.
lead_para: Silicon Valley’s technology boom has fueled a growing divide between rich and poor in the nation’s innovation capital. It’s a divide that has festered, turning into demonstrations around potent symbols like the buses that Google uses to ferry employees to work. Tech companies have tried to salve the wounds by giving away technology, among other moves.
headline: Daily Report: Where to See the Inequality Gap Wrought by the Tech Boom

abstract: Top-tier employers may be changing their official policies in a nod to work-life balance, but brutal competition remains an inescapable component of workers’ daily lives.
lead_para: On Wall Street, in Silicon Valley, across the legal profession and the corporate world, a growing chorus of companies are singing the praises of a kinder workplace, announcing policies like generous maternity leave at Netflix, and Goldman Sachs’s rule against investment-banking analysts working on Saturdays.
headline: Work Policies May Be Kinder, but Brutal Competition Isn’t

abstract: Two Amazon pilots going up on Friday both feature lead characters engaging in subterfuge.
lead_para: Judging “Sneaky Pete,” which stars Giovanni Ribisi as a con man and recent ex-con hiding out in upstate New York, has a lot to do with context. As an Amazon pilot — it’s one of two, along with “Casanova,” going up on Friday — it looks kind of ordinary, surprisingly like a broadcast network drama. Semi-episodic, slightly procedural, light dusting of dark humor.
headline: Review: In ‘Sneaky Pete’ and ‘Casanova,’ a Fast Talker and a Smooth Talker

abstract: Ms. Egan’s book, due out Tuesday, centers on a magazine editor whose life is upended when she takes a fast-paced job at a company much like Amazon.
lead_para: “I’m an oversharer,” Elisabeth Egan said before an interview had even begun.
headline: Elisabeth Egan’s ‘A Window Opens’ Has Echoes of Her Amazon Odyssey

abstract: The recent New York Times article about Amazon inspired an unprecedented online conversation about workplace stress. Here are a few of the thousands of comments posted across the web.
lead_para: The recent New York Times article about Amazon inspired an unprecedented online conversation about workplace stress. Here are a few of the thousands of comments posted across the web.
headline: Amazon’s Social Rift

abstract: Walmart’s announcement of increased investment in e-commerce was a tacit acknowledgment that it had fallen far behind Amazon, a leader in the field.
lead_para: When Walmart announced last week that it was significantly increasing its investment in e-commerce, it tacitly acknowledged that it had fallen far behind Amazon in the race for online customers.
headline: Walmart Plays Catch-Up With Amazon

abstract: Amazon opens the latest battle against Google and Apple by banning the sale of its rivals’ streaming media players.
lead_para: The technology industry in recent years has been shaped by a clash of the titans — Google, Apple, Amazon and one or two other companies, which are increasingly getting into each other’s businesses as software and hardware blend and mix.
headline: Daily Report: Amazon and the Clash of the Titans

abstract: The move is intended to address anger over benefits that have been granted to companies like Starbucks and Amazon.
lead_para: BRUSSELS — European Union finance ministers agreed on Tuesday to force member states to share information about preferential tax deals granted to multinational corporations.
headline: E.U. to Force Members to Share Data on Multinationals’ Tax Deals

abstract: Amazon stopped offering the plastic card-reader device to new merchants as of Friday evening, and it will stop supporting Amazon Register by February.
lead_para: There is one fewer player in the payments processing game.
headline: Amazon Shutting Down Its ‘Register’ Credit Card Processor

abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Nick Corasaniti, Kirk Johnson and others.
lead_para: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »
headline: What We’re Reading

abstract: Farhad Manjoo is off this week, so tech reporter Nick Wingfield joins Mike Isaac to discuss Microsoft, whose chief, Satya Nadella, has made some helpful changes in the last 18 months.
lead_para: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Mr. Manjoo is off this week, so Mr. Isaac is conversing with fellow tech reporter Nick Wingfield.
headline: Mike and Nick’s Week in Tech: Microsoft in the Cloud

abstract: Companies from Artsy to Amazon hope to use digital technology to improve a business that has long relied on the personal touch of traditional auction houses.
lead_para: Since the dawn of the web, companies have tried — and mostly failed — to sell fine art online.
headline: Purchasing Fine Art Is Increasingly Just a Click Away

abstract: Like its rival Amazon, the retailer sees a variety of potential uses for unpiloted flying machines.
lead_para: Walmart and Amazon may soon be taking their e-commerce battle into the air.
headline: Walmart Seeks Permit to Do Tests With Drones

abstract: After Amazon, Microsoft and Google reported earnings on Thursday, their market capitalizations soared, partly on the growth of cloud computing.
lead_para: Tech historians will look at Oct. 22, as a watershed. Cloud computing is no longer on the way, just a contender, or even a competitor to traditional enterprise technology companies. Instead, it is here, full force, and all the signs are that it is about to get a lot bigger, fast.
headline: The Cloud Is Here, Separating Disrupters From Disrupted

abstract: Oracle wants to do what it does best: build software that has the specific kinds of features that companies needs to manage their operations.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Counter to the expectations of many industry watchers, Oracle, the world’s largest maker of software for businesses, is not planning a global computing system to rival Amazon Web Services or Microsoft Azure, the other big global cloud companies.
headline: Oracle Will Not Build a Giant Cloud System Like A.W.S.

abstract: For Season 2 of Amazon’s hit show, the director and showrunner Jill Soloway explores family history and introduces new shades into the character of Maura.
lead_para: LOS ANGELES — On the set of “Transparent,” a handful of actors dressed for a flashback scene on a 1930s ocean liner — cloche hats, woolen jackets, long skirts — crowd together on benches in a large wooden container perched atop a gimbal, a device that can simulate the rolling of a ship. Sitting cross-legged on a long table a few yards away, the director Jill Soloway, who created this Amazon series, quietly throws out a few suggestions to the gently swaying actors.
headline: In ‘Transparent,’ a Heroine Evolves Further Still

abstract: Amazon Prime Music, available free to Prime subscribers, has a far smaller catalog than Spotify and Apple Music, but it may appeal to families and listeners who don’t require all the latest hits.
lead_para: SEATTLE — The music industry’s streaming wars are usually seen as having three major combatants: Spotify, Apple and Pandora.
headline: Amazon’s Streaming Music Aims for More Casual Listeners

abstract: Some companies go private to free themselves of meddling investors. But there’s another way: Ignore them.
lead_para: It was one of the biggest rebukes of the public markets in recent memory — and it may not be the last.
headline: Public Companies Trying to Mimic Private Firms

abstract: With a tap on a smartphone, consumers in some areas can have almost anything delivered within hours. But the cost of that is significant, and not always obvious.
lead_para: WHEN Emily Yang, a San Francisco tech worker, is running out of cat food, she taps an app called Instacart to order a new bag of kibble to be delivered to her door within hours. For dinner, she often orders through Sprig and Munchery, app-powered services that bring fresh organic meals to her home.
headline: The High Price of Delivery App Convenience

abstract: Tech companies want to own the airspace for many purposes. They are also looking for regulatory workarounds.
lead_para: Amazon released a video on Sunday showing off its prototype delivery drone.
headline: Drone Videos Could Help Amazon Sell Prime Subscriptions

abstract: The United States is under Nazi and Japanese occupation in this 10-episode alternative-history drama on Amazon Prime.
lead_para: The flag of Nazi-ruled America of 1962 in “The Man in the High Castle” has red and white stripes and a swastika on a field of blue. But even more chilling is how fascism has stamped itself upon American popular culture.
headline: Review: ‘The Man in the High Castle’ Imagines America Ruled by 2 Foreign Powers

abstract: Few would argue that Google knows better than most how to manage huge data centers. But in recent years Amazon has become the leader in selling that expertise to other companies.
lead_para: One of the great mysteries of the tech industry in recent years has been the seeming disinterest of Google, which is now called Alphabet, in competing with Amazon Web Services for corporate customers.
headline: Daily Report: Google Gets Serious About Competing in Cloud With Amazon Web Services

abstract: At a time when small-screen audiences have never had more viewing options, network executives are highlighting star turns and audacious themes as they aim to be heard above the din.
lead_para: PASADENA, Calif. — Jesus, a pregnant lesbian, an Asian-American family. A hip-hop empire, cybercrime fighters and the last man on earth. Those are among the cast of characters broadcasters now are depending on to rescue them from a season of troubling ratings declines.
headline: As Content Pours From Everywhere, New Network Shows Strive for Boldness

abstract: In a 23-page letter, the European Commission described a “complex” arrangement involving Amazon subsidiaries and outlined why it is pursuing the case.
lead_para: BRUSSELS — The European Union’s antitrust office on Friday released a preliminary finding that a tax deal between Amazon and the Luxembourg government appears to amount to unfair state aid that may have enabled the company to underpay its taxes for a decade or more.
headline: Amazon’s Tax Deal With Luxembourg May Break Rules, E.U. Regulator Says

abstract: The police have raided Amazon’s Tokyo headquarters, a distribution center and the offices of an affiliate, according to Japanese news reports.
lead_para: HONG KONG — Amazon.com’s Japan unit has said that it is cooperating with the local authorities in an investigation into whether child pornography has been sold on its website.
headline: Amazon Investigated in Japan Over Child Pornography

abstract: A nemesis for publishers, Amazon collected a Golden Globe for “Transparent,” becoming the first digital streaming service to win one for best TV series.
lead_para: LOS ANGELES — Among the usual names invoked during the acceptance speeches at Sunday’s Golden Globes — Harvey Weinstein, Scott Rudin, Les Moonves — was an unusual one: the tech billionaire Jeff Bezos, founder and chief executive of Amazon.
headline: With Win, Amazon Shakes Up Yet Another Industry

abstract: In a scene in “Mozart in the Jungle,” musicians are portrayed in a studio recording an over-the-top score for a low-budget film, a scene that verges on anachronistic.
lead_para: Nestled among the zany plotlines of the Amazon series “Mozart in the Jungle” are scenes that many classical musicians will recognize of the struggles, and indignities, that they face as they try to make it in New York.
headline: For Musicians, a TV Series Underscores Diminishing Role

abstract: Six months after its introduction, Kindle Unlimited is proving controversial and disruptive, just like so many other Amazon innovations.
lead_para: Amazon is disruptive, which means it is divisive. So inevitably the retailer’s new all-you-can-read venture, Kindle Unlimited, is the subject of heated debate, pro and con, among self-published writers.
headline: Writers Are Mixed Over Amazon Unlimited

abstract: The company delivered better earnings than expected in the fourth quarter, breaking a recent pattern of disappointments.
lead_para: Amazon’s profits fell in the fourth quarter. Revenue did not meet expectations. The company said it might lose money in the current quarter.
headline: Amazon Reports a Profit, Citing Prime as the Key

abstract: A series of investments by some of the tech industry’s biggest companies may sound odd, but they point to larger ambitions in moving giant amounts of data.
lead_para: In the last two weeks, investments from some of the biggest technology companies have raised an important question: Have they gone crazy?
headline: Tech Giants Invest in New Dreams of Grandeur

abstract: “Mozart in the Jungle” is a sexed-up, druggy, daffy and fictional look inside a major symphony, but most surprising is how true its depiction of the classical music industry rings.
lead_para: “Classical music has been losing money for people for 500 years,” an orchestra administrator tells her numbers-obsessed colleague in the new Amazon series “Mozart in the Jungle.” “It’s not a business.”
headline: Classical Music as ‘Jungle’ Rings True

abstract: Woody Allen will make his first television series, a full season of half-hour episodes, available only on Amazon’s Prime streaming service.
lead_para: After more than four decades of making films, Woody Allen is coming to television — streaming television.
headline: Amazon Signs Woody Allen to Write and Direct TV Series

abstract: Amazon’s latest foray: back-end email systems.
lead_para: Amazon Web Services on Wednesday announced Amazon WorkMail, an email service that adds a new front to the fierce competition in the cloud. WorkMail, which works behind existing interfaces like Microsoft Outlook, is being promoted as safer and cheaper than other systems.
headline: Amazon’s Got Mail

abstract: The company is posting its latest batch of original pilots just a few days after winning a Golden Globe for “Transparent.”
lead_para: Amazon won’t be sneaking up on anyone this time. It’s posting its latest batch of original pilots on Thursday, just a few days after winning a Golden Globe for one of the shows from the last batch, “Transparent.” Last week it was the supporting player of streaming video on demand; now it’s pushing Netflix for the lead role.
headline: Amazon Comes Out Swinging

abstract: Amazon’s “all you can eat” reading service, Kindle Unlimited, is driving down prices even as it boosts sales. For self-published authors, that’s a cause for concern.
lead_para: One big argument for “all you can eat” music, video and book services is that they encourage people to sample new artists and ultimately develop a deeper relationship with a few of them. You listen to songs you have never heard before because there is no additional cost, and then maybe you go to the concert and, perhaps, buy a T-shirt. Artists are rewarded at the end of the process, not in the beginning the way they used to be.
headline: For the Indie Writers of Amazon, It’s Publish or Perish

abstract: The online retailing giant signaled its broader ambitions to revolutionize the traditional system used to shepherd movies from the theaters to home screens.
lead_para: First the small screen, now the big screen. Amazon’s entertainment ambitions come in all sizes.
headline: Movie Studio by Amazon for Screens Big and Small

abstract: Amazon.com has agreed to buy Annapurna Labs, an Israeli chip developer, for about $350 million.
lead_para: Amazon.com has agreed to buy Annapurna Labs, an Israeli chip developer, a spokeswoman for the American company said on Thursday.
headline: Amazon to Buy Israeli Chip Developer

abstract: Amazon has busted up the traditional publishing system and done more to widen access to books than anything since the invention of the mass-market paperback. It is the reader’s best buddy. Or is it?
lead_para: During the 2012 campaign, Mitt Romney made an off-the-cuff comment about how “corporations are people.” He was mocked but perhaps was ahead of his time. A few years later, corporations are not only people but our friends.
headline: Amazon and Its Friends

abstract: At a time when many booksellers are struggling, Eslite is thriving, with 43 stores in Taiwan and one in Hong Kong. One secret to its success in Taiwan: It operates like a self-contained mall.
lead_para: It is late night on a Saturday and the floor is packed. On one side, two female fashion models huddle together, whispering. Across the room, a group of men cast furtive glances at other patrons from a raised platform.
headline: Saturday Night in Taipei, and the Cool Kids Are at the Bookstore

abstract: Disney and 20th Century Fox said that the six movies – “Star Wars,” “Return of the Jedi,” “The Empire Strikes Back,” “The Phantom Menace,” “Attack of the Clones” and “Revenge of the Sith” — would arrive online worldwide on April 10.
lead_para: LOS ANGELES – Luke Skywalker is finally becoming one with the iPad generation: The “Star Wars” movies – for the first time — are being made available for purchase through digital stores like iTunes, Google Play and Amazon.
headline: ‘Star Wars’ Movies Will Be Available at Digital Stores Like Amazon and iTunes

abstract: Amazon said in its first-quarter earnings report that its cloud division, Amazon Web Services, had revenue of $1.57 billion and operating income of $265 million.
lead_para: Amazon unveiled the financial performance of its powerful growth engine for the first time on Thursday, and the numbers sure looked pretty — especially compared with big companies like Microsoft and Google that are chasing it, David Streitfeld and Nick Wingfield report.
headline: Daily Report: Amazon Dominates Cloud Computing, but Tech Giants Are in Pursuit

abstract: For the first time, the web retailer broke out its numbers for its cloud computing division, which Jeff Bezos, the chief executive, called “a $5 billion business and still growing fast.”
lead_para: Amazon resumed its money-losing ways in the first quarter, even though it sold a lot of things.
headline: Amazon Swings to Small Loss While Revenue Jumps 15%

abstract: Even with an upgrade, there are several ways to work with Microsoft Office files. Also, backing up data on an Amazon Fire tablet.
lead_para: Q. I’m running Mac OS 10.6.8 and want to upgrade to the new OS X 10.10 (Yosemite). When installing, I got a warning that Yosemite won’t support Microsoft Office, so I stopped. Is there any way to use Yosemite and still have access to Word and Excel files?
headline: Working With Old Office Files on a New Mac OS

abstract: Bringing the efficiency of the web to common household tasks has opened a new door to the home services industry, which is estimated to be worth more than $800 billion.
lead_para: The installation of Deborah David’s new kitchen faucet was a $145 job. But it lies at the heart of an expanding $400 billion commercial war.
headline: Amazon, Google and More Are Drawn to Home Services Market

abstract: Bringing the efficiency of the web to common household tasks has opened a new door to the home services industry, which is estimated to be worth more than $800 billion.
lead_para: Some of the biggest names in e-commerce, along with a growing pool of start-ups, are vying for a chunk of the fragmented, quotidian, heretofore entirely local market of electricians, plumbers, dog walkers and other manual labor, known broadly as home services.
headline: Daily Report: Amazon, Google and More Are Drawn to Home Services Market

abstract: The deal between the online giant Amazon and the publisher HarperCollins covers both print and digital titles.
lead_para: HarperCollins has signed a deal with Amazon to sell its books, much like the contracts the online bookseller has reached with other publishers.
headline: HarperCollins and Amazon in Multiyear Publishing Deal

abstract: Want to work at Amazon, Apple or McKinsey? Some business schools have impressive records placing graduates in certain fields and even companies.
lead_para: With some 13,000 graduate schools of business across the globe, the M.B.A. degree has clearly become a commodity.
headline: M.B.A. Programs That Get You Where You Want to Go

abstract: Amazon said in its first-quarter earnings report that its cloud division, Amazon Web Services, had revenue of $1.57 billion and operating income of $265 million.
lead_para: Amazon unveiled the financial performance of its powerful growth engine for the first time on Thursday, and the numbers sure looked pretty — especially compared with big companies like Microsoft and Google that are chasing it.
headline: With Amazon Atop the Cloud, Big Tech Rivals Are Giving Chase

abstract: Amazon Web Services, the world’s biggest cloud company, is now selling cheap data analysis and prediction. It’s likely to get baked into all kinds of applications, bringing pain to the old guard.
lead_para: Welcome to the era of low-cost predictions. Your products and services will never be the same, and a couple of big companies may wish we’d never arrived.
headline: Amazon to Sell Predictions in Cloud Race Against Google and Microsoft

abstract: Pressure is mounting for American tech companies, including Google, to stop using complex tax structures and pay more on their European operations.
lead_para: In the continuing battle between Europe and American tech companies, score one for Europe.
headline: Amazon to Stop Funneling European Sales Through Low-Tax Haven

abstract: You can send the message to someone not in the original conversation by taking a couple of steps.
headline: Forwarding Text Messages on the iPhone

abstract: The stakes are high, and the valuations lofty, in a country that is adding five million new Internet users, many of them on mobile, a month.
lead_para: BANGALORE, India — Intense interest from prominent investors is helping to drive eye-popping valuations among Indian tech start-ups.
headline: Tech Start-Ups in India Attract Big Name Investors, and Money

abstract: The start-ups Enjoy and Jet.com are hoping to knock Amazon off its perch as the leader of online shopping.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — There are two ways for start-ups to take on Amazon, the reigning monarch of American online shopping.
headline: Two Retail Veterans Take Aim at Amazon’s E-Commerce Reign

abstract: Officials said the investigation would address whether large players like American tech giants were impeding competition for European consumers.
lead_para: LONDON — European officials on Wednesday opened an antitrust investigation into whether large technology companies were impeding competition in online shopping, the latest in a string of inquiries in Europe focused on the web’s biggest players.
headline: E.U. Commission Opens Antitrust Inquiry Into E-Commerce Sector

abstract: The competition commissioner, who took office in November and did not set new deadlines, cited difficulties in obtaining information.
lead_para: BRUSSELS — European officials investigating whether Apple, Amazon and other companies received sweetheart tax deals from Ireland and Luxembourg will not take action as soon as expected, the European Union competition commissioner said Tuesday.
headline: European Union Delays Action on Apple, Amazon and Starbucks Tax Inquiries

abstract: There’s a new guy in “Silicon Valley,” and he’s awful, which is great.
lead_para: Season 2, Episode 3: “Bad Money”
headline: ‘Silicon Valley’ Recap: It’s Not About How Much You Earn

abstract: The digital reading service will add over 9,000 audiobooks, as competition grows among e-book subscription services to become the Netflix of books.
lead_para: E-book subscription services are bulking up and expanding their libraries and services as the competition to become the Netflix of books escalates. On Thursday, the subscription reading service Scribd announced that it would add more than 9,000 audiobooks from Penguin Random House Audio to its platform, increasing its audiobook catalog to more than 45,000 titles.
headline: Scribd Expands Audiobook Catalog in Deal With Penguin Random House

abstract: The German automaker will test the program in Munich, hoping to solve the problem of packages that can’t be delivered because no one is home.
lead_para: FRANKFURT — Almost since the invention of the automobile, people have been using cars for more than just getting from place to place. The car is also a place to eat, to sleep and soon, it appears, to receive packages.
headline: Audi to Test Plan to Deliver Amazon Packages to Drivers’ Trunks

abstract: AWS kicked off the first of 16 meetings with a daylong direct assault on the existing corporate computing business. The Seattle-based cloud giant is now offering features and services for so-called hybrid clouds.
lead_para: Competition for the corporate dollar didn’t take long to heat up.
headline: Amazon Web Services Takes Fuller Aim at Enterprise Computing

abstract: AmazonCrossing brought out 44 new English translations from a diverse slate of literature, more than any other American publisher, according to data from Three Percent, a literary translation blog.
lead_para: It’s not Random House, and it’s not a specialized indie outfit like Europa Editions or New Directions. It’s Amazon.com. Last year, the company’s translation imprint, AmazonCrossing, brought out 44 new English translations from a diverse slate of literature, including Icelandic, Turkish and Korean. That’s more translated titles than any other American publisher, according to data from Three Percent, a literary translation blog at the University of Rochester.
headline: Who Is the Biggest Publisher of Foreign Literature in the U.S.?

abstract: The ride-hailing start-up Lyft appoints a new chief operating officer who worked at Amazon.
lead_para: Amazon has long focused on delivering packages to customers as efficiently as humanly possible. It makes sense, then, that Lyft, a ride-hailing start-up, would want to hire staff from the online retail giant.
headline: Lyft Hires Amazon Executive as Chief Operating Officer

abstract: The politics behind the European Union’s antitrust charges against the American Internet giant.
lead_para: Have you heard the term Gafa yet? It hasn’t caught on here in the United States — and I’m guessing it won’t — but in France, it has become so common that the newspapers hardly need to spell out its meaning. Everyone there already knows what Gafa stands for: Google-Apple-Facebook-Amazon.
headline: Europe’s Google Problem

abstract: G.E. is adding more sensor technology to products like street lights, heralding a sensor explosion that many believe will fuse the physical world with the Internet, anticipating and facilitating human behaviors.
lead_para: The technology world is looking at ways to make everything more efficient.
headline: The Sensor-Rich, Data-Scooping Future

abstract: The biggest American tech companies face intensifying scrutiny by European regulators, with — pressure that could potentially curb their sizable profits in the region and affect how they operate around the world.
lead_para: The biggest American tech companies face intensifying scrutiny by European regulators, with — pressure that could potentially curb their sizable profits in the region and affect how they operate around the world.
headline: How Europe Is Going After Apple, Google and Other U.S. Tech Giants

abstract: Full seasons, released all at once, are something genuinely new. And we’re just starting to figure out their conventions and aesthetics.
lead_para: At some point during Netflix’s “Sense8” — a gorgeous, ridiculous series about eight strangers scattered across the world who use a psychic connection to aid one another in fights and at one point have a virtual orgy — I had to ask myself: What am I watching?
headline: Streaming TV Isn’t Just a New Way to Watch. It’s a New Genre.

abstract: The Haggler tries to get to the bottom of where fake online product reviews originate. One notable source seems to be the website Fiverr.
lead_para: The holiday online shopping season has begun, and that means reading lots of online product reviews. Some of these reviews are helpful, others are not. And many are fakes — raves or pans from people who have never actually used the product. Where do fake reviews come from? In this column, a close-up look at one notable source.
headline: All the Product Reviews Money Can Buy

abstract: The e-commerce giant appeared to solidify its hold on the online world this holiday season. What remains to be seen is how that will translate into profits.
lead_para: It’s not your imagination: Every recycling bin on your block really is filled with Amazon boxes.
headline: Daily Report: A Happy Holiday for Amazon

abstract: An Amazon Prime membership offers thousands of streaming videos that can be watched on a multitude of devices — not all of the videos are free, however.
lead_para: Q. If I sign up for Amazon Prime, are all videos free to watch and do I need a Kindle Fire tablet to do so?
headline: Watching Video on Amazon Prime

abstract: Amazon capped its blockbuster year by reporting what it said was a record-breaking holiday season, shipping 200 million items through its Prime subscription service.
lead_para: Two decades after Jeffrey P. Bezos started Amazon in his Bellevue, Wash., garage, his e-commerce juggernaut could be forgiven for letting up on its rapid growth.
headline: It’s Amazon and Also-Rans in Retailers’ Race for Online Sales

abstract: Reviewing the gadget trade-in and recycling programs offered by Amazon, Gazelle and Best Buy.
lead_para: PEOPLE give all sorts of electronics as gifts around the holidays: phone chargers, e-book readers, video games, drones and more. But what should we do with the devices they are replacing?
headline: How to Sell or Recycle Old Electronics

abstract: Which news stories resonated the most with our readers? Here are the top five.
lead_para: On the community desk, we like to say that comments enhance the news. But sometimes, the comments are the news. Such was the case this year when an exposé became the most commented-on news story in Times history (that story is revealed below). Also this year: One of our top commenters upstaged his famous sibling and another became a celebrity in his hometown. To see which stories resonated most with our readers, you need look no further. These are the five most talked-about stories of the year.
headline: The Most Commented-On Articles of 2015

abstract: This comedy-drama on Amazon broadens its focus beyond Jeffrey Tambor’s character, Maura, to include the family’s children, in-laws, exes and long-gone ancestors.
lead_para: “What is being queer if not questioning everything?” asks Ali Pfefferman (Gaby Hoffmann), during an argument with her lover. Ali, who may be attracted to another woman, argues that she wants to avoid forcing a “heteronormative” model on their relationship. Her lover suggests that Ali, who only recently came out, is being perhaps a little self-serving. “Listen to yourself,” she says. “You’ve been queer for, like, 30 seconds.”
headline: Season 2 of ‘Transparent’ Expands Its View of the Pfefferman Clan

abstract: Amazon is reportedly removing some of the motorized scooters from its store after a series of fires.
lead_para: Amazon is reportedly removing some of the motorized scooters from its store after a series of fires.
headline: Amazon Pulls Hoverboards

abstract: The company’s report says streaming subscribers are spending more time in front of a screen.
lead_para: About two in five American households now subscribe to a video streaming service like Netflix, Amazon Prime or Hulu Plus, according to a new report from the media measurement company Nielsen that tracked the penetration of the digital offerings.
headline: Nielsen Charts Reach of Video Streaming

abstract: Ruth Porat, Morgan Stanley’s chief financial officer, is leaving for Google in the most visible example yet of the flow of talent from Wall Street to Silicon Valley.
lead_para: One of the country’s largest banks, Morgan Stanley, is losing its chief financial officer to Google in the most visible example yet of the flow of talent from Wall Street to Silicon Valley.
headline: Wall St. Stars Join Silicon Valley Gold Rush

abstract: Here are some prominent services offering live TV, à la carte networks and other on-demand streaming options in the United States.
lead_para: Here are some prominent services offering live TV, à la carte networks and other on-demand streaming options in the United States.
headline: Suddenly, Plenty of Options for Cord Cutters

abstract: This letter describes Amazon’s plans for a drone delivery system.
lead_para: This letter describes Amazon’s plans for a drone delivery system.
headline: Amazon Letter to the Federal Aviation Administration

abstract: The unusual move for Amazon is not about retail sales, but rather about shoring up its Fire TV streaming devices, which are crucial to its vision for the future.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon said on Thursday that it would stop selling devices from Apple and Google that compete with its own streaming media players, escalating the entertainment battle between the major tech companies.
headline: Amazon to Stop Selling Apple TV and Chromecast

abstract: The company reported net income of 17 cents a share, rather than the 13-cent loss analysts expected. Its shares rose as much as 10 percent after-hours.
lead_para: Amazon is selling a lot of things to a lot of people, and is even managing to carve out a little profit in the process.
headline: Amazon Posts an Unexpected Profit, and Its Shares Soar

abstract: Amazon’s new service, Handmade at Amazon, will offer artisans a broader market and rules that ensure products are not factory-produced.
lead_para: Amazon stepped into the handcrafted-goods ring on Thursday, opening an arts-and-crafts bazaar online that squarely takes aim at a niche but growing market dominated by the Brooklyn-based Etsy.
headline: Amazon Challenges Etsy With Strictly Handmade Marketplace

abstract: A prosthetic nose being sold online for Halloween from America’s largest retailer managed to offend both Arabs and Jews.
lead_para: After a raft of complaints on social networks, Walmart on Tuesday stopped selling a large prosthetic nose, described in its online Halloween store as “perfect for an Arab Sheik.”
headline: Walmart Withdraws Hooked ‘Sheik Fagin’ Nose From Halloween Store

abstract: We tested video streaming devices from Apple, Amazon, Roku and Google, and the Apple TV stood out. But it’s not the best for everyone. Here are the pros and cons of each device.
lead_para: We tested video streaming devices from Apple, Amazon, Roku and Google, and the Apple TV stood out. But it’s not the best for everyone. Here are the pros and cons of each device.
headline: How Apple TV Stacks Up: A Rundown of Streaming Devices

abstract: Walmart was once a disrupter in its own right but now it finds itself falling behind in the race for online customers.
lead_para: Walmart was once a disrupter in its own right but now it finds itself falling behind in the race for online customers.
headline: Jim Stewart on Walmart’s Challenges

abstract: A rocket company founded by Jeffrey P. Bezos, the Amazon chief executive, announced plans to use a historic launch site at Cape Canaveral.
lead_para: Blue Origin, a secretive rocket company started by Jeffrey P. Bezos, the chief executive of Amazon, made a splashy public announcement on Tuesday, saying it will build rockets and send them into orbit from Florida.
headline: Blue Origin, Jeff Bezos’ Rocket Company, to Launch From Florida

abstract: The online marketplace will now allow its Prime members to download some movies and TV shows to iOS and Android devices to watch programming offline.
lead_para: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the industry. Mr. Manjoo is off this week, so Mr. Isaac is conversing with fellow tech reporter Quentin Hardy.
headline: Mike and Quentin’s Week in Tech: Amazon’s Offline Game Changer

abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting interesting stories from around the web. In this installment, great reads from Jenna Wortham, John Eligon and others.
lead_para: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »
headline: What We’re Reading

abstract: The Times’s community team rounded up a selection of reader reactions to a recent story about the workplace culture at Amazon.
lead_para: Toilet paper-delivering drones may not be a thing (yet), but history was made over the weekend when Jodi Kantor and David Streitfeld’s exposé on workplace practices at Amazon became the most commented-on story at The New York Times.
headline: A Deluge of Comments From Readers With an Opinion About Amazon

abstract: The company’s chief told employees that he didn’t recognize the “soulless, dystopian workplace” that he said was depicted in a New York Times article.
lead_para: For 20 years, Amazon has reveled in its toughness. “Work hard” are the first two words of a company motto. An oft-repeated line from Jeff Bezos, the founder and chief executive, calls the company culture “friendly and intense, but if push comes to shove we’ll settle for intense.”
headline: Jeff Bezos and Amazon Employees Join Debate Over Its Culture

abstract: The sudden and rapid sell-off across global markets has caught many on Wall Street off guard.
lead_para: From his getaway cabin deep in the woods, an experienced adviser to wealthy hedge fund investors was hopping from one conference call to another to manage clients’ mounting anxiety.
headline: A Stock Market Rout in a Month That Hedge Funds Would Sooner Forget

abstract: Hackers post data stolen from a website for would-be adulterers, and an exposé about the world’s leading online retailer ruffles feathers.
lead_para: Farhad: Hey, Katie! Mike is off snorkeling in Hawaii, so I’m thrilled that you’re free to help me make sense of this week’s tech news. You have some small shoes to fill!
headline: Farhad and Katie’s Week in Tech: Amazon and Ashley Madison Exposed

abstract: Congress and the FCC can help consumers have more broadband options as they choose online services over cable TV.
lead_para: In recent years, a lot of media and telecommunications executives dismissed the idea that Americans would stop subscribing to cable and satellite TV services. But the cord-cutting phenomenon can no longer be ignored.
headline: Preparing for Life After Cable

abstract: The agreement includes civil penalties and stricter state standards on how toy guns look, which are intended to make them distinguishable from real guns.
lead_para: In New York, toy guns must walk a fine line: Be convincing enough for a child, but not convincing enough for an adult.
headline: New York Reaches Accords With Sellers of Toy Guns

abstract: In an email to all Amazon employees, Jeff Bezos wrote, “The article doesn’t describe the Amazon I know or the caring Amazonians I work with every day.”
lead_para: After the weekend publication of an article in The New York Times about his company’s management practices, Jeff Bezos, chief executive of Amazon, sent this message to all employees, linking to the Times article and a counterpoint written on LinkedIn:
headline: Amazon Chief’s Message to Employees

abstract: With the number of shows approaching 400 this year, John Landgraf of FX Networks says the cluttered TV landscape is challenging viewers and the industry.
lead_para: John Landgraf’s comments arrived like a thunderbolt.
headline: Soul-Searching in TV Land Over the Challenges of a New Golden Age

abstract: Reports of Amazon layoffs, a new digital assistant service and artificial intelligence in general.
lead_para: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the industry.
headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Facebook Assistant

abstract: Ron Perlman plays a corrupt judge, and Dana Delany is his cynical wife in this series.
lead_para: The pilot of “Hand of God,” Amazon’s second original hourlong drama, was posted just over a year ago. So we’ve known all this time that the series begins with Ron Perlman — an actor of formidable size who has played characters called Hellboy and the Beast — standing naked in a public fountain, speaking in tongues.
headline: Review: ‘Hand of God,’ on Amazon, Is a California Neo-Noir Thriller

abstract: Amazon is hoping to gain dominance in the living room with the same strategy it used to take over the e-books business: lower prices.
lead_para: Amazon is hoping to gain dominance in the living room with the same strategy it used to take over the e-books business: lower prices.
headline: Amazon Updates Its Fire TV and Tablet Offerings

abstract: With readers on a reverse migration to print, the “e-book terror has kind of subsided” for bookstores and publishers.
lead_para: Five years ago, the book world was seized by collective panic over the uncertain future of print.
headline: The Plot Twist: E-Book Sales Slip, and Print Is Far From Dead

abstract: The company says it plans to add more full-time employees, including software developers and engineers.
lead_para: Amazon plans to expand its Detroit office, adding more full-time jobs in hopes of creating a technology hub.
headline: Amazon Envisions a New Tech Hub as It Expands Its Detroit Presence

abstract: The growing competition between the two companies could take so-called machine learning to the masses.
lead_para: Google is chasing Amazon Web Services in a new area –- providing access to “on-demand” supercomputing resources.
headline: Google Follows Amazon Web Services Into On-Demand Supercomputing

abstract: This season, television audiences will be introduced to programs based on films, including “Limitless,” “Uncle Buck,” “Ash vs. Evil Dead” and “Rush Hour.”
lead_para: Television in recent years has been likened to the new novel. This coming season it seems that television is the old movie.
headline: Mining the Movies for the Next TV Hit

abstract: New shows from Louis C.K., Sacha Baron Cohen, Diablo Cody, Tig Notaro and Shane Black will be included in a slate of pilots that will debut on Amazon later this fall.
lead_para: New shows from Louis C.K., Sacha Baron Cohen, Diablo Cody, Tig Notaro and Shane Black will be included in a slate of pilots that will debut on Amazon later this fall.
headline: Amazon Announces New Pilots From Louis C.K., Tig Notaro and Sacha Baron Cohen

abstract: The reporters Jodi Kantor and David Streitfeld provided insight into their reporting on Amazon and its fast-paced, sometimes punishing, culture.
lead_para: Last January, when we began interviewing Amazon veterans about what it is like to work at the company, we realized that we were stepping into a heated private debate.
headline: Inside Amazon: Reporter’s Notebook

abstract: The rise of modern computing owes much to human-centered software design. A leading computer scientist has built a web site highlighting the work of the field’s pioneers.
lead_para: The march of progress in computing is a climb. Each big step forward is also a step up, so that communication is further away from the machine, more on human terms.
headline: Humanizing Technology: A History of Human-Computer Interaction

abstract: The company created its Amazon Appstore app for Android shoppers, but it has now released the Amazon Underground app to provide access to its digital goods.
lead_para: Q. Do you have to have one of Amazon’s Fire tablets to use its Amazon app store, or do I have other shopping options besides Google Play?
headline: Shopping for Amazon Apps With Android

abstract: A Wall Street analyst, a car company and an overpriced stock.
lead_para: Do you remember when Henry Blodget first became famous?
headline: The Tesla Cheerleader

abstract: The perception of Amazon as a difficult place to work could force the online retailer to initiate reforms, as Walmart has done with its own billion-dollar program.
lead_para: Amazon’s latest results were so superb that they catapulted the online retailer’s market value beyond that of Walmart Stores for the first time. Now, the $250 billion goliath led by Jeff Bezos finds itself in another spot that its bricks-and-mortar rival will more happily cede: defending labor practices.
headline: Why Amazon May Take a Page From Walmart’s Labor Playbook

abstract: Turning off the default motion tracking function, defending against PC scams and requesting order history reports from Amazon.
lead_para: Stopping
headline: Stopping the iPhone Step Counter

abstract: Details of working conditions at Amazon led to a response from employees, relatives and friends.
lead_para: Amazon recently surpassed Walmart as the most valuable retailer in the country. It is ceaselessly inventive, unafraid to try something and fail. Its ambitious goal: sell everything to everyone everywhere. It is also figuring out how to extract the most from its employees, whose dedication and obsession is the real engine behind the company’s success.
headline: Depiction of Amazon Stirs a Debate About Work Culture

abstract: Facebook is wading into the increasingly crowded field of digital personal assistants with a new offering called M.
lead_para: In the future, the world’s largest tech companies, like Apple, Amazon and Microsoft, want to make completing everyday chores as simple as asking a question of a digital assistant.
headline: Facebook Tests a Digital Assistant for Its Messaging App

abstract: The company is conducting an experiment in how far it can push white-collar workers to get them to achieve its ever-expanding ambitions.
lead_para: SEATTLE — On Monday mornings, fresh recruits line up for an orientation intended to catapult them into Amazon’s singular way of working.
headline: Inside Amazon: Wrestling Big Ideas in a Bruising Workplace

abstract: “Never looking back,” said one of a number of readers who have given up cable.
lead_para: Friday morning’s editorial on the growing number of Americans who are giving up cable- and satellite-TV service resonated with many readers. A number of them said in comments on the piece and on Facebook and Twitter that they, too, had happily given up cable.
headline: Have You Cut the Cable Cord?

abstract: Working long and continuous hours isn’t a prescription for higher productivity, much less higher quality or more innovation.
lead_para: Dear Jeff Bezos,
headline: Why Jeff Bezos Should Care More for Amazon’s Employees

abstract: Readers discuss the management style of Jeff Bezos, which many view as overly harsh and inhumane.
lead_para: Readers discuss the demanding, competitive environment promoted by Jeff Bezos.
headline: A Look Inside Amazon

abstract: The online argument over Amazon’s white-collar workplace gathered steam as employees and ex-employees recounted their own experiences at the retailer.
lead_para: The hard-charging white-collar culture at Amazon, which was chronicled by Jodi Kantor and David Streitfeld over the weekend, has sparked numerous online debates about the company.
headline: Daily Report: Amazon’s Workplace Culture Continues to Spur Online Debates

abstract: Plus, this is an Alaïa, no e-commerce for Céline and more from the week in style.
lead_para: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.
headline: Beyoncé Designs a Shoe, McDonald’s Ready-to-Wear and the American Apparel Saga Continues

abstract: European officials proposed new disclosure rules meant to make it more difficult for countries to work out special tax-avoidance deals with multinationals.
lead_para: BERLIN — European Union officials on Wednesday proposed new rules to try to discourage tax-avoidance deals with multinational corporations, which critics say give some countries unfair business advantages.
headline: European Union Moves to Limit Special Tax Deals

abstract: A V-shaped unmanned vehicle is the centerpiece of the social network’s plans to connect with the five billion or so people it has yet to reach.
lead_para: MENLO PARK, Calif. — In classical mythology, Aquila is the eagle carrying Jupiter’s thunderbolts skyward. At Facebook, it is the code name for a high-flying drone, indicative of the social networking company’s lofty ambitions.
headline: Drones Beaming Web Access Are in the Stars for Facebook

abstract: Unidentified hackers have attacked GreatFire.org, a website that provides access to news websites blocked by China.
lead_para: For years, a group of anonymous activists known as GreatFire.org has monitored online censorship in China, provided access to blocked websites and collected messages deleted by censors.
headline: Hackers Attack GreatFire.org, a Workaround for Websites Censored in China

abstract: The new program from Amazon allows customers to reorder household items like laundry detergent and paper towels with the push of a single physical button.
lead_para: Amazon has built a booming business of making it easy to buy things online. It has a patented one-click ordering mechanism. It offers subscription-style services. And on Tuesday, Amazon unveiled a pilot program that allows customers to order items with the push of a single physical button.
headline: Amazon Dash Aims to Be a Push-Button Substitute for the Supply Run

abstract: Google just matched Amazon for cheap online storage, with an important difference: While Amazon promises to fetch the cheap data in hours, Google offers to do it in three seconds.
lead_para: Google is offering a new kind of data storage service – and revealing its cloud computing strategy against Amazon Web Services and Microsoft Azure.
headline: Google Offers Cheap Storage for Certain Kinds of Data

abstract: While Amazon can now move its tests from inside a warehouse, the retailer still has a long way to go to realize its vision of autonomous delivery drones.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Federal regulators have given Amazon a green light to begin testing drones, but it will most likely take years before the online retailer can start delivering packages from the air to peoples’ homes.
headline: Amazon Wins Approval to Test Delivery Drones Outdoors

abstract: The lead developer of Lantern, a censorship-evading tool, discusses how it works and how it has reacted to the new measures by Chinese Internet regulators.
lead_para: In recent months, China’s Internet regulators have further restricted the already limited access that the nation’s 648 million Internet users have to the web. Several Google services, including Gmail and Gchat, have become inaccessible. Virtual private networks, or V.P.N.s, that once let users skirt online censorship have also been blocked.
headline: Q. and A.: Adam Fisk on Evading Internet Censorship in China

abstract: While Amazon can now move its tests from inside a warehouse, the retailer still has a long way to go to realize its vision of autonomous delivery drones.
lead_para: Federal regulators have given Amazon a green light to begin testing drones, but it will most likely take years before the online retailer can start delivering packages from the air to peoples’ homes, writes Nick Wingfield.
headline: Daily Report: F.A.A. Gives Amazon Limited Permission on Drones

abstract: After years of battling traditional players in the television business, the big three streaming services must defend against a variety of new offerings.
lead_para: Netflix, Amazon and Hulu have suddenly found themselves playing a new role: the establishment.
headline: Netflix, Amazon and Hulu No Longer Find Themselves Upstarts in Online Streaming

abstract: Internet-based retailers, especially Amazon, have had a particularly devastating impact on electronics retailers, many of whom have struggled to adapt to the technological age they helped usher in.
lead_para: I was assembling a home audio system recently and needed speaker wires. A friend recommended RadioShack. I went to two — in Manhattan and in Brooklyn — but, to my surprise, neither carried any. How could RadioShack, the place Americans go to for cables, connectors, circuits and all kinds of other electronic doodads, not have speaker wires?
headline: Goodbye to the Electronics Store

abstract: Learn about the differences between Amazon Fire TV and Fire TV stick (besides price), and also discover how to transfer airline boarding passes between iPhones.
headline: Choosing Between Amazon’s TV Streaming Hardware

abstract: Amazon has hired Mr. Carney as senior vice president for global corporate affairs. The move is unusual, as Amazon is known for grooming employees from within.
lead_para: Amazon, a technology company obsessed with secrecy, is hiring a former press secretary for President Obama, whose administration has been widely criticized for its aggressive leak investigations.
headline: Amazon Hires Jay Carney, Former Obama Press Secretary

abstract: A soon-to-start online marketplace that aims to loosen Amazon’s grip on e-commerce raises $140 million.
lead_para: Jet.com, a soon-to-start online marketplace that aims to loosen Amazon’s grip on e-commerce, said Wednesday that it had raised $140 million in a new round of funding.
headline: Jet.com Gets Investment That Values It at $600 Million

abstract: Proposed regulations requiring daylight flights with craft always being kept in sight might ground planned delivery services like Amazon’s Prime Air.
lead_para: In an attempt to bring order to increasingly chaotic skies, the Federal Aviation Administration on Sunday proposed long-awaited rules on the commercial use of small drones, requiring operators to be certified, fly only during daylight and keep their aircraft in sight.
headline: F.A.A. Rules Would Limit Commercial Drone Use

abstract: The online storage and collaboration company is trying to capture things like medical and financial records with a new style of data encryption.
lead_para: Box, a cloud-based data storage and collaboration company, hopes it has solved one of the last great impediments to businesses going fully online.
headline: Box Toughens Security to Draw Regulated Customers

abstract: Amazon’s television production wing ordered full seasons of its pilot programs for “The Man in the High Castle,” “Mad Dogs,” “The New Yorker Presents,” “Just Add Magic” and “The Stinky & Dirty Show.”
lead_para: In January, Amazon Studios, the online retail giant’s television production wing, posted 10 original pilots for viewers to watch and vote on. This morning, five of them were ordered to series: “The Man in the High Castle,” based on the Philip K. Dick novel that imagines an alternate reality in which the Axis powers won World War II; “Mad Dogs,” a dark comedy executive produced by Shawn Ryan (“The Shield,” “Terriers”); “The New Yorker Presents,” a docu-series overseen by Alex Gibney (“Taxi To the Dark Side,” “We Steal Secrets”); and the kids series “Just Add Magic” and “The Stinky & Dirty Show.”
headline: Amazon Orders Full Seasons for Five New Shows

abstract: Based on Michael Connelly’s series of novels, “Bosch” stars Titus Welliver as a rule-bending Los Angeles detective scarred by a grim childhood.
lead_para: The list of brooding, taciturn small-screen police detectives is already impossibly long, so you might think Amazon made a mistake in committing to “Bosch,” whose title character is yet another variation. But this 10-episode series, which is being rolled out Friday on Amazon Prime, proves gripping nonetheless.
headline: Review: ‘Bosch,’ Amazon Prime’s New Crime Series

abstract: The e-commerce giant has big plans to use autonomous aircraft to deliver packages, and is testing the devices in rural England. We went to find them.
lead_para: WORSTED LODGE, England — After hours of searching, I pulled onto a dirt track here in the rolling hills of Cambridgeshire and spotted a small dot whirring across the blue sky, gently swaying in the breeze as it steadily flew about 200 feet above the ground.
headline: A Peek at the Secret English Farm Where Amazon Tests Its Drones

abstract: Google is unveiling its answer to Echo, an artificially intelligent home device that vaulted Amazon ahead of Google in a race to build technology that interacts as humans do.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — When Amazon introduced its Echo device in late 2014, Google executives were caught off guard. For years, they had predicted the creation of a virtual assistant that would answer questions or help accomplish tasks, and they focused on building that capability into smartphones and tablets.
headline: Google, Lagging Amazon, Races Across the Threshold Into the Home
