abstract: Companies like Amazon and Microsoft are building data centers across the Continent in response to Europeans’ desires to keep their information close to home.
lead_para: In the battle to dominate Europe’s cloud computing market, American tech giants are spending big to build up their local credibility.
headline: U.S. Tech Giants Are Investing Billions to Keep Data in Europe

abstract: The creator of “Mad Men” has signed on for an eight-episode series for the streaming service.
lead_para: A year and a half after ending “Mad Men” on a note of enlightenment and a Coca-Cola jingle, Matthew Weiner is apparently ready to return to television.
headline: Matthew Weiner to Create a Series for Amazon

abstract: Farhad is going as sexy Donald Trump and Mike as Guy Fieri. Amazon gets them reminiscing about Matthew McConaughey in a 1990s stoner movie.
lead_para: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.
headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Microsoft, Apple and Halloween!

abstract: Thousands of public libraries around the country offer digital content you can borrow for a short period to use on your mobile device and computer.
lead_para: This article is part of a series aimed at helping you navigate life’s opportunities and challenges. What else should we write about? Contact us: smarterliving@nytimes.com.
headline: Guide for Borrowing Library Books on Your Phone and Tablet

abstract: Carlyle Group has joined the growing list of investors who are taking their money out of hedge funds. The private equity firm is instead opting for direct lending.
lead_para: First it was public pension funds, then insurance companies. Now private equity is joining in, too.
headline: Morning Agenda: Shunning Hedge Funds, Chip Makers Consolidate, Tech Lessons

abstract: Amazon’s new show, about a group of young journalists, has serendipitous parallels to the contentious gender politics dominating the presidential election.
lead_para: One of the most quotable scenes in “Mad Men” comes after Joan (Christina Hendricks) endures a meeting with male colleagues who harass her with sexual innuendos. Afterward, she tells her co-worker Peggy (Elisabeth Moss), “I want to burn this place down.”
headline: Review: In ‘Good Girls Revolt,’ the ‘Nasty’ Women of the 1960s Fight Job Discrimination

abstract: Wildly successful tech companies often can’t see the next big thing because they’re too busy making money. Even Google can be prone to this condition.
lead_para: Google, for all its financial success and world-beating technology, has a problem: It often lags or is never even a player in markets it could have dominated.
headline: Daily Report: Google’s Slow Response to Amazon’s Echo is a Warning

abstract: At annual presentations in San Francisco, tech companies deluge potential customers with data on their progress in cloud computing, machine learning and artificial intelligence.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Autumn is a good time to see what is happening next in the $3 trillion business technology market. In particular, it’s a good time to check out what’s new in corporate paranoia.
headline: Taking the Temperature Inside the (Feverish) Cloud

abstract: Which is a better helper, Google Home or Amazon Echo? A side-by-side test for six days revealed strengths and weaknesses.
lead_para: TO get an idea of how annoying it can be to say “O.K., Google” multiple times a day, try replacing the word Google with another brand.
headline: Google Home vs. Amazon Echo: A Face-Off of Smart Speakers

abstract: Even as more people shop online, millions, including two sisters from New York and New Jersey, still rely on Black Friday discounts in stores.
lead_para: RIVERDALE, N.J. — With a baby strapped to her front, a knapsack on her back and a Donald Duck coffee mug in one hand, Christi Mulder arrived at the Target here, about 30 miles northwest of Manhattan, early Friday morning. She and her sister, Erica Renaud, who brought her 7-week-old son, were on the hunt for holiday gifts for the 11 children they have between them.
headline: Stalking Black Friday Bargains

abstract: Some are facing a backlash after remarks that appeared to oppose or support his election.
lead_para: Donald J. Trump’s victory in the presidential race has presented some companies with a new challenge: how to find the right balance in their postelection messages to employees and customers.
headline: American Companies Tailor Responses to Trump Election

abstract: About 250 pilots for the carrier, ABX Air, went on strike on Tuesday, accusing their employer of forcing them to work an excessive number of flights.
lead_para: SEATTLE — A federal judge on Wednesday ordered striking airline cargo pilots who transport packages for Amazon and other customers to immediately resume work.
headline: Airline Used by Amazon Wins Order to End Cargo Pilots’ Strike

abstract: The retailer needs more customers wandering its aisles over the holiday season and a sustainable plan to compete with Amazon.
lead_para: Target’s bull’s-eye will be hard to repeat.
headline: Target’s Turnaround Still Faces Challenges

abstract: Despite what the ads say, the overwhelming majority of deals on the day after Thanksgiving are duds.
lead_para: ATTENTION holiday shoppers, here is your annual public service announcement: The overwhelming majority of Black Friday deals are duds.
headline: How Not to Overpay on Black Friday? Let the Web Be Your Guide

abstract: Fake messages claiming to be from Amazon are one of the many tactics online thieves use to try and get your financial information.
lead_para: Q. I got an email from Amazon for something I didn’t order. Should I be worried my account has been compromised? So far, nothing has happened.
headline: Skip the Phish on the Menu

abstract: Some actors are pursuing audiences where they believe they are staying.
lead_para: The fashionable notion that television is better than ever and that cinema or film is battling in vain to maintain relevance is, depending on where you sit, either a potent truth or a spectacularly tedious kernel of received nonwisdom. The fact that popular streaming video services are now investing hefty sums in the creation of content in formats that fit comfortably into commonly accepted notions of TV (varied series in half-hour and full-hour episodes) and motion pictures (self-contained features averaging two hours) puts a new spin on the debate.
headline: Actors Flock to Netflix to Satisfy Their Most Loyal Fans

abstract: Most devices connect to the television through an HDMI port, but you can find gear to work with the composite connections used by legacy TV sets.
lead_para: Q. I have an analog television in the kitchen that predates the digital HDTV revolution. I’d like to attach an inexpensive streaming device like the Amazon Fire TV Stick to it, but the specifications say an HDMI port is required. Am I out of luck?
headline: How to Stream Video on an Older TV

abstract: Twitter, Facebook, Google and Amazon shared their second-quarter earnings reports, and Yahoo agreed to sell itself to Verizon for about $5 billion.
lead_para: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.
headline: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: The Cautionary Tale of the Fall of Yahoo

abstract: The British Civil Aviation Authority will allow the company to test several technologies that the United States has not permitted.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Amazon has partnered with the British government to significantly expand drone testing, a move that could allow the devices to deliver packages to British homes far earlier than in the United States.
headline: Amazon Expands Drone Testing in Britain

abstract: Making Amazon’s voice-activated speaker smarter is not intuitive, but with a little tinkering, consumers can expand its skills.
lead_para: BILL PYSZCZYMUKA was installing an air-conditioner in an upstairs window last spring when it occurred to him that there was a way to control the machine without getting up from the couch downstairs: his Amazon Echo.
headline: Alexa, What Else Can You Do? Getting More From Amazon Echo

abstract: Plenty of internet-ready hardware can pull in programming over a broadband connection, and it takes just takes a few steps to set it all up.
lead_para: Q. How do you get Netflix, Acorn TV and other streaming services directly on the television?
headline: Flowing Internet Video Streams Through the Television

abstract: Blockbuster Earnings From Google and Amazon |Redstone Trial Set for October
lead_para: PROFITS TUMBLE AT EUROPEAN BANKS UBS said its second-quarter profit dropped 14 percent from a year earlier because uncertainty in financial markets was weighing on its wealth management and investment banking businesses.
headline: Morning Agenda: Profits Tumble at European Banks

abstract: Department store customers, taking advantage of returns policies set by retailers competing with e-commerce, are playing havoc with sales commissions.
lead_para: Earnestine Gay, a longtime worker in the fragrance department at Macy’s in Herald Square, clearly remembers a bottle of perfume that was returned recently. It was practically empty.
headline: Liberal Return Policies for Consumers Can Reduce Retail Workers’ Pay

abstract: A Nielsen study on how we consume media finds people are still watching plenty of TV but services like Netflix and Amazon Prime are growing rapidly.
lead_para: You still love television. You use your tablet more than ever. And now you are as likely to have paid services like Netflix or Amazon Prime as you are to have a DVR service.
headline: How Much Do We Love TV? Let Us Count the Ways

abstract: Our critics look at a few of the latest crop of original pilots. Viewers can watch and vote on their favorites.
lead_para: Since 2013, Amazon has released a batch of original TV pilots several times a year for the public to review and vote on. Our TV critics look at a few from the latest crop.
headline: Amazon’s Literary Forays for TV: ‘The Interestings’ and ‘The Last Tycoon’

abstract: Dr. Cecily Koppuzha and Lionel Sotomayor were married May 21 in Orlando, Fla. The couple met in college and kept their relationship secret from her parents.
lead_para: Dr. Cecily Koppuzha and Lionel Sotomayor were married May 21 in Orlando, Fla. The couple met in college and kept their relationship secret from her parents.
headline: Forbidden Love

abstract: Apple, Facebook, Amazon and Alphabet will post quarterly earnings this week, reflecting how they are doing in online ads, mobile and cloud computing.
lead_para: This week will offer a glimpse into just how dominant some of the world’s biggest technology companies have become.
headline: Tech Behemoths Report Their Results

abstract: Analysts say the global cloud-computing business will be worth $67 billion by 2020. Amazon and Microsoft are the current leaders in the industry.
lead_para: When it comes to cloud computing, Google is in a very unfamiliar position: seriously behind.
headline: Google Races to Catch Up in Cloud Computing

abstract: Popular shows like “Daniel Tiger’s Neighborhood” will be removed from rivals Netflix and Hulu as Amazon becomes the only premium service to stream them.
lead_para: In the increasingly competitive space of children’s television, Amazon Prime reached a deal to become the exclusive premium streaming service for most of PBS’s shows for children, the company said on Friday.
headline: Amazon Prime Strikes Deal for Most PBS Children’s Shows

abstract: Once relatively self-effacing, Amazon has joined its tech cohort in building new, quirky spaces befitting its size and influence.
lead_para: Orchids from Ecuador. Carnivorous pitcher plants. Exotic philodendrons.
headline: Daily Report: Amazon Flaunts Its Prominence With New Construction in Seattle

abstract: Oracle’s announced purchase of NetSuite is aimed at getting deeper into the game, while Amazon drew more than half its operating earnings from the segment.
lead_para: The world of enterprise software and computing is not sexy — in fact, the mere mention of it may put you to sleep. But if you’re still with me, there’s been plenty of action in that world lately.
headline: Gathering Cloud-Computing

abstract: Amazon reported net income of $857 million, the second quarter in a row it has shown a record profit even as it invests heavily in its own growth.
lead_para: SEATTLE — For most of its life, Amazon sacrificed profits if it could build another few warehouses to ship orders to customers more quickly or find some other investment to fuel its growth.
headline: Amazon’s Profits Grow More Than 800 Percent, Lifted by Cloud Services

abstract: The week’s top parties were hosted by Amazon Fashion, Cadillac and Dazed Media.
lead_para: As far as partying is concerned, New York Fashion Week: Men’s does not compare to the debauchery of the larger fashion weeks. But there were still plenty of opportunities to hang with models, designers and celebrities.
headline: Partying with Common, Kellan Lutz and Others at Men’s Fashion Week

abstract: As retailers face consumer lawsuits over discounts, Amazon is changing the way it presents bargains to customers.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — In a major shift for online commerce, Amazon is quietly changing how it entices people to buy.
headline: Amazon Is Quietly Eliminating List Prices

abstract: Amazon is building a complex at its Seattle headquarters where employees can sit by a creek, walk on suspension bridges and brainstorm in the boughs.
lead_para: REDMOND, Wash. — Just off a remote stretch of road here, near wineries, horse stables and farms, Amazon is secretly growing something, but it’s not what Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive, calls the “tiny seeds” that could become the company’s next big businesses.
headline: Forget Beanbag Chairs. Amazon Is Giving Its Workers Treehouses.

abstract: The audiobook and spoken-word company is selling access to an extensive library of short-form audio, including original programs, for $4.95 per month.
lead_para: Amazon hopes to persuade people to pay for something they have traditionally enjoyed free: short-form audio.
headline: Amazon’s Audible Goes Long on Short-Form Audio

abstract: European efforts to rein in the largest American tech companies are only a taste of what countries like Brazil, India and China are likely to do.
lead_para: Imagine you are a French lawmaker. For decades, you have protected your nation’s cultural output with the diligence of a gardener tending a fragile patch against invasive killer weeds.
headline: Why the World Is Drawing Battle Lines Against American Tech Giants

abstract: The rising tension between borderless technology and countries that cling to their cultural identities has echoes in disruptive technology of the past.
lead_para: Virtual reality is all fun and games, until your avatar gets strip-searched at the border.
headline: American Tech Giants vs. the Nation-State

abstract: Some streaming services now allow temporary downloads of certain videos to watch when you do not have internet access.
lead_para: Q. Several streaming music services allow you to listen without an internet connection — are there any video-streaming services that let you download a movie to a tablet for watching on a plane?
headline: Downloading Video Streams to Go

abstract: The new Amazon site will offer free lesson plans, teaching modules and other digital resources for educators.
lead_para: Just ahead of the back-to-school season, Amazon plans to make a major foray into the education technology market for primary and secondary schools, a territory that Apple, Google and Microsoft have heavily staked out.
headline: Amazon Unveils Online Education Service for Teachers

abstract: There may be no love lost between Donald Trump and the tech world, but he is likely to need tech backers as his campaign turns to the general election.
lead_para: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Donald J. Trump would not be Silicon Valley’s first choice as president. Or its second. Or maybe even its third.
headline: Silicon Valley Finds Trump’s Disruption Unwelcome

abstract: The Amazon chief, buoyed by record profit, said he bought the newspaper to make it a more powerful publication on a national, and even global, stage.
lead_para: RANCHO PALOS VERDES, Calif. — Jeff Bezos built Amazon into an e-commerce and computing powerhouse. Now his ambitions are more sprawling as he takes on ever larger civic and business challenges.
headline: Jeff Bezos, Riding High, Defends Decision to Buy Washington Post

abstract: Apple and Dell, longtime rivals in the battle over sales to educators and students, now have plenty of company from companies like Amazon and others.
lead_para: For years, Apple and Dell battled over sales to students and schools.
headline: Tech Makes Its Pitch to the Education Community

abstract: A feature makes it easier to save your place in complex books like “A Game of Thrones” while you glance at reference pages with photos, maps or family trees.
lead_para: SEATTLE — For years, Amazon has been chiseling away at the irritants that keep many people from switching to e-readers. The company has improved the legibility of the text on Kindle screens to make it nearly indistinguishable from print, and fiddled with the ergonomics of the new Kindle Oasis to make using it feel more like holding a book.
headline: Amazon Kindle Learns to Navigate Literary Thickets

abstract: Amazon Inspire, a resource site where teachers share lesson plans, removed three items after complaints that the products were copyrighted materials.
lead_para: DENVER — File this under how not to roll out a high-profile digital education platform.
headline: Amazon Inspire Removes Some Content Over Copyright Issues

abstract: Consumer reviews have become increasingly popular both online and off, but they may not be the reliable indicators of quality one might expect.
lead_para: Botto Bistro is far from the worst restaurant in America. But it doesn’t mind if you think so.
headline: Online Reviews? Researchers Give Them a Low Rating

abstract: A former bookstore owner discusses why books were a perfect product for discounting when Jeff Bezos started Amazon.
lead_para: To the Editor:
headline: Real and False Discounts

abstract: The company said to expect as much as $1.25 billion in operating income for the fourth quarter and as little as nothing, a remarkably wide range.
lead_para: SEATTLE — For the last several quarters, Amazon delighted investors by delivering something unusual for the company: a bumper crop of profits.
headline: Amazon Comes Up Short on Profits, Focusing on Warehouses and Movies

abstract: These bots are generally powered by artificial intelligence software that allows them to pull in data and turn it into comprehensible answers.
lead_para: Your bank really wants to chat.
headline: Banks Bet on the Next Big Thing: Financial Chatbots

abstract: A new service offering tens of millions of songs will cost customers as little as $4 per month if they listen through the Echo device.
lead_para: For years, Amazon has been a quiet but potent force in the music industry, selling more CDs and vinyl albums than any other retailer.
headline: Amazon Pairs Its Speaker With Streaming Music, at a Bargain Price

abstract: The company’s Originals program will include “Adventure Time Marshall Lee Spectacular,” from BOOM! Studios and the graphic novel “Harvey Kurtzman’s Marley’s Ghost.”
lead_para: ComiXology, a digital distributor of comic books, will be expanding its library with exclusive comics.
headline: ComiXology Joining the Original Programming Party With Exclusive Comics

abstract: The search giant is one of several American tech companies facing inspections overseas for the way they do business.
lead_para: Europe has a big headache: the current state of American technology companies. And it may take a long time to go away.
headline: Daily Report: Google’s Day in Europe’s Court Highlights Nature of New Tech

abstract: Amazon accepts returns for many of the things it sells, including — under certain circumstances — Kindle books.
lead_para: Q. Can you return a Kindle e-book? If so, how?
headline: Getting Your Money Back for a Digital Book

abstract: David E. Kelley’s new legal series represents a change of venue from broadcast TV. Making it for Amazon, he says, means “characters can have more time and room.”
lead_para: SANTA MONICA, CALIF. — Say what you will about Ally McBeal — and, over the years, people have said a lot — she was a likable character, or at least she was intended to be. Same with Bobby Donnell, the morally squishy senior partner on “The Practice,” and the womanizing Alan Shore, of both “The Practice” and “Boston Legal.” David E. Kelley, the creator and prolific writer of many of TV’s most celebrated legal dramas, made them that way, partly for his own sanity.
headline: Billy Bob Thornton Plays a Lawyer in ‘Goliath.’ A Drunkard, Too.

abstract: Sometimes people forget that old guys can be geeks. This week: How Samsung helped Apple, will Verizon win a discount, and a new riff on a classic excuse.
lead_para: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Jim Kerstetter, the deputy technology editor in San Francisco, and Nick Wingfield, technology reporter in Seattle, are filling in for Farhad and Mike this week.
headline: Jim’s and Nick’s Week in Tech: Smoldering Phones, the Yahoo Markdown and Amazon Music

abstract: By just about every metric, Amazon, Apple, Facebook, Google and Microsoft are getting larger, more entrenched in their own sectors, more powerful in new sectors and better protected from competition.
lead_para: There’s a little parlor game that people in Silicon Valley like to play. Let’s call it, Who’s Losing?
headline: Tech’s ‘Frightful 5’ Will Dominate Digital Life for Foreseeable Future

abstract: Analysis on Apple’s iPhone sales, Microsoft’s rebound, Amazon’s profits and Facebook’s success with mobile advertising.
lead_para: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.
headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Lessons From Earnings Season

abstract: At its best, the Sundance Film Festival is still helping to write the next chapters in American cinema.
lead_para: PARK CITY, Utah — Art and industry are still slugging it out at the Sundance Film Festival. That’s true even if you no longer hear many anguished discussions about the meaning of independent cinema. These days, chatter about distribution deals, a movie’s commercial potential and even if a title will be in play at the next Academy Awards tends to drown out meaningful discussions of cinema and whether independence can be quantified by vision, spirit, money or some ineluctable combination of these. Then again, given how thoroughly the industry has colonized the festival (as the clusters of agents at screenings suggest), anguishing about it can feel like misplaced nostalgia.
headline: Sundance Fights Tide With Films Like ‘The Birth of a Nation’

abstract: This testosterone-fueled series, adapted from a British drama, focuses on the adventures of four middle-aged American men.
lead_para: “American men, you love to fight,” a supporting female character observes in the very male dark-comic thriller “Mad Dogs,” whose 10-episode first season debuts Friday on Amazon Prime.
headline: Review: On ‘Mad Dogs,’ an Amazon Series, Male Bellicosity Rules

abstract: The Golden Globe awards rewarded shows outside the norms of television-success formulas, giving the nod to offbeat, even dark productions.
lead_para: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Over the last decade, NBC Universal’s cable chief, Bonnie Hammer, has occasionally visited the Golden Globes under less-than-glamorous conditions: sitting in a production truck for the E! network, dressed in jeans and sneakers, with her hair pulled back. By time the network wrapped up its red carpet show and the show actually began, a limo would be summoned, a pizza ordered and Ms. Hammer’s night would be all but over.
headline: Golden Globes Reflect a New Trajectory for TV

abstract: The earnings reports released by Amazon and Microsoft reinforced that cloud computing is a booming, multibillion-dollar business.
lead_para: If there is one conclusion to draw from the company earnings reported on Thursday, it is this: Cloud computing is a booming business.
headline: Daily Report: Divergent Fortunes in Cloud Computing

abstract: An already busy start to the year for the tech sector is set to ramp up with the beginning of the tech earnings season this week.
lead_para: Just 11 days into 2016, it has already been a busy period for tech news — and that’s about to ramp up further.
headline: Daily Report: The Tech News Cycle is About to Ramp Up

abstract: Which giant tech company does Netflix most take after? For some, the answer is Amazon.
lead_para: Netflix is taking steps to dominate the world of digital streaming globally. Which other tech company does it most take after?
headline: Daily Report: The Netflix-Amazon Connection

abstract: For his first foray into television, Mr. Allen is relying on one of his tried and true formulas — casting an attention-grabbing young actress alongside himself. This time it’s Ms. Cyrus.
lead_para: For his first foray into streaming television, Woody Allen is relying on one of his tried and true formulas — casting an attention-grabbing young actress alongside himself. In this case, Miley Cyrus, the former Disney kid turned outré pop star, will appear in his coming streaming series for Amazon.
headline: Miley Cyrus Joins the Cast of Woody Allen’s Amazon Series

abstract: Advice for those thinking about buying a 4K television, also called Ultra HD, which has a higher resolution than the current high-definition 1080p TV sets.
lead_para: TELEVISION makers like Sony, Samsung Electronics and Panasonic will be working overtime this week to sell you on so-called ultra high-definition 4K television.
headline: Despite the CES Hype, It’s Better to Wait on That 4K TV

abstract: One new plan offers video streaming only, while another offers full Prime benefits. Both cost more than annual subscribers pay.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon is introducing new options to subscribe to its Prime membership service on a monthly basis, a change that could make the company’s video service a tougher competitor to Netflix.
headline: Amazon Challenges Netflix by Opening Prime to Monthly Subscribers

abstract: Season 2 of this Amazon Prime show picks up with its stars expecting a baby a couple of years after an unplanned pregnancy led, eventually, to romance.
lead_para: Love is a mess. It’s awkward and clumsy and can lead to the uncomfortable gestation of a small human.
headline: ‘Catastrophe’ Adds a New Wrinkle to Its Ribald Love Story: Children

abstract: The new $289 Kindle Oasis e-reader has an asymmetrical shape meant to mimic a book, and includes a case with a battery that extends charge time.
lead_para: SEATTLE — When Amazon introduced Kindle, its pioneering e-reader, in 2007, society was on the cusp of being changed by mobile devices.
headline: Kindle Oasis From Amazon Promises ‘Months and Months’ of Battery Life

abstract: This economics of tiny things demonstrates the global power of the few companies, including Amazon, Microsoft and Google, that can make fortunes from the small.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Imagine building an enormous beach resort, maybe the best in the world. Instead of renting the rooms, you charge guests based on the grains of sand they touch. You charge very little per grain, but if they lie on enough of them, it adds up.
headline: Billing by Millionths of Pennies, Cloud Computing’s Giants Take In Billions

abstract: Amazon made a profit of $513 million in its most recent quarter, and its Amazon Web Services was the star of the show.
lead_para: Ten years ago last March, Amazon started the era of renting data storage and computing over the Internet, what is now known as cloud computing. On Thursday, Amazon showed how critical it is to the retailer’s future.
headline: Cloud Services Show Their Value in Earnings Reports

abstract: At the Television Critics Association’s semiannual gathering, shows were previewed, decisions reviewed and the industry itself examined.
lead_para: PASADENA, Calif. — Twice a year, executives, show runners and actors convene for the Television Critics Association press tour to preview shows, review bad decisions and examine the industry at large.
headline: TV’s Self-Reflection: Ratings May Be Down, but the Choices Are Many

abstract: Virtual assistants from tech behemoths including Apple, Microsoft, Amazon and Google are graded on their abilities to actually be of assistance.
lead_para: WHEN I asked Alexa earlier this week who was playing in the Super Bowl, she responded, somewhat monotonously, “Super Bowl 49’s winner is New England Patriots.”
headline: Siri, Alexa and Other Virtual Assistants Put to the Test

abstract: Ms. Jones, the Broadway star, is playing a lesbian poetry professor with strong feelings about transgender issues on Amazon’s “Transparent.”
lead_para: Cherry Jones may have played the president on the Fox series “24,” but she admits to being a “theater snob” who always thought she would do her best work on the stage. Then she saw the first season of “Transparent,” the critically lauded series on Amazon, chronicling the life of Maura Pfefferman (Jeffrey Tambor), who comes out to her adult children as a transgender woman.
headline: A Word With Cherry Jones: ‘I’m Having the Kind of Year Actors Live For’

abstract: Amazon’s China subsidiary has received United States approval to ship ocean freight for other companies, in another move by the retailer to build out its logistics operations.
lead_para: Drones might get all the attention, but Amazon’s interest in more traditional methods of moving things around is not slowing down.
headline: Amazon Subsidiary Gains Approval to Ship Ocean Freight

abstract: Investments in well-known tech giants like Amazon, Microsoft and Google fueled three top-performing funds in the fourth quarter.
lead_para: Bets on the biggest purveyors of technology — companies like Amazon, Google and Microsoft — powered three of the top-performing funds of the fourth quarter.
headline: Fund Managers Win With Tech Stalwarts and Burly Brand Names

abstract: Despite a 22 percent increase in revenue, the e-commerce company’s shares fell after its fourth-quarter profit failed to meet analysts’ lofty expectations.
lead_para: Amazon was expected to run away with the holiday season. Instead, it merely strolled.
headline: Amazon Sales Soared 22% in Holiday Quarter, but Profit Fell Short

abstract: Access to Amazon Instant Videos can be gained in many ways, including via game consoles and devices that connect to your TV set.
lead_para: Q. Is there a way to watch Amazon’s Instant Video on my television instead of my tablet? If I’m subscribed to Amazon Prime in the United States, can I watch the Prime Instant Video outside the country, like when I’m traveling overseas for work?
headline: Amazon Prime Video, Home and Away

abstract: At the 2016 Sundance Film Festival, the big streaming services, not the traditional studios, are driving the deal-making.
lead_para: PARK CITY, Utah — It was the independent film equivalent of a crack of thunder.
headline: So Far, Amazon and Netflix Are Sundance’s Top Buyers

abstract: At an experimental store on the ground floor of a new Amazon office building in Seattle, shoppers will be able to pluck what they want off the shelves and leave without waiting to pay.
lead_para: SEATTLE — There is almost no aspect of retail that Amazon has not upended with online shopping. Now, the company is trying to computerize the experience of buying sandwiches and soda from the corner convenience store.
headline: Amazon Moves to Cut Checkout Line, Promoting a Grab-and-Go Experience

abstract: The shape-shifting character actor reflects on his roles in “Office Space” and the “prescient” Amazon series “The Man in the High Castle.”
lead_para: You’ve seen Stephen Root far more than you might think. He’s the shape-shifting character actor you know you recognize, but can’t place. Of course, there’s his unforgettable creation from the cult classic “Office Space”: Milton, the stapler-obsessed arsonist hidden under extremely thick glasses, stilted speech and a pocket protector. But Mr. Root has mined a number of idiosyncratic veins over the past several decades, with memorable parts in films like “No Country for Old Men,” TV shows as disparate as “NewsRadio, “Louie” and “Boardwalk Empire,” and voice work in animated ones like “King of the Hill” and “Adventure Time.”
headline: Stephen Root Is Just the Man for a Cubicle or a Castle

abstract: This year’s $3.3 billion acquisition of Jet.com will accelerate the push to compete with Amazon in 2017.
lead_para: Walmart Stores’ tortoise-like digital pace may yet pay off.
headline: Walmart Slowly Makes Strides in E-Commerce

abstract: The wide array of available video-streaming devices can be overwhelming, but a bit of research will help you figure out what features you really need.
lead_para: Q. There seems to be quite a range of prices on streaming video set-top boxes and sticks. What more do you really get with the more expensive ones priced at $150 or more, compared with the plug-in sticks that cost $30 to $40?
headline: The Quest for Your Dream Streamer

abstract: Pre-owned products can be purchased with confidence; they are subject to rigorous testing and often come with return policies.
lead_para: WHEN you sell a used video game console to the retailer GameStop, it goes on a long journey before winding up in the pre-owned section inside a store.
headline: Taking the Stigma Out of Buying Used Electronics

abstract: Shares rose 12 percent after the company reported net income of $513 million, in contrast to last year’s loss of $57 million.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon delivered a blowout quarter on Thursday, joining Facebook as one of the rare bright spots in a technology sector that has recently produced a string of disappointing earnings reports.
headline: Amazon’s Cloud Business Lifts Its Profit to a Record

abstract: First-quarter results are expected to be in for Facebook, Amazon, Apple and Twitter, as well as for some of Europe’s largest banks.
lead_para: This is what to expect from the week ahead.
headline: Technology and Banking Sectors Brace for Earnings Reports

abstract: The deals show a willingness by music publishers to find new sources of income as music sales dry up.
lead_para: The biggest star behind a spate of new streaming television shows is no celebrity or top-flight director, but rather innovative music deals.
headline: Bob Dylan-Inspired Drama Is in the Works

abstract: The online retail giant reports quarterly earnings on Thursday, after tech companies including Apple and Microsoft posted weaker-than-expected results.
lead_para: Can Amazon buck the gloomy tech earnings season?
headline: Will Amazon Stand Apart From Weak Tech Earners?

abstract: Some discussion of an app that can post criticism of one’s work and of Facebook’s new live video push and how users are pushing back.
lead_para: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Mr. Manjoo is off this week, so John Herrman, a David Carr fellow, is filling in.
headline: Mike and John on Annotation Terror and Annoying Video Alerts

abstract: Life in the new tech workplace is suspiciously like life in the old sweatshop.
lead_para: AT HubSpot, the software company where I worked for almost two years, when you got fired, it was called “graduation.” We all would get a cheery email from the boss saying, “Team, just letting you know that X has graduated and we’re all excited to see how she uses her superpowers in her next big adventure.” One day this happened to a friend of mine. She was 35, had been with the company for four years, and was told without explanation by her 28-year-old manager that she had two weeks to get out. On her last day, that manager organized a farewell party for her.
headline: Congratulations! You’ve Been Fired

abstract: Even if you did not download the music to your iOS device from the iTunes store, you can still take it along on your mobile gadget.
lead_para: Q. I have many CDs that I purchased from various retail stores (not Apple iTunes) and loaded into my iTunes library on my computer. Is it possible to download these albums to my iPhone and iPad? If so, how?
headline: Moving CD-Ripped Music From the Computer to the iPad

abstract: The (relative) decline of Apple, the ascendance of Amazon and the continuing dominance of Mark Zuckerberg’s social network.
lead_para: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.
headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: The Unstoppable Facebook

abstract: In Seattle, job growth is steroidal. But I ignore the usual measurements of what makes a city robust. Could Kramer from ‘Seinfeld’ live here?
lead_para: SEATTLE — I tend to ignore the usual measurements of what makes a city robust and healthy, the urban bragging points. Along the West Coast, these superlatives roll out with regularity. Seattle, two years ago, was proclaimed the fastest growing city in the United States. San Francisco usually tops the list of most expensive places to live. And Portland, Ore., just posted the highest percentage rise in home prices among major cities.
headline: Dude, Where’s My City?

abstract: Google’s Home device puts it in the race to become the go-to company for A.I. — along with several rivals.
lead_para: Artificial intelligence. Chatbots. Messaging. Sound familiar?
headline: Silicon Valley’s Artificial Intelligence Marathon Is On

abstract: Pens matter. Ink does not. The blocking of the Staples-Office Depot union illustrates the complications the age of Amazon has created in the retail industry.
lead_para: Pens matter. Ink does not.
headline: Antitrust in the Age of Amazon

abstract: If one company has a small success, the others pile on, and you get “30 different versions of some dumb wearable.” Also, meet Mike’s flower guy, Guy.
lead_para: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.
headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: The Herd Mentality of Tech C.E.O.s

abstract: Salesforce, itself a cloud-computing company, will use Amazon Web Services to grow more rapidly in a deal valued at $400 million.
lead_para: Amazon Web Services, the biggest of the cloud-computing providers, has a new line of work: Taking other cloud-computing giants into other countries.
headline: Salesforce to Use Amazon’s Cloud to Expand in Canada and Australia

abstract: Do tech venture capitalists really want to support a system in which moving fast results in company-ending lawsuits?
lead_para: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.
headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Techies vs. the Media

abstract: Amazon announced eight new shows on Thursday, including six for children, that it will consider turning into series for its streaming service.
lead_para: Matt Bomer, Kelsey Grammer, Lauren Ambrose, David Krumholtz, Jessica Paré, David Arquette and Zoë Kravitz will be among the stars included in the latest slate of Amazon pilots, debuting on June 17.
headline: New Amazon Pilots Star Matt Bomer and Kelsey Grammer, Among Others

abstract: Here’s how Google’s voice-controlled, Internet-connected speaker compares with Amazon’s popular Echo device.
lead_para: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Google on Wednesday introduced Google Home, a voice-controlled, Internet-connected speaker that competes directly with Amazon’s smart speaker, Echo, which costs $180. The company also introduced Allo, a messaging app, and a rebranding of its virtual assistant.
headline: Google Home vs. Amazon Echo. Let the Battle Begin.

abstract: High turnover may be one reason unions have made little progress at the e-commerce company, but some see manipulation and intimidation.
lead_para: SEATTLE — In early April, Kellen Wadach, the general manager at Amazon’s warehouse in Middletown, Del., told hundreds of workers at the cavernous facility a troubling story about his family being abandoned by his father’s union.
headline: Amazon Proves Infertile Soil for Unions, So Far

abstract: As Seattle’s economy booms, spiraling housing prices are leaving some families behind, fueling a crisis of homelessness.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Look outside almost any window at the Guest Rooms homeless shelter here, and the view speaks of wealth and power that the residents inside all lack. Construction cranes claw the sky. Trucks hauling steel or concrete rubble shake the streets. Amazon, the giant online retailer, is building out its headquarters campus in every direction as it and other tech companies, in a scramble for real estate and highly educated talent, reshape the city and its work force.
headline: Lured by Seattle’s Tech Boom, but Being Left Behind

abstract: Mr. Fellowes adds charm and humor to each of the four episodes of his mini-series, which will become available for streaming Friday on Amazon Prime.
lead_para: For six seasons, Julian Fellowes’s “Downton Abbey” was shown in the United States as part of PBS’s “Masterpiece,” which meant that its episodes were introduced by the American actress Laura Linney. Mr. Fellowes’s new examination of British pride and impropriety, “Julian Fellowes Presents Doctor Thorne,” will stream on Amazon Prime (the four episodes are available Friday), where it has a host who’s more in the classic vein: Mr. Fellowes, doing his best Alistair Cooke impression.
headline: Review: Julian Fellowes Hosts ‘Doctor Thorne,’ a British Period Drama, on Amazon

abstract: Even if you read Amazon’s e-books on different devices, you can find all your notes and highlights ready to print or save online.
lead_para: Q. Can I save and print highlights from books I use with Kindle for PC (running on Windows 10)? I also read these books on my iPad.
headline: Keeping Notes and Highlights From Kindle Books

abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Joe Nocera, Fernanda Santos and others.
lead_para: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »
headline: What We’re Reading

abstract: Amazon and some of its rivals appear to have run afoul of new rules around foreign ownership of e-commerce companies operating in India.
lead_para: International markets are a growth opportunity for many American technology companies. The problem is that many of those markets are highly unpredictable.
headline: Amazon Encounters a Bumpy Road in India

abstract: The government added regulations related to pricing and the sourcing of sales on sites that Amazon and several rivals appear to break.
lead_para: SEATTLE — For Amazon, no country is more important to its global growth ambitions than India, the second-most-populous nation in the world behind China, where online shopping is in its infancy and growing explosively.
headline: Amazon May Violate India’s New Rules on Foreign E-Commerce

abstract: In the bizarre world of Internet “discounts,” inconsistent list prices can make it tough to figure out what a product is really worth.
lead_para: Amazon has some unbelievable bargains on its virtual shelves.
headline: Some Online Bargains May Only Look Like One

abstract: The tech giant is working with a nonprofit to temporarily house the homeless. City officials hope it’s not just a one-time act of civic-mindedness.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon’s new urban headquarters — more than 30 office buildings and three towers that, once completed, will dominate a low-slung section of the city — are a gleaming symbol of boom times here. The tech giant has added 20,000 new jobs in Seattle and attracted other tech companies that want to rub elbows. Google plans to expand here as well, with four new buildings and perhaps 4,000 workers. Smaller start-ups dot old brick neighborhoods like Pioneer Square, and newer developments like South Lake Union, where Amazon is building.
headline: With Seattle Shelter Effort, Amazon Shows Glimmers of a ‘Good Neighbor’

abstract: The quarter’s top-performing mutual funds sought stock in companies that not only paid dividends, but that also had a durable business and a burly balance sheet.
lead_para: Over the last several years, growth stocks, like Amazon and Netflix, have brought much momentum to the market. But in the first quarter, those kinds of stocks lost some of their sizzle, as old-school dividend payers came back into favor.
headline: Taking Shelter in Old-School Dividend Stocks

abstract: Maggie Smith play a homeless Londoner in “The Lady in the Van.” “Nina” has Zoe Saldana as Nina Simone. And Amazon features “Thunderbirds Are Go.”
lead_para: Maggie Smith downgrades her “Downton” wardrobe as a homeless Londoner parked in the driveway of the playwright Alan Bennett in “The Lady in the Van.” “Nina” stirs up controversy with the casting of Zoe Saldana as Nina Simone. And Amazon blasts to the future in “Thunderbirds Are Go,” a reimagining of that 1960s animated series.
headline: What’s on TV Friday

abstract: Starz is the latest premium TV network to introduce an app that bypasses cable packages and lets viewers stream television shows and movies directly.
lead_para: And then there was Starz.
headline: With a Stand-Alone App, Starz Looks Beyond the Cable Bundle

abstract: The luxury retailer known for wedding registry finery plans to close its sole brick-and-mortar store in Manhattan on April 16.
lead_para: Michael C. Fina helped popularize bridal registries, and its Park Avenue store was a destination for Manhattan elites. It provided silver for John F. Kennedy’s inauguration festivities and catered to the likes of Frank Sinatra and Lennox Lewis.
headline: Michael C. Fina, Park Avenue Wedding Retailer, Bets on Amazon.com

abstract: Uber for bow ties, shopping with Amy Schumer and Calvin Klein’s transgression.
lead_para: Amazon’s prime
headline: All the Week’s Fashion News That’s Fit to Reprint

abstract: Walmart reported Thursday that quarterly revenue rose 0.9 percent, signaling that its strategies to combat a dismal retail environment were working.
lead_para: One percent growth may not seem like a lot — unless you’re the world’s largest retailer.
headline: Walmart Outperforms Estimates, but Online Retail Lags

abstract: Arkansas investigators are seeking access to what may have been recorded on the electronic personal assistant.
lead_para: In a move that promises to raise new questions about electronic privacy, detectives investigating a murder in Arkansas are seeking access to audio that may have been recorded on an Amazon Echo electronic personal assistant.
headline: Bid for Access to Amazon Echo Audio in Murder Case Raises Privacy Concerns

abstract: Jeff Bezos announced on Twitter that his company had made its first automated shipment, a two-mile, 13-minute trip to a shopper in Cambridgeshire.
lead_para: When Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive, first said that the e-commerce giant wanted to use drones to deliver packages directly to customers’ homes, many people thought he was crazy.
headline: In Major Step for Drone Delivery, Amazon Flies Package to Customer in England

abstract: The series, which returns with its second season on Friday, has a new relevance in a postelection United States.
lead_para: Before the premiere of “The Man in the High Castle” last fall, Amazon upset New York City subway riders with an advertising campaign that plastered train cars with Nazi imagery. This year, Amazon promoted the series, set in an America under fascist rule, with billboards depicting the Statue of Liberty, her arm thrust out “Sieg Heil” fashion.
headline: ‘The Man in the High Castle’: An Alternative America Hits Home

abstract: While Washington frets over an AT&T-Time Warner merger, Silicon Valley giants have taken over the media business.
lead_para: The proposed merger of AT&T and Time Warner has drawn censure from both sides of the political aisle, as well as a Senate hearing that looked into the potential for the combined company to become a monopoly.
headline: Forget AT&T. The Real Monopolies Are Google and Facebook.

abstract: Few companies have been able to keep Amazon at bay after it decides to target a new market. Zalando, Europe’s biggest online fashion retailer, is the latest to try.
lead_para: BERLIN — Robert Gentz stepped off an Air Berlin plane in Beijing with the goal of conquering online fashion in China. By the time he boarded his return flight to Berlin, he had a new plan: to copy it.
headline: In Shadow of Amazon, European Challenger Looks to China for Inspiration

abstract: The rapid expansion of internet-connected devices will put even more power in the hands of a few companies with the biggest cloud services.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Jeff Bezos of Amazon, along with a couple of his rivals, may eventually control much of the $1 trillion global market for business computers and software.
headline: Why the Computing Cloud Will Keep Growing and Growing

abstract: The pioneering hip-hop group filed a $50 million lawsuit saying that retailers have sold unauthorized products.
lead_para: Run-DMC, the ‘80s hip-hop group, wants its brand back.
headline: Run-DMC Sues Amazon and Walmart for Infringement

abstract: The executives meeting with Mr. Trump in Manhattan on Wednesday include Elon Musk of Tesla, Timothy D. Cook of Apple and Jeff Bezos of Amazon.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — At the top of the agenda when President-elect Donald J. Trump meets with tech leaders on Wednesday afternoon: jobs, jobs and more jobs.
headline: When Trump Meets Tech Leaders, Jobs Will Be on the Agenda

abstract: A select list of holiday classics and non-classics. But, please remember, “Zombie Lake” is not a Christmas movie.
lead_para: Before the recommendations, an anecdote: Beginning my research for this column, I searched Amazon Video using the term “Christmas Movies.” About 20 pages in, I saw “Zombie Lake” listed. Now, “Zombie Lake” is an unusually tatty 1981 film by the director Jean Rollin (whose best work, of which this is not an example, is grisly and poetic with a lot of erotic obsessiveness) about dead German soldiers who rise out of a lake where they’d been dumped by the French Resistance fighters who’d killed them. It is not good (even Rollin nuts rate it low), but I checked it out again to see if there was some Christmas or holiday theme I’d missed before. No dice. There’s a brief winter battle scene, atrociously cut into a narrative that takes place largely when trees are in bloom, but that’s it.
headline: O.K., Who Put the Nazi Zombie Under the Tree?

abstract: Online services offer many alcohol-related films. Here are some in the “What Am I Doing With My Life?” and “Well, That Wasn’t So Bad, Was It?” categories.
lead_para: In the parts of the world that experience winter as winter, New Year’s Day is special. On a sunny cold New Year’s Day here in New York, the piercing light and the sharp air can serve as a metaphorical — and metaphysical — reproach, even if you’re stone cold sober; it’s not desirable hangover weather. In the years before my domestication, my New Year’s Day hangover cure involved more alcohol and a trip home to New Jersey, where I and some similarly afflicted friends would gorge on regional comfort food — deep-fried hot dogs and fries all the way at Rutt’s Hut in Clifton, perhaps, or a cheeseburger and onion rings from the sadly departed Hearth on Route 46. Only after completing this ritual would we consider a movie, preferably something loud and empty.
headline: Oh, My Aching Head: Movies for the Soused or Now Sober

abstract: Mr. Bezos introduced reporters to Blue Origin for the first time on Tuesday, offering updates on his space tourism plans and a new engine that is being developed.
lead_para: KENT, Wash. — The headquarters of Blue Origin, the secretive rocket company in an industrial park here, is anonymous, with not even a sign at the road to announce the occupants.
headline: Jeff Bezos Lifts Veil on His Rocket Company, Blue Origin

abstract: Apple’s legal battle with the government tests the limits of law enforcement agencies’ access to personal data.
lead_para: Google, Amazon, Facebook, Microsoft and a parade of other technology companies filed a barrage of court briefs on Thursday, aiming to puncture the United States government’s legal arguments against Apple in a case that will test the limits of the authorities’ access to personal data.
headline: Apple Is Rolling Up Backers in iPhone Privacy Fight Against F.B.I.

abstract: Amazon, Google, IBM and Microsoft are using high salaries and games pitting humans against computers to try to claim the standard on which all companies will build their A.I. technology.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — The resounding win by a Google artificial intelligence program over a champion in the complex board game Go this month was a statement — not so much to professional game players as to Google’s competitors.
headline: The Race Is On to Control Artificial Intelligence, and Tech’s Future

abstract: New uses for commercial drones, 33-foot trucks, improved roads and bridges: Amazon and its lobbyists urge officials to support expansion efforts.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Ever since Jeff Bezos started the website Amazon to sell books, he has wrestled with how to deliver its products as quickly and cheaply as possible. Today, Amazon, now a retail giant, remains obsessed with this issue, building its own fleet of drones, buying trailers for trucks and signing up drivers for on-demand deliveries.
headline: Amazon Leans on Government in Its Quest to Be a Delivery Powerhouse

abstract: An Amazon warehouse will give Fall River, Mass., the cash to tackle a host of improvements planned for its downtown, propelling a city strategy.
lead_para: FALL RIVER, Mass. — For this former mill town, the deal to secure a large Amazon distribution center means much more than the $3.78 million coming from the land sale and the successful culmination of three years’ worth of negotiations.
headline: A Red Carpet for Amazon in Fall River, Mass., and Hopes for More

abstract: When the same skillet costs $200 at a dozen web stores, the bargain isn’t so obvious to consumers, and scrutiny of this practice is growing.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — As traditional retailing falters, shutting stores and shedding workers, online merchants are reaping the rewards. People like the convenience of e-commerce, and they love the feeling that they are getting a deal.
headline: It’s Discounted, but Is It a Deal? How List Prices Lost Their Meaning

abstract: Judge Slams F.T.C. for Testimony in Office Depot | Credit Suisse Chief Says Risky Bets Were a ‘Surprise’
lead_para: VALEANT LOSSES DRAG ACKMAN HEDGE FUND DOWN | Pershing Square Holdings, the publicly listed entity of William A. Ackman’s firm, reported a year-to-date loss of 25.2 percent as of March 22,Alexandra Stevenson reports in DealBook.
headline: Morning Agenda: Valeant Losses Drag Ackman Hedge Fund Down

abstract: The Amazon show, which stars Sharon Horgan, Rob Delaney and Carrie Fisher, starts its second season.
lead_para: When last we saw Sharon Horgan and Rob Delaney in Amazon’s “Catastrophe,” their unplanned pregnancy had led them beyond the altar to a honeymoon maelstrom — something about her gnarly toenails — that threatened to end things before they’d barely begun. Then her water broke. What calamities could Season 2 possibly bring?
headline: On ‘Catastrophe,’ a Monster-in-Law and More Chaos

abstract: The chat goes from new talking devices, a drone that sees things, goggles (really) and the Apple cliffhanger. (Where’s Mike, anyway?)
lead_para: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Mr. Isaac is out this week, so Joe Plambeck, deputy technology editor, is filling in.
headline: Farhad and Joe Examine Silicon Valley’s Pull in Washington

abstract: Two reporters discuss and marvel at what is and isn’t in Amazon’s sole brick-and-mortar store as it plans to expand its physical locations.
lead_para: This week, Amazon revealed the location of its second brick-and-mortar bookstore, which will open in a few months in Southern California, at a mall near the University of California, San Diego. The online retailer seems to have big ambitions for its physical stores.
headline: A Trip Through Amazon’s First Physical Store

abstract: If you have purchased books on an Amazon Kindle e-reader, you can download the collection onto your iPad with the iOS Kindle app.
lead_para: Q. I have many books on my Kindle. How can I get them onto my iPad? And why does my Kindle app on the iPad not let me buy a book with that device?
headline: Loading the Kindle Library on an iPad

abstract: The giant Internet marketplace is planning to open more storefront locations, a source briefed on the matter said, though not the 300 to 400 shops a shopping mall executive reported on Tuesday.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon signs may be headed to more physical storefronts.
headline: Amazon Is Said to Be Planning an Expansion Into Retail Bookstores

abstract: The releases, which will weave features from the popular streaming video service into the gaming experience, are Amazon’s first games aimed at hard-core players.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon paid about $1 billion two years ago to acquire Twitch, the streaming video service with a fanatical following among gamers. Now the company is using Twitch to start a deeper push into the video game business.
headline: Amazon Creates 3 Games for Twitch Fans

abstract: The promise of big data and big paychecks is drawing some of academia’s top economists to study consumer behavior for tech companies like Airbnb, Amazon and Uber.
lead_para: For eight years, Peter Coles had an economist’s dream job at Harvard Business School.
headline: Goodbye, Ivory Tower. Hello, Silicon Valley Candy Store.

abstract: Household staples like coffee and paper towels arrive automatically, but the prices may vary by as much as 170 percent.
lead_para: WHAT do subscriptions to a newspaper, magazine or Netflix account have in common? Once you sign up, you expect to pay the same rate every month.
headline: Subscribe and Save on Amazon? Don’t Count on It

abstract: The latest Amazon comedy pilots: an adaptation of Chris Kraus’s book; another stab at turning the Tick into a TV series; and a Jean-Claude Van Damme parody.
lead_para: Amazon is posting three new comedy pilots on Friday. You know what they say in baseball — if you get a hit one out of every three at-bats, you’re in the Hall of Fame.
headline: Jill Soloway of ‘Transparent’ Aims to Challenge With ‘I Love Dick’ on Amazon

abstract: The Walmart-Jet deal poses the question of whether Amazon is stoppable. Also, why hiring people who aren’t 20-something Stanford bros can be helpful.
lead_para: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.
headline: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: Betting on Jet and Diverse Work Forces

abstract: Marc Lore, left, the chief executive of Jet.com, and Doug McMillon, the chief executive of Walmart, are teaming up against Amazon.
lead_para: Marc Lore, left, the chief executive of Jet.com, and Doug McMillon, the chief executive of Walmart, are teaming up against Amazon.
headline: Walmart’s New E-Commerce Strategy

abstract: The rules will put new pressure on American tech companies, but European officials say they will unite the Continent’s various national economies.
lead_para: Google may have to pay publishers for their content. Facebook might, too. WhatsApp could have to follow tougher telecom standards.
headline: E.U. Rules Look to Unify Digital Market, but U.S. Sees Protectionism

abstract: It is a conversation occurring on campuses across the country: If more and more students are buying and renting their course books online, why do they need a bookstore?
lead_para: STONY BROOK, N.Y. — As school started at Stony Brook University this month, two freshmen, Juan Adames and John Taveras, set out to buy textbooks.
headline: As Amazon Arrives, the Campus Bookstore Is a Books Store No More

abstract: The bride, a senior executive for Amazon Original Movies, and the groom, a TV writer, were introduced through Hinge.
lead_para: Julie Tripler Rapaport and Greg Levine are to be married Sept. 4 at Kamp Kohut, a summer camp in Oxford, Me., that is owned by the bride’s parents, Lisa M. Tripler and Daniel Rapaport of Cape Elizabeth, Me. Benjamin Samit, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to officiate.
headline: Julie Rapaport, Greg Levine

abstract: The companies are planning to charge as little as $5 a month for new streaming music services, half the cost of the current pricing model.
lead_para: How much are people willing to spend for streaming music?
headline: Amazon and Pandora to Gauge Music’s Value in the Internet Age

abstract: Four people involved in the creation of an industry partnership say its intent will be clear: to ensure that A.I. research is focused on things that will benefit people, not hurt them.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — For years, science-fiction moviemakers have been making us fear the bad things that artificially intelligent machines might do to their human creators. But for the next decade or two, our biggest concern is more likely to be that robots will take away our jobs or bump into us on the highway.
headline: How Tech Giants Are Devising Real Ethics for Artificial Intelligence

abstract: Amazon Prime’s new series in Britain, soon to air in France, chronicles a Parisian fashion house with lots of similarities to the historic one.
lead_para: PARIS — For Dior, it is a revolution: a woman leading its creative side for the first time in the house’s 69-year history. On Friday, Maria Grazia Chiuri will unveil her first collection for the house to an audience (and clients) on the edge of their seats with anticipation. So it is fortuitous that this turning point coincides with the release of a glossy, eight-part television drama calculated to remind us how it all began.
headline: Dior and TV: A ‘New Look’ All Around

abstract: The overall tablet market is no longer a growth juggernaut, with weak sales from the likes of Apple and Samsung. But Amazon’s sales are rising.
lead_para: SEATTLE — When Amazon introduced its first tablet, it seemed like just another me-too entrant in a hot category pioneered by Apple. The company did nothing to diminish this view when it later came out with a smartphone that bombed so badly it stopped selling the phone a year later.
headline: Amazon Has a Potent Weapon in the Tablet Wars: Low Prices

abstract: The comedian Tig Notaro stars in Amazon’s tender-funny “One Mississippi,” in which a loss brings a troubled family together.
lead_para: It’s been said that comedy is tragedy plus time. Lately, it’s been more like tragedy minus a half-hour.
headline: Review: Have You Heard the One About the Grieving Daughter?

abstract: Ms. Waller-Bridge is bringing her sexually rapacious, anger-riddled, flailing London cafe owner to a TV series on Amazon.
lead_para: In her 20s, Phoebe Waller-Bridge found herself confused about what makes a good feminist and how much sex women should have. She wove her deliriously smutty preoccupations, along with a wallop of rage, into “Fleabag,” a show at the 2013 Edinburgh Festival Fringe that scooped up an Olivier nomination and the Stage award for solo performer.
headline: Phoebe Waller-Bridge’s Rage and Sex, in ‘Fleabag’

abstract: The Partnership on AI unites Amazon, Facebook, Google, IBM and Microsoft to ease public fears of machines that are learning to think for themselves.
lead_para: Five major technology companies said Wednesday that they had created an organization to set the ground rules for protecting humans — and their jobs — in the face of rapid advances in artificial intelligence.
headline: Protecting Humans and Jobs From Robots Is 5 Tech Giants’ Goal

abstract: Amazon doesn’t reveal much, but a little sleuthing suggests that drones may be central to the online retailer’s long-term strategy.
lead_para: Amazon is the most obscure large company in the tech industry.
headline: Think Amazon’s Drone Delivery Idea Is a Gimmick? Think Again

abstract: Rackspace has become a partner with Amazon and Azure selling services and helping companies transport data and software to them.
lead_para: Apollo Global Management and Searchlight Capital are making a $4.3 billion bet on capitulation.
headline: Small Cloud Computing Firm Turns to Helping Others Work With Giants

abstract: When the father of a Muslim soldier killed in Iraq challenged Donald J. Trump, interest in the founding document was kindled across the nation.
lead_para: The Constitution appears to be having a moment.
headline: Pocket Constitution Sales Soar After Trump Feud With Khan Family

abstract: The tech giant wants to weave its intelligent assistant into other smart gadgets, even those not made by Amazon. But weakness in mobile could be an obstacle.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon surprised a lot of people when its Echo, a $180 so-called smart speaker, became a hit, giving them a novel way to play music, turn on the lights in their homes and set thermostats with voice commands.
headline: Amazon Has Big Plans for Alexa: Running the ‘Star Trek’ Home

abstract: When the online retailer unveiled its drone project in 2013 it was mocked. It still sounds like a long shot, but it doesn’t seem so crazy anymore.
lead_para: We interrupt your video stream of a man climbing the Trump Tower in Manhattan to bring you this message: Amazon is being a lot more clever with its oddball drone delivery project than you might think.
headline: Daily Report: Amazon’s Drones May Not Be So Crazy After All

abstract: “Eat the World With Emeril Lagasse,” a six-episode Amazon series, debuts on Friday.
lead_para: How does a chef divine the connection between food and place? He asks another chef, naturally. In “Eat the World With Emeril Lagasse,” a six-episode Amazon series that begins Friday, Sept. 2, Mr. Lagasse (of Food Network fame) nibbles his way around the globe with guidance from some well-traveled colleagues. In China, Mario Batali joins him on a quest for the best dumpling soup. In Sweden, the teacher is Marcus Samuelsson, and the lesson is New Nordic cuisine. Danny Bowien provides an introduction to Jeong Kwan, a Zen Buddhist nun in South Korea known as the Philosopher Chef. And José Andrés takes Mr. Lagasse to Barcelona, where the modernist genius Ferran Adrià and his army of thinkers dissect food down to the molecule. It might be Amazon’s answer to Netflix’s “Chef’s Table,” with enough food porn and zesty banter to keep viewers aroused. But fears of a loud American prowling the globe should be laid to rest: Not a single “bam!” resounded in the two episodes I watched.
headline: Emeril Lagasse Takes Bite-Size Steps Across the World

abstract: Discovering what’s in a package delivered to the wrong building.
lead_para: Dear Diary:
headline: A Modest Reward for Helping Amazon Fix a Mistake

abstract: Novelty and technology alone won’t necessarily get you very far. Leading companies turn their tactical edge into durable advantage.
lead_para: Walmart’s $3.3 billion purchase of Jet.com, an online retailer, and Unilever’s $1 billion acquisition of Dollar Shave Club, a company that mostly sells razor blade subscriptions online, were home runs for brilliant entrepreneurs (and, of course, their backers).
headline: Why It’s Not Enough Just to Be Disruptive

abstract: The acquisition of Jet, the largest deal ever for an e-commerce company, is intended to help both companies compete with Amazon.
lead_para: Traditional retailers have spent more than a decade and billions of dollars trying to transform their brick-and-mortar businesses for the online shopper. Yet Amazon and other digital upstarts continue to lap them.
headline: Walmart Rewrites Its E-Commerce Strategy With $3.3 Billion Deal for Jet.com

abstract: Technology is now so pervasive in business that it might be time to call G.E. and Johnson & Johnson tech stocks, not just the Silicon Valley stars.
lead_para: Apple, Google, Microsoft and Amazon have created something of a watershed moment in the stock market.
headline: When Every Company Is a Tech Company, Does the Label Matter?

abstract: As some tech sectors show signs of slowing, cloud services have created remarkable demand for highly educated engineers and mathematicians. And they are being compensated very well.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon Web Services, a globe-spanning cloud computing network that is part of the online retailing giant Amazon, has rapidly become one of the most powerful forces in technology. It has also become a target for poachers.
headline: Tech Companies, New and Old, Clamor to Entice Cloud Computing Experts

abstract: The new devices, the Amazon Tap and Echo Dot, expand what appears to be a successful product line for the Internet retailer.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon’s Alexa is gaining new powers, and a couple of new looks, too.
headline: Amazon Introduces 2 Alexa Voice-Controlled Devices

abstract: Sherwin-Williams to Buy Valspar | Starwood Says Anbang Has the Superior Offer
lead_para: BANKS PULL FINANCING FROM COAL INDUSTRY | Wall Street’s retreat from the coal industry is an ominous sign for a sector already in decline,Michael Corkery writes in DealBook. JPMorgan Chase said it would no longer finance new coal-fired power plants in the United States or other wealthy nations. Bank of America, Citigroup and Morgan Stanley have made similar decisions.
headline: Morning Agenda: Banks Pull Financing From Coal Industry

abstract: The voice-controlled computer has the potential to become a dominant force in the most intimate of environments: our homes.
lead_para: Many of the world’s largest technology companies have spent the last five years searching in vain for the holy grail, a machine to succeed the smartphone as the next must-have gadget.
headline: The Echo From Amazon Brims With Groundbreaking Promise

abstract: Industry titans like Amazon and Oracle are duking it out for cloud engineers, taking swipes at the competition and attracting workers with salaries as high as $1 million.
lead_para: Even as much of the tech industry is shifting into a less frothy period, one thing hasn’t changed: the fierce competition for top technical talent.
headline: Tech Giants Battle for Top Cloud Talent

abstract: Convoy gives local truckers — who specialize in jobs that could be completed in a day — a more efficient way to connect with clients who need goods shipped.
lead_para: SEATTLE — It has become a tech industry cliché to describe new on-demand businesses as “Ubers for X” — with X being anything from furniture movers to dispensers of medical marijuana.
headline: Convoy Sees Itself as the Uber of Local Trucking

abstract: In an interview, Margrethe Vestager, the European Union’s competition commissioner, discusses the issues underpinning her current investigations and whether she unfairly targets American companies.
lead_para: BRUSSELS — Margrethe Vestager is already having a busy 2016.
headline: Europe’s Antitrust Enforcer on Google, Apple and the Year Ahead

abstract: The Internet giant is adding dozens of products to its Dash Button program, making it possible to order a specific product with the push of a plastic widget.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Aaron Horn, an information technology director for the Iowa Interstate Railroad, recently decided to take convenience in his home to the next level.
headline: More Brands Mean Many More Buttons for Quirky Amazon Service

abstract: Tech’s new architecture melds large computing clouds and artificial intelligence to create efficient computing resources and data-based businesses.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — As the oracles of Silicon Valley debate whether the latest tech boom is sliding toward bust, there is already talk about what will drive the industry’s next growth spurt.
headline: Silicon Valley Looks to Artificial Intelligence for the Next Big Thing

abstract: Drawn from Michael Connelly’s California noir novels, the second season of this Amazon series starts by having the protagonist come off a suspension.
lead_para: Season 2 of Amazon’s “Bosch” begins the way Season 1 did — with a car gliding down a Los Angeles hillside, the lights of the city twinkling in the background and a violent death just around the corner. No other current series is as conversant with the images, the moods and, sometimes, the clichés of Southern California noir.
headline: Review: ‘Bosch’ Returns a Detective to the Force

abstract: The neighborhood literary hangout, once struggling, appears to be winning over young readers who enjoy the face-to-face social experience of shopping for “real books.”
lead_para: The decades of trauma suffered by independent neighborhood bookstores — damage from bargain megastores, the ascension of the e-book and Amazon’s flash delivery of cut-rate reading — hardly hindered Chris Doeblin’s search for the right place to open his fourth independent bookstore in Manhattan.
headline: Indie Bookstores Are Back, With a Passion

abstract: The agreement would let businesses like Google and Facebook continue to move personal data across the Atlantic, but European privacy officials may balk.
lead_para: European officials on Tuesday agreed to a deal with the United States that would let Google, Amazon and thousands of other businesses continue moving people’s digital data, including social media posts and financial information, back and forth across the Atlantic.
headline: U.S. and Europe in ‘Safe Harbor’ Data Deal, but Legal Fight May Await

abstract: As the stock market continues its 2016 slide, technology stocks are falling even further, victims partly of their own success.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — As the United States economy muddled along over the last few years, investors paid handsome sums to get in on high-flying technology companies that were among the few pockets of steady growth. Now comes the payback.
headline: Tech Stocks Have Fallen Faster and Further Than Broader Market

abstract: Yahoo and Twitter are just the latest tech companies shaping plans for major overhauls and management shake-ups. A look back at how Priceline, Amazon and eBay weathered turbulent times.
lead_para: Ups and downs are nothing new in the fast-moving technology industry. And as soon as a company hits turbulence, calls for a management shake-up almost always follow.
headline: Tech’s Track Record of Shake-Ups at the Top

abstract: A day after saying that Amazon planned to open 300 to 400 brick-and-mortar bookstores, a shopping mall executive stepped back from his comments.
lead_para: SEATTLE — A day after saying that Amazon plans to open hundreds of physical bookstores, the chief executive of a large shopping mall operator has backed away from the comments.
headline: Mall Executive Backtracks From Statement on Amazon Retail Stores

abstract: Furla lets you get personal, Apiece Apart and Dieppa Restrepo are teaming up on a sample sale, and more.
lead_para: On Thursday, Amazon Fashion will unveil a shopping destination featuring the spring collections of the 2015 CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund contenders just in time for “The Fashion Fund” Series 3 premiere on the Internet retailer’s streaming service. You’ll find sweet picks like a Jonathan Simkhai radial gingham dress ($445), Brother Vellies ankle-strap sandals ($435) and a Gypsy Sport mixed media cap ($132) from the three winners, and items from all of the remaining seven finalists. At amazon.com/FashionFundShop.
headline: Amazon Puts Spotlight on ‘The Fashion Fund’

abstract: How an offhand remark about Amazon opening new bookstores spawned a viral reaction and a backtracking.
lead_para: Amazon is poised to expand its one Seattle bookstore into a chain of such stores. Or is it?
headline: Daily Report: The Mystery of Amazon’s Bookstores

abstract: Delivery services now come through in hours, not days. But the boxes after boxes generated create environmental concerns, and some guilt.
lead_para: Ruchit Garg, a Silicon Valley entrepreneur, says that he worries that something isn’t right with his Internet shopping habit. With each new delivery to his doorstep — sometimes several in a day — he faces the source of his guilt and frustration: another cardboard box.
headline: E-Commerce: Convenience Built on a Mountain of Cardboard

abstract: Start-up funding isn’t as extravagant as it used to be, and some firms will not survive the downturn.
lead_para: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.
headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Start-Ups and the Circle of Life

abstract: Nielsen executives say that they have heard the complaints of TV and ad executives and are ready to track the many ways people consume media. But skeptics abound.
lead_para: Dennis Cheatham said he felt as if he were receiving a message from the past last May when a package arrived in the mail from Nielsen asking him to participate in the survey that for decades has detailed the television viewing habits of Americans.
headline: Nielsen Plays Catch-Up as Streaming Era Wreaks Havoc on TV Raters

abstract: Whodunit? The government, of course, in a British thriller that follows in the hallowed footsteps of “Edge of Darkness” and “State of Play.”
lead_para: The new Amazon series “Fearless” is a solid, atmospheric but unsurprising exercise in a British perennial: the old-boy’s-club conspiracy thriller, in which an ordinary bloke discovers that the aristocrats and technocrats who run the country will go to murderous lengths to cover up their indiscretions. Superior versions include “Edge of Darkness” (1985, available on DVD) and the great “State of Play” (2003, streaming at Britbox).
headline: Review: Amazon’s British Thriller ‘Fearless’ Is for the Conspiracy-Minded
