abstract: Other countries have their eyes on the money that lawmakers want to put on American tax rolls. But a European crackdown could work in Washington’s favor.
lead_para: President Trump and congressional lawmakers are not the only ones interested in collecting taxes on global profits that American corporations are hoarding overseas. European regulators, knee deep in a campaign to stamp out tax avoidance, have their own plans for that money.
headline: U.S. and Europe May Collide on Taxing Apple and Amazon

abstract: Streaming services are constantly adding new stuff to their libraries. Here are six fresh favorites.
lead_para: Watching is The New York Times’s TV and film recommendation newsletter and website.
headline: What’s New on Netflix and Amazon Prime This Weekend

abstract: Amazon’s original-programming division was already considering a change in strategy before the accusation against its top executive.
lead_para: The head of Amazon Studios, Roy Price, resigned on Tuesday, just days after a producer publicly accused him of sexual harassment, a spokesman for the company said.
headline: Roy Price Quits Amazon Studios After Sexual Harassment Claim

abstract: Cities used to be tied to geography: a river, a port, the lee side of a mountain range.
lead_para: SEATTLE — I live in the city that hit the Amazon jackpot, now the biggest company town in America. Long before the mad dash to land the second headquarters for the world’s largest online retailer, Amazon found us. Since then, we’ve been overwhelmed by a future we never had any say over.
headline: How Amazon Took Seattle’s Soul

abstract: Reporting on technology has changed this year — what once felt like a world of boundless possibility now comes freighted with worry.
lead_para: It’s gadget season in the tech world. Think of it like New York Fashion Week, untucked white-man edition.
headline: Why Tech Is Starting to Make Me Uneasy

abstract: Fans and cast members hope the Amazon series will return after Roy Price, the head of Amazon Studios, resigned amid sexual harassment allegations.
lead_para: Amazon Studios declined to order another season of the feminist series “Good Girls Revolt” last year, just as the show’s relevance was on the rise.
headline: The Women Behind ‘Good Girls Revolt’ Think the Time Is Right to Revive the Feminist Show

abstract: Aetna, which reported a jump in profit, could be a new source of customers for its suitor, CVS.
lead_para: Aetna’s third-quarter results show its value to CVS Health. Revenue at the $56 billion health-coverage firm fell 5 percent in the three months to the end of September, partly because it pulled out of health insurance exchanges. But profit jumped 48 percent as the company kept costs under control. That offers alluring protection for CVS, whose pharmacy and drug-benefit business is threatened by rising competition and transparency.
headline: Aetna Could Offer CVS Valuable Protection

abstract: Go to Yankee Stadium? Buy from Amazon or Starbucks? Mayor Bill de Blasio just can’t do it, even when his job would seem to call for such gestures.
lead_para: Hours after New York City released its bid for Amazon’s second headquarters, Mayor Bill de Blasio conveyed an entirely different message to a Brooklyn audience on Wednesday night: The behemoth online retailer is bad for small businesses. Shop local, like he does.
headline: What May Seem Good for New York Is Not Always Good for Its Mayor

abstract: Welcome to the latest edition of the Smarter Living newsletter.
lead_para: Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter. The Smarter Living team emails readers once a week with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox every Monday morning.
headline: 5 Cheap(ish) Things to Help You Recover From a Tough Workout

abstract: Former adversaries see advantages in partnerships as they face the threat of interlopers like Amazon. But will consumers benefit or face a lot less choice?
lead_para: They seem like odd couples: Aetna, one of the nation’s largest health insurers, is in talks to combine with CVS Health, which manages pharmacy benefits. The Cleveland Clinic, a highly regarded health system, joined forces with an insurance start-up, Oscar Health, to offer individuals a health plan in Ohio.
headline: As Health Care Changes, Insurers, Hospitals and Drugstores Team Up

abstract: Employees at several e-commerce companies recently acquired by Walmart are finding that their coverage will come at a far higher price.
lead_para: The steady growth of e-commerce has been a source of jobs and benefits as employment in traditional stores declines. But at online retailers taken over by Walmart, workers are finding one benefit in retreat: their company-sponsored health coverage.
headline: As Walmart Buys Online Retailers, Their Health Benefits Suffer

abstract: The online retailer is a rarity: A start-up that has been profitable. But investors will have to decide if it can compete with the e-commerce behemoth.
lead_para: Stitch Fix is an increasingly rare kind of start-up pursuing a public listing, because it has shown it can turn a profit. The question for investors is whether a company whose business could be swamped by Amazon — in this case, selling clothes over the internet — is a safe bet.
headline: Stitch Fix Prepares an I.P.O. in the Shadow of Amazon

abstract: Most third-party sellers on Amazon do not collect sales tax. States, thirsty for the millions of dollars in unpaid revenue, are coming for the money.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon and the tax man are back at it again.
headline: Amazon Sellers Brood as States Come Calling for Taxes

abstract: The e-commerce giant posted strong results for its most recent quarter but still faces challenges that include growing outside of its core business.
lead_para: HONG KONG — When Joseph C. Tsai, the billionaire vice chairman of the Alibaba Group, recently agreed to buy a 49 percent stake in the Brooklyn Nets, it was a sign of the enormous financial success that the company has enjoyed amid China’s e-commerce boom.
headline: Alibaba’s Earnings Jump as China’s Online Shopping Boom Continues

abstract: Rachel Brosnahan kills as a housewife in transition in this slow-to-develop but effervescent comedy about comedy, set in a stylized 1950s Manhattan.
lead_para: Amy Sherman-Palladino has a new TV series, and it’s about a comedian; but I repeat myself.
headline: Review: In ‘The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel,’ a Comic Asks, Take My Strife, Please

abstract: Except for Amazon, most major retailers have scaled back plans for hiring temporary employees during the year’s biggest shopping season, and Walmart is adding almost none.
lead_para: After 14 years of staying home to raise her family, Melanie Colon landed a job for the holidays at a Target store in Queens, selling toys, bedsheets and linens. She hopes it will lead to a full-time position.
headline: Retailers’ Recipe for the Holidays: Big Sales; Fewer Seasonal Workers

abstract: The software giant plans to invest billions of dollars in renovating its campus in Redmond, Wash., to create a more urban atmosphere.
lead_para: SEATTLE — While Amazon is hunting for a second headquarters away from its hometown, its neighbor in the Seattle area — Microsoft — is doubling down on the region, with plans to invest billions of dollars in redeveloping its existing campus.
headline: Microsoft to Expand Campus, as Amazon Looks Elsewhere

abstract: For Seattle, Amazon has become far more than a big employer and taxpayer.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon, the colossus of internet commerce that was founded here, is conducting the most dramatic sweepstakes of modern capitalism in throwing open a competition for a coequal second headquarters. The company has promised to create about 50,000 new jobs at HQ2, as Amazon is calling it, paralleling the similar number the company plans to employ here over the next couple of years.
headline: 5 Lessons Seattle Can Teach Other Cities About Amazon

abstract: Amazon announced on Monday that it has retained the rights to adapt J.R.R. Tolkien’s “Lord of the Rings” for television for its Prime streaming service.
lead_para: Middle Earth is coming to TV.
headline: ‘Lord of the Rings’ Series Coming to Amazon

abstract: “Increasingly, if you win on Amazon, you win, period,” a beverage executive says.
lead_para: Amazon’s rapidly expanding influence on a wide portion of the American public has become impossible to ignore — and it is giving rise to a whole new side of the advertising industry.
headline: As Amazon’s Influence Grows, Marketers Scramble to Tailor Strategies

abstract: The company already has one of the most spectacular records in stock market history, enriching investors and making its founder a wealthy man.
lead_para: Amazon and its founder, Jeff Bezos, are having a moment.
headline: The Mind-Boggling Ascent of Amazon and Jeff Bezos

abstract: The common refrain is that Amazon and other e-tailers are killing retail jobs, but one new statistical analysis begs to differ.
lead_para: Retailing is dead. Sales clerks are losing their jobs by the thousands. The employment picture for young people with only a high school education is going to get even worse. And all this is happening because of Amazon and its ilk, which are driving the shift among consumers toward e-commerce.
headline: E-Commerce as a Jobs Engine? One Economist’s Unorthodox View

abstract: The Amazon chief executive was briefly the richest person in the world, by one reckoning, but then the company issued a disappointing earnings report.
lead_para: Thursday was something of an up-and-down day for Jeff Bezos.
headline: The Riches of Jeff Bezos

abstract: Most of Hampton Creek’s board resigned last month, another setback in Silicon Valley’s push to innovate beyond the high-tech industry.
lead_para: Silicon Valley’s plan to reinvent so many things outside the high-tech industry has had a rough go of it lately.
headline: Daily Report: Reinventing Food Isn’t Easy

abstract: The company’s acquisition of Whole Foods sets up a clash between two vastly different visions for the future of labor.
lead_para: At 9 p.m. Eastern time on July 10, Amazon initiated its annual show of force: Prime Day, a 30-hour exercise in the fullest possible expression of what Amazon can do. The sale, timed to the company’s ‘‘birthday,’’ is marketed with an urgency bordering on panic. What’s for sale? Basically anything. Where is it for sale? Wherever you are. Some sales last the whole prolonged day; others last a few minutes. A car seat. Golf clubs. Jeans and a screen door. Turmeric extract. A gallon of Elmer’s glue. An Amazon product — the voice-controlled Echo, which can order more products from Amazon. Makeup brushes. Jumper cables. A tablet computer. The shopping experience is at turns euphoric and anxiety-inducing, Amazon’s already-busy interface teeming with decontextualized blinking numbers: Sunglasses by “Hulislem,” $16.79, down from $115.95 after a previous discount to $28.99, 86 percent off, ends in 2:08:51, 63 percent already claimed. No? Next. Pro Series Waist Trimmer: $15.16-$18.96, 22 percent claimed, ends in . . . 0:00:43. Damn. Time is running out.
headline: What Will Service Work Look Like Under Amazon?

abstract: The authorities said the smart home device made an emergency call, but Amazon and a 911 official said that was not plausible.
lead_para: It started as a tale of technology coming to the rescue: The authorities said an Amazon Echo called 911 during a violent assault in Albuquerque.
headline: Did an Echo Call 911 During a Domestic Assault? Amazon Says No.

abstract: Amazon’s annual deals blowout, Prime Day, is back again — but not all the deals are worthwhile. Luckily, we can help.
lead_para: Amazon’s Prime Day — the annual, summer version of an all-Amazon Cyber Monday — starts today. As with the last few years, most deals aren’t worth it, but there are a few gems sprinkled throughout. Subscribers to Amazon’s Prime service (which gets you two-day shipping on items and other perks for $99 yearly) have access to thousands of items on sale.
headline: How to Make the Most of Amazon’s Prime Day

abstract: Amazon’s purchase of Whole Foods could deprive us of human contact.
lead_para: The next time you check out at Whole Foods, you might meet my friend Esther at the register. In a few years, you might meet a robot. Or no one at all.
headline: You Don’t Want to Buy Groceries From a Robot

abstract: A longtime approach of making bold — and sometimes head-scratching — moves has brought Jeff Bezos staggering success.
lead_para: Joke all you want about drone-delivered kale and arugula. Amazon’s $13.4 billion bet to take on the $800 billion grocery business in the United States by acquiring Whole Foods fits perfectly into the retailer’s business model.
headline: Whole Foods Deal Shows Amazon’s Prodigious Tolerance for Risk

abstract: Over several decades, John Mackey grew a 2,000 square-foot store in Austin into a $13.4 billion deal with Amazon.
lead_para: Led by co-founder John Mackey, Whole Foods Market quickly grew from a small store in Austin, Tex., to the largest natural-foods supermarket chain in the United States. But as organic foods grew in popularity, Whole Foods was squeezed by lower-cost grocery rivals.
headline: How Whole Foods Became the Organic Giant

abstract: Amazon agreed to buy the grocery chain Whole Foods for $13.4 billion.
lead_para: Amazon agreed to buy the grocery chain Whole Foods for $13.4 billion.
headline: When Amazon Comes to Town

abstract: If Walmart wants to make a rival bid for Whole Foods, it will need to overcome strategic and financial obstacles. For now, Amazon has the upper hand.
lead_para: Walmart’s market capitalization dropped 5 percent, losing $11 billion, after Amazon unveiled its $13.4 billion deal to buy Whole Foods Market on Friday. Meanwhile, Whole Foods shares closed Friday nearly 2 percent above the agreed price, implying that some investors think a rival bid could emerge. But even for Walmart, that would be a stretch.
headline: Walmart Will Struggle to Top Amazon’s Offer for Whole Foods

abstract: The Amazon chief asked for tips where his money could be used in the “here and now,” unlike many of his business investments.
lead_para: You’re an astronomically wealthy tech mogul who has mastered the art of getting people to spend money with your company over the internet. How do you come up with fresh ideas for giving some of your fortune away?
headline: Jeff Bezos Wants Ideas for Philanthropy, So He Asked Twitter

abstract: To understand why Jeff Bezos bought Whole Foods, look at the profit margins Apple generates at its stores.
lead_para: Blood is running in the retail aisle. Sears, the most iconic name in American retailing, told its investors in March that “substantial doubt exists related to the Company’s ability to continue as a going concern.” The appliance retailer HH Gregg went defunct at the end of May, and once-celebrated companies like Bebe and Limited are desperately trying to survive as online-only storefronts. The carnage has spread beyond empty shopping malls and big-box stores to the grocery trade. Last week, a poor earnings report cost Kroger, the nation’s second-largest food retailer, 19 percent of its stock market value in a matter of hours — and that was before Amazon announced its acquisition of Whole Foods Market.
headline: Can Amazon Be the Next Apple?

abstract: People have wondered if the Amazon chief was waiting until retirement to make a big charitable splash. In a tweet, he solicited ideas from the public.
lead_para: Jeff Bezos, the founder and chief executive of Amazon, is well on his way to becoming the richest person in the world, with a net worth of more than $80 billion. What’s less certain is what he plans to do with his fortune, and how he could reinvent philanthropy.
headline: At Last, Jeff Bezos Offers a Hint of His Philanthropic Plans

abstract: The newest versions of Amazon’s tablets, starting at $50, are unabashedly slow and unflashy, but just capable enough to be worth the cheap price.
lead_para: What can $50 buy? An inexpensive pair of sneakers, maybe dinner for two in San Francisco or a couple of tickets to the ballgame. But few ever imagined that it could also buy a tablet computer capable of running apps and streaming Netflix.
headline: What You Get (and What You Don’t) From a $50 Amazon Fire

abstract: The proposed Whole Foods acquisition might lower prices in the short run but will definitely create an unhealthy concentration of market power.
lead_para: Amazon on Friday announced plans to acquire Whole Foods, the high-end grocer. If approved by antitrust enforcers, the $13.7 billion deal would give Amazon control of more than 400 stores, an extensive supply chain and a new source of consumer data.
headline: Amazon Bites Off Even More Monopoly Power

abstract: The explosion in index-tracking E.T.F.s and soaring tech stocks have put traditional mutual fund managers like those at Parnassus Investments on the defensive.
lead_para: Technology stocks had another scorching weeklong run last month, capped off by Amazon’s startling decision to buy Whole Foods for $13.4 billion.
headline: Tech Stocks Boom, but Some Stock Pickers Are Wary

abstract: Three Times tech reporters discuss Snap’s difficulties as a public company, and the so-called net neutrality debate.
lead_para: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. This week, Farhad and Mike also talked with Nellie Bowles, who just joined The Times as a technology reporter.
headline: Farhad’s and Mike’s and Nellie’s Week in Tech: Struggles for Snap

abstract: Should every company create its own self-driving program? Mike and Farhad debate.
lead_para: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.
headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Meal Kits, Lyft and ‘Despacito’

abstract: References to “2001: A Space Odyssey,” “The Night of the Hunter” and “Carnival of Souls” are seen in a recent hour of Mr. Lynch’s revival.
lead_para: The artist and filmmaker David Lynch has an uncanny ability to create work that doesn’t just evoke dread and discomfort — it can make a viewer actually feel that dread and discomfort. “Lynch is a director of mood and texture, the queasier the better,” the critic J. Hoberman observed back in 1984. In the same piece, Mr. Hoberman proclaimed that Mr. Lynch “may be the American director with the most direct pipeline to his unconscious.” These traits are explicitly evident in “Twin Peaks: The Return,” the extraordinary limited series — or 18-hour movie, as Mr. Lynch would have it; he’s divided it into “parts” rather than “episodes” — now unspooling on Showtime, and its attendant streaming site and app Showtime Now.
headline: David Lynch Weaves Film History Into ‘Twin Peaks: The Return’

abstract: The city is newly stylish, with hyped restaurants and an Ace hotel, thanks to a steady flow of Carnegie Mellon grads who decided to stay.
lead_para: PITTSBURGH — In 2015, Monocle magazine, a favorite read of the global hipsterati, published an enthusiastic report on Lawrenceville, the former blue-collar neighborhood here filled with cafes, hyped restaurants and brick rowhouses being renovated by flippers.
headline: Pittsburgh Gets a Tech Makeover

abstract: “The Last Tycoon,” a nine-episode series, is the latest good-looking attempt to adapt F. Scott Fitzgerald for the screen.
lead_para: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — Meltdowns are not Matt Bomer’s style, not even remotely, but he would have been due one in mid-March.
headline: Amazon Tackles Hollywood’s F. Scott Fitzgerald Obsession

abstract: The American tech behemoth may be seeking to tailor its widely used voice recognition system to an Australian audience.
lead_para: SYDNEY, Australia — Think you know the ins and outs of Australian English? Amazon is hiring.
headline: Want a Job, Mate? Amazon Is Hiring Aussie Speakers

abstract: Siri is so five years ago: How a sleek, smooth-talking cylinder from Amazon stole our hearts, bamboozled our spouses and enchanted our children.
lead_para: The other day, a newly single friend confessed that lately she had found herself not just chatting up Alexa, Amazon’s crisp-voiced domestic bot, but also looking forward to her responses. “That’s a road,” she said darkly, “you don’t want to be heading down.”
headline: ‘Alexa, Where Have You Been All My Life?’

abstract: Wall Street would probably have pummeled any other retailer that turned in the kind of performance Amazon reported Thursday: profits that were less than a third of what analysts had expected.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Investors gave Amazon’s stock a bump early Thursday in anticipation of a strong earnings report later in the day, briefly making Jeff Bezos, the company’s chief executive, the world’s wealthiest person.
headline: Amazon Profits Fall Far Short of Expectations, but Investors Shrug

abstract: In this week’s tech newsletter, Farhad and Mike discuss Uber’s C.E.O. search and their love of C-Span.
lead_para: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.
headline: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: The End of the iPod, Plus Uber News

abstract: Several large corporations quickly expressed dismay with President Trump’s decision and said they would continue their environmental efforts.
lead_para: Soon after President Trump announced that the United States would back out of the Paris climate accord, several large companies based in the United States that had supported the international pact said they were disappointed by the decision and would continue their environmental efforts.
headline: ‘Climate Change Is Real’: Many U.S. Companies Lament Paris Accord Exit

abstract: By purchasing the upscale chain, Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief, has a chance to tinker with how people buy groceries — and map the future of the physical store.
lead_para: When big tech companies make big moves, it’s natural to see the news in earthshaking terms.
headline: In Whole Foods, Bezos Gets a Sustainably Sourced Guinea Pig

abstract: Annie Baker and Heidi Schreck wrote an episode of Amazon’s “I Love Dick” that our critic calls the best 20 minutes of television she has seen in years.
lead_para: Are you a woman? Have you been a woman? Do you know any women? O.K. Great. Watch the fifth episode of Jill Soloway’s “I Love Dick,” streaming on Amazon. Right now. You can also watch the four preceding episodes, but you don’t have to. Go ahead. I’ll wait.
headline: Groundbreaking TV About Female Desire, Thanks to Playwrights

abstract: Bananas can’t get cold. Milk mustn’t tip. Online food delivery still trips up companies. A day on the truck shows why.
lead_para: Every couple of days, Sinclair Browne fights through traffic in Times Square, squeezes his delivery truck into a parking spot, walks up four flights of stairs and delivers groceries to a guy whose order he knows by heart.
headline: A Street Fight Among Grocers to Deliver Your Milk, Eggs, Bananas

abstract: Tips to make the most of your weekend.
lead_para: Psst. Hey you. Got a secret.
headline: What to Cook, Watch, Listen To and More This Weekend

abstract: The pop star’s music will be available on all major streaming services, including the paid and free tiers of Spotify, Amazon and Google Play.
lead_para: Taylor Swift is returning her music catalog to streaming services, ending the digital music world’s highest-profile feud and affirming that streaming is now the dominant music format.
headline: Taylor Swift Returns Her Music Catalog to Streaming Services

abstract: The next jobs set to disappear may be ones that are a bigger part of people’s daily lives: retail workers and cashiers in stores and restaurants.
lead_para: Imagine this scene from the future: You walk into a store and are greeted by name, by a computer with facial recognition that directs you to the items you need. You peruse a small area — no chance of getting lost or wasting time searching for things — because the store stocks only sample items. You wave your phone in front of anything you want to buy, then walk out. In the back, robots retrieve your items from a warehouse and deliver them to your home via driverless car or drone.
headline: Amazon’s Move Signals End of Line for Many Cashiers

abstract: Amazon’s newest Echo smart speaker has a touch screen. Our reviewer asked whether that made the gadget much different from a smartphone or a tablet.
lead_para: A week ago, I began testing Amazon’s Echo Show, a new smart speaker that has a touch screen. For due diligence on the device’s capabilities, I ran it through a battery of tests, including its ability to play podcasts, book a restaurant table and list movie showtimes.
headline: Alexa, What Happens if the Echo Has a Screen? You Get This Review

abstract: Our Top 10 Comments of the Week: Readers debate being interrupted at work, the shooting of a politician and the fate of American “Dreamers.”
lead_para: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.
headline: ‘I Have Stopped Taking My Notebooks and Pens to Meetings’

abstract: Shares of Netflix, Apple and other giant technology companies that have powered a market rally have taken an uncharacteristic pause.
lead_para: The laws of gravity apparently apply to technology stocks after all.
headline: A Slump in Tech Stocks That Leaves Some Investors Mystified

abstract: Apple’s Watch has a bug, Facebook might be undermining democracy, and Amazon is telling us how to make bombs. Tech news is weird right now.
lead_para: Each Friday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.
headline: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: A Very Bad Week for Digital Giants

abstract: Two tech reporters analyze the week’s big tech news, including Uber’s surprising new C.E.O. and how Amazon might change Whole Foods.
lead_para: Each Friday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Mike is out this week so Nick Wingfield, a Times technology reporter based in Seattle, filled in.
headline: Farhad’s and Nick’s Week in Review: Uber’s New Boss and Amazon’s New Supermarket

abstract: Let’s skip the nationwide bidding war and cut right to the winner.
lead_para: Let’s skip the nationwide bidding war and cut right to the winner.
headline: Dear Amazon, We Picked Your New Headquarters for You

abstract: Amazon’s warehouses, which now employ more than 125,000 people across the United States, are being outfitted with the latest in robots and tech, but not at the expense of human jobs.
lead_para: Amazon’s warehouses, which now employ more than 125,000 people across the United States, are being outfitted with the latest in robots and tech, but not at the expense of human jobs.
headline: Robots and Humans Team Up at Amazon

abstract: Why the government seems paralyzed in the face of the power and influence of companies like Apple, Google and Microsoft.
lead_para: The tech giants are too big. They’re getting bigger. We can stop them. But in all likelihood, we won’t.
headline: Can Washington Stop Big Tech Companies? Don’t Bet on It

abstract: Media, telecom and other industries struggled to find lawmakers who would be critical of big technology companies. Not anymore.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — For years, the country’s biggest technology companies have been virtually untouchable in Washington. The public adored the companies’ new devices, educators embraced their tools and politicians extolled their contributions to the economy. Even traditionally powerful voices, like media and telecom businesses, found little success in criticizing the technology industry.
headline: Big Tech’s Rivals Pounce at Chances to Win in Washington

abstract: Among the factors that will affect where the company chooses to put its new headquarters: cost, diversity, universities — and coffee roasters.
lead_para: Amazon said this week it had received proposals from 238 cities and regions across North America that are vying for its new, second headquarters, called HQ2. No wonder: With a prize of 50,000 high-paying jobs, a promised $5 billion in construction spending and the prestige of having a headquarters for one of the world’s fastest-growing, best-known tech companies, the contest is vastly more important than a World Series or Super Bowl.
headline: Following the (Bike) Trail to Amazon’s Second Headquarters

abstract: Welcome to the latest edition of the Smarter Living newsletter.
lead_para: Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter. The Smarter Living team emails readers once a week with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox every Monday morning.
headline: 5 Cheap(ish) Things to Improve Your Home Office

abstract: With permission, Amazon’s couriers in many cities will unlock homes and drop packages inside. Other companies are trying similar tactics.
lead_para: SEATTLE — For many online shoppers, packages often linger for distressingly long hours outside their homes, where they can be stolen or soaked by rain. Now, if customers give it permission, Amazon’s couriers will unlock the front doors and drop packages inside when no one is home.
headline: Amazon’s Latest Way Into Your Life Is Through the Front Door

abstract: American tech companies positioned themselves as entities that brought positive change by connecting people and spreading information. Perceptions are shifting.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — At the start of this decade, the Arab Spring blossomed with the help of social media. That is the sort of story the tech industry loves to tell about itself: It is bringing freedom, enlightenment and a better future for all mankind.
headline: Tech Giants, Once Seen as Saviors, Are Now Viewed as Threats

abstract: This week’s newsletter examines the urge to resist outsiders, from the bookish left and the populist right.
lead_para: Damien Cave, our Australia bureau chief, shares insights on global news, local recommendations and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. To receive it in your inbox, sign up here.
headline: Australia Battles Amazon, With Populist Defiance

abstract: While Amazon appears interested in exploring the pharmacy business, the questions are when they would make the move, and in what direction.
lead_para: SEATTLE — With little more than a whiff of Amazon’s interest in a new business, the company can crater the stocks of potential competitors, prompting them to consider bold acquisitions and other drastic measures in response. Just ask companies in the home improvement, meal-kit and grocery businesses.
headline: Hearing Amazon’s Footsteps, the Health Care Industry Shudders

abstract: Changes to the formulas used to build albums and singles charts will weigh paid streams more than free ones. What will the impact be? A conversation, on Popcast.
lead_para: The Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.
headline: What Are the Billboard Charts Really Measuring?

abstract: Some are heading to Washington to explain their role in the 2016 election. Others are facing regulatory scrutiny. Consumers don’t seem to care.
lead_para: Big technology companies are being dragged in front of Congress to answer tough questions about their impact on the 2016 presidential election, and their market power is under increasing scrutiny.
headline: What Worries? Big Tech Companies Post Glowing Quarterly Profits

abstract: Mr. Tambor denies the allegations, but said he could not return to the show “given the politicized atmosphere that seems to have afflicted our set.”
lead_para: Jeffrey Tambor, the star of the Amazon series “Transparent,” will not return for the show’s fifth season after two women accused him of sexual misconduct.
headline: Jeffrey Tambor Leaves ‘Transparent’ After Sexual Misconduct Allegations

abstract: Apple had said its HomePod speaker, a response to Amazon’s Echo, would debut this year. Now it won’t be released till early next year.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple is putting the brakes on the arrival this year of HomePod, its much-ballyhooed rival to Amazon’s Echo smart speaker.
headline: Apple Postpones Release of HomePod Speaker

abstract: In the new Amazon show “Jean-Claude Van Johnson,” the seemingly washed-up Muscles from Brussels gleefully sends up his action star image.
lead_para: SIMI VALLEY, Calif. — On a recent afternoon on his expansive estate here, in a beautifully appointed living room the size of a mead hall, Jean-Claude Van Damme suddenly fired a high kick at my face, stopping short of crunching cartilage and bone. I didn’t ask him to do it, but it was a thrill nonetheless. After all, he’s aimed that very same foot at the heads of action superstars like Dolph Lundgren, Bolo Yeung and Sylvester Stallone.
headline: Jean-Claude Van Damme Plays Jean-Claude Van Damme, for Kicks

abstract: Thousands of Indian sellers have shipped bedding, jewelry, kitchenware and clothing to Amazon warehouses to serve bargain-hunting Americans.
lead_para: MUMBAI, India — Americans shopping on Amazon.com this holiday season may find that the best deals for popular gifts like leather shoes and luxury bedding are coming from an unexpected source: Indian merchants.
headline: Amazon, in Hunt for Lower Prices, Recruits Indian Merchants

abstract: What if it’s not that bad that so much economic, social and political power is held by Apple, Amazon, Google, Facebook and Microsoft?
lead_para: The tech giants are too big. But what if that’s not so bad?
headline: The Upside of Being Ruled by the Five Tech Giants

abstract: After a bitter dispute, Nelson Peltz’s firm announced that a vote count showed that Mr. Peltz had been elected to Procter & Gamble’s board of directors, despite previous preliminary counts.
lead_para: Happy Wednesday. We’re waiting to see when — or if — the Justice Department moves to block AT&T’s bid for Time Warner. And we’re watching the latest twists in the Senate’s tax overhaul efforts. (Want this in your own email inbox each morning? Here’s the sign-up.)
headline: Peltz May Have Won After All: DealBook Briefing

abstract: With the streaming service determined to find the next “Game of Thrones,” three quirky comedies about contemporary women may represent an endangered species.
lead_para: In recent months Amazon has articulated a new original-content strategy: go “Game of Thrones” or go home. It wants “big shows,” genre dramas with automatic fan appeal, and it’s signed up creators like the film director Wong Kar-wai and the “Walking Dead” impresario Robert Kirkman to provide them.
headline: Review: Amazon’s New Pilots, the End of an Era?

abstract: Technologists once told us that social bots would change our lives forever. They were right — but not in the way they expected.
lead_para: In 2016, restless tech-industry forecasters enjoyed a rare moment of consensus: Whatever else might be coming next, everyone seemed to agree that bots would be a big part of it. The analyst Benedict Evans, in a representative essay, located a promising future specifically in chat bots — conversational interfaces for artificial intelligence, designed to assist with particular tasks. Facebook, the year before, created a personal-assistant chat bot, and the company would soon open its Messenger app up to outside developers, who it hoped would create more bots to help people shop, look things up or otherwise organize their lives. Amazon’s Echo, by then already a surprise mainstream success, provided a tailwind: Here was a widely used artificial intelligence just sitting there on millions of countertops.
headline: Not the Bots We Were Looking For

abstract: The internet retailer used an annual conference to show how machine learning will spur growth at Amazon Web Services, its most profitable business.
lead_para: SEATTLE — The holidays are a time when there are constant reminders of how much Amazon dominates online shopping — the boxes stacking up on front porches, for example.
headline: Amazon Trumpets Its Cloud Lead With N.F.L. and Other Deals

abstract: Ms. Shawkat talks about her three series — “Search Party,” “Transparent” and “Arrested Development” — as well as why sexual harassment in Hollywood feels like her personal war.
lead_para: Little Dory Sief, the amateur sleuth of TBS’s “Search Party,” is all grown up now, and so are the mysteries surrounding her.
headline: Alia Shawkat on Growing Up and Gaining Control

abstract: The New York store will be the eighth location the company, which has been cautiously expanding its brick-and-mortar presence, has opened or announced.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon is bringing one of its experiments in brick-and-mortar retailing to New York.
headline: Amazon to Open Retail Store in Manhattan at Time Warner Center

abstract: A slew of major American companies prominently featured everyday Muslim men, women and children in their marketing last year.
lead_para: The gentle piano music starts as the doorbell chimes. A white-haired Christian pastor greets his friend, a Muslim imam, and the two converse and laugh over a cup of tea, wincing about their creaky knees as they prepare to part ways. Later, it spurs the same idea in each for a gift: kneepads sent via Amazon Prime. (It is a commercial, after all.)
headline: In Year of Anti-Muslim Vitriol, Brands Promote Inclusion

abstract: The announcement by the online giant reflects what an economist sees as an inevitable process in which new industries rise and replace old ones.
lead_para: Amazon’s new warehouse in Baltimore is a rare economic bright spot there, employing 3,000 people full-time in a city ravaged by poverty and a lack of opportunities for less educated workers.
headline: Amazon to Add 100,000 Jobs as Bricks-and-Mortar Retail Crumbles

abstract: Giant tech companies are usually challenged by start-ups. But with no obvious upstart competitors, it may be governments that pose the biggest threat.
lead_para: In the technology industry, the sharks have never long been safe from the minnows. Over much of the last 40 years, the biggest players in tech — from IBM to Hewlett-Packard to Cisco to Yahoo — were eventually outmaneuvered by start-ups that came out of nowhere.
headline: Tech Giants Seem Invincible. That Worries Lawmakers.

abstract: Many of Silicon Valley’s largest companies face a growing list of regulatory challenges — and potentially large fines — in Europe this coming year.
lead_para: For American tech behemoths like Google and Facebook, Europe can be both a blessing and a curse.
headline: What U.S. Tech Giants Face in Europe in 2017

abstract: The wildly popular home assistant offers a vision of an automated future — one that Amazon itself is poised to dominate.
lead_para: When “Star Trek: The Next Generation” first aired in the 1980s, it envisioned a number of technological advances for humankind’s future. Set in the 24th century, the show featured 3-D printers, visors that could provide artificial sight and a virtual reality simulator called the holodeck. But perhaps its most prescient creation was the supercomputer onboard the ship. The software — usually referred to only as “Computer” — could locate people, open doors and retrieve answers to complicated questions. Crew members spoke their requests, and an always-present helper responded within seconds.
headline: How Alexa Fits Into Amazon’s Prime Directive

abstract: A boost in sales for books like George Orwell’s “Animal Farm” and “1984” seems to reflect an organic response from readers wary of President Trump’s rhetoric.
lead_para: Last weekend, as hundreds of thousands of women gathered in Washington to protest the inauguration of President Trump, the novelist Margaret Atwood began getting a string of notifications on Twitter and Facebook. People were sending her images of protesters with signs that referenced her dystopian novel “The Handmaid’s Tale.”
headline: Uneasy About the Future, Readers Turn to Dystopian Classics

abstract: Ford Motor is announcing it will incorporate Amazon’s Alexa into its vehicles, one of many efforts by automakers to improve voice-recognition systems.
lead_para: EVERY once in a while, just for laughs, Kevin Smith-Fagan tries to call a friend of his, Priscilla, using the voice-recognition system in his 2013 Chevrolet Volt.
headline: Coming From Automakers: Voice Control That Understands You Better

abstract: Amazon’s voice-controlled Echo device is “always getting smarter” — but making us dumber.
lead_para: It started around the holidays. My eyes began to dart involuntarily to call-outs of my name on social media.
headline: Ask Alexa? No, Hear This Alexa

abstract: Amazon and Expedia have joined a lawsuit in federal court in Seattle, asking for key parts of the executive order to be declared unconstitutional.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Technology executives have for days assailed President Trump’s executive order suspending immigration from seven mostly Muslim countries, framing their arguments largely in moral terms.
headline: Tech Companies Fight Trump Immigration Order in Court

abstract: Cutting-edge innovations are set to upend some of the constants of growing old.
lead_para: Welcoming a robot into her family was never Maxine Duncan’s idea of a support aide in her older years. But this winter, she and her partner, Herbert Yarbrough, signed up to test a telepresence robot in their retirement community, the Heritage Downtown, in Walnut Creek, Calif. Their new pal has a screen for a head and scuttles around on wheels. The lure was being able to connect more easily with their families via video calls.
headline: Seniors Welcome New, Battery-Powered Friends

abstract: The company is in the middle of a push to get Alexa, its voice-activated assistant, in cars, appliance and more. It looks like a giant play for data.
lead_para: They say talk is cheap. In tech right now, it is also very valuable.
headline: Daily Report: The Next Voice You Hear Will Be Amazon’s

abstract: While Facebook ponders its place in the news industry, tech companies try to stay on the good side of the president-elect.
lead_para: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.
headline: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: Thiel, Tech Companies and Trump

abstract: Amazon’s “Z: The Beginning of Everything,” about Zelda and F. Scott Fitzgerald, depicts the couple’s early years, though without much sizzle.
lead_para: Perhaps the kindest way to look at the Amazon series “Z: The Beginning of Everything” is as a brave example of revisionist history. Any college English major knows that Zelda and F. Scott Fitzgerald were one of the liveliest literary couples ever, right? And the flapper era was a blizzard of energy and saucy fun, wasn’t it? Well, this series, which arrives Friday on Amazon, makes both the Fitzgeralds and the 1920s seem drab as dishwater.
headline: Review: ‘Z,’ Hardly the Last Word on the Fitzgeralds

abstract: Sears, as well as other longtime retailers, are struggling because of the Amazon juggernaut.
lead_para: The Sears Holdings Corporation, which is projected to lose more than $2 billion this year, is in the retailing dead pool. As its prospects for a turnaround appear to grow dimmer, it may seem to be another morality tale for bricks-and-mortar retailers in the age of Amazon.
headline: Sears Clings to Catalog Thinking in an Online World

abstract: The business would mesh nicely with the e-commerce giant, while the acquisition would show that Silicon Valley supports efforts to keep jobs at home.
lead_para: In the retail-store slump, Jeff Bezos may be holding a Trump card. Amazon.com, the e-commerce giant he runs, is considering a bid for the bankrupt American Apparel, according to a Reuters exclusive, just as Macy’s and other department stores are losing sales and cutting staff. A deal could be a handy way to show a president-elect suspicious of Silicon Valley that thousands of working-class jobs are being saved.
headline: American Apparel Could Bolster Amazon’s Standing With Trump

abstract: App stores backed by giant corporations have created choke points for the internet, which governments are now exploiting.
lead_para: There’s a new form of digital censorship sweeping the globe, and it could be the start of something devastating.
headline: Clearing Out the App Stores: Government Censorship Made Easier

abstract: In this Amazon series, Giovanni Ribisi stars as an ex-con passing himself off as the long-lost grandson of a clan that runs a bail-bond shop. Bryan Cranston plays his nemesis.
lead_para: At some point during the year and a half since Amazon first posted the pilot of “Sneaky Pete,” an appealing new series available on Friday, a few changes crept into the episode. It’s hard to pinpoint them all, because the original pilot isn’t around for comparison. But the scene in which the famously rare bourbon Pappy Van Winkle is drunk out of paper cups is definitely new.
headline: Review: Con Man Poses as Long-Lost Grandson in ‘Sneaky Pete’

abstract: The dystopian novel, published in 1949, about tyranny and the suppression of critical thought, has found a fresh audience in the United States.
lead_para: George Orwell’s classic book “1984,” about a dystopian future where critical thought is suppressed under a totalitarian regime, has seen a surge in sales this month, rising to the top of the Amazon best-seller list in the United States and leading its publisher to have tens of thousands of new copies printed.
headline: George Orwell’s ‘1984’ Is Suddenly a Best-Seller

abstract: Macy’s and Sears have recently announced numerous closings, reflecting a climate in which online and discount retailers have outmaneuvered them.
lead_para: For decades, a corner spot at the mall was a sure path to success for big American department stores like Macy’s. Not anymore.
headline: Department Stores, Once Anchors at Malls, Become Millstones

abstract: Technology is changing everything about how Americans work, but the industry is left largely unscathed by the Republican tax bill that Congress took up this week.
lead_para: Let’s pretend you have just been picked to run a small island nation. Congratulations!
headline: What the Tax Bill Fails to Address: Technology’s Tsunami

abstract: Epic failures this year exposed your personal data to hackers, wasted your money on unnecessary or ethically dubious products and fed you misinformation.
lead_para: Let’s face it: Technology this year was one big “fail” after another. And the biggest loser from all of this was you.
headline: The Biggest Tech Failures and Successes of 2017

abstract: For the first time, big tech companies began to accept responsibility in 2017 for how their platforms affect the world. The scope of that change remains unclear.
lead_para: This was a terrible year for the tech industry.
headline: How 2017 Became a Turning Point for Tech Giants

abstract: In this week’s tech newsletter, our correspondents discuss Bitcoin, Amazon and the tech industry’s ongoing problems with sexual harassment.
lead_para: Each Friday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.
headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: The Big Bitcoin Boom

abstract: Book World is closing its 45 stores amid the holiday shopping season, signaling the final gasps for large book sellers as e-commerce rises.
lead_para: APPLETON, Wis. — This fall, at a moment when retailers traditionally look forward to reaping holiday profits, the owner of the fourth-largest bookstore chain in the country surrendered to the forces of e-commerce.
headline: Bookstore Chains, Long in Decline, Are Undergoing a Final Shakeout

abstract: Amazon Prime’s drama wraps the violent end of British colonialism in the Middle East in nostalgia for the seductions of expatriate life.
lead_para: The fall of the British Empire and the rise of Arab nationalism have rarely looked as ravishing as they do in “The Last Post,” a highly scenic evocation of the days of gin and tonics at the club and discreet bed-hopping in the officers’ quarters.
headline: Review: ‘The Last Post’ Shows an Empire Awash in Adultery and Gin and Tonics

abstract: The e-commerce giant’s actions – some big, like buying Whole Foods Markets; some smaller, like Amazon meal kits – have led to stock sell-offs for a wide range of businesses.
lead_para: The e-commerce giant’s actions – some big, like buying Whole Foods Markets; some smaller, like Amazon meal kits – have led to stock sell-offs for a wide range of businesses.
headline: How Amazon Rattles Other Companies

abstract: Once hailed as progressive and enlightened, the Amazon series “Transparent” now must reckon with sexual misconduct allegations against Jeffrey Tambor, who stars in it as a transgender woman.
lead_para: Once hailed as progressive and enlightened, the Amazon series “Transparent” now must reckon with sexual misconduct allegations against Jeffrey Tambor, who stars in it as a transgender woman.
headline: The Tarnished Image of ‘Transparent’

abstract: Over the years, the online giant has picked off different retail businesses, from books to electronics. Now apparel sellers are starting to succumb.
lead_para: SEATTLE — If future anthropologists want to study the rubble of early-21st-century retail, a good place to start will be what Amazon.com did to apparel shopping in the few years before and after 2017.
headline: Amid Brick-and-Mortar Travails, a Tipping Point for Amazon in Apparel

abstract: Let’s face it: The biggest tech companies are monopolies.
lead_para: In just 10 years, the world’s five largest companies by market capitalization have all changed, save for one: Microsoft. Exxon Mobil, General Electric, Citigroup and Shell Oil are out and Apple, Alphabet (the parent company of Google), Amazon and Facebook have taken their place.
headline: Is It Time to Break Up Google?

abstract: The third season of the show begins Friday on Amazon, and finds the couple where they left off.
lead_para: At the start of “Catastrophe,” Sharon (an Irish schoolteacher played by Sharon Horgan) and Rob (an American ad man played by Rob Delaney) meet in a London bar and proceed to have loads of sex, most of it unprotected. “A terrible thing has happened,” he tells her after learning that their six-night bacchanal has resulted in pregnancy. “Let’s make the best of it.” And with that, one of television’s funniest, filthiest, most realistic takes on the sweet mess of coupledom and parenting was born.
headline: Sharon Horgan and the Fun Filth of ‘Catastrophe’

abstract: Amazon Web Services has become the profit engine of the internet retailer. Can it stay ahead of rivals like Microsoft and Google?
lead_para: It’s been said before but it bears repeating: If it were not for its cloud-computing business, Amazon.com would have difficulty reaching profitability.
headline: Daily Report: Cloud Computing Asserts Itself

abstract: The impact on quarterly results announced Thursday was particularly acute at Amazon, far and away the leader in online computing services.
lead_para: SEATTLE — The moneymaking machines at the core of Amazon, Microsoft and Alphabet, the parent company of Google, are notably different. But the respective kings of online retailing, software and internet search should all credit a relatively new line of business for lifting their financial results.
headline: Cloud Produces Sunny Earnings at Amazon, Microsoft and Alphabet

abstract: For those who like their mysteries snowy, sunny or operatically violent, new seasons have begun.
lead_para: Remember when you could still complain that there was nothing on television but crime shows? You know, the bad old days of the 2000s. While the TV renaissance has radically changed the mix — hello, superheroes, political soaps, brittle sitcoms — the crime drama hasn’t gone away. And the rising tide has meant that it’s often more interesting than it used to be, and present in greater variety.
headline: ‘Fortitude,’ ‘Bosch,’ ‘Gomorrah’: TV Crime Never Sleeps

abstract: Amazon recently received an intriguing patent for an “on demand” apparel manufacturing system, which can quickly fill online orders for suits, dresses and other garments.
lead_para: The process starts when customers submit online orders to the retailer for shirts and other articles of clothing, accessories, bedding, curtains and towels. The patterns,  printed onto rolls of fabric or other material, are arranged to reduce scrap.
headline: Detailing Amazon’s Custom-Clothing Patent

abstract: The thriller picks up nine weeks after a wasp-filled cataclysm and introduces Dennis Quaid to a cast of characters facing environmental catastrophe.
lead_para: The supermarket shelves are nearly bare. The government in Oslo has turned its back. And the caverns holding the prehistoric treasure that transformed an Arctic outpost devoid of crime and death into a violence-filled petri dish have been buried under 300,000 tons of snow and ice. Season 2 of “Fortitude,” the British thriller previously shown on Pivot in the United States, opens with a rare heavenly spectacle called a blood aurora, a decapitation and a move to Amazon Prime starting Friday, April 14. Picking up nine weeks after the first installment’s wasp-filled cataclysm, the series finds Sheriff Dan Anderssen (Richard Dormer) vanished into the glacial wilderness after shooting the woman (Verónica Echegui) he loved. It also introduces Dennis Quaid into the cast as Michael Lennox, a genial fisherman intent on doing whatever it takes to find a cure for his terminally ill wife (Michelle Fairley) — and more unnameable dread than ever as this town on the Svalbard archipelago in Norway hurtles toward environmental catastrophe.
headline: Season 2 of ‘Fortitude’ Has More Icy Dread in Store

abstract: We followed major developments in the markets throughout the day. Check here for the latest updates.
lead_para: We’re following major developments in the markets throughout the day. Check below for the latest updates.
headline: Movers: Dan Loeb Takes Aim at Honeywell

abstract: The internet retailer agreed to pay about $50 million for the streaming rights to 10 games, according to a person briefed on the deal.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon customers will soon be able to watch live football games as part of the retailer’s growing online video service.
headline: Amazon Will Stream N.F.L.’s Thursday Night Games

abstract: The French election, Amazon’s fashion plan — and Kawakubo at the Met.
lead_para: Each week, the Open Thread newsletter will offer a look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. The latest newsletter appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.
headline: Open Thread: This Week in Style News

abstract: The 20-game agreement makes the basketball league the first women’s professional sports group to sign a rights deal with the social media service.
lead_para: A few months ago, W.N.B.A. President Lisa Borders reached out to Seattle Storm guard Jewell Loyd, who had injured her ankle while playing in China. Borders wanted to see how Loyd was recovering. During their conversation, Borders also asked Loyd for any ideas on how to broaden the game and help expand the league’s reach.
headline: Twitter Signs a Deal to Stream Regular-Season W.N.B.A. Games

abstract: Amazon’s new Echo Show includes a touch screen and the ability to ask Alexa, its voice-activated assistant, to make video or voice calls over a Wi-Fi connection.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — With an Amazon Echo speaker today, you can talk to Alexa, the virtual assistant that powers the device, and ask it to play songs, order diapers and even turn on your air-conditioner.
headline: With New Echo Speakers, Amazon Lets You Ask Alexa to Phone Mom

abstract: Let us now praise a famous Master of the Internet, who has changed the way we live — and isn’t done yet.
lead_para: Twenty years ago this week, Amazon.com went public.
headline: 20 Years On, Amazon and Jeff Bezos Prove Naysayers Wrong

abstract: This cult feminist novel has been adapted, and updated, by the creator of “Transparent” for Amazon.
lead_para: Twenty years ago, “I Love Dick” — Chris Kraus’s novel chronicling her one-sided obsession with a cultural critic named Dick and how she staked out her own identity as a writer through a wild series of letters to him — was published to little notice. Since then, it has grown into a feminist cult classic. The book anticipated an era of popular female autofiction — from Emily Gould’s “And the Heart Says Whatever” to Sheila Heti’s “How Should a Person Be?” — and with a cheeky title that feels made to be Instagrammed, it has taken on new resonance as a text for women in the social media age. This month, it will continue its pop cultural rise with a television adaptation by another feminist auteur.
headline: Chris Kraus and Jill Soloway Talk About the Show ‘I Love Dick’

abstract: The e-commerce giant Amazon plans to connect its voice-command Echo technology to Ikea’s new line of smart lighting products.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Today, most people know Amazon’s Echo speaker as an easy way to play music using voice commands, but the device and others like it are catching on as ways to control light switches, thermostats and other smart home appliances.
headline: Need Mood Lighting to Go With Your Music? Ask Alexa. No App Required.

abstract: Kathryn Hahn stars in a curious, daring and messy new series on Amazon that explores feminism, identity and power, as expressed through culture and art.
lead_para: Watching “I Love Dick” is like attending an exhibition for which the artist has supplied her own curator’s notes. It’s an experience as much as a story: arresting, disorienting and provocative. It’s also very conscious of explaining to you how and why it arrests, disorients and provokes.
headline: Review: ‘I Love Dick’ Sketches an Artistic Love Triangle

abstract: The company is introducing voice and video calling with the Echo, the device that is powered by Alexa, its voice-activated smart assistant.
lead_para: Alexa, please phone home.
headline: Daily Report: Using Amazon’s Echo to Phone Home

abstract: Faith Soloway, a writer for the Amazon series who is the sister of its creator, will present the show “Should ‘Transparent’ Become a Musical?” at Joe’s Pub.
lead_para: The third season of “Transparent” ends with Shelly Pfefferman, played by Judith Light, performing her one-woman show “To Shell and Back” on a cruise ship. The musical moment, one of many in the award-winning Amazon series, happens so naturally that it’s easy to wonder: What if this were a musical?
headline: ‘Transparent,’ the Musical: Coming Soon?

abstract: One writer explores foreign murder mysteries as a way of seeing the world — and learning the gritty truth about other cultures.
lead_para: Detective chief inspector Jane Tennison was the gateway drug. As played by the actress Helen Mirren on the British series “Prime Suspect,” she triggered my now-entrenched addiction to international crime dramas. Tennison — a relentlessly driven, hard-living, sexually indiscriminate female detective (as written by Lynda La Plante) — was exceptional and revolutionary; when the show debuted here in 1992, she had no equivalents on American TV. And Mirren was abetted by an equally riveting costar: the city of London as I’d never seen it — grubby and bristling with colorful miscreants.
headline: In Praise of International Crime Dramas

abstract: We are beginning to understand that tech companies don’t have our best interests at heart. Did they ever?
lead_para: We are beginning to understand that tech companies don’t have our best interests at heart. Did they ever?
headline: Silicon Valley Is Not Your Friend

abstract: As big tech companies continue to assert their influence, a handful of businesses are dominating both in sales and on Wall Street.
lead_para: SEATTLE — On Monday, Amazon.com’s share price briefly crossed the $1,000 mark for the first time in its 20-year history as a publicly traded company.
headline: A Price Amazon Is Content to Keep High: $1,000 a Share

abstract: After crushing the independent bookstore industry, Amazon opens its own. Leave your cash at home.
lead_para: A non-virtual, real-life Amazon bookstore opened in Manhattan on Thursday with no obvious signs of corporate guilt at having driven countless independent bookstores to oblivion with the scythe-like power of the company’s e-book discounting.
headline: At Amazon’s Bookstore, No Coffee but All the Data You Can Drink

abstract: Amazon, Apple, Microsoft, Facebook and Google dominate our day-to-day activities. Imagining being forced to give up some of them could lead to hard choices.
lead_para: A few weeks ago, I bought a new television. When the whole process was over, I realized something incredible: To navigate all of the niggling details surrounding this one commercial transaction — figuring out what to buy, which accessories I needed, how and where to install it, and whom to hire to do so — I had dealt with only a single ubiquitous corporation: Amazon.
headline: Tech’s Frightful Five: They’ve Got Us

abstract: At physical bookstores like the new one opening in Manhattan this week, the company is drawing on its vast troves of customer data to shape the design.
lead_para: Jeff Bezos, the chief executive of Amazon, has often struck a defiant tone when asked about the company’s dominance of the book industry.
headline: Amazon Sets Up Shop in the Heart of the Publishing Industry

abstract: The new F.C.C. chairman’s plan to slacken net neutrality rules is a boon to tech giants and a bane to competitors and innovators.
lead_para: Every year, the internet gets a little less fair. The corporations that run it get a little bigger, their power grows more concentrated, and a bit of their idealism gives way to ruthless pragmatism.
headline: Giving the Behemoths a Leg Up on the Little Guy

abstract: Tech firms are in a race to dominate consumers’ digital lives, and their services increasingly overlap each other. The convergence helps customers.
lead_para: There is a growing drumbeat that the five leading tech behemoths have turned into dangerous monopolies that stifle innovation and harm consumers. Apple, Alphabet, Microsoft, Amazon and Facebook — what the tech columnist Farhad Manjoo calls the Frightful Five — have a combined market capitalization of more than $2.7 trillion and are an increasing part of everyday life.
headline: The ‘Frightful Five’ Aren’t So Scary, as Long as They’re Competing

abstract: The Big Five tech companies increasingly dominate our lives. Could you ditch them?
lead_para: The Big Five tech companies increasingly dominate our lives. Could you ditch them?
headline: Which Tech Giant Would You Drop?

abstract: This week’s Australia Letter includes events you should attend, stories you should tell, and the difference between “chips” and “fries.”
lead_para: Damien Cave, our Australia bureau chief, shares insights on global news, local recommendations and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. To receive it in your inbox, sign up here.
headline: Holiday Treats for Australian Readers

abstract: Police say package theft is up during the holiday shopping crush, but homeowners and retailers are striking back with cameras and other technology.
lead_para: SEATTLE — It is a season for giving and, according to law enforcement officials in Washington County, Ore., taking as well.
headline: ‘Porch Pirates’ Steal Holiday Packages as They Pile Up at Homes

abstract: Apple, Google, Microsoft and other giants are accelerating their efforts to remake health care with new tracking apps, sensors and other tools.
lead_para: When Daniel Poston, a second-year medical student in Manhattan, opened the App Store on his iPhone a couple of weeks ago, he was astonished to see an app for a new heart study prominently featured.
headline: How Big Tech Is Going After Your Health Care

abstract: Numerous electronics brands have sprung up offering inexpensive gadgets. Here’s how Amazon enables them, and how other brands may copy that success.
lead_para: A few weeks ago, Wyze Labs, a one-year-old start-up in Seattle, sent me its first gadget to try. It’s a small, internet-connected video camera, the kind you might use for security or to keep tabs on your dog or your baby.
headline: The Hidden Player Spurring a Wave of Cheap Consumer Devices: Amazon

abstract: The retail giant started off with a modest product offering, seeking to steal a piece of Australia’s retail sector.
lead_para: MELBOURNE, Australia — Amazon quietly began operations in Australia on Tuesday, the start of what could be a shake-up of that country’s retail market, which is worth hundreds of billions of dollars.
headline: Amazon’s Australian Debut Brings Excitement, Dread and Defiance

abstract: In Amazon’s “Jean-Claude Van Johnson,” we learn that films like “Bloodsport” and “Timecop” were covers for a career as a secret agent. That’s a relief.
lead_para: Aging male movie stars have been taking roles that play off their macho personas for a long time now — Clark Gable in “The Misfits,” John Wayne in “True Grit,” Sylvester Stallone in just about everything.
headline: Review: In ‘Jean-Claude Van Johnson,’ Van Damme Gives Us the True Hollywood Story

abstract: The staff of the acclaimed Amazon series believed it had created a special workplace. Then harassment accusations pierced the idealism.
lead_para: For the acclaimed Amazon series “Transparent,” things were supposed to be different.
headline: For ‘Transparent,’ Accusations Against Jeffrey Tambor Burst an Idealistic Bubble

abstract: Hot toys like the Barbie Hello Dreamhouse quickly sold out online this year, then appeared on eBay and Amazon at inflated prices.
lead_para: Fingerlings, those colorful chirping monkeys (and sloths and unicorns) that wrap around your finger, have become one of the most desired toys on holiday shopping lists.
headline: How the Bot Stole Christmas: Toys Like Fingerlings Are Snapped Up and Resold

abstract: While some technology companies used their websites to proclaim support for equal internet access, some of the giants, including Google and Microsoft, were lying low.
lead_para: Protests to preserve net neutrality, or rules that ensure equal access to the internet, migrated online on Tuesday, with numerous online companies posting calls on their sites for action to stop a vote later this week.
headline: Net Neutrality Protests Move Online, Yet Big Tech Is Quiet

abstract: The deal would combine CVS’s pharmacy and clinic business with a giant insurance company. The combination could lead to lower prices — or fewer choices — for consumers.
lead_para: CVS Health said on Sunday that it had agreed to buy Aetna for about $69 billion in a deal that would combine the drugstore giant with one of the biggest health insurers in the United States and has the potential to reshape the nation’s health care industry.
headline: CVS to Buy Aetna for $69 Billion in a Deal That May Reshape the Health Industry

abstract: Amazon’s new Echo Show smart speaker, which comes with a touch screen, represents the model for a new kind of communal, household computer.
lead_para: In the late 1970s, Jef Raskin, a pioneering technologist who was one of Apple’s earliest employees, sketched out a radical vision for the future of computing.
headline: Amazon’s Vision of Computing’s Future: An Information Appliance

abstract: The suit accuses the company of improperly classifying a former shift manager in California as an employee exempt from overtime pay.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon’s warehouses have a reputation as often grueling environments for the workers who pick, pack and load orders there. Managers are pushed hard, too, according to the plaintiff in a new lawsuit against the internet retailer.
headline: Former Amazon Warehouse Manager Sues for Overtime Wages

abstract: Corporate giants once had all-powerful chiefs with domains to match. But activist investors and technological change are remaking the executive suite.
lead_para: FAIRFIELD, Conn. — They bestrode the business world, or at least the suburban corporate campus, like a colossus.
headline: The Decline of the Baronial C.E.O.

abstract: Encouraged by streaming services like Netflix, networks are spending heavily to get their shows noticed by prospective Emmy voters.
lead_para: On a recent Sunday in the heart of Beverly Hills, Calif., the hordes were ready.
headline: For Your Consideration: An Increasingly Lavish Emmy Campaign Season

abstract: With the announcement of HomePod, a new home assistant, the company seems to be finally embracing the technologies it has long put on the back burner.
lead_para: SAN JOSE, Calif. — One of Apple’s greatest strengths is timing. The company that’s hailed for innovation does not often invent things first — it didn’t create the first personal computer, the first digital music player or the first smartphone. Instead, Apple reinvents, slipping in and producing something more original than what we used to use.
headline: Apple Needs to Reinvent Itself. It Just Might Be Doing So.

abstract: The company’s $13.4 billion deal for Whole Foods is the latest signal of Amazon’s ambitions to have a hold on nearly every facet our lives — like the computer servers that power our favorite websites and the food we eat.
lead_para: The company’s $13.4 billion deal for Whole Foods is the latest signal of Amazon’s ambitions to have a hold on nearly every facet our lives — like the computer servers that power our favorite websites and the food we eat.
headline: Amazon Is Trying to Do (and Sell) Everything

abstract: It’s planning to end net neutrality while opposing the Time Warner and AT&T merger. This doesn’t make sense.
lead_para: Peter Thiel, Facebook’s first outside investor, once wrote: “Competition is for losers. If you want to create and capture lasting value, look to build a monopoly.” Executives at Facebook, Google and Amazon seem to have taken his blunt advice.
headline: The Trump Administration’s Incoherent Stance on Competition

abstract: Isa Hackett, of “The Man in the High Castle,” goes public with her story of lewd propositions she says Roy Price made toward her in 2015.
lead_para: Roy Price, the executive in charge of Amazon’s growing investment in movies and television shows, was suspended by the company on Thursday after a Hollywood producer publicly accused him of making unwanted sexual advances toward her.
headline: Amazon Studios Chief Suspended After Sexual Harassment Claim

abstract: With universities, an international airport and lots of space, the New Jersey city says it is the perfect location for the online retailer’s second headquarters.
lead_para: The city sits astride an extensive transportation network of trains, planes and automobiles. It has six colleges and universities with a total of 60,000 students. There is prime office space available, and new apartments downtown are far less expensive than housing in New York City or even Jersey City.
headline: Newark Says, Hey Amazon, Look Over Here

abstract: The offering would come two years after the German company postponed plans for a public listing in 2015.
lead_para: LONDON — HelloFresh, the German meal delivery company, said on Tuesday that it planned to raise up to $352 million in an initial public offering in Frankfurt.
headline: HelloFresh, the Meal Delivery Service, Pursues I.P.O. in Frankfurt

abstract: Damien Cave, Australia bureau chief, found that the average internet connection speed in the country ranked below Kenya’s, but that a local website could teach Craigslist some lessons.
lead_para: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Damien Cave, the Australia bureau chief for The Times, who is based in Sydney, discussed the tech he’s using.
headline: How Australia’s Technology Stands Out

abstract: To land Amazon’s second headquarters, the city is playing up its tech talent pool and infrastructure, but the cost of doing business is steep.
lead_para: The Empire State Building, 4 Times Square, 1 World Trade Center and other New York City skyscrapers were bathed in orange light on Wednesday night. Halloween had not come early. The color was a nod to the arrow in the logo of the giant retailer Amazon, designed to mark the moment New York City delivered its bid for the company’s second headquarters.
headline: In Amazon Bid, New York Brags About, Well, Everything

abstract: Seeking an edge against Amazon, the retail giant is pushing a service that delivers your order to your car. Customers never have to step inside the store.
lead_para: A personal shopper is something you might expect at Bergdorf Goodman or a boutique on Madison Avenue.
headline: Walmart Puts Its Eggs in a Time-Saving Basket: Grocery Pickup

abstract: The bidders came from 43 U.S. states, as well as Canada and Mexico. Amazon says the project will create 50,000 jobs, and that the winner will be announced next year.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon said on Monday it got a total of 238 proposals from cities and regions across North America that want to be the home of its proposed second headquarters.
headline: Amazon Counts Its Suitors: 238 Want to Be Home for 2nd Headquarters

abstract: Amazon’s handling of accusations of sexual harassment involving Roy Price, who ran its movie and television operations, has set off confusion, debate and finger-pointing.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon on Friday tried to quell concerns among employees about sexual harassment accusations against an executive, sending an email to its staff saying the company would review its policies to ensure that “they are doing their job to provide a harassment-free workplace.”
headline: Inside Amazon, Diversity Concerns Flare Up After Harassment Accusations

abstract: The proposed deal, which could be worth more than $60 billion, would accelerate the health care industry’s transformation.
lead_para: CVS Health, the giant drugstore chain that also runs walk-in clinics and a pharmacy benefit business, is in talks to buy Aetna, one of the nation’s largest health insurance companies, according to people briefed on the talks.
headline: CVS Is Said to Be in Talks to Buy Aetna in Landmark Acquisition

abstract: Machines will make a raft of decisions for my kids and others like them as they proceed through life. I’m worried.
lead_para: “You are going to have a chance to play with Alexa,” I told my daughter, Grace, who’s 3 years old. Pointing at the black cylindrical device, I explained that the speaker, also known as the Amazon Echo, was a bit like Siri but smarter. “You can ask it anything you want,” I said nonchalantly.
headline: Co-Parenting With Alexa

abstract: Information technology managers have started to worry about the difficulty of switching cloud suppliers in the event of a breakdown or hacking attack.
lead_para: Fear of no choice is starting to help Amazon’s cloud rivals.
headline: Fear of a Monopoly Will Help Amazon’s Cloud Rivals

abstract: The New York Community Trust writes that the Amazon founder’s generosity is an example for all who want to make life better.
lead_para: To the Editor:
headline: Jeff Bezos’s Philanthropy

abstract: Acquiring the clothing brand born on the internet is intended to energize Walmart’s e-commerce strategy as it races to catch up with Amazon.
lead_para: Walmart has agreed to acquire the men’s clothing company Bonobos for $310 million.
headline: Walmart to Buy Bonobos, Men’s Wear Company, for $310 Million

abstract: If your phone’s operating system supports the use of third-party keyboards, you can find apps that let you do more than just type.
lead_para: Q. What’s the point of using a keyboard that’s different from the one that came with the smartphone?
headline: Surfing With a New Keyboard

abstract: The grocery-store industry now faces, in addition to overseas competitors, a deep-pocketed rival with a track record of moving customers online.
lead_para: Shares of Walmart, Target, Kroger and Costco, the largest grocery retailers, all tumbled on Friday. And no wonder.
headline: Amazon Deal for Whole Foods Starts a Supermarket War

abstract: Amazon Wardrobe, part of the Prime service and part of the company’s effort to expand in apparel, will let customers order three to 15 items of clothing without buying it.
lead_para: SEATTLE — For many people, buying clothing online is not worth the hassle of getting a pair of pants or a shirt that does not fit. Many retailers have sought to eliminate that risk by offering free returns on clothing, but now Amazon is going even further.
headline: Amazon Will Let Customers Try On Clothes Before Buying

abstract: With its purchase of Whole Foods, Amazon is buying access to a large pool of wealthy customers.
lead_para: Amazon.com just bought its way to the top of the food chain. The e-commerce giant is going whole hog for United States grocery stores with the $13.7 billion acquisition of the upscale chain Whole Foods Market.
headline: Jeff Bezos Goes Grocery Shopping

abstract: A tweet may have implied support for legislation helping states force online retailers to collect sales taxes. But that is already Amazon’s practice.
lead_para: President Trump may not have meant to, but on Wednesday he seemed to endorse a longer reach for the tax collector.
headline: Trump, Amazon and ‘Internet Taxes’: What Did He Mean?

abstract: The battle to sell men’s shirts and food, and just about everything else, is a competition that will define the future of retail.
lead_para: With Amazon buying the high-end grocery chain Whole Foods, something retail analysts have known for years is now apparent to everyone: The online retailer is on a collision course with Walmart to try to be the predominant seller of pretty much everything you buy.
headline: The Amazon-Walmart Showdown That Explains the Modern Economy

abstract: Timothy Cook, Jeff Bezos and Eric Schmidt were among 18 tech executives at a forum held by an administration they have had conflicts with.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Silicon Valley is fuming about President Trump’s stance on climate and immigration, but top technology executives still made a pilgrimage to the White House on Monday to discuss a potential upgrade of government technology.
headline: Tech Titans Make Pilgrimage to White House to Discuss Government Systems

abstract: Facebook, Google and Amazon are coming under increasing pressure by regulators concerned about their growing power.
