lead_para: WASHINGTON — Last month, Facebook and Google came out forcefully against a bill that would hold companies accountable for hosting sex trafficking on their websites. They said that while they worked hard to combat sex trafficking, changing the law “jeopardizes bedrock principles of a free and open internet” that have been crucial to innovation for decades.
headline: Internet Giants Face New Political Resistance in Washington

abstract: Nick Wingfield, a New York Times technology reporter who writes about Amazon and Microsoft, discusses the tech he’s using.
lead_para: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Nick Wingfield, a technology reporter based in Seattle, discussed the tech he is using.
headline: How to Keep on Top of Technology When You Write About It

abstract: As teachers launch personal brands and cast themselves as influencers, start-ups and tech giants alike are racing to cultivate them to spread their wares.
lead_para: MAPLETON, N.D. — One of the tech-savviest teachers in the United States teaches third grade here at Mapleton Elementary, a public school with about 100 students in the sparsely populated plains west of Fargo.
headline: Silicon Valley Courts Brand-Name Teachers, Raising Ethics Issues

abstract: As the first reports of eclipse eye damage emerge, a reporter attempts to get to the bottom of the shady shades fiasco.
lead_para: Earlier this week, a couple in Colorado filed a class-action lawsuit against an eyewear chain they say gave them faulty eclipse glasses. Watching the moon’s spectacular crossing of the sun on Aug. 21 left them with distorted vision, according to their lawyer. A couple in South Carolina filed a similar lawsuit against Amazon in late August.
headline: Shades of Noir: My Hunt for an Eclipse Glasses Villain

abstract: Hubert Joly, Best Buy’s chief executive, has reshaped nearly every aspect of the business. He explains the playbook behind the company’s success.
lead_para: While running errands the other day, I ducked into a local Best Buy to pick up a pair of new headphones. What I saw inside was shocking.
headline: Best Buy’s Secrets for Thriving in the Amazon Age

abstract: The company would help itself, and the country, by putting its new headquarters outside of the Northeast, the West Coast or Chicago.
lead_para: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.
headline: Where Amazon Should Go

abstract: Drama, comedy and the search for meaning: This weekend brings the goods.
lead_para: Watching is The New York Times’s TV and film recommendation newsletter and website.
headline: What’s New on Netflix and Amazon Prime This Weekend

abstract: Providing incentives to businesses is fine, as long as they are not at the expense of taxpayers and local and state governments.
lead_para: Amazon recently sent state and city officials across the country scrambling to respond to its announcement that it was seeking enticements to build a second headquarters, promising 50,000 new jobs and $5 billion in investment to the winning location. Governments are mobilizing to devise lucrative incentive packages. I know how this works, because I spent eight years supporting these types of incentives as the governor of Delaware.
headline: Let’s Stop Government Giveaways to Corporations

abstract: Many of the country’s largest technology companies pledged Tuesday to help finance an initiative meant to prepare American students for careers in so-called STEM fields.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Many of the country’s largest tech companies, including Amazon, Facebook, Google, Microsoft and Salesforce, on Tuesday pledged a total of $300 million for computer science education, part of a partnership with the Trump administration meant to prepare students for careers in technology.
headline: Tech Firms Add $300 Million to Trump Administration’s Computer Science Push

abstract: We invite you to make a pitch to Amazon for its second headquarters, giving your choice of location, and your reasons.
lead_para: Cities across North America are engaged in a competition to sell themselves as a place for Amazon to build a second headquarters, with the infusion of tens of thousands of jobs and billions of dollars (“To Woo Amazon, Nothing’s Too Weird,” Business Day, Sept. 26).
headline: Wooing Amazon: Your Turn

abstract: The series from Will Packer sounds like the reverse of HBO’s “Confederate.” It will depict a separate country founded by former slaves.
lead_para: Joining a recent boon in alt-history dramas, Amazon is developing a series called “Black America” that imagines what would happen if freed African-Americans after the Civil War formed their own nation from three Southern states as reparations for slavery.
headline: Amazon’s ‘Black America’ Imagines a New Nation in the South

abstract: Netflix’s “Wet Hot American Summer: Ten Years Later” and Amazon’s “Comrade Detective” bear unusual ideas for spoofing the past, but the execution is lacking.
lead_para: A classic item in the news-parody outlet The Onion once reported on a “U.S. Department of Retro” warning: Americans, it said, are consuming so much nostalgia that “we may run entirely out of past.”
headline: Nostalgia Goes Niche in ‘Wet Hot American Summer’ and ‘Comrade Detective’

abstract: Amazon’s nationwide jobs fair on Wednesday offered a vivid illustration of its ascendance and seemingly insatiable need for workers to fuel its growth.
lead_para: ROMEOVILLE, Ill. — Brandon Williams arrived at an Amazon fulfillment center here, about an hour outside of Chicago, around 7:30 a.m. on Wednesday, one of thousands across the country who turned up for the company’s first Jobs Day. While he appeared to wilt slightly during the five hours he waited before an M.C. summoned him for a tour, his enthusiasm did not wane.
headline: Amazon’s Jobs Fair Sends Clear Message: Now Hiring Thousands

abstract: Shareholders are expected to approve a $13.4 billion bid. At a conference in Wyoming, neither Janet Yellen, the Fed chairwoman, nor Mario Draghi, president of the European Central Bank, is expected to address policy.
lead_para: Here’s a look at what’s coming up this week.
headline: Whole Foods Voting on Amazon Takeover, and Pending Verdict in Samsung Case

abstract: The American company’s local partner tells customers not to offer ways to dodge China’s internet filters, as a new cybersecurity law takes effect.
lead_para: SHANGHAI — Days after Apple yanked anti-censorship tools off its app store in China, another major American technology company is moving to implement the country’s tough restrictions on online content.
headline: Joining Apple, Amazon’s China Cloud Service Bows to Censors

abstract: In an unusual partnership, Amazon and Microsoft are working together to extend the abilities of their voice-controlled digital assistants.
lead_para: SEATTLE — The crowded pack of voice-controlled digital assistants — Apple’s Siri, Google Assistant, Amazon’s Alexa and Microsoft’s Cortana — are good at numerous things. They can help people play music, set up calendar appointments and check the weather.
headline: ‘Cortana, Open Alexa,’ Amazon Says. And Microsoft Agrees.

abstract: President Trump wrongly suggested, again, that Amazon does not pay taxes. The company paid $412 million last year and collects sales taxes in all states that levy them.
lead_para: After President Trump accused Amazon on Wednesday morning of hurting local retailers and jobs by not paying taxes, the company’s shares dipped in premarket trading.
headline: Does Amazon Pay Taxes? Contrary to Trump Tweet, Yes

abstract: Setting up a so-called smart home can be mind-boggling. Here’s a guide to help you sort through the jumble and become acclimated to your first voice-controlled smart home.
lead_para: Setting up a so-called smart home can be mind-boggling. Here’s a guide to help you sort through the jumble and become acclimated to your first voice-controlled smart home.
headline: How to Make Your House a Smart Home

abstract: What you need to know about eclipses, how to be safe during an eclipse and some fun experiments you can try during this rare event.
lead_para: What you need to know about eclipses, how to be safe during an eclipse and some fun experiments you can try during this rare event.
headline: How to Watch a Solar Eclipse

abstract: A group of 16 Democratic attorneys general have filed suit in New York, claiming that Mr. Trump had improperly upended the policy known as Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals.
lead_para: President Trump’s immigration policies faced a renewed legal onslaught on Wednesday, as a coalition of Democratic attorneys general, nonprofit groups and private companies announced they would oppose his rollback of Obama-era protections for people who entered the country illegally as children.
headline: Democrats Begin Legal Assault on Trump’s Move to End ‘Dreamer’ Program

abstract: A British television news report said that the online retailer’s algorithms were automatically offering items that could be used to create an explosive device.
lead_para: LONDON — Amazon said on Wednesday that it was reviewing its website after a British television report said the online retail giant’s algorithms were automatically suggesting bomb-making ingredients that were “Frequently bought together.”
headline: Amazon ‘Reviewing’ Its Website After It Suggested Bomb-Making Items

abstract: From the continuing saga of the Equifax hack to Twitter’s Russia links to Uber’s international travails, it was another busy week in tech.
lead_para: Each Friday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.
headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Twitter’s Eventful Few Days

abstract: A week after Amazon announced plans for a second headquarters somewhere in North America, Walmart said on Friday that it is building a new home office in Bentonville.
lead_para: Take that Amazon. Walmart is doubling down on its hometown of Bentonville, Ark.
headline: While Amazon Plays the Field, Walmart Stays True to Arkansas

abstract: Readers make pitches for the city it should pick for its second headquarters. But a Seattle reader cautions, “Be careful what you wish for.”
lead_para: Amazon is often promoting the idea of improving the world. Therefore its second headquarters should do that. Knowing that it is a game changer, Amazon should go to a Rust Belt city and forever alter the economy of the region. Take a good look at Pittsburgh or Cleveland. Both have had a renaissance and offer lovely downtowns, beautiful architecture, great waterfronts, beautiful parks, treelined streets, excellent cultural amenities, great public transportation and pro sports teams. Even better, they have great colleges and medical facilities.
headline: Dear Amazon: Please Build Here

abstract: The online retail giant said it is seeking a location in North America for a new complex that would cost as much as $5 billion to build and operate.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Wanted: A place with a million people, a diverse population, good schools and malleable lawmakers. Room to accommodate up to 50,000 workers. Canadian provinces also welcome to apply.
headline: Amazon Plans Second Headquarters, Opening a Bidding War Among Cities

abstract: Officials and business leaders across North America are going to extreme lengths to court Amazon to put its second headquarters in their city.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Business leaders in Tucson have tried to mail Amazon’s chief executive, Jeff Bezos, a 21-foot cactus. The largest conference room in the Tulsa, Okla., mayor’s office has been converted to a war room, with 50 volunteers poring over videos of Mr. Bezos.
headline: For Cities Wooing Amazon’s New Headquarters, Nothing Is Too Strange

abstract: Why Amazon’s new headquarters decision should be an act of patriotism.
lead_para: A couple of interesting things are happening with the massive companies that rule our online lives. First, the lords of Silicon Valley face political headwinds. There is tech-company skepticism on the populist right, the anti-corporate left and the good-government center. There is talk of trustbusting and utility-style regulation from Steve Bannon as well as Bernie Sanders. There is a palpable feeling, as Ben Smith of Buzzfeed wrote last week, that the online giants’ “golden age” of political immunity is ending, and that it might be “normal politics, normal regulation” from here on out.
headline: Meet Me in St. Louis, Bezos

abstract: Amazon is on the forefront of automation, finding new ways of getting robots to do the work once handled by human employees.
lead_para: FLORENCE, N.J. — Nissa Scott started working at the cavernous Amazon warehouse in southern New Jersey late last year, stacking plastic bins the size of small ottomans. It was not, she says, the most stimulating activity. And lifting the bins, which often weigh 25 pounds each, was also tiring over 10-hour shifts.
headline: As Amazon Pushes Forward With Robots, Workers Find New Roles

abstract: The company introduced a wide collection of new Echo devices that are smaller, cheaper and, in some cases, built for specific areas of the home.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon released the first Echo smart speaker three years ago, not long after the company’s attempt at a smartphone proved to be a humiliating failure.
headline: Amazon Wants You to Wake Up With Alexa, and That’s Just the Start

abstract: Vast physical distances are becoming less limiting, bringing conveniences but perhaps eroding the state’s special identity.
lead_para: PALMER, Alaska — For years, pet owners in this Anchorage suburb of big homes and lawns have fretted over snares set in the local parks by fur-trappers going after fox, lynx and rabbits. But in a quiet revolution this spring, dog lovers got the upper hand, and after a series of public meetings where few trappers showed up to fight back, trapping was banned by the borough council. The suburbs had won.
headline: Alaska Warily Eyes Change Bringing Suburbs and Amazon Boxes

abstract: If the judgment of investors is any guide, Ross Stores, Home Depot and AutoZone may have the wherewithal to withstand the e-commerce titan, which just swallowed Whole Foods.
lead_para: The Amazon vortex won’t suck in everyone. That’s the verdict of investors in the retail sector.
headline: The Retailers That Can Resist the Amazon Onslaught

abstract: Amazon said that starting Monday, Whole Foods will offer lower prices on a “selection of best-selling staples across its stores, with much more to come.”
lead_para: SEATTLE — The era of Whole Paycheck, the derisive nickname for Whole Foods, may be drawing to a close. Amazon, which takes control of the upscale grocer on Monday, intends to slash prices the same day.
headline: Amazon’s Play to Rattle Whole Foods Rivals: Cheaper Kale and Avocado

abstract: In nearly tripling its debt to buy Whole Foods, the e-commerce behemoth is starting to look like a traditional retailer.
lead_para: Amazon’s aggressive salesmanship now extends to its own debt.
headline: $16 Billion Bond Sale Shows Amazon’s Power to Pursue Deals

abstract: Two New York Times reporters discuss the week’s biggest events in Silicon Valley and the broader technology world.
lead_para: Each Friday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.
headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Review: Apple’s Self-Driving Shift

abstract: Amazon promised lower prices at Whole Foods starting Monday. We went shopping to see if prices really got cheaper.
lead_para: We went shopping on Monday to see how much cheaper Whole Foods, the supermarket chain known for natural foods and high prices, had become after Amazon took over as its new owner.
headline: The Amazon Effect: How Prices Dropped at Whole Foods

abstract: The F.T.C. said that the acquisition would not harm competition. In addition, Whole Foods shareholders voted to approve the deal.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon’s bid to become a bigger player in the grocery business took a major step forward Wednesday, as federal antitrust regulators approved the internet company’s acquisition of Whole Foods Market.
headline: Amazon-Whole Foods Deal Clears Last Two Major Hurdles

abstract: The streaming service has extensive film and TV series offerings from India’s movie industry, but it’s not one-stop shopping.
lead_para: All film lovers, amateur and professional, no matter how well-versed, have gaps in their movie knowledge. For me, one category in which I lack, and which nags at me the most, is Bollywood. I excuse myself by remembering that South Asian cinema is a gigantic entity, particularly when taking into account movies produced outside of Mumbai, which looms as large to that genre as Los Angeles does to “Hollywood.”
headline: Wade Into the Deep Bollywood Pool With Amazon’s Heera

abstract: The companies are working together to keep pace in the race for online shoppers. They hope a transition to voice technology will help.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Google and Walmart are testing the notion that an enemy’s enemy is a friend.
headline: Google and Walmart Partner With Eye on Amazon

abstract: “The Defenders,” on Netflix, and “The Tick,” on Amazon, are the latest beneficiaries of a seemingly insatiable appetite for comic-book tales.
lead_para: This is the story of two piles of rubble.
headline: Never-Ending Superheroes: Here Come the Defenders and the Tick

abstract: John Mackey wanted to fight off the activist investors attacking Whole Foods. He found a savior in Amazon, a company blamed for laying waste to retailers.
lead_para: Since John Mackey co-founded a precursor to Whole Foods in 1978, he has taken a hands-on management approach to the organic grocery chain. He personally oversaw each step of its national expansion. During a takeover battle 10 years ago, Mr. Mackey used a pseudonym to write anonymous blog posts attacking a competitor.
headline: Rooted in Counterculture, Whole Foods’ Founder Finds an Unlikely Refuge

abstract: The owner of an independent bookstore says it doesn’t use an algorithm to decide what to stock.
lead_para: To the Editor:
headline: The Antithesis of Amazon’s Retail Shop

abstract: Amazon announced it was buying Whole Foods, and the internet started cracking jokes.
lead_para: Hey, did you hear the one about organic drones?
headline: An Online Retailer Walked Into a Salad Bar

abstract: A growing number of films arrive at the festival with distribution deals from companies like Netflix and Amazon. And that has created tension.
lead_para: Just as giant streaming services like Netflix and Amazon have quickly established themselves as movie production entities, resentment and panic from studios and filmmakers (and what some might term a critical peanut gallery) have grown more blatant.
headline: At the Cannes Film Festival, Tech and Tradition Collide

abstract: “These two innovators will merge the ideals of conscious capitalism and wicked efficiency,” one reader says. Others are less enthusiastic.
lead_para: To the Editor:
headline: Amazon-Whole Foods: A Good Deal?

abstract: For investors in highflying shares like Amazon’s, there is an awareness that the conflicting sentiments of greed and fear must be balanced.
lead_para: Facebook. Amazon. Apple. Netflix. Google.
headline: Five Big Tech Stocks Build Market Euphoria, and Jitters

abstract: The deal for a physical grocery retailer reflects Amazon’s ambition to become an even more frequent shopping habit to customers.
lead_para: Amazon agreed to buy the upscale grocery chain Whole Foods for $13.4 billion, in a deal that will instantly transform the company that pioneered online shopping into a merchant with physical outposts in hundreds of neighborhoods across the country.
headline: Amazon to Buy Whole Foods for $13.4 Billion

abstract: Just as investors were mourning the demise of the old-style conglomerate, Jeff Bezos’ company announced it would stretch its boundaries by buying Whole Foods.
lead_para: The conglomerate was supposed to be dead, a relic of a bygone era of corporate America. Investors, we have been repeatedly told, want smaller, nimbler, more focused companies.
headline: Conglomerates Didn’t Die. They Look Like Amazon.

abstract: President Trump has taken credit for a surging market this year. But tech stocks, the Fed and the president himself could change that picture.
lead_para: Throughout the turbulence of his first months in office, President Trump has been able to point to one bastion of support: the stock market. Earlier this month he tweeted the “great economic news” he thinks the mainstream media has been ignoring: The Dow Jones industrial average was up 16 percent and the Nasdaq up 19.5 percent since his election. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross maintained that the Trump administration had bestowed $4 trillion in gains on investors.
headline: Tech, Fed, Trump: So Many Reasons to Worry About the Market

abstract: Catch up on Oprah Winfrey and Ava DuVernay’s sexy, sudsy drama before the second season arrives on OWN. And the CMT Music Awards pay tribute to Gregg Allman.
lead_para: Catch up on “Queen Sugar,” Oprah Winfrey and Ava DuVernay’s sexy, sudsy drama, before the second season arrives on OWN. And listen to the Gregg Allman tribute at the CMT Music Awards.
headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘Queen Sugar’ and the CMT Music Awards

abstract: The decision comes as European authorities consider a raft of proposals aimed at increasing the amount of tax paid by American technology companies.
lead_para: BRUSSELS — European Union officials will order Luxembourg to collect back taxes from the online retail giant Amazon, a source with knowledge of the decision said Tuesday, the latest in a series of moves where Brussels has sought to flex its regulatory muscle over Silicon Valley.
headline: E.U. Said to Order Luxembourg to Collect Back Taxes From Amazon

abstract: The e-commerce giants are spending billions in new markets like Southeast Asia and India to tap a rising new class of young, middle-class shoppers.
lead_para: SINGAPORE — From this concrete warehouse perched on the edge of a potentially vast new market for online shopping, the Alibaba Group of China hopes to beat Amazon one head of lettuce at a time.
headline: A Showdown Brews Between Amazon and Alibaba, Far From Home

abstract: After years of relying on a no-frills lobbying operation, Amazon is spreading its message far and wide in the nation’s capital.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — On a sunny day in July, commuters arriving at Union Station, in the shadow of Capitol Hill, were greeted with free bananas passed out by Amazon employees. In a Senate building, lawmakers and their aides attended policy panels on how Amazon manages privacy on its Echo devices and how sales for small businesses are booming on its online store.
headline: Amazon Turns on the Charm Amid Criticism From Right and Left

abstract: The European Commission said it would take Ireland to court for not clawing back billions from Apple, and ordered Luxembourg to recover around $293 million from Amazon.
lead_para: BRUSSELS — European competition regulators on Wednesday mounted a push against tax avoidance by Silicon Valley giants, announcing plans to take Ireland to court for failing to collect back taxes from Apple and ordering Luxembourg to claim unpaid taxes from Amazon.
headline: E.U., Citing Amazon and Apple, Tells Nations to Collect Tax

abstract: Apple, Google and other tech giants are pushing deeper into cultural industries — and stumbling in ways that suggest a certain cluelessness.
lead_para: The tech giants are too big. Other than Donald J. Trump, that’s the defining story of 2017, the meta-narrative lurking beneath every other headline.
headline: The Frightful Five Want to Rule Entertainment. They Are Hitting Limits.

abstract: The shopping site keeps a record of the products you browse in the hope you’ll return to close the deal, but you can turn off the tracking.
lead_para: Q. When I go to the Amazon site on my computer, it shows me a bunch of stuff I previously looked at. Is there a way to make it stop recording every product I click on?
headline: Editing Your History on Amazon

abstract: How can third-party sellers offer “new” books at prices below even the Amazon discount?
lead_para: LAST March, Amazon quietly changed the way it sells books. An obscure and seemingly harmless modification to its website has opened the door for some third-party sellers to deceive Amazon’s customers by selling books as “new” that may not come straight from a publisher or its wholesaler, thus depriving authors of royalties they should have earned from the sale of a new book.
headline: From Amazon, a Change That Hurts Authors

abstract: The online retailer is moving in. Booksellers are nervous. But disrupting Australians’ reading habits might not be so easy to do.
lead_para: MELBOURNE, Australia — When Borders opened in 2002 across the street from Readings, Melbourne’s best-known independent bookseller, retail experts predicted catastrophe for the musty old shop competing with the shiny new chain store.
headline: Australia’s Amazon Book Battle

abstract: Company boycotts are one of the few concrete ways we have to protest unethical corporate behavior.
lead_para: On the list of companies I dislike, Amazon ranks near the top, for putting bookstores out of business everywhere and destroying the ability of authors and publishers to earn a living. Having fed itself to monstrous size on such small potatoes, the company has now moved on to gut the rest of Main Street retail and cut the heart out of communities everywhere.
headline: Why We Don’t Vote With Our Wallets

abstract: In Silicon Valley, small companies used to unseat big ones. Now the clutches of the five biggest tech companies are hard to escape.
lead_para: The tech giants are too big. But so what? Hasn’t that always been the case?
headline: How the Frightful Five Put Start-Ups in a Lose-Lose Situation

abstract: Called “The Romanoffs,” this drama will be an 8-episode anthology about people who believe they are descendants of the former ruling family of Russia.
lead_para: Russia, a daily fixture in the nation’s headlines these days, will also figure prominently in Matthew Weiner’s new series for Amazon.
headline: Matthew Weiner Shares Details About His Amazon Series

abstract: After acquiring Jet and ModCloth, the company is forming an internal venture to create start-ups and support new online retail businesses.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — The purchase of Jet, an upstart e-commerce venture, for $3.3 billion last summer was meant to give Walmart, the nation’s largest retailer, a way to transform its online retail strategy.
headline: Walmart Expands Its E-Commerce Ambitions With a New Investment Arm

abstract: The purchase price for Souq.com is pocket change for the online retailing giant, yet overseas buyers have found this market challenging.
lead_para: Amazon, the $400 billion online retailer, is purchasing, cheaply, a curious trinket.
headline: Amazon Takes a Gamble on Middle Eastern E-Commerce

abstract: Dozens of companies, including Amazon and Apple, signed on to a brief in support of Gavin Grimm’s fight against his school district over which bathrooms he may use.
lead_para: Dozens of companies, including Amazon, Apple, IBM and Microsoft, have signed on to a Supreme Court brief supporting a transgender boy’s fight against his school district over which school bathrooms he may use.
headline: Corporations Show Support for Transgender Boy in Supreme Court Case

abstract: A rare service breakdown has provided an opportunity for rivals like Google and Microsoft to preach the benefits of working with multiple providers.
lead_para: SEATTLE — There have been many opportunities to consider how crucial Amazon has become to the smooth operation of the internet over the past few years.
headline: Miscue Calls Attention to Amazon’s Dominance in Cloud Computing

abstract: An error at an Amazon data center in Virginia caused chaos for a number of websites. The mistake offers a lesson on dependency.
lead_para: For all of its famed redundancy, the internet at times can appear awfully fragile.
headline: Tech Roundup: Amazon Error Is a Reminder That No Company Is Infallible

abstract: “The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel,” from the creator of the “Gilmore Girls,” is among four comedies that join a space drama in the latest batch of TV pilots.
lead_para: Since 2013, Amazon has released a batch of original TV pilots several times a year. Some of them will become full-fledged series, some not. Our TV critics look at the latest crop.
headline: Amy Sherman-Palladino’s Newest Is an Amazon Pilot Standout

abstract: There’s an abundance of electronics designed to simplify home life. The Wirecutter’s smart home editor explains how to decide which devices are for you.
lead_para: Shopping for consumer electronics can be overwhelming. The staff of the The Wirecutter and The Sweethome, product review websites owned by The New York Times Company, do the hard work of narrowing down the options. We spoke with Grant Clauser, smart home editor at The Wirecutter, about how to sort through the choices for home automation.
headline: Thinking of Rigging Your Home With Smart Devices? Start Here

abstract: Mr. Jenkins, the filmmaker behind “Moonlight,” will write and direct this series based on Colson Whitehead’s award-winning novel.
lead_para: Barry Jenkins, the writer and director of “Moonlight,” named best picture at last month’s Academy Awards, is teaming again with that film’s producers for a new television series for Amazon.
headline: Barry Jenkins’s ‘The Underground Railroad’ in the Works at Amazon

abstract: The online retailing giant is trying to bring its own formula to traditional retailing. If it is successful, it could change how all stores operate.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Last Sunday in Palm Springs, Calif., Jeffrey P. Bezos, the chief executive of Amazon, climbed into the cockpit of a 13-foot robot and began flailing his arms as though warming up for a workout, causing the robot’s enormous appendages to mimic his movements.
headline: Amazon’s Ambitions Unboxed: Stores for Furniture, Appliances and More

abstract: Amazon has tried out numerous experiments in its hometown, cementing the city’s reputation as a hub for retail innovation.
lead_para: How do behemoth technology companies test out new concepts? If you are Amazon, you use your hometown as a living lab.
headline: Daily Report: Why Retail’s Future Is in Seattle

abstract: Investors have long been generous with Amazon. But lower-than-expected quarterly revenue growth dropped the company’s share price more than 4 percent.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon showed the kind of growth over the holidays that most big companies would die for, as it continued to suck away sales from crumbling bricks-and-mortar retailers. But it was not enough.
headline: Amazon’s Holiday Quarter Doesn’t Match High Expectations

abstract: A darkly humorous new series is like “Mr. Robot” redone as a whimsical farce
lead_para: How about a show that combines some of the better aspects of “Mr. Robot,” “Fargo” and “The Americans” — in a comedy? Would that pique your peak-TV interest?
headline: Review: Amazon’s ‘Patriot’ Takes the Spy Thriller to a New Place

abstract: Consumers have felt liberated from traditional packages of media, music and retail services, but what they’ve really done is trade one bundle for another.
lead_para: The internet promised to be the great unbundler. The evisceration of distribution costs would free consumers from paying for cable television channels they never watched, allowing them to bypass cable monopolies and pay only for the shows they wanted. No longer would anyone have to buy a $99-a-month triple-play package when all they wanted was the History Channel.
headline: Don’t Look Now, but the Great Unbundling Has Spun Into Reverse

abstract: The company is putting its stamp on the city with an expanding array of unconventional experiments in bricks-and-mortar sales.
lead_para: SEATTLE — On a busy stretch of road in this city’s Ballard neighborhood, a curious new grocery store is taking shape — and so begins another effort by Amazon to use the residents of its hometown as guinea pigs.
headline: Amazon’s Living Lab: Reimagining Retail on Seattle Streets

abstract: Netflix may be the most popular movie and TV streaming service, but Hulu, Vudu and more also offer pleasures.
lead_para: There’s a reason people say — jokingly or not — “Netflix and chill” and not “Amazon Video and chill” or “Hulu and chill” or “Vudu and chill.”
headline: ‘Netflix and Chill’? Sure. But There Are Others, Too.

abstract: Large technology companies, and the big profits they produce, lifted the markets earlier this year. But during October’s tumble they were only part of a broad-based downturn.
lead_para: The world’s largest technology companies drove the stock market to record highs earlier this year. As stocks have tumbled, though, it’s more like they’re just along for the ride.
headline: Tech Drove Stocks Skyward. It Was a Different Story on the Way Down.

abstract: The auction site said it was tipped off to the situation by an eBay seller who had been contacted by Amazon.
lead_para: SEATTLE — EBay claims Amazon has illegally tried to lure top sellers off its marketplace by exploiting its internal messaging system.
headline: EBay Claims Amazon Illegally Tried to Poach Top Sellers

abstract: The new anthology from the creator of “Mad Men” has moments of wonder amid sluggish storytelling.
lead_para: As the creator of “Mad Men,” Matthew Weiner had a thing about spoilers. Each season arrived with a list of no-nos for critics, such as the number of floors in the advertising office where it was set. When he announced a series for Amazon Prime, I joked that maybe he’d make it a spoiler to say what the new show was about.
headline: Review: ‘The Romanoffs’ Is Elegant but Frustrating

abstract: Many in the tech industry don’t want to be part of the military-industrial complex. But defense work is already part of Silicon Valley’s DNA.
lead_para: The sunny precincts of Silicon Valley have been wrestling for months with the question of whether technology companies should stay out of work related to the military. Google recently announced that it would no longer compete for a $10 billion Pentagon cloud computing contract. Microsoft employees have pressured its chief executive to do the same.
headline: Silicon Valley Can’t Escape the Business of War

abstract: Profit-sharing plans for rank-and-file employees are vanishing as corporate America has adopted a new approach toward who reaps a healthy company’s gains.
lead_para: Half a century ago, a typical Sears salesman could walk out of the store at retirement with a nest egg worth well over a million in today’s dollars, feathered with company stock. A warehouse worker hired now at Amazon who stays until retirement would leave with a fraction of that.
headline: When Sears Flourished, So Did Workers. At Amazon, It’s More Complicated.

abstract: It’s Halloween season, so this month we’re paying extra attention to horror-themed TV series and movies coming to the major streaming services.
lead_para: Watching is The New York Times’s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.
headline: The Best TV Shows and Movies New to Netflix, Amazon and More in October

abstract: With the prepaid cards, parents don’t need to have cash on hand. Promoters say the cards give parents digital oversight of their children’s spending.
lead_para: No need to worry about coming up with cash for a child’s allowance. Parents can now choose from a rapidly expanding menu of prepaid debit cards, aimed at giving them digital oversight of their children’s spending and saving habits.
headline: Children’s Allowances in a New Form: Debit Cards Linked to Parents’ Phones

abstract: The levy is a first step toward tackling how big tech companies move revenue and costs between jurisdictions, but it may not be aggressive enough.
lead_para: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________
headline: The Problems With Britain’s New Digital Tax

abstract: Several tech companies report earnings, including Amazon and Alphabet. The European Central Bank will discuss monetary policy.
lead_para: Here’s what to expect in the week ahead:
headline: Few Big Names Expected at Saudi Conference, and Data on U.S. Economy

abstract: Last week the company was praised for increasing what it paid its warehouse workers. Now the company is explaining what that means for bonuses and stock grants.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Last week, Dave Clark, Amazon’s senior vice president in charge of operations, stood on a ladder in a warehouse near Los Angeles and announced to employees that Amazon was raising pay for its vast blue-collar work force.
headline: Why Some Amazon Workers Are Fuming About Their Raise

abstract: Amazon missed an opportunity to generate good will and bridge the divide between red and blue America by picking a city in the heartland.
lead_para: So, the Amazon bragging rights go to New York City and the Washington, D.C., area. Why do I feel a little deflated?
headline: Why Amazon Chose the Wrong Locations for Its HQ2

abstract: The infinite retailer appears to be ushering untold numbers of stealth brands into your life, even as it plans to take over the East Coast. If you like Ween Charm, you’ll love Austin Mill!
lead_para: In 1618, an aspiring alchemist in Constantinople named Avedis created his first copper alloy cymbals. In 2018, a few hundred products from his brand, Zildjian, one of the oldest companies in the world, are eligible for Amazon Prime shipping, just like Hanes underwear or Xerox copiers or Bounty paper towels or Chanel perfume or an Eames chair or Colgate toothpaste or a brand-new PopSocket for your phone.
headline: Everything on Amazon Is Amazon!

abstract: A possible headquarters in Long Island City sparked fears of subway crowding and hopes that some big ideas in transit would come to pass.
lead_para: Is Amazon ready for the New York City subway?
headline: What Amazon May Mean for Queens: Gentrification and (More) Packed Trains

abstract: Chris Marker’s 13-episode documentary series (streaming on VHX) is a heady but playful examination of the impact of ancient Greece on modern life.
lead_para: Chris Marker’s 1989 television series, “The Owl’s Legacy,” is something for the ages. This 13-episode examination of ancient Greece’s contribution to the modern world (streaming on  VHX) is at once illuminating and confounding, heady but playful.
headline: ‘The Owl’s Legacy’ Explores the Glory That Was Greece

abstract: The Long Island City site was designated as an “opportunity zone,” an incentive created by President Trump’s tax bill to help low-income areas attract investment.
lead_para: There are wine bars and a cycling studio along the riverfront in Long Island City, among gleaming high-rise apartment buildings with views of Midtown Manhattan. The soon-to-open library branch is a modern art cube of concrete, the median income is $138,000 a year, and America’s hottest online retailer is about to move in.
headline: Amazon’s New York Home Qualifies as ‘Distressed’ Under Federal Tax Law

abstract: Crystal City, a declining neighborhood in Arlington, Va., cheered Amazon’s arrival on Tuesday. It’s getting a new name — National Landing — to go along with its victory.
lead_para: ARLINGTON, Va. — Over the past few months, murals had started appearing on a fence surrounding an empty brick warehouse in the Crystal City neighborhood of Arlington. Sporting geometric shapes and adorned with hanging bicycles, the murals also displayed aspirational slogans in big black letters like “What If?” and “Why Not?”
headline: With Hoopla and Murals, Crystal City Welcomes Amazon

abstract: Investors have soured on the stocks of Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Netflix and Alphabet since the start of October, wiping out their gains in market value this year.
lead_para: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________
headline: The Tech Stock Fall Lost These 5 Companies $800 Billion in Market Value

abstract: Two days into a strike by antiquarian booksellers against the Amazon unit AbeBooks, the company capitulated.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — A worldwide strike by antiquarian booksellers against an Amazon subsidiary proved successful after two days, with the retailer apologizing and saying it would cancel the actions that prompted the protest.
headline: After Protest, Booksellers Are Victorious Against Amazon Subsidiary

abstract: Wall Street has dominated New York’s economy for too long. Amazon’s HQ2 is a huge opportunity to diversify.
lead_para: For decades, experts have called for the diversification of the New York City economy. In the wake of postwar deindustrialization, our reliance on Wall Street and the financial industry in general had by the 1990s left our city disproportionately vulnerable to swings in the financial markets. We have experienced significant downturns that today feel like distant memories but could certainly return. I know this from my own experience as director of planning for Manhattan after Sept. 11.
headline: New York City Needs Amazon as Much as Amazon Needs Us

abstract: Amazon is not in the business of saving your hometown.
lead_para: Amazon could have transformed a city. It could have created 50,000 high-paying jobs in a place with higher-than-average unemployment. It could have become the largest employer in a midsize city, or the central player in a new regional tech hub.
headline: Dominating Retail? Yes. Reviving a City? No Thanks.

abstract: The race to surpass the symbolic market cap is Apple’s to lose, but Amazon is increasingly giving it some stiff competition.
lead_para: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________
headline: The Pursuit of $1 Trillion: Amazon Closes In on Apple

abstract: David Streitfeld has covered technology for years for The Times. He thinks the Luddites are misunderstood.
lead_para: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? David Streitfeld, a technology reporter in San Francisco, discussed the tech he’s using — and not using.
headline: When a Tech Reporter Doesn’t Use Much Tech

abstract: Amid a growing call for governments to rein in the use of the technology, Microsoft became the first tech giant to join the chorus.
lead_para: Microsoft on Friday became the first tech giant to join a growing call for regulations to limit the use of facial recognition technology.
headline: Microsoft Urges Congress to Regulate Use of Facial Recognition

abstract: The autonomous vehicle company spun off from Google is offering people in the Phoenix area rides for running errands.
lead_para: Waymo, Google’s autonomous-vehicle spinoff, wants to help you run your errands.
headline: Waymo Teams Up With Walmart, Avis and Others for Short Driverless Rides

abstract: Amazon says it will offer more than a million deals, including discounts on Echo devices, kitchen appliances and more — and extend the sale by an extra six hours compared with last year.
lead_para: Amazon has added an extra six hours to Prime Day, the company’s summer version of Cyber Monday. This year, Prime Day starts on July 16 at 3 p.m. Eastern Time and ends on July 17 at midnight. Amazon says it will offer more than a million deals.
headline: How to Make the Most of Amazon Prime Day 2018

abstract: Booksellers on the online marketplace are charging thousands for books that normally sell for a few dollars. Authors are perplexed — and annoyed.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Many booksellers on Amazon strive to sell their wares as cheaply as possible. That, after all, is usually how you make a sale in a competitive marketplace.
headline: Amazon’s Curious Case of the $2,630.52 Used Paperback

abstract: “Calibre,” Netflix’s Scottish thriller, is a movie you can pause, but you’re not going to want to. Damon Packard‘s films on Amazon are unsettling.
lead_para: Earlier this month, the Netflix original movie “Calibre” received a ringing endorsement from no less than the redoubtable author Stephen King, an expert in the fright department. “This one’s a genuine nail-biter,” he tweeted, “It’s got a Hitchcock vibe with a little bit of ‘The Wicker Man’ tossed in for good measure.” I’d heard good things about it, too, from friends outside journalism and entertainment; the movie seems to have built an organic word-of-mouth buzz (although it does have its own social media account).
headline: On Netflix, a Genuine Nail-Biter, and on Amazon, a Genuine Eccentric

abstract: A boom in artificial intelligence research has drawn the tech industry’s biggest companies and their checkbooks to the storied English city.
lead_para: CAMBRIDGE, England — When you step off the train here and walk into the city square outside the railway station, you will not see the spires of King’s College Chapel or the turrets atop the Trinity Great Court. The University of Cambridge is still a cab ride away. But you will see a stone and glass office building with a rooftop patio. This is where Amazon designs its flying drones.
headline: Silicon Valley’s Giants Take Their Talent Hunt to Cambridge

abstract: The three-part mini-series starring Hugh Grant is coming to Amazon. Here’s a primer on the lurid tale behind it and the sensational press of its time.
lead_para: When the three-part mini-series “A Very English Scandal” hits Amazon Prime on June 29, it will be received by a much different audience than the one that rapturously watched it on BBC One last month. That audience was presumably much better-versed on the scandal that inspired the series (and the John Preston true-crime novel it was adapted from), which involved a closeted gay member of Parliament named Jeremy Thorpe, a male model, blackmail and a murder plot.
headline: ‘Sex, Cash and Death’: The Story Behind ‘A Very English Scandal’

abstract: The purchase of PillPack, an online pharmacy, is the latest sign of Amazon’s increasing interest in health care.
lead_para: In the world of health care, PillPack, an online pharmacy, is a pretty small player. Its work force of 1,000 or so people pales in comparison with the 235,000 who work for Walgreens.
headline: Amazon to Buy Online Pharmacy PillPack, Jumping Into the Drug Business

abstract: The streaming service looks to add to its slate of original programming with the Oscar-winning writer and director of “Get Out.”
lead_para: Jordan Peele, the writer and director of the hit film “Get Out,” has signed a deal giving Amazon the first look at his ideas for television series, the company said on Tuesday.
headline: Jordan Peele Signs TV Deal With Amazon

abstract: For a minimum investment of $10,000, people in the United States will be able to open and manage their own start-ups to deliver Amazon packages.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon has more than 100 warehouses. It has a fleet of trucks, and even its own airplanes. Now, in another effort to help get its millions of packages to shoppers faster, it wants to build an army of delivery people, too.
headline: Amazon Has a Business Proposition for You: Deliver Its Packages

abstract: Digital comics. New apps. More interactivity. Here’s what technology has done to the comic books industry.
lead_para: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? George Gene Gustines, a senior editor in graphics and video who also writes about comic books, discussed the tech he’s using.
headline: How Technology Transforms the World of Comic Books

abstract: The internet’s first megaplatform was more than just an auction site — it was the blueprint for everything that followed.
lead_para: There was a time when eBay was practically synonymous with buying and selling things online. Now it’s surprisingly easy to forget that it exists, until you need to buy something you can’t find anywhere else or clear some space in the attic. Or until someone like Elon Musk, made fabulously wealthy when PayPal was acquired by eBay in 2002, muscles his way back into your consciousness by, for example, launching rockets into space or burrowing tunnels under major American cities. Where did he come from, exactly? As with a surprising number of tech heavyweights, the answer is complicated, but it runs through eBay.
headline: Want to Understand What Ails the Modern Internet? Look at eBay

abstract: Some Amazon shareholders say the technology raises privacy concerns. The company joins other big tech firms coming under increasing scrutiny for their government work.
lead_para: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________
headline: Amazon Urged Not to Sell Facial Recognition Technology to Police

abstract: The company’s $550 million investment is another sign of how American tech giants still want to do business in China, despite the many hurdles.
lead_para: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.________
headline: Google’s JD.com Deal Shows Silicon Valley Still Wants In on China

abstract: Technology firms have built systems that governments find attractive, but staff at those companies are less enthusiastic about sharing their know-how.
lead_para: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________
headline: Amazon Is Latest Tech Giant to Face Staff Backlash Over Government Work

abstract: Jennifer Salke, the new head of the tech giant’s TV and movie division, is letting Hollywood know that the door is open for creative talent to find a home at Amazon.
lead_para: CULVER CITY, Calif. — Jennifer Salke has been the head of Amazon’s television and movie division for four months. Her sunny corner office at Culver Studios, a historic movie lot that now serves as Amazon’s entertainment headquarters, has not yet been fully put together. She is still getting to know some staff members in the film department.
headline: Amazon Studios’ New Boss Is Reshaping Its Strategy. Step One: Lure New Talent.

abstract: Majority-black cities, like my hometown near Pittsburgh, want to be part of the tech revival. Companies should do more to include them.
lead_para: In the mid-1980s, when I was on my high school’s cross-country team, I used to run along Penn Avenue from my hometown, Wilkinsburg, into the East Liberty neighborhood of Pittsburgh. I never knew exactly during those days where I entered or exited either city.
headline: Who Gets Left Out of the Urban Tech Boom?

abstract: The errors emerged as part of a test by the A.C.L.U. that compared the photos of all federal lawmakers against a database of 25,000 publicly available mug shots.
lead_para: Representative John Lewis of Georgia and Representative Bobby L. Rush of Illinois are both Democrats, members of the Congressional Black Caucus and civil rights leaders.
headline: Amazon’s Facial Recognition Wrongly Identifies 28 Lawmakers, A.C.L.U. Says

abstract: Amazon has transformed the way Americans buy products as different as books and diapers, but with drugs, it will need to work with powerful entrenched players.
lead_para: When Amazon announced last week that it was buying the online pharmacy PillPack, it sent stocks of drugstore companies like Walgreens and Rite Aid tumbling, as investors worried that the retail behemoth would soon upend the pharmacy market.
headline: Why Amazon’s Push Into Prescription Drugs Isn’t a Guaranteed Success

abstract: Tech companies have changed the world by building answers to obvious questions — but now the obvious, pressing questions are about them.
lead_para: In start-up lore, no figure is more venerated than the tech-world founder. No mere entrepreneur, the founder is unique, sitting above the categories other people might use to order the society around them. In fact, the personage is cast as a sort of revolutionary, proposing big solutions to questions nobody else is even thinking to ask — less often because the questions are too complicated or obscure than because they’re too obvious, too expansive.
headline: Have the Tech Giants Grown Too Powerful? That’s an Easy One

abstract: The online retailer’s profits exceeded expectations but its revenues did not, leading to a muted response from Wall Street.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Hold that champagne.
headline: Amazon Delivers a Pile of Cash, but No Fireworks

abstract: Among the items for sale on the site were Nazi-themed action figures and onesies for babies stamped with alt-right images, the report said.
lead_para: Two nonprofits are criticizing Amazon for allowing its platforms to spread white supremacy and racism, identifying in a report how shoppers can buy onesies for babies stamped with alt-right images, Nazi-themed action figures and anti-Semitic books and music.
headline: Amazon Is Used to Promote White Supremacist Merchandise and Views, Report Says

abstract: With big ambitions in India, the retail giant has recruited hundreds of small businesses to get packages to the most remote customers — including those 11,562 feet up in the Himalayas.
lead_para: LEH, India — Perched high in the Himalayas, near India’s border with China, the tiny town of Leh sometimes seems as if it has been left behind by modern technology. Internet and cellphone service is spotty, the two roads to the outside world are snowed in every winter, and Buddhist monasteries compete with military outposts for prime mountaintop locations.
headline: Delivering Amazon Packages to the Top of the World

abstract: A second-quarter G.D.P. estimate is issued, and there will be a hearing on tariffs on Chinese goods.
lead_para: The tumult has continued for the American tech giants, but this week they get to focus on their main strength: making money. Google's parent company, Alphabet, announces its earnings on Monday after the closing bell. Then Facebook reports on Wednesday, Amazon on Thursday and Twitter on Friday. Alphabet's earnings call comes less than a week after European regulators fined the company $5.1 billion for abusing its dominance in the smartphone industry, while Facebook's chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, may have to handle questions about his company's confusing policies on hate speech and misinformation.
headline: Tech and Auto Earning Reports, and an E.U. Official Visits Trump

abstract: Amazon Prime’s “Zoe” stars Ewan McGregor and Léa Seydoux; a daring indie series is out on Filmatique; and Martin Scorsese and Paul Schrader talk “Taxi.”
lead_para: The best way to approach “Zoe,” a science-fiction romance that debuts on Amazon Prime on July 20, would be to skip past the first 25 minutes. At this point, you can enjoy a good swath of the chemistry between the lead actors, Ewan McGregor and Léa Seydoux, as their characters discover each other and enrich their time together. They really do make a nice couple. It’s the buildup to this section, and the subsequent fallout from it, where you find trouble areas.
headline: A Robot Romance on Amazon, American Indies and a ‘Taxi Driver’ Commentary

abstract: The cloud computing market is booming, but companies are leery of relying on one tech giant. That is helping Microsoft.
lead_para: Just a few years ago, Thomas M. Siebel often faced skepticism when encouraging big companies to adopt internet-style cloud computing. Many companies, he said, had qualms about relying on the faraway data centers.
headline: Microsoft Emerges as Clear No. 2 in Cloud Computing

abstract: This three-part mini-series, debuting Friday on Amazon, stars Hugh Grant as a closeted British politician who conspires to murder his former lover.
lead_para: It’s 1965, and two well-heeled British men share a fussy lunch where they surprisingly each confess a history of gay sexual encounters. “My wife insists that ‘gay’ means happy,” one groans. “I think she’s absolutely right,” the other says. “And I intend to be very happy — very many times in my life.”
headline: Review: ‘A Very English Scandal’ Is Very Good. And Scandalous.

abstract: The push by the online retail giant highlights the seismic shifts happening in the world of entertainment, as digital outlets compete for eyeballs with traditional broadcasters.
lead_para: LONDON — A generation ago, Sky, then an upstart satellite broadcaster, outbid rivals for the rights to televise the Premier League. The deal revolutionized the fortunes of the TV service, and helped turn the British soccer league into one of the world’s most watched — and lucrative — in sports.
headline: Amazon Wins Exclusive U.K. Rights to Broadcast Some Premier League Matches

abstract: A new report is drawing scrutiny to Foxconn’s employment practices again.
lead_para: Foxconn’s employment practices are drawing scrutiny again.
headline: Foxconn Is Under Scrutiny for Worker Conditions. It’s Not the First Time.

abstract: A Seattle tax, which Amazon helped kill, would have penalized, rather than rewarded, companies for bringing in jobs.
lead_para: To the Editor:
headline: Punishing Job Creation

abstract: A meeting in May was meant for a discussion of foreign meddling in this year’s midterm elections. But some tech officials left frustrated.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Eight of the tech industry’s most influential companies, in anticipation of a repeat of the Russian meddling that occurred during the 2016 presidential campaign, met with United States intelligence officials last month to discuss preparations for this year’s midterm elections.
headline: Top Tech Companies Met With Intelligence Officials to Discuss Midterms

abstract: Google and Facebook are struggling to catch up with Twitch, a service that Amazon bought four years ago for $1.1 billion.
lead_para: Late on a recent night, more than 600,000 people watched one of the most popular video game players, Tyler Blevins, engage in Fortnite Battle Royale with a celebrity guest: Drake.
headline: With Twitch, Amazon Tightens Grip on Live Streams of Video Games

abstract: The company now has roughly 100 private label brands for sale, but few of those are sold under the Amazon brand.
lead_para: It started with a simple battery.
headline: How Amazon Steers Shoppers to Its Own Products

abstract: In “A Very English Scandal,” Mr. Grant’s first major TV role since the 1990s, he plays a British politician who conspired to murder his former lover.
lead_para: LONDON — A handsome, charismatic politician whose star is rising. A younger man, fragile and unstable. A same-sex affair that could destroy careers and bring down a political party. A bungling assassin. A dead dog. Conspiracies and cover-ups. A trial that riveted Britain.
headline: For Hugh Grant, a Smaller Screen Brings a More Complex Role

abstract: It’s not just sports franchises: Tax incentives to lure companies tend to help politicians, but they don’t really make economic sense.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Near the bottom of the lengthy ballot San Francisco voters considered this week, in this state famous for its abundant and oddball ballot initiatives, Proposition I asked voters to establish a policy of not coveting other cities’ sports teams.
headline: Why Cities Can’t Stop Poaching From One Another

abstract: With civil liberties groups raising privacy concerns, the city decided to end a pilot program using Amazon Rekognition technology in the Police Department.
lead_para: Amid a growing outcry about privacy concerns by civil liberties groups, officials in Orlando, Fla., said Monday that the city’s Police Department was, for now, ending a pilot program to use Amazon Rekognition facial technology.
headline: Orlando Pulls the Plug on Its Amazon Facial Recognition Program

abstract: Amazon announced its plans for a second headquarters a year ago on Friday. People in the 20 finalist cities are looking for any sign of a winner.
lead_para: Over Labor Day weekend, a club promoter who goes by the name Purple posted a photo on Instagram from the LIV nightclub in Miami. In front of a wall graffitied with names and a single “Life Is Beautiful” sticker, Purple’s arm was casually draped over the shoulders of Jeff Bezos, the Amazon chief executive, whose pants matched the host’s name.
headline: The Mystery of Amazon HQ2 Has Finalists Seeing Clues Everywhere

abstract: He has promised money for schools. There are several grass-roots efforts to spread the Montessori method that could really use some.
lead_para: Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon and the owner of The Washington Post, surprised the education world when he announced this month that he was donating $2 billion to support homeless families and create a network of free Montessori-inspired preschools.
headline: Jeff Bezos and the Trap of the Charitable-Industrial Complex

abstract: Amazon announced more than a dozen devices and tools for its Alexa voice assistant, including a microwave.
lead_para: SEATTLE — If you’re one of the millions of people without a smart speaker in your home, Amazon wants to talk to you.
headline: Hey, Alexa, Why is Amazon Making a Microwave?

abstract: A quick take on some of the important finance and business stories of the day.
lead_para: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________
headline: Tilray’s Wild Day: DealBook’s Closing Bell

abstract: Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts positioned herself as an alternative to the standard-bearers of the Democratic Party during a TimesTalks conversation.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts positioned herself as an alternative to the standard-bearers of the Democratic Party, refusing to classify herself within the party during an hourlong interview on Thursday.
headline: Elizabeth Warren on Big Banks and the Democratic Party: 5 Takeaways

abstract: The money, put into a project he called the Day 1 Fund, is by far the largest donation by Mr. Bezos, the world’s richest person.
lead_para: The Amazon founder and chief executive, Jeff Bezos, and his wife, MacKenzie, pledged $2 billion on Thursday for a new fund to start preschools and help homeless families.
headline: Jeff and MacKenzie Bezos Pledge $2 Billion for Homeless and Preschoolers

abstract: Mr. Bezos and his wife, MacKenzie, made what was by far their largest political contribution to the With Honor Fund, which backs congressional candidates with military backgrounds.
lead_para: Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon and the richest man in the world, has recently faced the ire of elected officials across the political spectrum, President Trump on the right and Senator Bernie Sanders on the left.
headline: Jeff Bezos’ First Major Political Donation Is $10 Million to Elect Veterans

abstract: The European Union’s antitrust chief announced an inquiry into the e-commerce giant over its use of data collected about third-party merchants.
lead_para: For many independent merchants who sell their goods on Amazon, there has long been deep concern that if the e-commerce giant saw a particular product selling well, the company would duplicate it, but at a lower price.
headline: Amazon Dominates as a Merchant and Platform. Europe Sees Reason to Worry.

abstract: Steven Spielberg’s Amblin Entertainment ruled the box office this weekend as “Clock” beat expectations. But Amazon Studios suffered its fourth straight flop.
lead_para: The weekend box office boiled down to a competition between two very different kings: Steven Spielberg, who has reigned over the film business for more than 40 years, and Jeff Bezos, the Amazon titan who would love to add Hollywood to his list of conquered lands.
headline: ‘The House With a Clock in Its Walls’ Is No. 1 as ‘Life Itself’ Fizzles

abstract: A five-year agreement with the producer behind “Glee” and “American Horror Story,” whose Fox contract expires this summer, leaves Disney and Amazon in the lurch.
lead_para: The streaming giant Netflix has won yet another battle against old Hollywood.
headline: Ryan Murphy Heads to Netflix in Deal Said to Be Worth Up to $300 Million

abstract: LinkedIn C.E.O. Jeff Weiner, speaking at The New York Times’s 2018 New Work Summit, discussed the creation of new jobs thanks to artificial intelligence and other types of innovation.
lead_para: LinkedIn C.E.O. Jeff Weiner, speaking at The New York Times’s 2018 New Work Summit, discussed the creation of new jobs thanks to artificial intelligence and other types of innovation.
headline: Jeff Weiner on Jobs of the Future

abstract: Amazon Worldwide Consumer C.E.O. Jeff Wilke, speaking at The New York Times’s 2018 New Work Summit, said the evolution of technology tends to change jobs — not necessarily eliminate them.
lead_para: Amazon Worldwide Consumer C.E.O. Jeff Wilke, speaking at The New York Times’s 2018 New Work Summit, said the evolution of technology tends to change jobs — not necessarily eliminate them.
headline: Jeff Wilke on Worker Retraining

abstract: Amazon and other tech giants have made devices connected to the internet increasingly prevalent. Now is the time to be freaking out about the dangers.
lead_para: More than 40 years ago, Bill Gates and Paul Allen founded Microsoft with a vision for putting a personal computer on every desk.
headline: A Future Where Everything Becomes a Computer Is as Creepy as You Feared

abstract: The e-commerce titan is raising hourly pay to $15 an hour in the wake of attacks over how it treats workers. But will investors buy it?
lead_para: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________
headline: Amazon’s Wage Increase Comes Down to Cost vs. Political Capital for Investors

abstract: The company also said it would lobby the federal government for a higher minimum wage.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon said on Tuesday that it would raise the minimum wage to $15 an hour for its United States employees, a rare acknowledgment that it was feeling squeezed by political pressure and a tight labor market. The raises apply for part-time workers and those hired through temporary agencies.
headline: Amazon to Raise Minimum Wage to $15 for All U.S. Workers

abstract: Bloomberg says Chinese spy chips were placed in equipment used by Apple and Amazon. The companies involved flatly deny it. Either way, the story raises important questions.
lead_para: Good Friday. Want this by email Sign up here.
headline: DealBook Briefing: The Big Problem at the Heart of Tech’s Latest Spy Scandal

abstract: Amazon won’t say a word about where it plans to put its much-hyped second headquarters. But there is a growing consensus that it will go across the river from Washington.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon won’t say a word about where it plans to put its much-hyped second headquarters. Officials in the 20 cities and regions named as finalists say that they don’t know anything — and that even if they did, they wouldn’t share it publicly.
headline: Amazon HQ2 Watch: Northern Virginia Checks the Most Boxes

abstract: A hit podcast is reimagined with creepy sets, unsettling visuals — and Julia Roberts.
lead_para: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif. — What do you see? If you’re listening to “Homecoming,” the cult hit podcast from Gimlet Media, the answer is nothing. A psychological thriller set largely inside a mysterious corporate facility somewhere in Florida, the podcast’s story is relayed strictly through sound, even more so than other fictional podcasts of late, or the cliffhanger-loving radio dramas that preceded them. Seemingly cobbled together from found recordings of phone calls and therapy sessions, there’s not even a narrator to tell you where you are, or when.
headline: In ‘Homecoming,’ a Sound Experiment Becomes Something to See

abstract: How the country might return to a time when corporate executives rejected pure greed.
lead_para: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.
headline: Amazon’s Surrender Is Inspiring

abstract: Many locations will receive investment from Amazon if they aren’t home to its second headquarters — and they will escape expensive incentives, too.
lead_para: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________
headline: There Is a Silver Lining for Losers of Amazon’s HQ2 Competition

abstract: A breakup of the web grants privacy, security and freedom to some, and not so much to others.
lead_para: In September, Eric Schmidt, the former Google chief executive and Alphabet chairman, said that in the next 10 to 15 years, the internet would most likely be split in two — one internet led by China and one internet led by the United States.
headline: There May Soon Be Three Internets. America’s Won’t Necessarily Be the Best.

abstract: In Amazon’s thriller, Julia Roberts plays a counselor for war veterans who starts to question who her research is really meant to help.
lead_para: Sam Esmail’s “Mr. Robot” is one of the most audacious, inventive TV dramas of this decade. It is also, well, a lot. It’s narratively and creatively maximalist, full of subplots, conspiracies, directorial triple back flips and twist upon baffling twist.
headline: Review: ‘Homecoming’ Is Military, Industrial and Complex

abstract: Joel Waldfogel’s new book concludes that the massive disruption the internet has wrought on the creative industries has created a pop culture renaissance.
lead_para: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________
headline: Review: ‘Digital Renaissance’ Argues Consumers of Media Never Had It So Good. Is That the Case?

abstract: With TV culture stuck in binge mode, there’s something to be said for high-stakes, low-commitment series.
lead_para: The new Amazon drama “Homecoming” has a lot going for it. Julia Roberts in her first starring TV role. Bravura directing from Sam Esmail of “Mr. Robot.” A top-notch supporting cast, taut writing and a mind-bending military-corporate thriller plot.
headline: Let’s Hear It (Quickly) for the Half-Hour Drama

abstract: JBG Smith is the largest landowner in a Virginia area some have called a ghost town. That could change fast with Amazon’s new office plans.
lead_para: Two years ago, Matt Kelly couldn’t have known that a failed merger involving his real estate firm would propel him toward a central role in Amazon’s expansion plans.
headline: Amazon’s HQ2 in Virginia Leaves a Real Estate Firm Poised to Cash In

abstract: The tech giant is said to have settled on Long Island City in Queens as one of two locations to house some 50,000 employees. The other is in Virginia.
lead_para: New York City last week announced $180 million in new spending on Long Island City to bolster transit, fix the sewer system and attract new, good-paying jobs. Now it appears that spending was, in part, deliberately timed.
headline: Amazon’s HQ2? Make That Q for Queens

abstract: As concerns about growth and privacy issues took a toll, technology and banking stocks led a slide in Europe, and futures indicated that markets in the United States could follow.
lead_para: Apple was worth more than $1 trillion at the start of November. Now, it’s valued at $880 billion.
headline: Amazon, Apple and Facebook Once Led the Market. Now They Are Driving It Down.

abstract: Friday: Tech giants talk expansion, and two columnists sign off.
lead_para: Update, 10:35 a.m.: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Joseph Lhota, has resigned.
headline: New York Today: We Like Big. Are Google and Amazon Too Big?

abstract: The designer on bongs, white jeans and his new get-it-quickly collection, Now House.
lead_para: Here is what was on view on Election Day in Jonathan Adler’s company headquarters on Hudson Street in Manhattan: a bit of Brutalism; lots of organic modernism (of the sort once seen in 1960s-era Reform synagogues); a dash of Egyptian revival (but the ’70s version); scenes from the Memphis movement; references to pre-Columbian pottery, and to early ’80s disco tropes and Pop Art; many, many objects emblazoned with marijuana leaves (including a stunning beaded and embroidered textile that read “Weed” in a medley of greens); and an elderly and very grumpy Chihuahua atop a lavender towel on a shredded lime-colored chair.
headline: Amazon to Queens? Jonathan Adler is Ready

abstract: The governor and mayor have been aggressively selling their deal to bring Amazon to New York. But local lawmakers and others critics aren’t budging.
lead_para: [What you need to know to start your day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]
headline: Cuomo and de Blasio Saw the Amazon Deal as a Winner. Now Comes the Backlash.

abstract: Very little escapes scrutiny from witty online commentators.
lead_para: Upon searching “Pacific Ocean” using Google Maps, one might expect to find a diagram of the world that illustrates Earth’s largest body of water. And yes, the result returns an interactive graphic displaying just that.
headline: How Was Your Experience? Please Rate the Entire World

abstract: Labor organizers and researchers said they had not heard of Amazon previously coming to the table after worker pressure, even for private discussions.
lead_para: Soon after Hibaq Mohamed immigrated to Minneapolis from Kenya, where she had been living as a refugee, in 2016 she got a job at a new Amazon warehouse near the city. At first, she enjoyed packing boxes for delivery to consumers.
headline: Somali Workers in Minnesota Force Amazon to Negotiate

abstract: Lawmakers and others criticized the social network after a New York Times report revealed Facebook gave its partners extensive access to user data.
lead_para: Facebook and some of the other largest technology firms in the world faced sharp criticism on Wednesday for failing to disclose the extent of the social network’s data-sharing deals, many of which went back to the company’s early years.
headline: Facebook Rebuked for Failing to Disclose Data-Sharing Deals

abstract: Two Amazon executives faced jeers and pointed questions during three hours of testimony at a hearing about the plan to build a new outpost in Queens.
lead_para: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]
headline: Amazon Went to City Hall. Things Got Loud, Quickly.

abstract: Amazon’s offices in Queens will be built over an aging sewage system. The city says the pipes can handle the wastewater, but residents are worried.
lead_para: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]
headline: What Happens When 25,000 Amazon Workers Flush Toilets?

abstract: The follow-up to an Emmy-winning first season looks fantastic and hasn’t lost a beat, but its core story repeats itself.
lead_para: The high-class problem for a series that had an impressive first season is how to keep that momentum into the second. This is one problem that Amazon’s “The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel” — the first streaming series to win the best comedy Emmy — does not have.
headline: Review: ‘The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel’ Takes Its Time, as Fast as It Can

abstract: Steve Case has been on the road with J.D. Vance, the author of “Hillbilly Elegy,” to promote entrepreneurship across the United States.
lead_para: NEW ORLEANS — Steve Case has been on a barnstorming tour of the United States in a red bus that reads “The Rise of the Rest.” You would be forgiven for thinking he was running for office.
headline: The Effort to Reimagine Company Towns

abstract: There are nations and industries in sound economic shape that are ignored by investors because they are not all about tech. Maybe that is about to change.
lead_para: After a decade of extraordinary gains, the American stock market has come unhinged in recent weeks, with the technology sector leading the rapid decline. American tech giants are down on average 25 percent from recent peaks, and it appears the big global bubble of the 2010s is bursting. The question on everyone’s mind is what comes next.
headline: When the Bubble Bursts, Consider the Anti-Bubble

abstract: We dare you to live through 2018 — again.
lead_para: We dare you to live through 2018 — again.
headline: What Happened in 2018? Shake to Remember

abstract: Amazon executives faced protesters during several hours of heated testimony before the New York City Council over a deal the company received to put an office in Queens.
lead_para: Amazon executives faced protesters during several hours of heated testimony before the New York City Council over a deal the company received to put an office in Queens.
headline: ‘Amazon Has Got to Go,’ Protesters Tell Executives

abstract: Readers discuss the company’s process of choosing a city for its second headquarters.
lead_para: To the Editor:
headline: Cities’ Bid for Amazon Isn’t a One-Way Street

abstract: A doctor faults a health plan developed by Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan Chase.
lead_para: To the Editor:
headline: The 3 Giants’ Health Plan

abstract: Experts suggest we should temper expectations about the venture, which also involves JPMorgan Chase and Berkshire Hathaway.
lead_para: The announcement on Tuesday that Amazon, JPMorgan Chase and Berkshire Hathaway would be joining forces to create a health care company moved stock markets and prompted optimistic predictions of major reform in a notoriously complex industry.
headline: Can Amazon and Friends Handle Health Care? There’s Reason for Doubt

abstract: The retail giant winnowed a list of more than 238 applicants to just 20 on Thursday, including two cities in the metropolitan New York area.
lead_para: The New York metropolitan area picked up a one-two punch Thursday in the battle among North American cities hoping to become home to Amazon’s second headquarters, when both Newark and New York City landed on the retail giant’s shortlist.
headline: Amazon Names Newark and New York City as ‘HQ2’ Finalists

abstract: Toronto is the only city outside the United States on Amazon’s list. Its mayor credited Canada’s open approach to immigration and strong support for education.
lead_para: OTTAWA — John Tory, the mayor of the only city outside the United States to make the list of 20 finalists for Amazon’s second headquarters displayed some typical Canadian modesty on Thursday. Toronto, Mr. Tory said, had only “made the playoffs.”
headline: Why Toronto Made ‘the Playoffs’ for Amazon’s Headquarters

abstract: Hundreds of cities hoped Amazon would think outside the box in picking its second headquarters. A desire for talent and a welcoming environment led it to the usual spots.
lead_para: Amazon has disrupted great swaths of the retailing landscape, but it’s choosing not to break the mold with its second headquarters. The e-commerce giant has cut the field of candidates to 20 prime locations to complement its Seattle base, including Atlanta, Dallas and New York.
