Hundreds of cities hoped Amazon would think outside the box, but a desire for talent and a welcoming environment led it to the usual hot spots.
headline: Amazon HQ2 Choices Are Disappointingly Undisruptive

abstract: Amazon’s sci-fi anthology takes license with Philip K. Dick stories, but — with one striking exception — the episodes are pale replicants.
lead_para: Beginning in the 1950s, the writer Philip K. Dick laid down themes for decades of science fiction (and non-science fiction). As technology perfects virtual experiences, what does “real” mean? Is an original necessarily more authentic than its simulacrum?
headline: Review: In ‘Electric Dreams,’ the Future Seems Outdated

abstract: Many economists see deals offering tax breaks to attract corporate sites as inefficient, expensive and ultimately ineffective.
lead_para: When New Jersey announced a $7 billion package of tax incentives to try to lure Amazon’s second headquarters to Newark, local officials saw a chance to jump-start a city that has long struggled with poverty and joblessness.
headline: Promising Billions to Amazon: Is It a Good Deal for Cities?

abstract: The filmmaker is writing a new script, but stars are distancing themselves from him and his distributor, Amazon, is discussing ending their relationship.
lead_para: Hollywood says it’s done with Harvey Weinstein, James Toback, Kevin Spacey and other figures ousted for misconduct through the #MeToo movement. But what about Woody Allen?
headline: Can Woody Allen Work in Hollywood Again?

abstract: The technology inside Amazon’s new convenience store, opening Monday in downtown Seattle, enables a shopping experience like no other — including no checkout lines.
lead_para: SEATTLE — The first clue that there’s something unusual about Amazon’s store of the future hits you right at the front door. It feels as if you are entering a subway station. A row of gates guard the entrance to the store, known as Amazon Go, allowing in only people with the store’s smartphone app.
headline: Inside Amazon Go, a Store of the Future

abstract: New York’s governor, Andrew Cuomo, and New York City’s mayor, Bill de Blasio, came together at a news conference to celebrate their victory in a competition to land a new Amazon headquarters.
lead_para: New York’s governor, Andrew Cuomo, and New York City’s mayor, Bill de Blasio, came together at a news conference to celebrate their victory in a competition to land a new Amazon headquarters.
headline: Cuomo and de Blasio Team Up to Welcome Amazon

abstract: The e-commerce giant, while mulling 20 finalists for its second headquarters, has kept up a “blistering” pace of expansion for technology jobs and fulfillment centers.
lead_para: As Amazon dances through courtship rituals with the 20 cities hoping to host its second headquarters, the company is also charging ahead on a slate of other real estate projects.
headline: Amazon, Not Waiting for HQ2, Announces Projects in Boston and Vancouver

abstract: He could double the National Cancer Institute’s budget or tutor two million students in math every year for all time.
lead_para: CHICAGO — Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, is one of the most successful businessmen of all time. He has amassed an unfathomable fortune, reportedly $131 billion. This presents a predicament. Mr. Bezos commands far more money than any one person could possibly spend, far more than any one family dynasty could possibly spend. What should he do with all this money?
headline: Better Ways for Jeff Bezos to Spend $131 Billion

abstract: Unrestrained strongmen use the state to punish — or silence — their enemies.
lead_para: President Trump has declared war on Amazon, the nation’s second most valuable company. Amazon is creating more jobs than all but a handful of entire states. And nearly every major city in the country is vying to land the second headquarters of this global retailer and the 50,000 high-paying positions it promises to bring.
headline: America Last: Trump’s Attack on the Amazon Job Machine

abstract: We decided to test how easy it soon might be for people in Europe to access their personal data compared with users in the United States.
lead_para: We decided to test how easy it soon might be for people in Europe to access their personal data compared with users in the United States.
headline: U.K. vs. U.S.: How Much of Your Personal Data Can You Get?

abstract: Amazon does not disclose its total compensation expense, but its disclosure of median pay provides some insight on the impact of paying its employees more.
lead_para: Good Monday. Here’s what we’re watching:
headline: What Might Happen to Amazon’s Profit if It Paid Its Workers More?

abstract: Amazon’s chief executive sent out his annual shareholder letter this week. Our tech columnist recounts what stood out from it.
lead_para: Each week, Kevin Roose, technology columnist at The New York Times, discusses developments in the tech industry, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.
headline: Kevin’s Week in Tech: Jeff Bezos Reminds Tech Who’s Boss

abstract: Amazon has surprised officials in cities vying for the company’s new headquarters by asking how to avoid soaring housing costs and paralyzing traffic.
lead_para: SEATTLE — When 10 representatives from Amazon visited the Denver area in late January, they did what you’d expect from a company scouting for a place to put its second headquarters. They toured more than a half-dozen potential sites for a new campus and talked about the technical talent available in the area.
headline: One Goal of Amazon’s HQ2: Learn the Lessons of Seattle

abstract: Winning the contest could mean a steeper increase in local housing costs over the next decade, a study finds. Nashville is already contemplating the impact.
lead_para: When Amazon announced in January that Nashville had made the list of 20 finalists being considered for its second North American headquarters, city leaders cheered. They saw the project as the next step in Nashville’s transformation from country-music capital into a regional and even national economic force.
headline: What Amazon’s New Headquarters Could Mean for Rents

abstract: Tech firms, military contractors, carmakers, cellphone companies, financial firms, sports leagues and Wall Street giants are all in his Twitter cross hairs.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Amazon, you’re not alone.
headline: Amazon Has Lots of Company as Trump Slams ‘Stupid’ Businesses

abstract: Despite the wall-to-wall Facebook news of the past few weeks, lots of important things are happening in the tech world that don’t involve the company.
lead_para: Each week, Kevin Roose, technology columnist at The New York Times, discusses developments in the tech industry, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.
headline: Kevin’s Week in Tech: Extra! Extra! News Beyond Facebook!

abstract: President Trump says Amazon costs the U.S.P.S. billions of dollars. But the available evidence is far less certain, and some of it suggests the opposite.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Five times in the last week, President Trump has pointed his Twitter arrows at Amazon over what he insists is a bad deal for the United States Postal Service.
headline: Is Amazon Bad for the Postal Service? Or Its Savior?

abstract: The value of the digital currency jumped this afternoon after Mr. Thiel’s Founders Fund venture firm emerged as an investor.
lead_para: Good Tuesday and happy new year!
headline: Peter Thiel Is a Bitcoin Believer: DealBook Briefing

abstract: Budgets for video-streaming content are rising faster than revenue. Something will have to give in 2018.
lead_para: The golden age of television programming is heading for a grisly finale. Netflix, Amazon, Apple and Hulu are on course to increase their spending on new shows and movies at a faster clip than the growth of the overall video-streaming market. Consolidation among traditional media groups is only adding to the frenzy. Something will have to give.
headline: TV Content Wars: Too Many Characters Chasing Not Enough Action

abstract: The Supreme Court should move state sales taxes into the internet age.
lead_para: Can online retailers be compelled by law to collect a sales tax? According to the Supreme Court, no — but that could change if, in the next few weeks, it decides to take up a case challenging the current rule.
headline: States Pay the Price When You Buy Online

abstract: The Amazon series, tailor-made for TV’s new golden age, grapples with questions even more relevant in our increasingly technologically augmented times.
lead_para: When filmmakers and TV showrunners want to drop viewers into a paranoid but all-too-believable future, they return again and again to the same material: the dozens of novels and stories by the science fiction writer Philip K. Dick.
headline: With ‘Electric Dreams,’ Philip K. Dick Gets the TV Anthology Treatment

abstract: The applications from 238 places contained valuable information, like potential tax breaks, that the company can use for other projects.
lead_para: SEATTLE — The other week, 218 cities and states lost in the sweepstakes to be the home of Amazon’s second headquarters, failing to make the list of 20 finalists.
headline: How Amazon Benefits From Losing Cities’ HQ2 Bids

abstract: The three companies will create a new venture with the goal of simplifying coverage for their employees, in a move that unsettled the health care world.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Three corporate behemoths — Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan Chase — announced on Tuesday that they would form an independent health care company for their employees in the United States.
headline: Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan Team Up to Try to Disrupt Health Care

abstract: Many people use digital assistants for the basics, like the weather forecast or music. It’s a long way from the digital home envisioned by their makers.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — These days, you can find virtual assistants like Amazon’s Alexa or Google’s Assistant in all sorts of things, from smart speakers and smartphones to washing machines and bathroom mirrors.
headline: Alexa, We’re Still Trying to Figure Out What to Do With You

abstract: In this week’s tech newsletter, we look at Amazon’s and Apple’s plans to invest in the United States, plus the collapse in cryptocurrencies.
lead_para: Each Friday, Farhad Manjoo, technology columnist at The New York Times, reviews the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.
headline: Farhad’s Week in Tech: Big Tech Is Pouring Love on America. Thank Trump?

abstract: A stringent set of data protection rules will take effect in Europe in May. Facebook, Google and others are working overtime to be ready.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Over the past two months, Google has started letting people around the world choose what data they want to share with its various products, including Gmail and Google Docs.
headline: Tech Giants Brace for Europe’s New Data Privacy Rules

abstract: The last year gave us some whopping deals, including Amazon.com’s acquisition of Whole Foods, that will shape the business landscape in 2018.
lead_para: Please take your seats.
headline: Toasts to the Deals (and Other Winners) of 2017

abstract: Amazon is coming to New York despite the city’s transit horrors. Other companies may not be so forgiving.
lead_para: The animosity directed at Amazon and the legislators who have opened the velvet rope to the city has been fomenting for weeks, but on Wednesday it reached peak rage. It was then that Amazon executives faced members of the City Council, a body that was locked out of the process of wooing the company here, as well as protesters whose numbers were large enough that the council chamber could not accommodate all of them.
headline: Maybe It’s Not Taxes That Scare Off Business but Failing Subways

abstract: How privacy, security and employee protests will shape the year ahead for Silicon Valley.
lead_para: If you thought 2018 was a bad year for tech, 2019 might turn out to be even worse. This year was filled with revelations about privacy, security and cyberwarfare. Next year, the consequences of those revelations will unfold. And we should be very worried about what the future holds.
headline: The 3 Biggest Challenges for Tech in 2019

abstract: In 2018, there were some early glimmers that corporate America is realizing bigger isn’t always better.
lead_para: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________
headline: In 2018, Did Business Get Too Big?

abstract: Even during a year of division and fear of the future in many corners of America, the Fixes column found people trying to make things better — and succeeding.
lead_para: What difference can one ordinary person make?
headline: Making a Difference in 2018

abstract: The city and state sent loads of data to Amazon during its search for a new headquarters, offering a peek into the valuable information the company collected during the process.
lead_para: [Updated Feb. 14: Amazon said it was canceling plans to build a corporate campus in New York City, after the deal had run into fierce opposition from local lawmakers who criticized providing subsidies to one of the world’s most valuable companies.]
headline: High-Tech Degrees and the Price of an Avocado: The Data New York Gave to Amazon

abstract: Google Home and Amazon Echo don’t carry paid advertising, so companies are trying more creative ways of using them to reach consumers.
lead_para: Heading into last year’s holidays, marketers at HBO were eagerly experimenting with how to use technology like augmented reality and virtual reality to promote their shows. But then, celebrating with their families across the country, they watched as everyone from children to elderly aunts unwrapped smart speakers from Google and Amazon and started barking orders.
headline: Marketing Through Smart Speakers? Brands Don’t Need to Be Asked Twice

abstract: The retail behemoth is laying the groundwork to penetrate Brazil’s huge consumer market, analysts say. Success won’t come easy.
lead_para: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Its market value briefly surpassed $1 trillion. It has transformed online shopping. And it has had North American cities holding out billions to deliver its new outposts to their doors.
headline: Amazon Sees in Brazil Continent-Size Profits and Problems

abstract: A backlog at the printing presses, plus a surging demand for popular hardcover titles, has hurt publishers at peak sales season, with popular titles out of stock in some stores.
lead_para: This year has been, much to everyone’s surprise, a blockbuster for the publishing industry. Despite the relentless news cycle, readers have bought books in droves. Hardcover sales are up, and unit sales at independent bookstores have risen 5 percent. Multiple titles — Bob Woodward’s “Fear,” Bill Clinton and James Patterson’s “The President Is Missing” and Michelle Obama’s “Becoming” — have passed the million-copy mark, while there is also a surprisingly strong appetite for literary fiction.
headline: Bottleneck at Printers Has Derailed Some Holiday Book Sales

abstract: Drones can help with searches or crowd control, but critics fear they will be used to snoop. Also: the Strand bookstore wants the city to back off.
lead_para: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here's the sign-up.]
headline: N.Y. Today: Why Police Drones Are Coming

abstract: Products that we enjoy continue to create privacy, misinformation and workplace issues. We can do better at getting the industry to do better.
lead_para: It has never felt worse to be a technology consumer. So what can you do about it?
headline: Yes, You Can Be an Ethical Tech Consumer. Here’s How.

abstract: The arrival of voice-controlled assistants in cars raises security and privacy concerns. Depending on automakers’ setups, it could expose your information or property.
lead_para: Amazon’s Alexa voice-controlled virtual assistant is the Chatty Cathy of the tech world, a digital darling that consumers can’t get enough of. It can tell chicken jokes, order pizza and turn off the kitchen faucet. So it’s not surprising that Alexa has made the leap from the home to the car.
headline: Alexa, What Happened to My Car?

abstract: Alexandra Alter, who covers books for The Times, discussed the limits to how tech has transformed the industry.
lead_para: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Alexandra Alter, who covers the books industry for The Times, discussed the tech she’s using.
headline: How Technology Is (and Isn’t) Changing Our Reading Habits

abstract: The e-commerce giant announced a short list of places that could become home to its second headquarters. The process has garnered the kind of enthusiasm normally reserved for bids to host the Olympics.
lead_para: Amazon’s hunt for a second headquarters, after several months of publicity stunts and dangled perks from cities and regions vying to lure the e-commerce giant, has been narrowed to 20 options from 238 bids.
headline: Where Amazon May Build Its New Headquarters

abstract: The historian Niall Ferguson’s new book goes a long way toward redressing the lack of perspective to a concept central to the technological “revolution”: networks.
lead_para: It is indisputable that the internet — facilitated by both vast improvements in access and computing power — has had a disruptive impact on not just business but politics and many aspects of our daily lives. Demonstrating precisely what that impact is, however, has been remarkably challenging. Pronouncements on the topic have a tendency to be overblown. “Transformational,” “exponential” and “revolutionary” are increasingly favored adjectives, whether they are applicable or not.
headline: Review: Even on the Internet, What’s Old Is New Again

abstract: The list released Thursday leaned toward cities in the Midwest and on the East Coast, and away from the tech-saturated hubs of the West Coast.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Like a college applicant waiting for that special message in the mail, officials in Boston got what they wanted on Thursday: a cryptic four-sentence note informing them that the city made the finals in its bid to host Amazon’s second headquarters.
headline: Amazon Chooses 20 Finalists for Second Headquarters

abstract: Four big banks announce fourth-quarter results, an economic giant may be shifting gears and a film festival proceeds without one of its most active shoppers.
lead_para: Here’s what to expect in the week ahead:
headline: More Bank Earnings, China’s Growth and Sundance Without Weinstein

abstract: Mr. Bezos is the world’s richest person and can afford virtually any luxury. But obscurity is no longer among them.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Jeff Bezos rubbed elbows last weekend with Halle Berry, Chris Hemsworth and other Hollywood celebrities at an after-party for the Golden Globes. In December, he walked the red carpet, along with Meryl Streep and Tom Hanks, at a screening of “The Post” in Washington.
headline: Jeff Bezos, Mr. Amazon, Steps Out

abstract: What details make the Amazon Go store different from a traditional grocery store?
lead_para: Before reading the article:
headline: Teaching Activities for: ‘Inside Amazon Go, a Store of the Future’

abstract: Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan Chase offer no details on how they plan to remake health care. Some experts attempt to imagine what they’ll do.
lead_para: The fledgling plan from Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan Chase to create an independent health care system for their American employees is just as bare-bones as it is bold.
headline: ‘Dr. Alexa, I’ve Been Sneezing and My Throat Is Sore’

abstract: Facebook’s lead liaison with Beijing has left the company without getting the social network access to China’s huge internet market.
lead_para: HONG KONG — The executive in charge of Facebook’s efforts to court China has left the company, a fresh setback for the social network as it seeks to get its products into China’s huge internet market.
headline: Executive Behind Facebook’s China Charm Campaign Is Out

abstract: The legislation would ban New York City from entering into nondisclosure agreements during negotiations about prospective development projects.
lead_para: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]
headline: After Amazon Contest, N.Y. Lawmakers Want to Block Negotiations Done in Secret

abstract: It’s time for the Grinchy Awards, given to the year’s worst actors in the news media and anyone else who interfered with a free press.
lead_para: I’m usually cheerful during the holiday season. This year? Not so much. My bad list has grown too long, my patience way too short.
headline: The Top 18 Media Grinches of 2018

abstract: With the ‘Yellow Vest‘ movement widening the country’s budget shortfall, the French government is accelerating a plan to hit companies like Apple, Facebook and Google with a big bill.
lead_para: PARIS — With the so-called Yellow Vest movement forcing concessions that have widened the country’s budget shortfall, the French government is accelerating a plan to place hefty taxes on American technology giants that have long maneuvered to keep their bills low while reaping huge sums of money.
headline: France, Not Waiting for European Union, to Tax U.S. Tech Firms as ’19 Starts

abstract: My dad was a longtime labor activist. He despises what Jeff Bezos built, but he can’t quit it.
lead_para: Sharing an Amazon Prime account with loved ones is surprisingly intimate. You’re privy to one another’s impulse buys, fondness for corny ’90s comedies and preferred brands of vaginal suppositories. Like many families, mine shares a login for the ubiquitous delivery behemoth. Every time my dad or my sister orders an item, I see a cheerful red badge pop up on my app: “Your Amazon.com shipment is on its way!”
headline: Hate Amazon? Try Living Without It

abstract: Ms. Glen, a former Goldman Sachs executive, had been in charge of major initiatives to expand and preserve affordable housing in New York City.
lead_para: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]
headline: Deputy Mayor Who Oversaw Amazon Deal and Troubled Housing Authority Is Leaving

abstract: Amazon’s power is even more pronounced in the nail-biter sprint toward Christmas. A two-decade obsession with delivery speed has given it a huge edge.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Olivia Zimmermann started her holiday shopping early this year, buying a Bluetooth speaker from Best Buy for her sister. It was supposed to arrive by Dec. 10, two weeks before Christmas.
headline: Last-Minute Shoppers Increasingly Trust Only Amazon to Deliver

abstract: The corporate giant has hired well-connected lobbyists to convince lawmakers and residents of the benefits of its new hub in Long Island City.
lead_para: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]
headline: Amazon Hires Lobbyists for N.Y. Site and Tries to Fend Off Ocasio-Cortez’s Supporters

abstract: Nashville and others are thriving thanks to a mix of luck, astute political choices and well-timed investments, while cities like Birmingham, Ala., fall behind.
lead_para: NASHVILLE — Forty years ago, Nashville and Birmingham, Ala., were peers. Two hundred miles apart, the cities anchored metropolitan areas of just under one million people each and had a similar number of jobs paying similar wages.
headline: Nashville’s Star Rises as Midsize Cities Break Into Winners and Losers

abstract: A task force concluded that package delivery, including for the online retailer, was subsidizing other parts of the service. But its report included recommendations that made online retailers uneasy.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — President Trump spent much of last spring accusing Amazon of pulling a “scam” on the American taxpayer and ripping off the United States Postal Service. On Tuesday, his administration delivered its own verdict: Not so much.
headline: Trump Said Amazon Was Scamming the Post Office. His Administration Disagrees.

abstract: A key document from New York City’s bid for the company’s second headquarters disappeared from a city website. But we found it anyway.
lead_para: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.
headline: The Amazon HQ2 Document We Weren’t Supposed to See

abstract: The justices heard arguments about whether to overrule a 1992 decision that shielded many internet retailers from having to collect sales taxes.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — A closely divided Supreme Court struggled on Tuesday to decide whether internet retailers should have to collect sales taxes in states where they have no physical presence.
headline: Supreme Court Divided on Sales Taxes for Online Purchases

abstract: Shares in the United States were up slightly a day after the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index fell more than 10 percent from its recent peak.
lead_para: FRANKFURT — Stocks in the United States were up slightly Tuesday morning after a tough day on Wall Street had sent the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index down more than 10 percent from its recent peak.
headline: U.S. Stocks Rebound Slightly After Tech-Driven Slump

abstract: The president calls the paper, which is owned by Amazon’s chief executive, Jeff Bezos, “a lobbyist weapon,” among other things. “There isn’t anybody here who is paid by Amazon,” the editor, Martin Baron, said.
lead_para: Amazon does not own The Washington Post. President Trump, however — impervious to certain facts and armed with a Twitter account — has tried hard to convince the public otherwise.
headline: To Trump, It’s the ‘Amazon Washington Post.’ To Its Editor, That’s Baloney.

abstract: The opening of Amazon Go was alarming for many retailers, who saw a sudden willingness by Amazon to wield its power in new ways.
lead_para: SEATTLE — To see what it’s like inside stores where sensors and artificial intelligence have replaced cashiers, shoppers have to trek to Amazon Go, the internet retailer’s experimental convenience shop in downtown Seattle.
headline: Retailers Race Against Amazon to Automate Stores

abstract: Google’s ad business is twice as big as Facebook’s. But executives at Google and other big tech companies have avoided intense scrutiny. For now.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Two pages of notes sitting in a binder in front of Mark Zuckerberg during his congressional testimony this week hinted at a message the Facebook chief executive rarely got a chance to deliver: We’re not the only ones.
headline: Facebook Takes the Punches While Rest of Silicon Valley Ducks

abstract: People are increasingly calling for boycotts of the big tech companies amid a backlash. The problem is that Facebook, Apple, Amazon and Google are nearly inescapable.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Ryan Knight, a Democratic activist in Los Angeles, called for a boycott of Apple in February because it hadn’t responded to calls to delete a channel from the National Rifle Association from its streaming-video service after the Parkland, Fla., school shooting.
headline: They Tried to Boycott Facebook, Apple and Google. They Failed.

abstract: The stock market continued to plunge Monday, as investors were unnerved by the unpredictable White House. Stocks are now down 4 percent this year.
lead_para: The Trump Bump is becoming the Trump Slump.
headline: Markets That Climbed the Trump Bump Are Tumbling Down From It

abstract: Mr. Trump is deliberately undermining faith in the American press corps. Other countries are taking note.
lead_para: Many people, including many Republican lawmakers, dismiss President Trump’s attacks on The Washington Post, CNN and other news organizations as just one of those crazy — but ultimately harmless — things he does to blow off steam. They’re wrong.
headline: The True Damage of Trump’s ‘Fake News’

abstract: If you don’t have one of these — or you’ve waited until the options were good enough before investing — now is the time to buy.
lead_para: It’s easy to forget how far technology has come in just a few years. We went from praying that our CD players wouldn’t skip to streaming music wirelessly to wearing AirPods in our ears. But even some recent devices have made the jump from high-end items for tech enthusiasts to must-haves for many homes. Here are a few of them.
headline: 3 Gadgets You Didn’t Know You Needed, but Are Worth Buying

abstract: Many of Amazon’s opponents have struggled for years to be heard. Now they have the country’s most powerful bullhorn — President Trump — on their side.
lead_para: One of Amazon’s antagonists seized the moment last month with an unusual newspaper advertisement addressed to President Trump. The ad, from a nonprofit that advocates less government, attacked a Defense Department technology contract that Amazon intends to bid on, calling it a lucrative handout for the company.
headline: Amazon’s Critics Get New Life With Trump’s Attacks on the Company

abstract: It’s in trouble. And Washington’s flawed antitrust policy is a big reason.
lead_para: Barnes & Noble is in trouble. You hear that, in worried tones, when you talk to people in the book business. You feel it when you walk into one of the chain’s stores, a cluttered mix of gifts, games, DVDs (DVDs?) and books. And you really see the problems if you dig into the company’s financial statements.
headline: Save Barnes & Noble!

abstract: Economists agree on one thing: Politicians shouldn’t attack specific companies based on their own whims or preferences
lead_para: If President Trump resumes his fight with Amazon, the ultimate loser is clear: It will be the American economy.
headline: When the President Takes On Amazon, Nobody Wins

abstract: The digital assistant confused a discussion about hardwood floors with several commands, in what Amazon called an “unlikely” string of events.
lead_para: They’re always listening. They’re on the internet. But what happens when digital assistants like Alexa go rogue? Could they share our private conversations without our consent? Privacy advocates have long warned this could happen, and now it has.
headline: Is Alexa Listening? Amazon Echo Sent Out Recording of Couple’s Conversation

abstract: The narrative of “it was all cultural anxiety” isn’t persuasive.
lead_para: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.
headline: Yes, the Economy Helped Elect Trump

abstract: A case study in the problems with American antitrust policy over the past 40 years.
lead_para: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.
headline: Amazon vs. Barnes & Noble

abstract: A six-episode series on Amazon retells a tale of Victorian-era repression and vanishing Australian schoolgirls.
lead_para: As a novel (in 1967) and a film (in 1975), “Picnic at Hanging Rock” had a couple of features that could be problematic in 2018.
headline: Review: Taking Another Spooky Hike Up ‘Hanging Rock’

abstract: The show’s costume designer explains the genesis of the most influential looks from Amazon’s new series.
lead_para: Traveling in a horse-drawn buggy, a group of schoolgirls dressed in white pass through a small Australian town and pull off their gloves, their expressions giddy and relieved. They are headed to a picnic — and a tragedy — in the Australian countryside, and their headmistress, Mrs. Appleyard, had instructed them to wear their gloves until they escape the townspeople’s watchful glares.
headline: Costume Secrets From ‘Picnic at Hanging Rock’

abstract: Top executives of the company, which was once tech’s biggest villain, are outspoken advocates for protecting user privacy and establishing ethical guidelines for new technology like artificial intelligence.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Facebook and Google are under the microscope for the ways their technologies can spread misinformation, while Amazon’s growing market power is a regular target of President Trump. And Apple pioneered the modern smartphone, a device increasingly seen as too addicting.
headline: Microsoft Tries a New Role: Moral Leader

abstract: Warren Buffett said he was “delighted” with Apple’s plan to repurchase $100 billion of its shares.
lead_para: Good Saturday. Welcome to a special DealBook Briefing of Berkshire Hathaway’s annual meeting.
headline: Berkshire’s Annual Meeting: Buffett Approves of Apple’s Buyback Plan

abstract: More than two dozen civil rights organizations asked the tech giant to stop selling its image recognition system to law enforcement agencies.
lead_para: SEATTLE — In late 2016, Amazon introduced a new online service that could help identify faces and other objects in images, offering it to anyone at a low cost through its giant cloud computing division, Amazon Web Services.
headline: Amazon Pushes Facial Recognition to Police. Critics See Surveillance Risk.

abstract: Apps can replace a paper-money allowance for children, encouraging them not only to do their chores but also to save and spend their money carefully.
lead_para: Jonathan and Erin Kraftchick started out by paying their two children’s allowance the old-fashioned way, using paper money.
headline: How Parents Teach Smart Spending With Apps, Not Cash

abstract: There is no economic benefit to huge tax incentives to lure new companies, so why do cities keep offering them?
lead_para: It’s official: Amazon has anointed New York and Northern Virginia as locations for a major expansion, involving at least 25,000 employees and an investment of $5 billion.

abstract: But several universities are now promising to do better.

abstract: The states offered tax credits, rebates and other incentives to lure the online retail giant and 25,000 jobs. Neighboring states offered even more.
lead_para: Amazon built a retail empire on low prices and free shipping. But for taxpayers, its new headquarters didn’t come cheap.
headline: A $2 Billion Question: Did New York and Virginia Overpay for Amazon?

abstract: Tech companies and their employees love big cities, but Amazon needs to do better for people who live in any city chosen for its second headquarters.
lead_para: The prune capital of America. That was the future Silicon Valley’s greatest claim to fame in the 1920s, when it was a sleepy landscape of fruit orchards and farms far removed from the nation’s industrial might. Seattle was a city of fishing and timber, where a young entrepreneur named Bill Boeing had so few customers for his airplanes that he briefly pivoted to making furniture. The most innovative companies in the world clustered in the ferociously inventive cities of the East and Midwest — cars in Detroit; cash registers in Dayton, Ohio; light bulbs in Cleveland.
headline: A Warning From Seattle to Amazon’s HQ2

abstract: After a disastrous performance two years ago, social media companies rightly took disinformation and voter suppression seriously ahead of the midterms.
lead_para: Each week, technology reporters and columnists from The New York Times review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.
headline: The Week in Tech: Social Media Faces Another Election Test

abstract: The Bay Area in California remains the nation’s high-tech epicenter. But New York’s tech work force has been growing impressively.
lead_para: In 2003, Craig Nevill-Manning, a computer scientist at Google, wanted to set up an engineering outpost in New York. Google’s top leaders were skeptical, but they told him that he could go ahead if he could find 15 “Google-worthy” software developers in the city.
headline: New York Is a Genuine Tech Hub (and That Was Before Amazon)

abstract: As a company owned by the world’s richest man prepares to transform Long Island City, tenants of the Queensbridge Houses worry that they’ll be left behind.

abstract: Crystal City in Virginia and Long Island City in Queens are about to become home to an internet giant. They will probably never appear the same again.

abstract: Amazon finally provided some details about its plan to open a hub in Long Island City, including tax subsidies and other benefits.
lead_para: [What you need to know to start your day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]
headline: Amazon Is Getting at Least $1.7 Billion to Come to Queens. Now Comes the Fight Over Whether It’s Worth It.

abstract: The deal reached between Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, Mayor Bill de Blasio and Amazon was constructed to blunt the veto power of local politicians.
lead_para: The deal to bring Amazon to Long Island City, at a cost of more than $2 billion in government incentives, has sparked outrage in many corners of New York City, particularly in Queens, where residents and elected officials have vowed resistance.
headline: Some New Yorkers Hate the Amazon Deal. Can They Stop It?

abstract: Amazon promises tens of thousands of new jobs, but should we expect more than that?
lead_para: The innovation myth used to involve the back of a suburban garage or an office park in Silicon Valley. The tech industry was incubated not on the mean streets of the big city, but in sleepy hamlets like Murray Hill, N.J., and Mountain View, Calif.

abstract: It isn’t just size. Unlike many big American companies, Amazon is not squandering its profits on stock buybacks.

abstract: After meeting with the governor and mayor, Amazon decided the men could put aside their differences, and it began to iron out a package worth over a billion dollars.
lead_para: On a late October day, Amazon executives flew to New York to answer a final question before they committed to opening a massive technology center in Queens: Could Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio stop bickering long enough to see the project through?
headline: Before a Deal, Amazon Had to Know: Could Cuomo and De Blasio Get Along?

abstract: There were tax breaks. Ads on Seattle buses. Amazon latte art. And, finally, fading hope that the e-commerce giant would be coming to town.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Chicago offered $2 billion in tax breaks. North Carolina wrapped buses in Seattle with a pitch for Raleigh. A Philadelphia coffee chain printed the Amazon logo into the foam of its lattes.
headline: Losers in Amazon Sweepstakes Aren’t Ready to Throw In the Towel

abstract: New York and Washington are leaving the rest of the country behind. Companies like Amazon explain why.
lead_para: In the end, even Amazon has behaved according to this rule: In the modern tech economy, cities that already have wealth, opportunity, highly educated workers and high salaries will just keep attracting more of them.
headline: In Superstar Cities, the Rich Get Richer, and They Get Amazon

abstract: The company is said to be in talks to acquire Flipkart, India’s leading online retailer, to counter Amazon’s push into the country.

abstract: You don’t have to like Amazon to fear Trump’s attack on it.
lead_para: In 2009, Turkey’s tax ministry imposed a $2.5 billion fine for alleged tax evasion on Dogan Yayin, a media conglomerate whose newspapers and television stations were critical of the Turkish leader Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Under financial and political pressure, the company began unloading some assets and closing others. Last month, the billionaire Aydin Dogan sold his remaining media properties, including the influential Hurriyet newspaper and CNN Turk, to a group of Erdogan loyalists.
headline: The Autocrats’ Playbook

abstract: The company also said it would raise the price of its popular Prime membership service to $119 from $99.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s founder and chief executive, long ago figured out how to keep Amazon’s sales figures shooting skyward. Now he is doing the same with profit.
headline: Amazon’s Profit Swells to $1.6 Billion, Lifted by Its Cloud Business

abstract: If you are getting ready to upgrade your e-reader or tablet and want to take your existing e-book library along, consider your options.
lead_para: Q. Is it possible to read Nook books on a Kindle? Is there an e-reader that handles books from multiple e-bookstores?
headline: Moving Your E-Book Collection to One Device

abstract: In an unusually public spat, Amazon is rethinking some building projects in Seattle because of a new tax being considered by the City Council.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon abruptly escalated a fight with its hometown on Wednesday, halting major expansion plans in Seattle because of a tax being considered by the City Council.
headline: Amazon Pauses Huge Development Plans in Seattle Over Tax Plan

abstract: His administration has come down on opposite sides of arguments about whether to enact internet sales taxes.
lead_para: For months, the Trump administration has rightfully been trying to thwart attempts by some European governments to impose a new corporate “digital tax” on American high-tech giants. This campaign to block internet-inspired extraterritorial taxation — taxation of income earned outside of a jurisdiction — is strongly supported by the American business community. But the White House, in an odd twist that turns its European Union digital tax arguments upside down, just argued before the Supreme Court that the same kind of extraterritorial taxation is acceptable when carried out by American states on retail sales on the internet.
headline: Is Trump’s Tax Incoherence Just a Way to Hurt Amazon?

abstract: The director delivers more than just a “filmed play” in this movie, now on Amazon Video, that was adapted from Antoinette Nwandu’s street-corner drama.
lead_para: The latest picture by the prolific and ever-stimulating filmmaker Spike Lee, “BlacKkKlansman,” is in competition at the Cannes Film Festival. His other 2018 movie, “Pass Over,” is on Amazon Video and free to Prime members. It’s a superb film, one that, as the saying goes, finds the director working at the height of his powers. (It’s also a rare instance of an Amazon production debuting on the video site with no theatrical release.)
headline: Spike Lee’s ‘Pass Over,’ an Offbeat Melding of Cinema and Theater

abstract: Researchers can now send secret audio instructions undetectable to the human ear to Apple’s Siri, Amazon’s Alexa and Google’s Assistant.
lead_para: BERKELEY, Calif. — Many people have grown accustomed to talking to their smart devices, asking them to read a text, play a song or set an alarm. But someone else might be secretly talking to them, too.
headline: Alexa and Siri Can Hear This Hidden Command. You Can’t.

abstract: Some expect the economy to grow more quickly than it has in recent years, but slower lending does not point to such a bullish outcome.
lead_para: Good Thursday. Here’s what we’re watching:
headline: One Risk to the Economy — A Slowdown in Lending: DealBook Briefing

abstract: In response to new sales tax rules, the company will redirect users in Australia from amazon.com to amazon.com.au. Some fear they will see less choice and higher prices.
lead_para: SYDNEY, Australia — Amazon’s decision to deny Australians access to its main website has set off a backlash in the country, with customers complaining they may face big price increases and a loss of access to sorely needed products.

abstract: The grocer will give large discounts for some products, and 10 percent off hundreds of sale items in stores.

abstract: After Amazon’s bold threat to curtail development in its hometown, the Seattle City Council approved a smaller tax than originally envisioned. Amazon says it’s still “apprehensive” about the future.

abstract: The AT&T case could lead to an expanded view of the content and distribution market, perhaps changing what constitutes antitrust violation.
lead_para: When it comes to antitrust enforcement, one of the guiding principles is the effect on consumer prices. So the antitrust question of the moment is this: Will combining AT&T with Time Warner or Sprint with T-Mobile so diminish competition that prices go up?

abstract: The larger than life bloodhound, the subject of dozens of children’s books, is coming back to television.

headline: ‘Clifford the Big Red Dog’ Returning to TV in 2019

abstract: The retailer is now making its own server chips. It’s the latest sign that big internet outfits are willing to cut out longtime suppliers.
lead_para: Amazon, the world’s largest online retailer and largest cloud-computing company, is pushing into a new line of work: computer chips.

abstract: Workers at tech companies like Amazon are starting to use the stock grants that they were paid to turn the tables on their employers.

abstract: Amazon and Google are aggressively opening offices outside of their Silicon Valley and Seattle hometowns. On Thursday, Apple said it would invest $1 billion in Austin, Tex.

abstract: Amazon’s planned headquarters has jacked up interest and prices in Long Island City.

abstract: The 67-story condominium won’t be completed until 2021, but already has nearly 700 buyer inquiries.

abstract: The Midwest capital city would seem to be a long shot for Amazon’s new headquarters, but its low costs and business-friendly climate might help its chances.

abstract: Stocks have risen for so long and with such steadiness that Wall Street is becoming nervous. What’s an investor to do? For insight, check out our quarterly report on investing.

abstract: With 218 places missing the cut for Amazon’s second headquarters, cities like Ottawa and Tucson were left to absorb the same result as “the longest of long shots.”
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — There were 218 communities whose proposals did not reach the second round in Amazon’s well-publicized search for its second headquarters. For those ambitious but unlucky folks, there were no “thanks for entering” gift baskets or any consolation prizes.

abstract: The studio canceled “One Mississippi,” “I Love Dick” and “Jean-Claude Van Johnson” and will turn its focus to a “Lord of the Rings” adaptation.
lead_para: Amazon Studios has canceled three critically acclaimed comedies: “One Mississippi,” “I Love Dick” and “Jean-Claude Van Johnson.” The decision continues a roller-coaster stretch for the studio, which recently lost its president, Roy Price, following sexual harassment allegations; scored a “Lord of the Rings” adaptation; and picked up wins at the Golden Globes.

abstract: In seeking a home for its second headquarters, Amazon winnowed a list of 238 candidates to 20 finalists, including Atlanta, Nashville and Miami.

abstract: The move, offering memberships for $5.99 a month instead of $12.99, expands an effort to attract more shoppers with low incomes, who favor Walmart.

abstract: At the exclusive three-day conference run by Amazon in the California desert, the merely brilliant rub shoulders with the geniuses.

abstract: At stake is the fate of thousands of supermarket workers, many of whom belong to labor unions and are owed pensions when they retire.

abstract: Humans will have to get used to their machine co-workers. But the robot next to you may not be ready to be your replacement. At least, not yet.

abstract: For many people, kitchens are the center of the home. Tech and appliance makers, aiming to deepen ties to customers, are increasingly targeting that room with smart devices.

abstract: The president’s commentary, made in a Twitter post, comes amid reports that Mr. Trump has expressed an interest in reining in the e-commerce business.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — President Trump escalated his attack on Amazon on Thursday, saying in an early-morning tweet that the online retail behemoth does not pay enough taxes — and strongly suggesting that he may use the power of his office to rein in the nation’s largest e-commerce business.
headline: Trump Attacks Amazon, Saying It Does Not Pay Enough Taxes

abstract: Some users reported that Alexa, Amazon’s digital assistant, has been laughing unexpectedly. The behavior is being fixed, the company says.
lead_para: For weeks, users of Amazon’s digital assistant, Alexa, have reported versions of the same unsettling event: being startled as they went about their day by Alexa letting out an eerie laugh.
headline: Amazon Knows Why Alexa Was Laughing at Its Customers

abstract: Readers view the president’s remarks as a threat to the free press and hypocritical.
lead_para: To the Editor:
headline: Trump’s Attack on Amazon Over Taxes

abstract: The tech giants singled out booming results from their devices in their quarterly financial results.
lead_para: SEATTLE — For Apple and Amazon, the holidays are the time to shine, the period when shoppers have the greatest appetite to buy their devices and, in Amazon’s case, anything else that can be stuffed into a box and delivered to homes.
headline: Amazon and Apple Gush Over Holiday Sales

abstract: Next to Apple’s iOS and Google’s Android, Amazon’s voice assistant may be turning into the third great consumer computing platform of our era.
lead_para: My wife and I were just settling into bed one night when Alexa, the other woman in my life, decided to make herself heard.
headline: Why We May Soon Be Living in Alexa’s World

abstract: The employees of Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan Chase may benefit from a new insurance scheme. But the rest of us could suffer.
lead_para: Here’s the good news about the announcement this week that Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan Chase are forming a new company to cover health care for their employees: If you’re one of the million-plus people who work at these companies, or a family member of one, you’re likely to get cheaper, better health care pretty soon.
headline: A Good Health Care Deal, but Only for Some

abstract: This year’s Oscar nominees feature a terrific array of talent whose work is nearly infinitely available to sample on streaming video.
lead_para: The range of films nominated for the 90th Academy Awards seems wider than average, and that’s gratifying. There are the nominations that move the needle a little in terms of making the American film industry less white-male dominated.
headline: Let the Pre-Oscar Bingeing Begin

abstract: It can be tempting to hook up everything you love to the internet. But take a moment to appreciate some of the objects that can remain unplugged.
lead_para: It still feels magical to light up your living room by saying “Alexa, turn on the lights.” But with all the hype surrounding so-called smart things — everyday devices that are connected to the internet — it’s easy to forget that sometimes the dumb stuff is just better.
headline: In an Era of ‘Smart’ Things, Sometimes Dumb Stuff Is Better

abstract: Also this week: Would drone deliveries help or hurt the environment? And will Canada push the United States on climate change?
lead_para: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.
headline: Can We Really Scrub Carbon Dioxide From the Atmosphere?

abstract: Amazon doesn’t have a plan to fix health care, but it loves that we’re talking about it. Facebook has a plan to fix the social network, but people may spend less time on it.
lead_para: Each Friday, Farhad Manjoo, The Times’s technology columnist, reviews the week’s news, offering analysis (and maybe a joke or two) about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.
headline: Farhad’s Week in Tech: Less Time on Facebook, More Noise From Amazon

abstract: Jennifer Salke, who championed shows like “This Is Us,” will succeed Roy Price, who was forced out in October after a sexual harassment allegation.
lead_para: The NBC Entertainment executive Jennifer Salke was named the new head of Amazon Studios on Friday, ending a nearly four-month search that began when Roy Price was ousted after a sexual harassment allegation.
headline: NBC Executive Takes Over Amazon Studios

abstract: The 73-year-old star of Jill Soloway’s Emmy-winning series will not return to the role that brought him late-career plaudits.
lead_para: Jeffrey Tambor is officially no longer part of the “Transparent” cast.
headline: Amazon Moves On Without ‘Transparent’ Actor Jeffrey Tambor

abstract: Everyone likes to complain about our company-based system, but there have been real examples of innovation.
lead_para: In the United States, most working-age people get their health insurance through work. It’s a weird, kludgy system, largely an artifact of history. Economists, politicians and workers alike complain that the setup is inefficient and maddening.
headline: Employer Health Insurance: Often-Hated, Sometimes Pioneering, and Now on Amazon’s Radar

abstract: If 2018 feels volatile to stock investors, it may be a reflection of how placid 2017 was.
lead_para: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________
headline: ‘Sleepwalking’ Markets Woke Up This Year. That’s a Good Thing.

abstract: Amazon defied expectations by splitting its second headquarters into two locations. For the internet company, it seems to be working out rather nicely.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — What a farce.
headline: Was Amazon’s Headquarters Contest a Bait-and-Switch? Critics Say Yes

abstract: Amazon appears to be leaning toward opening a new office in New York. Now word comes that Google, already a big employer in the city, may add on.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon may not be the only technology giant considering a big expansion in New York.
headline: Google Is Said to Be Shopping for More Real Estate in New York

abstract: How the company and local officials flesh out plans for the new corporate presence will be crucial to the economic lift it produces.
lead_para: When Amazon announced plans to build a second headquarters somewhere in North America, it set off a competition for a sort of new-economy golden ticket, a chance for one city to become, almost overnight, a magnet for the high-paying jobs and entrepreneurial spark that are hallmarks of urban success in the 21st century.
headline: Visions of a Tech Hub? Landing Amazon Is Just a Start

abstract: Readers worry about how the two locations chosen might be changed for the worse by the arrival of the retailer.
lead_para: To the Editor:
headline: Amazon’s HQ2 Plan Gets a Cool Reception

abstract: Eager candidates offered name changes, helipads and even cactuses to entice the company into setting up shop.
lead_para: After 14 months of pitches, meetings and offers of incentives and name changes, Amazon announced on Tuesday that its second headquarters would be on two sites: one in Long Island City, Queens, and another in Arlington, Va. The company is also developing a smaller operations and logistics facility in Nashville.
headline: Amazon HQ2: How New York and Virginia Won the Beauty Contest

abstract: The internet retailer took 14 months to decide on a second headquarters. Surprise! There will be two of them, and skeptics have plenty to chew on.
lead_para: Each week, technology reporters and columnists from The New York Times review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.
headline: The Week in Tech: Amazon Finally Makes an HQ2 Decision

abstract: Is it O.K. to shop on Amazon for everything and still not want one of the world’s richest companies to invade Queens?
lead_para: [What you need to know to start your day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]
headline: Amazon and the Urban Hypocrite

abstract: Subway leaders say the system is ready for Amazon’s new headquarters in Queens. But the city’s already struggling transportation network faces enormous challenges.
lead_para: [What you need to know to start your day: Get New York Today in your inbox]
headline: Amazon Is Coming. Can New York’s Transit System Handle It?

abstract: New York’s not ready for Amazon’s HQ2, but here’s how the city can get there.
lead_para: After a nationwide campaign, Amazon selected Long Island City in New York as one of two locations for expanding its headquarters. The company’s decisions about whom it hires and how quickly, and where those workers choose to live, will affect how much the expansion changes the city. Jenny Schuetz from the Brookings Institution and Elizabeth Goldstein from the Municipal Art Society offer two views on how to prepare.
headline: Will Amazon Ruin or Revitalize New York City?

abstract: Readers weigh in on the company’s minimum-pay increase.
lead_para: To the Editor:
headline: Earning More at Amazon (Maybe)

abstract: The company reported a net income of $2.9 billion in the third quarter, partly by being more efficient in its warehouses and data centers.
lead_para: Amazon’s profits were hit or miss for its first couple of decades. But now, for the first time, they are starting to look consistent — with four consecutive quarters above $1 billion in profit.
headline: Amazon Squeezes Out More Profit as Sales Growth Slows

abstract: It was a technological wonder — until the retail landscape changed and new innovation, and greedy owners, arrived.
lead_para: The orders poured in from everywhere — 105,000 a day at one point — so much so that the company became an economic force. It could make or break suppliers by promoting their products. It could dictate terms on manufacturing. Its headquarters city boomed as this tech-driven retailer built huge warehouses and factories and attracted other businesses and rivals. State and local governments complained that the company was harming small-town retailers.
headline: How Sears Was the Amazon of Its Day

abstract: The second series of the spy drama has gone down better in Germany than the first.
lead_para: BERLIN — When the spy series “Deutschland 83” had its premiere in 2015, it was portrayed as a breakthrough moment for German television. At that point, the country had yet to produce any prestige shows with an international following, unlike France and Denmark. The series, which followed a young East German soldier corralled into working as an undercover agent on the other side of the Iron Curtain, was the first German show to air on an American network, SundanceTV. In Britain it became the most-watched foreign-language drama ever.
headline: ‘Deutschland 83’ Was a Hit Abroad but a Flop at Home. What About ‘Deutschland 86’?

abstract: The self-declared Grand Duchess Maria, a descendant of Russian royalty, took it upon herself to issue a bitter critique of the fictional Amazon series.
lead_para: “The Romanoffs,” Amazon’s new drama series in which characters are descendants of Russia’s royal family, has not received the best reviews.
headline: A Romanov Is Not Too Happy With ‘The Romanoffs’

abstract: For a week now, people have been buzzing about an article that sounded as if it had come from a high-tech spy thriller. Does it point to larger problems?
lead_para: Each week, technology reporters and columnists from The New York Times review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.
headline: The Week in Tech: Fears of the Supply Chain in China

abstract: Financial engineers like Eddie Lampert are wreaking havoc on American companies.
lead_para: When Sears, once America’s largest retailer, made its bankruptcy filing Monday in a White Plains courthouse, the proximate cause was the decision by Eddie Lampert, by far its biggest individual creditor and shareholder, not to make a $134 million loan payment that was due. “This is not so much a melting ice cube, but a puddle,” a lawyer for a large creditor told the federal Bankruptcy Court.
headline: The Billionaire Who Led Sears Into Bankruptcy Court

abstract: The Emmy-winning TV creator talks about his return to television with “The Romanoffs” and addresses a harassment allegation.
lead_para: Los Angeles — Before writing an episode of his new Amazon series “The Romanoffs,” Matthew Weiner would ring a small bell. The trinket was a Christmas gift from one of the writers on the show, and the sound it made was essential for “clearing the air,” Mr. Weiner said. “It was a moment of faith in intuition and the process.”
headline: Matthew Weiner on Life After ‘Mad Men,’ Sexual Harassment and His New Amazon Show

abstract: Here’s what the Amazon founder’s vast fortune tells us about the economic concentration of the tech industry — and how he might help unravel that for the world.
lead_para: Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon and the world’s wealthiest man, has been publicly agonizing over a vexing problem: what to do with all his money.
headline: Why Jeff Bezos Should Push for Nobody to Get as Rich as Jeff Bezos

abstract: Some people say that the company is overvalued. But Jeff Bezos, its C.E.O., thinks that the sky is the limit.
lead_para: Good Wednesday. Want this in your inbox every morning? Sign up here.
headline: DealBook Briefing: Amazon Could March Past $1 Trillion

abstract: The decision by the Salesforce chief executive Marc Benioff to buy Time magazine raises the question of the duty that executives have to the companies that made them rich.
lead_para: If Time magazine runs another cover in a series of illustrations showing President Trump’s Oval Office taking on water, employees and shareholders of Salesforce might want to brace for a tweetstorm from the White House — or even calls for regulation of the software company.
headline: When an Owner’s New Company Puts the Old One in Trump’s Cross Hairs

abstract: The actor left the stage soon after playing Lear in 1986. Now 80, he is giving it another go, in a made-for-television film directed by Richard Eyre.
lead_para: SAMPHIRE HOE, England — High above the sea, on the white cliffs of Dover, soldiers hoisted equipment and secured tents in what looked like a military encampment. A man appeared at the edge of a tent, his white hair close-cropped, his grizzled face shadowed by a ragged beard. “Shall we get on with it?” Anthony Hopkins said.
headline: Anthony Hopkins Returns to ‘King Lear,’ Finally Up to the Challenge

abstract: Sales are booming at major chains that have taken cues from their giant online rival — signs of a revival in a $3.5 trillion industry.
lead_para: Malls are being hollowed out. Shops are closing by the thousands. Retailers are going bankrupt.
headline: Hard Lessons (Thanks, Amazon) Breathe New Life Into Retail Stores

abstract: The 70th Primetime Emmy Awards were dominated by “diversity,” “Mrs. Maisel” and a surprise proposal.
lead_para: Did you hear the one about the Emmys’ being super diverse this year?
headline: The Best and Worst Moments of the 2018 Emmys

abstract: Smart home devices will tell you the weather and answer trivia questions, sure, but they can do so much more. Try these tips to streamline your day, relax a little or just have some fun.
lead_para: If you’re an Amazon Echo or Google Home owner, you may only ask your device for the weather or to play music. That’s O.K., but these devices can do so much more — and they can offer more than a few useful tricks to make you feel as if you’re living in the future.
headline: The Most Fun (and Useful) Things You Can Do With an Amazon Echo or Google Home

abstract: Technology chief executives were once admired for their force-of-nature personalities and daring. Now boring is the new black (or is it beige?). Except for Elon Musk, of course.
lead_para: When Joe Barton, a Republican congressman from Texas, greeted Jack Dorsey at a congressional hearing last week, he sounded flummoxed.
headline: The Metamorphosis of Silicon Valley C.E.O.s: From Big to Boring

abstract: Tuesday Weld in “Pretty Poison” and Peggy Cummins in “Gun Crazy” are fresh-faced, trigger-happy young women in two films that attained cult status.
lead_para: “Pretty Poison,” starring Anthony Perkins and Tuesday Weld, was hardly the greatest Hollywood movie of 1968. As a film about delusional young folk run murderously wild, and the subject of critics’ debates, it was however one of that turbulent year’s quintessential stories.
headline: In ‘Pretty Poison’ and ‘Gun Crazy,’ Femmes Fatales With Deadly Firepower

abstract: Everyone is worried about the power of big technology companies. Apple alone has managed to turn the fears into an argument for its own business model.
lead_para: The business world has long been plagued by Apple catastrophists — investors, analysts, rival executives and journalists who look at the world’s most valuable company and proclaim it to be imminently doomed.
headline: How Apple Thrived in a Season of Tech Scandals

abstract: The “Saturday Night Live” veterans trade Beyoncé and Prince impersonations for a normcore couple in Southern California in their new series “Forever.”
lead_para: MALIBU, Calif. — During their lengthy runs on “Saturday Night Live,” Maya Rudolph and Fred Armisen created some of the sketch comedy show’s most outrageous characters.
headline: Maya Rudolph and Fred Armisen Play It (Relatively) Straight

abstract: Mining personal data has become a trillion-dollar business — which is why activists are pushing laws to curb the practice, and why Facebook and other companies are desperate to stop them.
lead_para: The way Alastair Mactaggart usually tells the story of his awakening — the way he told it even before he became the most improbable, and perhaps the most important, privacy activist in America — begins with wine and pizza in the hills above Oakland, Calif. It was a few years ago, on a night Mactaggart and his wife had invited some friends over for dinner. One was a software engineer at Google, whose search and video sites are visited by over a billion people a month. As evening settled in, Mactaggart asked his friend, half-seriously, if he should be worried about everything Google knew about him. “I expected one of those answers you get from airline pilots about plane crashes,” Mactaggart recalled recently. “You know — ‘Oh, there’s nothing to worry about.’ ” Instead, his friend told him there was plenty to worry about. If people really knew what we had on them, the Google engineer said, they would flip out.
headline: The Unlikely Activists Who Took On Silicon Valley — and Won

abstract: Since the Whole Foods sale a year ago, traditional grocers have agreed to a variety of deals and partnerships. The latest investment is a Japanese chain’s $110 million stake in Boxed.
lead_para: Chieh Huang spent years trying to get grocery industry executives excited about the technology at Boxed, his grocery e-commerce company. He regularly gave tours of the company’s state-of-the-art fulfillment centers, featuring a custom software system and roving bands of autonomous carts.
headline: Amazon’s Ripple Effect on Grocery Industry: Rivals Stock Up on Start-Ups

abstract: With Facebook, Google and Amazon dominating India’s internet, lawmakers have declared their intention to impose tough new rules on the tech industry.
lead_para: NEW DELHI — In India, American companies dominate the internet. Facebook’s WhatsApp is the most popular app on phones. Virtually every smartphone runs on Google’s Android system. YouTube is the favorite video platform and Amazon is the No. 2 online retailer.
headline: India Pushes Back Against Tech ‘Colonization’ by Internet Giants

abstract: Two end-of-the-world films worth comparing and contrasting: “How It Ends,” on Netflix, and the 1970 movie “No Blade of Grass,” on Amazon Prime.
lead_para: There’s nothing like a good end-of-the-world-as-we-know-it movie to get you through the dog days. I recall whiling away an August afternoon at my local single-screen theater with “The Omega Man” back in 1971, the summer I turned 12. No wonder I was such a morbid kid, growing up watching Charlton Heston screen “Woodstock” for his movie-palace audience of one in between fighting off zombielike hordes led by Anthony Zerbe.
headline: ‘How It Ends’ and ‘No Blade of Grass’: Grim Visions of Tomorrow

abstract: Frustrated with insurers, some large companies — including a certain cable behemoth — are shedding long-held practices and adopting a do-it-yourself approach.
lead_para: It’s hard to think of a company that seems less likely to transform health care.
headline: The Last Company You Would Expect Is Reinventing Health Benefits

abstract: The retailer said it would not let third-party merchants sell goods with Nazi and white nationalist symbols on its platform, amid pressure from nonprofits and lawmakers.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon said this week that it would not let third-party retailers sell products that feature Nazi and white nationalist symbolism on its platform, amid pressure from nonprofit groups and lawmakers.
headline: Amazon Removes Products Featuring Nazi Symbols

abstract: Digital assistants from Amazon, Apple and Google can only have meager back-and-forth exchanges with us. Listen to how that tells us something about where they’re going in the future.
lead_para: Digital assistants from Amazon, Apple and Google can only have meager back-and-forth exchanges with us. Listen to how that tells us something about where they’re going in the future.
headline: Alexa vs. Siri vs. Google: Which Can Carry on a Conversation Best?

abstract: Maya Rudolph and Fred Armisen play a couple stuck in a routine, in an Amazon series that is anything but that.
lead_para: One year, after 14 straight annual fishing trips, June (Maya Rudolph) and Oscar (Fred Armisen) decide to change up their routine and go skiing. Neither of them has ever skied before. They are middle-aged. It is perhaps too late for all this. They find themselves, freezing and unsteady, tottering on a bunny hill.
headline: Review: ‘Forever’ Is a Thrilling Story of Boring Love

abstract: The actress and comedian can move up and down the scales of race, age and gender with hilarious ease — a talent that grew from finding her place in a world where no one looked like her.
lead_para: Supposing that God is real and possessed of a human corporeal form — mankind being created in his image (reportedly) — we might reasonably conjecture that God’s anthropoid body integrates the totality of physical traits expressed in Earth’s human population: the skin tones blended to a light tan; the hair dark and thick; the height neither too tall nor too short — about 5-foot-7, say; every shade of human iris (the iridescent blue of a morpho butterfly, the pale green of lichen clinging to a tree, lots of brown) combining to create eyes that are ... also brown. Considering his propensity for giving life, God would probably be a mother. Considering his appreciation of beauty (e.g., snowflake geometry) and busy schedule (e.g., Genesis), he would probably clothe himself in breezily tasteful garments made from natural fabrics cut for maneuverability, like a long denim jumper dress worn over a shirt of pure white cotton. God would look, in other words, like Maya Rudolph running errands on a Tuesday.
headline: How Maya Rudolph Became the Master of Impressions

abstract: After years of Emmy glory, HBO hosted a civilized affair in an airy plaza. The Netflix party was loud, with Dave Chappelle and Tiffany Haddish among the revelers.
lead_para: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — Richard Plepler, the chairman and chief executive officer of HBO, stood at the center of an airy plaza at the Pacific Design Center, where the network has held its post-Emmys party for more than a decade.
headline: HBO and Netflix, Reluctant Rivals, Party Down After Winning 23 Emmys Apiece

abstract: With a single scholarly article, Lina Khan, 29, has reframed decades of monopoly law.
lead_para: The dead books are on the top floor of Southern Methodist University’s law library.
headline: Amazon’s Antitrust Antagonist Has a Breakthrough Idea

abstract: The online retailer is moving aggressively into digital advertising, emerging as a major competitor to Google and Facebook.
lead_para: Verizon doesn’t sell its mobile phones or wireless plans over Amazon. Nor does it offer Fios, its high-speed internet service. But Verizon does advertise on Amazon.
headline: Amazon Sets Its Sights on the $88 Billion Online Ad Market

abstract: Tech workers are pushing back against federal contracts, particularly with the Pentagon. Here’s why that might be a mistake.
lead_para: Alex Karp grew up in a liberal household and considers himself a progressive. He voted for Hillary Clinton, and he lives and works in Silicon Valley.
headline: Silicon Valley Doesn’t Like Trump. It Can Still Work With the Government.

abstract: As the online retailer looked at India, its top new market, it realized it needed to reach beyond the relatively small, urban English-speaking population.
lead_para: BANGALORE, India — Only 10 percent of India’s 1.3 billion people know English. Yet most of the country’s e-commerce services have been offered only in English, closing off online shopping to the vast majority of people here.
headline: Amazon’s Plan to Reach 500 Million Indians: Speak Their Language

abstract: The president has often taken to Twitter to criticize companies, but investors don’t appear to be taking the attacks too seriously.
lead_para: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________
headline: Trump’s Thumps Don’t Cause Stock Slumps

abstract: Apple became the first public company to be worth $1 trillion. Amazon hit the same milestone a month later, but the reasons for the e-commerce titan’s rise are more complicated.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — When Apple’s market value crossed a trillion dollars last month, the reason was simple: It makes devices that a lot of people are willing to spend a lot of money on.
headline: Amazon Hits $1,000,000,000,000 in Value, Following Apple

abstract: The e-commerce giant uses its headquarters city as a living laboratory, trying out new retail and logistics models.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Tourists in Seattle have a new must-see destination: Amazon Go, the cashierless store the company opened near downtown in January.
headline: Want to See What’s Up Amazon’s Sleeve? Take a Tour of Seattle

abstract: The biggest companies may be influencing things like inflation and wage growth, possibly at the expense of central bankers’ power to do so.
lead_para: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo. — Two of the most important economic facts of the last few decades are that more industries are being dominated by a handful of extraordinarily successful companies and that wages, inflation and growth have remained stubbornly low.
headline: Are Superstar Firms and Amazon Effects Reshaping the Economy?

abstract: The billionaire activist investor is citing the online retailer in opposing Cigna’s $52 billion deal for Express Scripts.
lead_para: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________
headline: For Icahn, Amazon Is a Reason Not to Do a Deal

abstract: Apple is part of a group of giant companies that dominate the United States economy. That is good for financial markets, but not necessarily for everyone else.
lead_para: U.S. Steel. General Motors. AT&T. Exxon Mobil.
headline: Apple’s $1 Trillion Milestone Reflects Rise of Powerful Megacompanies

abstract: Facebook’s earnings report sent tech stocks cratering. But don’t let that fool you: Apple, Google, Facebook, Amazon and Microsoft are still on their way to dominating the future.
lead_para: You may have heard that the tech giants are on their heels.
headline: Stumbles? What Stumbles? Big Tech Is as Strong as Ever

abstract: Amazon said its Whole Foods stores would let customers order groceries online and pick them up in person. Walmart already offers that service at nearly 1,800 stores.
lead_para: Amazon has found itself in the rare position of playing catch-up with its rivals.
headline: Playing Catch-Up With Walmart, Amazon Offers Digital Grocery Pickup at Whole Foods

abstract: Amazon Prime’s reboot of the Tom Clancy spy hero is still a Boy Scout and he’s still determined to save the world the American way.
lead_para: Played by four men in five movies across 24 years, Jack Ryan has been more of a curriculum vitae than a character. Boy Scout, Marine, history professor, C.I.A. analyst, reluctant action hero — he can be taken out of the drawer any time and handed to the next actor in line.

abstract: The company is investing $2.35 billion to make it easier to use apps and services securely from afar. Expect similar deals soon.
lead_para: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________
headline: Cisco’s Duo Acquisition Is Part of an Industry Push to Secure the Cloud

abstract: Jack Ryan, the C.I.A. analyst at the center of many Tom Clancy novels, has long been popular in Hollywood. A look at how the character has evolved.
lead_para: Quick: What’s the first franchise you think of involving a patriotic government staffer who has to beat up bad guys in order to foil international conspiracies, and who has been played by several actors over the course of decades? Bond? James Bond?
headline: Jack Ryan Still Just Wants to Sit at a Desk

abstract: As Amazon continues its search for its second headquarters, some city officials wonder what was offered and how much it will cost taxpayers.
lead_para: Jared Evans, a member of the Indianapolis City-County Council, is proud that the city is among 20 finalists for one of the most coveted prizes in the country: the planned second headquarters of Amazon.
headline: Cities’ Offers for Amazon Base Are Secrets Even to Many City Leaders

abstract: The Amazon chief executive has quietly been grooming a new image to go with his new status as rocket scientist, richest man in the world and potential Washington big shot.
lead_para: It has happened as steadily, and stealthily, as Amazon’s relentless march to vie with Apple for the title of world’s most valuable company.
headline: Jeff Bezos, Style Icon

abstract: Departing from a 1992 decision, the justices said that even without a physical presence in a state, businesses can be required to collect taxes there.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Americans have done more and more of their shopping online in recent years, drawn by the promise of low prices, wide selection and buy-from-home convenience. But e-commerce has also had another edge: Many of those sales were, in effect, tax-free.
headline: Supreme Court Widens Reach of Sales Tax for Online Retailers

abstract: Elon Musk is drilling tunnels, electric scooters command the sidewalks, and Amazon is throwing its weight around in Seattle. Welcome to the technocapitalist metropolis of the future.
lead_para: I’m not saying America’s cities are turning into dystopian technocapitalist hellscapes in which corporations operate every essential service and pull every civic string.
headline: How Tech Companies Conquered America’s Cities

abstract: States are getting more authority to collect taxes on e-commerce sales. That will hurt consumers and retailers, but probably not Amazon.

headline: Amazon Looks at New Sales Taxes, and Shrugs: DealBook Briefing

abstract: Dr. Atul Gawande, a Harvard professor, surgeon and writer, will lead the initiative formed to provide health care for the companies’ employees.
