headline: Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan Name C.E.O. for Health Initiative

abstract: The Supreme Court’s decision to expand states’ ability to tax e-commerce sales hurt many online sellers. Except for the big one.

headline: Shares of Amazon, Wayfair and Others Hit by the Supreme Court’s Ruling on Internet Sales Taxes

abstract: Investors have returned to the safety and growth of the biggest technology stocks.
lead_para: Investors have returned to the safety and growth of the biggest technology stocks.
headline: Tech Stocks Are Hitting Highs as Economic Uncertainty Rises

abstract: This week alone, the e-commerce giant made news in pharmaceuticals, supermarket pricing and deliveries.
lead_para: Each week, technology reporters and columnists from The New York Times review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

abstract: The Seattle City Council repealed the tax in a 7-to-2 vote that was accompanied by acrimony and accusations. Less than a month ago, it had passed unanimously.
lead_para: Seattle officials scuttled a corporate tax on Tuesday that they had wholeheartedly endorsed just a month ago, delivering a win for the measure’s biggest opponent — Amazon — and offering a warning to cities bidding for the retailer’s second headquarters that the company would go to the limit to get its way.
headline: Seattle Officials Repeal Tax That Upset Amazon

abstract: The company formed data-sharing partnerships with Apple, Samsung and dozens of other device makers, raising new concerns about its privacy protections.
lead_para: The company formed data-sharing partnerships with Apple, Samsung and dozens of other device makers, raising new concerns about its privacy protections.
headline: Facebook Gave Device Makers Deep Access to Data on Users and Friends

abstract: Welcome to the first edition of With Interest — the most important business and tech news of this week and next.
lead_para: Hello! Welcome to the first edition of With Interest. Every Sunday, we’ll send you the most important business and tech news, highlighting essentials from the past week and what’s in store for the next. We’ll keep it concise, informative and hopefully entertaining — because we know your time is precious, especially on the weekend.
headline: The Week in Business: What the Midterms Mean for Taxes, and Amazon’s 2 New Homes

abstract: A city that thrives on the energy of its neighborhood merchants should not offer incentives and giveaways to an internet giant known for squashing small businesses.
lead_para: This week, word leaked that Amazon may be close to finalizing a deal to set up a major operation in Long Island City, Queens. The news, which was embraced with peak sycophancy by Gov. Andrew Cuomo — he literally offered to change his name to “Amazon Cuomo” to make it happen — came with a slap in the face to New York and every other state that bid for this deal.
headline: New York Should Say No to Amazon

abstract: Interest in real estate open houses has already spiked, and prices will likely rise. Here’s a in depth look at the transformation of a neighborhood.
lead_para: Hopes are high in Long Island City that Amazon’s plan to open a new headquarters there will bring tens of thousands more residents to a Queens neighborhood that was once heavily industrial but now has a mix of rowhouses, shiny towers, and a slowly growing collection of residential staples like grocery stores and pharmacies.
headline: What Amazon Means for Long Island City

abstract: And is President Trump actually good for the Republican Party?
lead_para: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:
headline: Is Amazon Bad for America?

abstract: The online retailer will make products from its main website available, reversing a decision that angered its customers earlier this year.
lead_para: SYDNEY, Australia — Amazon will grant Australians access to products from its main website, walking back a decision made earlier this year that angered its customers in the country.
headline: Amazon Lifts Ban on Australians Shipping From Its Main Site

abstract: Mayor de Blasio’s progressive allies have lashed out at the heavy subsidies for Amazon’s move to Queens.
lead_para: [What you need to know to start your day: Get New York Today in your inbox]
headline: Can New York City’s Mayor Be an Amazon Booster and Still Be Progressive?

abstract: The surprise change would allow the company to tap into the talent pools of two different regions.
lead_para: SEATTLE — After conducting a yearlong search for a second home, Amazon has switched gears and is now finalizing plans to have a total of 50,000 employees in two locations, according to people familiar with the decision-making process.
headline: Amazon Plans to Split HQ2 Between Long Island City, N.Y., and Arlington, Va.

abstract: The city has what the company wants, talent. Why pay them $1.5 billion to come?
lead_para: Throughout its 14-month search for a second headquarters — which has concluded with the dual selection of Long Island City, Queens, and Arlington, Va. — Amazon talked of its need for things like transportation, housing and a business-friendly environment.
headline: New York’s Amazon Deal Is a Bad Bargain

abstract: Stocks often pick up subtle changes before they appear in the economic data. Other markets have also been signaling worry.
lead_para: Unemployment is near lows not seen in half a century. The American economy is set for its best year since 2005. Large corporations are producing giant profits. Even wages are starting to rise.
headline: Turbulent Stock Market Is Flashing a Warning About the Economy

abstract: A flash strike against AbeBooks, which began Monday, is a rare concerted action by vendors against any part of Amazon, which wields huge power in the book world.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — More than 450 antiquarian book dealers in at least 26 countries pulled their books off an Amazon subsidiary on Monday, an impromptu protest after the site abruptly said it would drop all sellers from several nations.
headline: Booksellers Protest Amazon Site’s Move to Drop Stores From Certain Countries

abstract: Even though Mr. Trump still takes potshots at Amazon, the industry’s relationship with the White House is shifting as tech companies find some common ground with the president.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Two days after Donald J. Trump won the 2016 election, executives at Google consoled their employees in an all-staff meeting broadcast around the world.
headline: Silicon Valley Warms to Trump After a Chilly Start

abstract: The last thing we need at this time is for Amazon, Facebook and Google to avoid antitrust scrutiny.
lead_para: Big tech platforms — Amazon, Facebook, Google — control a large and growing share of our commerce and communications, and the scope and degree of their dominance poses real hazards. A bipartisan consensus has formed around this idea. Senator Elizabeth Warren has charged tech giants with using their heft to “snuff out competition,” and even Senator Ted Cruz — usually a foe of government regulation — recently warned of their “unprecedented” size and power. While the potential tools for redressing the harms vary, a growing chorus is calling for the use of antitrust law.
headline: The Supreme Court Case That Could Give Tech Giants More Power

abstract: Department stores offered workers an array of benefits more than a century before the health care partnership recently announced by three leading companies.
lead_para: Lord & Taylor, going up — eighth floor: robes, lingerie, hosiery; 11th floor: eye, ear, nose and throat clinic, chiropodist, dental care, urinalysis, hospital operating room.
headline: Attention 1916 Shoppers: The Doctor Is In

abstract: A European Union plan would hit Silicon Valley’s technology giants especially hard, further straining relations with the United States over taxes and trade.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — A global attempt to prevent large, multinational companies from shifting their profits to lower-tax jurisdictions is setting off a fight between the United States and Europe, as policymakers on both sides of the Atlantic spar over efforts to impose new taxes on foreign firms.
headline: Europe’s Planned Digital Tax Heightens Tensions With U.S.

abstract: ‘The Big Picture’ builds a compelling narrative by telling the stories of the executives whose careers were destroyed or made by the changes to the film industry.
lead_para: News flash: Movie studios have come to rely overwhelmingly on “sequels, reboots, spinoffs, adaptations, and animated movies” and “now exist primarily for the purpose of building and supporting branded franchises.” By contrast, the number of original scripted television series commissioned continues to break records, reaching almost 500 in 2017. The challenge for The Wall Street Journal’s entertainment reporter Ben Fritz’s new book, “The Big Picture: The Fight for the Future of Movies,” is to build a compelling business narrative from phenomena that are obvious to anyone who has walked by a multiplex and has a subscription to Netflix or Amazon Prime. Despite some distracting lapses, to a surprising degree he succeeds.
headline: Review: ‘The Big Picture’ Chronicles a Changing Entertainment Industry

abstract: Mr. Ribisi, of Amazon’s “Sneaky Pete,” talks about the art of the con, the allure of Bryan Cranston and his own commitment to four “Avatar” sequels.
lead_para: If the strength of a handshake is a sign of character, then Giovanni Ribisi’s is rock solid. Still, if you’ve watched him in Amazon’s “Sneaky Pete,” now back for its second season, you might be inclined to check if your watch is missing afterward.
headline: Giovanni Ribisi Has Been Conned. So Have You.

abstract: Amazon and Google have filed patent applications, many still under consideration, that outline how digital assistants can monitor more of what users say and do.
lead_para: Amazon ran a commercial on this year’s Super Bowl that pretended its digital assistant Alexa had temporarily lost her voice. It featured celebrities like Rebel Wilson, Cardi B and even the company’s chief executive, Jeff Bezos.
headline: Hey, Alexa, What Can You Hear? And What Will You Do With It?

abstract: President Trump renewed his attacks against Amazon on Saturday, claiming on Twitter that the Postal Service loses billions of dollars shipping packages for the online giant.
lead_para: President Trump renewed his attacks against Amazon on Saturday, claiming on Twitter that the Postal Service loses billions of dollars shipping packages for the online giant. He also accused The Washington Post — which is owned by Jeff Bezos, the chief executive of Amazon — of functioning as a “lobbyist” on behalf of the retailer.
headline: The Facts Behind Trump’s Tweets on Amazon, Taxes and the Postal Service

abstract: Amazon now collects sales tax in every state that has one, but a report finds that the company still doesn’t collect local taxes in dozens of cities.
lead_para: When Amazon agreed last year to begin collecting sales tax in New Mexico, state officials celebrated what they said could be tens of millions of dollars in annual tax revenue.
headline: As Amazon Steps Up Tax Collections, Some Cities Are Left Out

abstract: It has been six months since Amazon took over Whole Foods for $13.4 billion. Here are a handful of notable changes Amazon has made to Whole Foods so far.
lead_para: Some signs are subtle, like the “Whole Foods + Amazon” one near the bananas. Others are more obvious, like the kiosk with Amazon devices for sale.
headline: Bit by Bit, Whole Foods Gets an Amazon Touch

abstract: A pilot program will pick up goods and move them to Amazon warehouses. It could expand over time into more of a threat to established delivery companies.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon is planning to test a program this year that would replace some delivery services now done by United Parcel Service and FedEx.
headline: Amazon to Test a New Delivery Service for Sellers

abstract: The e-commerce giant has won two patents for a tracking technology that can nudge a human hand in the right direction — toward a warehouse bin, say.
lead_para: LONDON — What if your employer made you wear a wristband that tracked your every move, and that even nudged you via vibrations when it judged that you were doing something wrong?
headline: If Workers Slack Off, the Wristband Will Know. (And Amazon Has a Patent for It.)

abstract: The retailer’s stock is soaring, but it wasn’t always that way. The company had lean years in which it told investors to have faith in its long-term strategy.
lead_para: Allen Gillespie is one lonely stock analyst.
headline: Amazon Asked for Patience. Remarkably, Wall Street Complied.

abstract: Amazon has made home automation a major focus because of the success of its Echo family of products.
lead_para: Amazon said Tuesday that it had acquired Ring, a maker of internet-connected doorbells and cameras, pushing more deeply into the home security market.
headline: Amazon Buys Ring, Maker of Smart Home Products

abstract: To create a Super Bowl snack, we bought the same ingredients at a new Whole Foods 365 store and a Walmart. The prices were different. So were the outcomes.
lead_para: Amazon and Walmart are battling to dominate the grocery market, fueling a price war that could rearrange where America shops for food.
headline: Amazon Effect, Meatball Edition

abstract: An effort by Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan to improve health care is the latest example of C.E.O.s trying to fill a void left by an ineffectual government.
lead_para: Can private businesses solve public policy problems better than the government? It’s a question that has persisted for decades and taken on new resonance now that a career businessman is in the White House.
headline: Businesses Look at Washington and Say, ‘Never Mind, We’ll Do It’

abstract: The Chinese internet behemoth is investing in brick-and-mortar stores as it seeks to apply its tech smarts to the way customers shop in the real world.
lead_para: HONG KONG — The Alibaba Group, the Chinese online shopping giant, has become so big that it is looking for growth by forging into new territory: the offline world.
headline: Alibaba’s Online Growth Surges, Even as It Looks Offline

abstract: The grocery chain’s deal and the retail giant’s drop in profits are the latest signs of the pressure that Amazon is putting on traditional businesses.
lead_para: The supermarket operator Albertsons said Tuesday morning that it would buy the remnants of the Rite Aid drugstore chain. By the end of the day, Walmart saw its stock drop by more than 10 percent on weak profit.
headline: Albertsons Is Buying Rite Aid. Walmart’s Stock Falls. There’s a Common Rival.

abstract: The producer agreed to a $300 million Netflix deal months after Shonda Rhimes signed for $100 million and Apple and Amazon contributed to a manic market.
lead_para: The battle between the Hollywood establishment and the streaming-media giants has caused big changes in the entertainment industry in recent months, driving up the prices of major stars and series producers while leaving traditional companies in danger of losing relevance.
headline: As the Streaming Wars Heat Up, Ryan Murphy Cashes In

abstract: A month after announcing it was closing 63 stores, Walmart’s warehouse club said it would offer free shipping on almost all items for a $100 annual fee.
lead_para: When Sam’s Club announced last month that it was closing 63 stores as part of its strategy to overhaul its business, many shoppers were outraged over the loss of jobs and memorable shopping venues.
headline: Sam’s Club Makes E-Commerce Push With Amazon Prime Competitor

abstract: Keeping the “human free” facility running requires the work of third-party contractors, who are often put into dangerous situations.
lead_para: Editors’ note: This is part of the Op-Eds From the Future series, in which science fiction authors, futurists, philosophers and scientists write Op-Eds that they imagine we might read 10, 50 or even 200 years from now. The challenges they predict are imaginary — for now — but their arguments illuminate the urgent questions of today and prepare us for tomorrow. The Opinion piece below is a work of fiction.
headline: Amazon’s First Fully Automated Factory Is Anything But

abstract: Countries have clashed in recent years over how — and where — to tax companies that operate across borders, particularly those that sell online.
lead_para: Digital tax dodgers, take heed: International leaders have advanced a plan to prevent large multinational companies like Apple, Facebook and Amazon from avoiding taxes by shifting profits between countries.
headline: Tech Giants Shift Profits to Avoid Taxes. There’s a Plan to Stop Them.

abstract: Guilty pleas to charges of hacking and an extortion conspiracy cap a legal saga that ensnared the tech companies in data breach scandals.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Two men pleaded guilty in federal court in San Jose, Calif., to charges of computer hacking and an extortion conspiracy on Wednesday, capping a thorny legal saga that ensnared tech companies like Uber and LinkedIn in data breach scandals.
headline: 2 Plead Guilty in 2016 Uber and Lynda.com Hacks

abstract: “Catch and Kill” was pulled from two of Australia’s biggest online book retailers amid legal threats from the former National Enquirer editor who features prominently in the book.
lead_para: SYDNEY, Australia — Two of Australia’s biggest online booksellers have suspended sales of Ronan Farrow’s new book after one of the men who is prominent in it threatened legal action.
headline: Australian Booksellers Block Sales of Ronan Farrow’s Book

abstract: The defense secretary’s son worked for one of the contract’s original bidders.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper recused himself from reviewing a controversial $10 billion cloud-computing contract because his son works for one of the contract’s original bidders, the Defense Department said on Tuesday.
headline: Esper Removes Himself From Reviewing Cloud-Computing Contract

abstract: Monday: Box-crowded sidewalks, traffic congestion and mushrooming warehouses are symptoms of New Yorkers' growing addiction to deliveries.
lead_para: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
headline: How Your Amazon Delivery Helps to Clog the Streets

abstract: Amazon has become a lucrative place to do business for many Hasidic Jews, offering anonymity to a largely insular community and allowing women to work from home.
lead_para: They are a religious community known for clinging to 18th-century fashions and mores — strict rules that keep men and women apart and constraints on attire, with men favoring black suits and formal hats and women in long sleeves and long skirts.
headline: How Amazon Has Transformed the Hasidic Economy

abstract: Amazon is flexing its financial power in Seattle’s City Council elections, putting an innovative program meant to combat such influence at risk.
lead_para: SEATTLE — In 2015, Seattle voters approved a plan to foil corporate political contributions, creating “democracy vouchers” that allow residents to assign public campaign funds to local candidates of their choice.
headline: Amazon Tests ‘Soul of Seattle’ With Deluge of Election Cash

abstract: Amazon was considered a front-runner for the cloud computing project before President Trump began criticizing the company’s founder, Jeff Bezos.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — The Department of Defense on Friday awarded a $10 billion technology contract to Microsoft over Amazon in a contest that was closely watched after President Trump ramped up his criticism of Amazon’s founder, Jeff Bezos, and said he might intervene.
headline: Microsoft Wins Pentagon’s $10 Billion JEDI Contract, Thwarting Amazon

abstract: Every month, a new batch of movies and TV shows begin streaming on Netflix, Stan and Amazon in Australia. Here are the titles we think are most interesting for October.
lead_para: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for October.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in October

abstract: Gig workers on Mechanical Turk, a platform run by Amazon, do computer-like tasks for pennies. Here’s what I learned when I joined their ranks.
lead_para: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
headline: Doing Tiny Jobs for Tinier Pay

abstract: The move of entrepreneurs, engineers and venture investors away from the consumer internet and to enterprise software has piqued regulator interest.
lead_para: When Rajiv Ayyangar and two other Yahoo alumni explored start-up ideas, they experimented with concepts directed at the public, like a personal finance app. But making money from consumers was too daunting, they concluded, partly because of the tight grip that digital giants like Google and Apple had over distribution.
headline: With Big Tech in Their Path, Start-Ups Turn to Business Markets

abstract: Customer reviews are incredibly important in e-commerce, but they can be unreliable or downright dishonest.
lead_para: In the world of e-commerce, the online review is king, the internet’s answer to walking into a store and trying out a product for yourself.
headline: When Is a Star Not Always a Star? When It’s an Online Review

abstract: The economy is relatively strong, and consumers are spending. So why are things so tough for some retailers?
lead_para: Retailers are trying everything they can to keep up with Amazon. Macy’s offers same-day delivery and in-store returns for online purchases. Black Friday deals are already starting at Kohl’s. And craft cocktails are served in the women’s shoe department at Nordstrom.
headline: Chasing Amazon, Retailers Are in a Never-Ending Arms Race

abstract: Orders from the Republican Party and other conservative groups helped push Mr. Trump’s best-selling book, records show.
lead_para: Boxes began arriving in early November at the Phoenix headquarters of Turning Point USA, a conservative student group with ties to the Trump family.
headline: Donald Trump Jr., Debut Author, Sees Sales Bolstered by G.O.P. Allies

abstract: The company said there should be an examination of whether political bias helped Microsoft win the bid.
lead_para: Amazon on Thursday said it planned to officially challenge the Pentagon’s surprise decision last month to award a $10 billion cloud-computing contract to Microsoft, setting off another legal battle over the lucrative, decade-long project.
headline: Amazon Protesting Pentagon’s $10 Billion JEDI Contract

abstract: The movement to reinterpret or change antimonopoly laws is running headlong into a legal community and interest groups just as invested in defending the status quo.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Thomas Lambert, a professor at the University of Missouri’s law school, gave his former colleague Josh Hawley a warning before Mr. Hawley became a senator in January.
headline: Powerful Coalition Pushes Back on Anti-Tech Fervor

abstract: A co-chief film critic of The New York Times debates himself on the subject.
lead_para: Our co-chief film critic is of two minds on the subject, and is not shy about speaking both of them.
headline: Will Streaming Kill the Art of Cinema or Grant It New Life?

abstract: For most people, it’s the click that brings a package to their door. But a look at Baltimore shows how Amazon may now reach into Americans’ daily existence in more ways than any corporation in history.
lead_para: BALTIMORE — Another big Prime Air 767 takes off from Baltimore-Washington International Airport — where Amazon’s shipping last year eclipsed that of FedEx and U.P.S. put together — and wheels above the old industrial city. Below, the online giant seems to touch every niche of the economy, its ubiquity and range breathtaking.
headline: Prime Mover: How Amazon Wove Itself Into the Life of an American City

abstract: As groups join a coalition against the internet giant, a new report underlines its troubling impact in warehouse towns.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon flourished over its first two decades with little opposition and less scrutiny. A new coalition and a report unveiled on Tuesday make clear that era is over.
headline: Activists Build a Grass-Roots Alliance Against Amazon

abstract: The mayor went from Amazon booster to critic when the company scuttled plans for a Queens campus; the shift may please progressives if he runs for president.
lead_para: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]
headline: With 2020 in Sight, de Blasio Turns Against Amazon

abstract: In an online post, the chief executive of Amazon said the tabloid’s owner had used “extortion and blackmail” to try to stop his investigation into leaked photos and text messages.
lead_para: The richest man on earth accused the nation’s leading supermarket tabloid publisher of “extortion and blackmail” on Thursday, laying out a theory that brought together international intrigue, White House politics, nude photos and amorous text messages.
headline: Jeff Bezos Accuses National Enquirer of ‘Extortion and Blackmail’

abstract: If no one reads the terms and conditions, how can they continue to be the legal backbone of the internet?
lead_para: The average person would have to spend 76 working days reading all of the digital privacy policies they agree to in the span of a year. Reading Amazon’s terms and conditions alone out loud takes approximately nine hours.
headline: How Silicon Valley Puts the ‘Con’ in Consent

abstract: Yes, Amazon’s departure will modestly hurt the city’s economy. But it’s also a victory against bad economic policy.
lead_para: Imagine that a bunch of children are sitting around a table when a seemingly beneficent adult walks into the room carrying a plate of cupcakes. The kids burst out in excitement — until they notice a problem: There are fewer cupcakes than children.
headline: New York Did Us All a Favor by Standing Up to Amazon

abstract: As the company cancels its plans for a major Queens campus, anti-corporate activists got what they wanted at a great cost.
lead_para: “You have to be tough to make it in New York City,” Mayor Bill de Blasio boasted, choosing to jeer at Amazon as it canceled its plans on Thursday to build a new headquarters in Queens, after some local officials angrily criticized its proposal.
headline: New York Returns 25,000 Jobs to Amazon

abstract: Lawmakers who opposed the company’s deal are calling its collapse a political victory, but some say this messaging may come back to haunt them.
lead_para: A technical error affected those who tried to listen to today’s episode before 7:30 a.m. Eastern. (The episode appeared to be 52 minutes long, with the show’s first half repeating over and over.) To fix the problem, close and reopen whichever listening application you use. A 26-minute episode should reload automatically. We apologize for any inconvenience.
headline: How New York Lost Amazon

abstract: The sell-off is the latest evidence of how quickly investors soured on Big Tech late last year.
lead_para: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________
headline: Big Investors Shed Tech Stocks as Markets Tumbled Last Quarter

abstract: Candidates like Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders were quick to praise New Yorkers who rebelled at the idea of giving tax breaks to a huge corporation.
lead_para: The decision by Amazon this week to abandon its planned headquarters in New York City tapped into one of the major themes of left-wing Democrats: that giant corporations — and in some cases the billionaires who run them — must be held to account for wage inequality, corporate greed and middle-class stagnation.
headline: For Some 2020 Democrats, Rejection of Amazon Aligns With Liberal Policy Views

abstract: Its plan to build a sprawling complex in Queens in return for nearly for $3 billion in government incentives had come under fierce opposition from local lawmakers.
lead_para: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]
headline: Amazon Pulls Out of Planned New York City Headquarters

abstract: The nonpartisan election features 17 candidates, and a number of variables.
lead_para: [Read more about the public advocate race in New York Today.]
headline: N.Y.C. Special Election: 7 Factors That Will Help Decide the Public Advocate Race

abstract: Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan Chase will call their health care upstart Haven.
lead_para: We can finally put a name to the thing striking fear within the health care establishment: Haven.
headline: The Imposing Venture of 3 Corporate Giants Gets a Not-So-Imposing New Name

abstract: Hundreds of thousands of miles of cable connect continents to support our insatiable demand for communication and entertainment. Companies have typically pooled their resources. Now Google is going its own way.
lead_para: Hundreds of thousands of miles of cable connect continents to support our insatiable demand for communication and entertainment. Companies have typically pooled their resources. Now Google is going its own way.
headline: How the Internet Travels Across Oceans

abstract: After losing top professors, college students are less likely to create artificial intelligence start-ups and get less venture funding, the research says.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — For years, big tech companies have used huge salaries, bonuses and stock packages to lure artificial intelligence experts out of academia. Now, a study released on Friday says that migration has hurt the post-college prospects of students.
headline: When the A.I. Professor Leaves, Students Suffer, Study Says

abstract: I have about 400 offers to buy illegal copies of my own work. Something is very wrong.
lead_para: One day not long ago in a college class I was teaching, some of my students couldn’t find the page I was talking about in the reading. And it dawned on me: There was only one required text in the class, an anthology of writing about the natural world called “American Earth.” And they were reading pirated copies — versions downloaded free from some dubious “provider” on the internet.
headline: Steal This Book? There’s a Price

abstract: Lawsuits and investigations could eventually lead to the breakup of some companies and to new laws that alter the balance of corporate power.
lead_para: Lawsuits and investigations could eventually lead to the breakup of some companies and to new laws that alter the balance of corporate power.
headline: 13 Ways the Government Went After Google, Facebook and Other Tech Giants This Year

abstract: Every month, subscription streaming services add a new batch of titles to their libraries. Here are the ones we think are most interesting for July.
lead_para: Watching is The New York Times’s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our twice-weekly newsletter here.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and More in July

abstract: Britain’s National Health Service has collaborated with Amazon to offer health information through Alexa, prompting questions about privacy and market advantage.
lead_para: LONDON — “Alexa, how do I treat a migraine?”
headline: Alexa Now Gives U.K. Users N.H.S. Medical Advice

abstract: A series of hearings on Capitol Hill showed the rising force of the political backlash against the country’s tech giants.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers leveled stinging criticism and sharp questions at Big Tech executives on Tuesday, attacking Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google for their market power, their perceived bias as gatekeepers of communication and Facebook’s ambitions to reshape the financial industry.
headline: Tech Hearings: Congress Unites to Take Aim at Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google

abstract: The company, long a target of President Trump, is seen as the leading competitor for a $10 billion cloud computing contract that the president said he was “getting tremendous complaints about.”
lead_para: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Thursday that he was looking “very seriously” at intervening in the hard-fought commercial battle for a $10 billion Pentagon cloud computing contract for which Amazon, a company he has frequently attacked, is seen as the leading contender.
headline: Trump Says He May Intervene in Huge Pentagon Contract Sought by Amazon

abstract: Homeowners are getting bombarded by speculators asking them to sell. Tenants are fighting rent increases. And Amazon hasn’t even started building.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Amazon has yet to break ground in Northern Virginia for its second headquarters, but residents are already turning away persistent speculators, recalculating budgets for down payments on homes and fighting rent increases.
headline: Amazon HQ2 Is Upending Northern Virginia’s Already Unstable Housing Market

abstract: In their rush to match Netflix, competitors like HBO, Hulu and Amazon are ordering a slew of content — ushering out the age of “prestige TV” and ushering in an age of anything goes.
lead_para: When Nick Weidenfeld heard what happened at HBO last summer, he was thrilled. “Everyone I knew was texting that article around, saying, ‘What the [expletive]!’ ” Weidenfeld, an independent TV producer, recently recalled. A lot of people who work in Hollywood were spooked by the news, but not him: “I thought it was amazing.”
headline: The Great Race to Rule Streaming TV

abstract: Amazon has expanded one-day shipping options in hopes of increasing sales.
lead_para: SEATTLE — So just how impatient are shoppers? Enough to bolster sales at Amazon.
headline: Amazon Earnings: Impatient Shoppers Help Lift Sales 20 Percent

abstract: The retailer wants to draw more people into its stores, and it hopes that packing, labeling and shipping returns for the online behemoth will help.
lead_para: It says volumes about the challenges facing brick-and-mortar stores that the “single biggest initiative” out of Kohl’s this year, according to the national retailer’s chief executive, is that it will now accept and process unwanted orders from Amazon.
headline: Kohl’s Is Betting on Amazon Returns to Drive Sales

abstract: R. J. Scaringe’s company, Rivian, has raised $1.7 billion from Amazon, Ford Motor and others without selling a single pickup truck and sport utility vehicle.
lead_para: NORMAL, Ill. — By definition, the time of the world’s richest man is pretty valuable. But early last fall, Jeff Bezos sought out a 36-year old entrepreneur named R.J. Scaringe and spent the better part of a day in Plymouth, Mich., at the company he founded, Rivian.
headline: Meet the Man Quietly Building the Tesla of Trucks, With Jeff Bezos Aboard

abstract: Instead of Whole Foods being the answer to the tech behemoth’s grocery ambitions, it seems to have encouraged executives to pursue other ideas, too.
lead_para: SEATTLE — In early 2017, a memo circulated inside Amazon that imagined an ambitious new grocery chain. The document was written like a news release, a common practice for ideas being weighed inside the company, with the title “Grocery Shopping for Everyone.”
headline: Amazon Wants to Rule the Grocery Aisles, and Not Just at Whole Foods

abstract: Local journalism has been pushed “to the verge of extinction,” said a member of a committee that plans 18 months of hearings and other scrutiny of the big technology platforms.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — A congressional investigation into the power of big tech companies began on Tuesday with bipartisan concern from lawmakers that the government’s lax oversight of the industry may be doing more harm than good.
headline: House Opens Tech Antitrust Inquiry With Look at Threat to News Media

abstract: Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google, facing the growing possibility of antitrust action and legislation to rein in their power, are spending freely to gain influence and access.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Faced with the growing possibility of antitrust actions and legislation to curb their power, four of the biggest technology companies are amassing an army of lobbyists as they prepare for what could be an epic fight over their futures.
headline: Tech Giants Amass a Lobbying Army for an Epic Washington Battle

abstract: Google, Facebook, Amazon and Apple are facing greater scrutiny from antitrust regulators in the Justice Department and Federal Trade Commission.
lead_para: Technology stocks tumbled on Monday, as declines in the biggest companies in the sector punctuated an otherwise quiet day on Wall Street.
headline: Big Tech Shares Slide as Prospect of Antitrust Scrutiny Mounts

abstract: Prime Day 2019 will be two days: July 15 and 16. Here are the deals to expect, how to shop if you’re not a Prime member, and how not to regret your purchases.
lead_para: Amazon Prime Day has become Black Friday in July. It’s no longer just one day, with last year’s Prime Day going on for over 36 hours. It’s also more than just Amazon, with competing retailers offering discounts and price matches of their own. And while the opportunity to save has grown, so has the risk of wasting money some impulsive purchase you don’t need.
headline: How to Prepare for Amazon Prime Day

abstract: Plus, tensions with Iran reach a boiling point and Trump’s meeting with China’s president.
lead_para: Here’s your quick rundown of the week’s biggest stories in business and tech, so you can spend more of your weekend hours enjoying the sun on the longest days of the year. (Or, you know, sit inside and watch season 2 of “Dark” on Netflix. You do you.)
headline: The Week in Business: Stocks Hit a Record High, and Facebook Wants to Replace Your Bank

abstract: Amazon Restaurants, which was available in nearly 200 American cities, will officially close on June 24. The company says it will focus on grocery delivery.
lead_para: With the online restaurant delivery market growing ever more competitive, Amazon is discontinuing the service it started four years ago as an alternative to popular apps like Grubhub and UberEats.
headline: Amazon to End Its Restaurant Delivery Service

abstract: Amazon says it’s not responsible if its creations are abused.
lead_para: Don’t bring a knife to a chaos factory.
headline: ‘If You’ve Built a Chaos Factory, You Can’t Dodge Responsibility for the Chaos’

abstract: The legal action against Silicon Valley’s giants will be long, difficult, uncertain and, for some people, disappointing.
lead_para: Each week, we review the week’s news, offering analysis about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.
headline: The Week in Tech: What Not to Expect From Big Tech’s Antitrust Showdown

abstract: A wide range of companies are lining up to complain about Silicon Valley’s power as lawmakers and regulators step up their scrutiny of Big Tech.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Oracle and the Handpulled Noodle would seem to have little in common. One is a multibillion-dollar software company in Silicon Valley with tens of thousands of employees all over the world. The other is a small Harlem spot that serves Chinese comfort food and is known for its tasty dumplings.
headline: Anger at Big Tech Unites Noodle Pullers and Code Writers

abstract: A handful of companies already dominate the market for digital assistants. The implications for consumer privacy are a serious concern, researchers say.
lead_para: PALO ALTO, Calif. — It has been almost two decades since Google started to dominate internet search the way Microsoft dominated software for personal computers a generation earlier.
headline: Stanford Team Aims at Alexa and Siri With a Privacy-Minded Alternative

abstract: The government plans to deploy new technology for next year’s head count, but risks abound.
lead_para: In the run-up to the 2020 census, the government has embraced technology as never before, hoping to halt the ballooning cost of the decennial head count. For the first time, households will have the option of responding online, and field workers going door to door will be equipped with smartphones to log the information they collect.
headline: Hacking, Glitches, Disinformation: Why Experts Are Worried About the 2020 Census

abstract: The online retailer is teaming with an owner of real estate brokerage firms to offer home buyers free Alexa speakers and services like furniture assembly.
lead_para: Over the past year, the decidedly analog business of buying and selling real estate has been upended by a flurry of new money and start-ups trying to usher in a world where homes are bought and sold online. Now, Amazon is creating a partnership that goes in the opposite direction by using its gigantic retail platform to facilitate phone calls with human real estate agents.
headline: How to Get a $5,000 Amazon Credit: Buy a House Through Realogy

abstract: The international tax system is behind the times. But we need coordinated reform.
lead_para: Last Thursday, the French Senate passed a digital services tax, which would impose an entirely new tax on large multinationals that provide digital services to consumers or users in France.
headline: Beware. Other Nations Will Follow France With Their Own Digital Tax.

abstract: The emergence of a major discount shopping season in the middle of the summer may cost retailers scrambling to keep up with Amazon.
lead_para: Amazon had already revolutionized the way people read books, watch TV and shop online. And now it has succeeded in transforming the retail calendar.
headline: Amazon Prime Day Brings Sales, and Risks, for Retailers

abstract: A bookstore owner shares her experience.
lead_para: To the Editor:
headline: Independent Bookstores vs. Amazon

abstract: We have become cheap dates to tech platforms.
lead_para: Here’s a little quiz. When was the last time a significant social media network was founded in the United States? And what about a competitive search engine company? An online ad network? And what about a truly wide-ranging e-commerce start-up?
headline: For Tech, We’re the Gift That Keeps on Giving. But We Get Prime!

abstract: “‘A little less creepy’ is still creepy.”
lead_para: Call it the Five Stages of Privacy Erosion.
headline: Your Inbox Is Spying on You

abstract: Don’t fall for a bundle blunder.
lead_para: It’s that time of the year — Prime Day is right around the corner on July 15 and 16. The event has turned into summer’s version of Black Friday, a shopping frenzy that can turn into a hangover of spending regret once the packages arrive on your doorstep.
headline: 5 Things to Avoid on Amazon Prime Day

abstract: European antitrust regulators have opened an investigation into the data that Amazon uses from third-party sellers who rely on the tech company’s site
lead_para: LONDON — Amazon faces a widening inquiry in Europe over whether it unfairly uses data collected from third-party sellers who rely on its platform, the latest move by regulators around the world to curb the growing power of big technology companies.
headline: Amazon Faces E.U. Inquiry Over Data From Independent Sellers

abstract: Striking Amazon employees complained about how robots changed their jobs, but the company may help them think differently.
lead_para: Each week, we review the week’s news, offering analysis about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.
headline: The Week in Tech: Some Workers Hate Robots. Retraining May Change That.

abstract: Sometimes it’s worth pausing to ask the simplest questions.
lead_para: This article is part of a limited-run newsletter. You can sign up here.
headline: Why Does Google Know Everything You’ve Bought on Amazon for the Past Six Years?

abstract: Popular novels, technical tomes and self-published books are pirated and sold on Amazon. That may actually be helping the company extend its grip on the book business.
lead_para: SPERRYVILLE, Va. — “The Sanford Guide to Antimicrobial Therapy” is a medical handbook that recommends the right amount of the right drug for treating ailments from bacterial pneumonia to infected wounds. Lives depend on it.
headline: What Happens After Amazon’s Domination Is Complete? Its Bookstore Offers Clues

abstract: The “Break Up Big Tech” billboard, paid for by the Democrat’s presidential campaign, doesn’t sit well with all San Franciscans who work in the industry.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — A threat of government regulation is casting a shadow over the tech industry. Now there is a billboard to remind tech workers about it on their commutes.
headline: Elizabeth Warren Sticks Her Message in Big Tech’s Face

abstract: This haunting documentary looks at the ritual of the hunt and its place in the history and identity of today’s Lakota Sioux.
lead_para: At first glance, “The Buffalo Hunt” seems fairly straightforward. Under the eye of the film’s director, Philip Di Fiore, the people of the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in South Dakota take apart a buffalo, using the skin to make drums and splitting up the meat for those who could not attend the hunt, as well as for a communal soup.
headline: ‘The Buffalo Hunt’ Review: The Sacred Ties That Bind

abstract: Until recently big tech companies were seen as one of the few relatively untainted sources of big-money donations for Democrats. Now, that’s changing.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Top Democrats in Washington and on the 2020 campaign trail are taking technology giants to task, calling them too big, too powerful and too careless about privacy. “The era of self-regulation is over,” Speaker Nancy Pelosi declared on Monday.
headline: Democratic Candidates Woo Silicon Valley for Donations, Then Bash It

abstract: Local governments must protect your privacy as they turn to “smart city” technology.
lead_para: Walking through the streets of New York City, you can feel the thrill of being lost in the crowd. As throngs of people filter past, each going about their days, it seems possible to blend in without being noticed.
headline: Smile, Your City Is Watching You

abstract: Ms. Warren seeks to break up companies like Amazon, Google, Apple and Facebook. And she has taken her fight to Silicon Valley.
lead_para: Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts believes that the government must break up monopolies and promote competitive markets. That’s why she has taken aim at America’s largest tech companies.
headline: Elizabeth Warren on Breaking Up Big Tech

abstract: Support for scrutiny of the tech giants is coming from across the political spectrum. For Google and Amazon, any investigations would be a major distraction, or worse.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Google and Amazon have thrived as American regulators largely kept their distance. That may be changing.
headline: Google and Amazon Are at the Center of a Storm Brewing Over Big Tech

abstract: A lifetime of browsing offers lessons in spotting disinformation.

abstract: The Amazon series is the latest to use otherworldly animation to explore the aftermath of trauma.
lead_para: “Is this a dream?” Alma (Rosa Salazar) asks her father, Jacob (Bob Odenkirk), in the second episode of “Undone.”
headline: Review: In the Entrancing ‘Undone,’ Life Is but a Dream State

abstract: Pledging that the retailer would be carbon neutral by 2040, Jeff Bezos, the C.E.O., said it was ordering 100,000 electric delivery trucks.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Amazon committed on Thursday to meeting the goals of the Paris climate agreement 10 years ahead of schedule and be carbon neutral by 2040, in the company’s most ambitious push yet to combat climate change.
headline: Amazon Accelerates Efforts to Fight Climate Change

abstract: Lawmakers investigating Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google for possible antitrust violations on Friday sent the companies detailed requests for information.
lead_para: Congress showed the breadth of its investigation into the big tech companies on Friday, making a public demand for scores of documents, including the personal emails and other communications from dozens of top executives.

abstract: A.I. research is becoming increasingly expensive, leaving few people with easy access to the computing firepower necessary to develop the technology.

headline: At Tech’s Leading Edge, Worry About a Concentration of Power

abstract: The influential series, which fired the actor Jeffrey Tambor over sexual harassment allegations, will wrap up with a musical finale.
lead_para: LOS ANGELES — Last February, Jill and Faith Soloway were filming the final episode of “Transparent” here at Paramount Pictures, in the studio’s cavernous Stage 14. It was the last day of a 20-day shoot, and Judith Light, as the nettlesome matriarch Shelly Pfefferman, was tearing through “Your Boundary Is My Trigger,” a show tune-slash-primal scream about how thankless it is to be a mother, and how Shelly gives and gives and gives, and for what?
headline: After Times of Turmoil, ‘Transparent’ Goes Out Singing

abstract: From Washington to London. From the price of avocados to Amazon Prime. Here’s how Joseph Plambeck, deputy tech editor, rides herd on how tech is changing the way we live.
lead_para: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Joseph Plambeck, deputy technology editor in New York, discussed the tech he’s using.

abstract: The formal declaration by a bipartisan group of state officials adds investigative muscle to the intensifying scrutiny of the tech giant.
lead_para: The state attorneys general from four dozen states officially declared on Monday that they were beginning investigations into the market power and corporate behavior of big tech companies.
headline: Google Antitrust Investigation Outlined by State Attorneys General

abstract: Economists have long criticized tax breaks to corporations; politicians and the public may be starting to share their skepticism.
lead_para: In exchange for tens of thousands of tech jobs, cities promised Amazon the moon — and an airport lounge, and naming rights, and a chance to pocket its own employees’ taxes. States offered incentive packages worth $7 billion, $8.5 billion, $9.7 billion, any of which would have set records.
headline: In the End, Amazon Didn’t Win Its Own Subsidy Game

abstract: Amazon might have been the center of a new tech ecosystem in Queens. Here’s what the city can do next.
lead_para: Amazon’s decision on Feb. 14 to cancel its plans in New York City was actually the second time that New York missed its chance to host Amazon headquarters. The first time was in 1994, and what happened then informs what might happen next.
headline: Does New York Still Have a Future in Tech?

abstract: After the online retail giant abandoned its controversial plan to open a headquarters in Queens, New Yorkers deconstructed what went wrong.
lead_para: Like seemingly every New Yorker, Adrianne Santiago was eager to weigh in on Amazon’s decision to abandon its plans to build a vast campus in Queens and create more than 25,000 jobs.
headline: Amazon Bails and New York Reacts: The City ‘Was Never Really On Board’

abstract: Virginia can teach New York a few things about how to make a deal that actually works.

abstract: What kinds of companies will be the next so-called unicorns? A hint: Many of them won’t have much in common with Uber or Airbnb.
lead_para: Hi. I’m Steve Lohr. I write about the technology industry, from the old titans like IBM to start-ups working on the future of artificial intelligence.
headline: The Week in Tech: A Break From Consumer Tech

abstract: Amazon’s pullout poses a challenge to one of the company’s bedrock beliefs: that being loved by customers is all that matters.
lead_para: Amazon’s surprise announcement on Thursday that it was canceling its planned expansion to a new corporate campus in New York was greeted with celebration by local activists and politicians who had opposed the deal, and frustration by local officials — and more than a few real estate agents in Queens — who had eagerly anticipated an influx of well-compensated tech workers.
headline: For Once, Amazon Loses a Popularity Contest

abstract: And it’s got a little bit of everything.

abstract: The sites — dozens in more than 20 states — are shutting down even as Amazon is otherwise expanding its physical retail presence with stores like Amazon Go and Whole Foods.

headline: Amazon Is Closing Pop-Up Stores, as Its Retail Strategy Evolves

abstract: After the company’s plans for a big New York presence ran into labor issues, a union says that an employee was fired for speaking out about working conditions.
lead_para: Amazon’s plan for a major corporate presence in New York ran headlong into concerns about the company’s labor practices in the city. The giant project fell apart, but the labor friction lives on.

abstract: Tuesday: Two-thirds of voters said the company’s withdrawal from a Queens campus was bad for the state, and over a third blamed the congresswoman for it.

abstract: He built the world’s largest fortune with an iron discipline. Now a wild cast of only-in-L.A. characters have seized his narrative.
lead_para: Jeff Bezos amassed the world’s greatest fortune by relying on what he has called a “regret minimization framework.” He built an $800 billion company with 14 codified principles and a brutally exacting culture. His annual salary of $81,840 has not budged since 1998.

abstract: Should Big Tech partner with the Pentagon? We examine a cautionary tale.

abstract: Amazon’s rawly honest comedy of marriage careens to a satisfying finish.
lead_para: When “Catastrophe” began in 2015, its title seemed to refer to a discrete event. Rob (Rob Delaney), an American businessman visiting London, had a whirlwind fling of marathon sex with Sharon (Sharon Horgan), who got pregnant. He stayed, they married, they bumpily transitioned from unplanned pregnancy to an unplanned life.
headline: Review: In ‘Catastrophe,’ True Love Is Not Convenient

abstract: An open letter asking Jeff Bezos to resuscitate a plan for Amazon to build a campus in Queens has not seemed to change the company’s position.

abstract: Dow Chemical stopped making napalm for the military in 1969, just four years after it began. But the reputational damage haunted the company for decades.
lead_para: Over the past few months, a fierce debate has erupted in Silicon Valley over whether large technology companies like Amazon, Google and Microsoft should join forces with the United States military, along with agencies like Immigration and Customs Enforcement.
headline: Why Napalm Is a Cautionary Tale for Tech Giants Pursuing Military Contracts

abstract: After poor box-office numbers for Mindy Kaling’s “Late Night,” the company shrank its ambitious release plan for a big fall movie, “The Aeronauts.”
lead_para: LOS ANGELES — “The Aeronauts,” an adventure film about swashbuckling 19th-century hot-air balloonists, was built for the big screen. Led by an Oscar winner, Eddie Redmayne, and a “Star Wars” star, Felicity Jones, it has real cinematic sweep, with sequences that take place miles above sea level. In May, Amazon Studios announced that the movie would play exclusively on IMAX screens for a one-week engagement before “a full theatrical run.”
headline: Behind Amazon’s Sudden Change in Its Film Strategy

abstract: The E.U.’s top antitrust regulator ordered Broadcom to halt specific practices while the bloc investigates possible anticompetitive activity.
lead_para: European authorities took an even more aggressive approach than usual to regulating the technology industry Wednesday when they applied a rarely used rule, ordering a company to halt a potentially anticompetitive practice while an investigation is underway.
headline: Europe’s Margrethe Vestager Takes a Rare Step Toward Big Tech

abstract: The company’s cloud computing efforts again pushed profits higher, to $10.7 billion in the latest quarter.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Microsoft doesn’t have an iPhone. It isn’t the Everything Store. It isn’t a verb for “search.”
headline: Microsoft Rides Cloud to a 21% Increase in Profits

abstract: Wherein our columnist gives up on shopping and lets Amazon’s Personal Shopper dress her for fall.
lead_para: This is a retail review in which I do not leave my apartment. All of the movements and decisions described take place in my mind or on my phone. Where mind ends and phone begins is sometimes unclear. All you have to know is that wherever I am, I am shopping.

abstract: Attorney General Xavier Becerra is in Google and Facebook’s backyard. But unlike nearly all other state attorneys general, he won’t say whether he’s investigating them.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — When numerous state attorneys general gathered last month on the steps of the Supreme Court to announce an antitrust investigation into Google, one was conspicuously absent: Xavier Becerra, California’s attorney general.
headline: California Attorney General Is a No-Show on Tech Investigations

abstract: The live-streaming platform, owned by Amazon, has struggled to police content as it is posted.

abstract: The push for convenience is having a stark impact on gridlock, roadway safety and pollution in New York City and urban areas around the world.

headline: 1.5 Million Packages a Day: The Internet Brings Chaos to N.Y. Streets

abstract: Members of Congress questioned whether the power of Facebook, Google, Apple and Amazon could hurt consumer privacy.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — House lawmakers on Friday pressed experts on how the market power of major tech platforms could hurt consumer privacy, showing that an antitrust investigation into Facebook, Google, Apple and Amazon is growing to include deeper questions about their business models.

abstract: The company announced free two-hour food delivery for Prime members in about 20 major metropolitan areas.

abstract: Margrethe Vestager won praise for her oversight of the tech industry. Now, with more authority from the European Union, she envisions a more aggressive agenda.
lead_para: BRUSSELS — Margrethe Vestager spent the past five years developing a well-earned reputation as the world’s top tech industry watchdog. From her perch overseeing Europe’s competition rules, she fined Google more than $9 billion for breaking antitrust laws, and forced Apple to pay about $14.5 billion for dodging taxes.
headline: Big Tech’s Toughest Opponent Says She’s Just Getting Started

abstract: Researchers in Japan and at the University of Michigan said they have found a way to take over the voice-controlled digital assistants.

abstract: The shift from network schedules to TV-when-you-want-it may change not just viewing habits but the whole culture of the medium.

abstract: Cities should treat rising rents like pollution and tax the companies that cause it.

abstract: “Homecoming,” “Dirty John” and “Lore” are just the first in a likely wave of headphone-to-screen adaptations.
