abstract: Technology publications are asking pointed questions about the online retail company. And Apple had rare, surprising bad news about sales.
lead_para: Each week, technology reporters and columnists from The New York Times review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.
headline: The Week in Tech: Amazon’s Burning Problems

abstract: The Amazon chief’s split from his wife raises questions about the disposal of their enormous stake in the company he founded. Investors deserve answers.
lead_para: Jeff Bezos and his wife, MacKenzie, may be the first billionaire couple with a huge stake in an enormous technology company to announce their divorce.
headline: Why Jeff Bezos’ Divorce Should Worry Amazon Investors

abstract: We can’t look away. But we should.
lead_para: It turns out that internet zillionaires are just as awkward as the rest of us when it comes to romantic text messages.
headline: The Sexts of Jeff Bezos and the Death of Privacy

abstract: Allen says the streaming service improperly canceled a four-movie contract because of a renewed focus on sexual abuse allegations he has long denied.
lead_para: Woody Allen sued Amazon in federal court on Thursday, seeking at least $68 million and saying that the company’s streaming service had improperly backed out of a four-movie deal because of a renewed focus on allegations of sexual abuse on Allen’s part.
headline: Woody Allen Sues Amazon Over Canceled $68 Million Deal

abstract: Brands are paying millions of dollars for the opportunity to make consumers laugh, cry and reach for their wallets.
lead_para: Super Bowl Sunday is the day when the advertising industry is not only tolerated but celebrated. And as in years past, brands paid millions of dollars this year for the opportunity to make consumers laugh, cry and reach for their wallets.
headline: Super Bowl Commercials 2019: Brands Play It Safe and Look to the Future

abstract: Almost everyone had an opinion on the company’s reversal on a second headquarters in Queens.
lead_para: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]
headline: What People Are Saying About Amazon’s Breakup With New York City

abstract: It’s for the good of the country. Especially our kids.
lead_para: Dear Jeff Bezos,
headline: Jeff Bezos, Please Release Your Dirty Selfies

abstract: The deal is the latest example of how the auto industry is being reshaped by new technologies and nimble companies that have raced ahead of many traditional carmakers.
lead_para: A potential rival to Tesla in electric cars just got a big boost from Amazon.
headline: Amazon Invests in Rivian, a Tesla Rival in Electric Vehicles

abstract: A court battle over trade secrets highlighted how the Big Three corporations’ new unit is unnerving major insurers in the field.
lead_para: UnitedHealth Group, the giant health insurance company, on Friday lost its case to prevent a former executive from working at the new health care venture formed by three powerful corporations, Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan Chase.
headline: UnitedHealth Loses Case to the Health Venture Begun by Amazon, Berkshire-Hathaway and JPMorgan Chase

abstract: The second season averaged 1.9 million viewers during its first seven days, according to Nielsen, which released an Amazon show’s figures for the first time.
lead_para: PASADENA, Calif. — Amazon Prime’s original series “The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel” has received warm reviews and scored big at the Emmys and the Golden Globes.
headline: Numbers Are In for ‘Marvelous Mrs. Maisel,’ Courtesy of Nielsen

abstract: History is clear: A city that rejects economic opportunity will lose its status as the center of the business world.
lead_para: On Nov. 13, 2018, Amazon announced that New York would become one of two locations for the company’s second North American headquarters, ending a competition that had involved more than 200 places, including cities as diverse as Chicago, Atlanta, Denver, Newark and Austin, Tex. But there was hardly any cheering in New York. State Senator Michael Gianaris and other leaders protested that the agreement was bad for New York and bad for its people. They argued that it is absurd for city and state taxpayers to subsidize one of the world’s most valuable companies, owned by the world’s richest man, with as much as $3 billion in taxpayer money.
headline: New York Needs Amazon

abstract: The city did the rest of the country a favor. Corporate-relocation handouts are terrible economic policy.
lead_para: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.
headline: Thank You, New York

abstract: A billboard blamed Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez for Amazon’s decision to exit New York; she blamed wealthy right-wing types for the ad.
lead_para: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]
headline: A Times Square Billboard Hits Ocasio-Cortez on Amazon. She Hits Back.

abstract: After her divorce from the Amazon founder and chief executive Jeff Bezos was announced earlier this year, Ms. Bezos has pledged away more than half of her wealth in committing to the Giving Pledge.
lead_para: MacKenzie Bezos has promised to give more than half of her fortune to charity as part of the Giving Pledge, the organization said Tuesday. Ms. Bezos, whose divorce from the Amazon founder and chief executive Jeff Bezos made news earlier this year, was among 19 new signatories announced by the group.
headline: MacKenzie Bezos Owns $36 Billion in Amazon Shares. Now She Is Vowing to Give Away Much of Her Wealth.

abstract: “A Rainy Day in New York,” starring Timothée Chalamet and Elle Fanning, will be released in Italy on Oct. 3. German and Spanish distributors have confirmed they are releasing it.
lead_para: Woody Allen’s latest movie, “A Rainy Day in New York,” a romantic comedy starring Timothée Chalamet and Elle Fanning, was dropped by Amazon last year. There is no sign it will be released in the United States.
headline: Amazon Dropped Woody Allen’s Latest Film. Europe Has Picked It Up.

abstract: Three women near Minneapolis argue that Amazon retaliated against them after they protested their working conditions.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Three Somali women working for Amazon near Minneapolis have accused the company of creating a hostile environment for Muslim workers and of retaliating against them for protesting their work conditions, according to a filing submitted this week to federal regulators.
headline: 3 Muslim Workers at Amazon File Federal Discrimination Complaint

abstract: Big tech stocks including Microsoft have been leading the market higher, a rally that would have been hard to imagine at the end of 2018.
lead_para: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________
headline: Microsoft Touches $1 Trillion Value, Signaling Big Tech’s Stock Market Comeback

abstract: The company had long struggled to gain traction in China despite operating there for more than a decade.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon may dominate online shopping in the United States, but in the world’s second-largest economy it is all but calling it quits.
headline: Amazon Gives Up on Chinese Domestic Shopping Business

abstract: A years-long battle over control of the domain name, which included promises of free Kindles, may soon be decided.
lead_para: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Amazon is the world’s biggest online retailer. It is also the world’s largest rain forest.
headline: Battle for .amazon Domain Pits Retailer Against South American Nations

abstract: The Amazon series based on Michael Connelly’s Los Angeles detective novels returns for a fifth season of unadorned police work.
lead_para: With a dozen or so high-profile television series debuting over the next week — the usual number these days — you could reasonably ask why the fifth season of an old-fashioned cop show deserves attention. Isn’t there a woke comedy or an oddball Netflix import we could be talking about?
headline: Review: ‘Bosch’ Is Back, Still on the Straight and Narrow

abstract: Talks between TV and movie writers and their agencies on a new code of conduct broke off before a midnight deadline. “It has become clear a big change is necessary,” the Writers Guild of America said.
lead_para: LOS ANGELES — Fire your agents.
headline: Hollywood Upended as Unions Tell Writers to Fire Agents

abstract: What we found shows the technology’s promise — and perils.
lead_para: What we found shows the technology’s promise — and perils.
headline: We Built an ‘Unbelievable’ (but Legal) Facial Recognition Machine

abstract: Companies have said for decades that we should be in charge of our data. Why now, more than ever, does it seem like we aren’t?
lead_para: Companies have said for decades that we should be in charge of our data. Why now, more than ever, does it seem like we aren’t?
headline: Tech Companies Say They Care

abstract: We claim to want it, companies claim to provide it, but we all just accept that, well, you have no privacy online.
lead_para: We claim to want it, companies claim to provide it, but we all just accept that, well, you have no privacy online.
headline: It’s Time to Panic About Privacy

abstract: Congestion pricing and the tax breaks offered to Amazon were among the issues that Mayor Bill de Blasio was grilled on by fellow Democrats.
lead_para: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]
headline: On His Visit to Albany, de Blasio Gets a (Mostly) Hearty Embrace

abstract: The clash has consequences beyond New York, going to the heart of a national debate likely to dominate the 2020 election: What is the best way to spread prosperity?
lead_para: The political opposition that prompted Amazon to walk away from building a corporate headquarters in New York City featured a touchstone of the progressives’ economic agenda: ending tax policies that unfairly reward and pamper the wealthy.
headline: In Amazon Fight, Progressives Showed What They Want: A New Economic Agenda

abstract: The largest tech companies aren’t driving the performance of the market, and that shift doesn’t bode well for a march to new highs.
lead_para: One by one, the concerns that have hung over the stock market have faded.
headline: Big Tech Is No Longer Carrying the Stock Market

abstract: The company is compensating for slowing growth in e-commerce by expanding its fast-moving, highly profitable cloud and advertising businesses.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon held off stiffer competition for online shoppers during the holiday season, once again increasing its sales. But the company said on Thursday that growth slowed from its usual breakneck pace — and it came at a cost, with the company spending far more on shipping to win customers.
headline: Amazon’s Sales Growth Slows, Even as Cloud Business Stays Hot

abstract: For decades, Gavin de Becker has counseled governments, celebrities and countless readers on how to ward off threats and stay safe in a scary world.
lead_para: Gavin de Becker, Jeff Bezos’ longtime security chief, may run his own consulting firm, write books, operate a private luxury terminal at Los Angeles International Airport and develop threat-assessment tools.
headline: Gavin de Becker, Bezos’ Security Chief, Is a Guardian to the Stars

abstract: The Senate has tapped a vocal critic of Amazon, State Senator Michael Gianaris of Queens, to sit on a state board that could kill the deal.
lead_para: [Update: Amazon said that it was canceling plans to build a corporate campus in New York City.]
headline: Amazon Deal Meets New Resistance as Cuomo and N.Y. Senate Clash

abstract: Normally the web is a haven for the dark side. This time, the Amazon chief executive used it to let in the light.
lead_para: I cannot quite believe I am writing about Jeff Bezos’ sex life for the second time in two weeks, let alone about his penis. But Mr. Bezos brought all of himself back into the news on Thursday by writing a blockbuster post on Medium accusing American Media, which owns The National Enquirer, of blackmail. The post is addressed to David Pecker, the head of American Media, and titled, “No Thank You, Mr. Pecker.”
headline: Jeff Bezos Isn’t Afraid of Total Exposure

abstract: Amazon may not call it home. But the city, by design and because of its allure, is increasingly a magnet for coders and companies.
lead_para: Euan Robertson started his job with New York City’s economic development team at an ominous moment. It was Monday, Sept. 15, 2008, the day Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy and ignited the financial crisis.
headline: It Started With a Jolt: How New York Became a Tech Town

abstract: Ruth Messinger, a former Manhattan borough president, says democracy has been ill served.
lead_para: To the Editor:
headline: Amazon and the Autocrats

abstract: A lawsuit exposes how unnerved major insurers are by the Big Three’s new venture into health care benefits.
lead_para: Inside a federal courtroom in Boston this week, a bit of intrigue has emerged as lawyers try to pry open the secretive plans of a new venture created by three of the world’s most powerful corporations.
headline: Clash of Giants: UnitedHealth Takes On Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan Chase

abstract: What was once an extra is now a necessity, as companies give their employees free ice cream and beer, Pop-Tarts and prime rib — often with an agenda attached.
lead_para: Everyone who works at Ben & Jerry’s headquarters in Burlington, Vt., is entitled to three free pints of ice cream for each day of work. At the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative think tank in Washington, employees are treated daily to an elaborate buffet with appropriately white-shoe fare like prime rib, crab cakes and housemade beignets.
headline: There Is a Free Lunch, After All. It’s at the Office.

abstract: Companies repeat themselves in dull earnings reports. But when they make many changes in the text from year to year, it often signals trouble.
lead_para: Don’t blame Wall Street analysts, rank-and-file investors and journalists for failing to read corporate earnings reports from beginning to end.
headline: How Companies Like Apple Sprinkle Secrets in Earnings Reports

abstract: The move is the most ambitious effort yet by a tech company to fund construction for local teachers, firefighters and other middle- and low-income residents.
lead_para: SEATTLE — The Seattle area, home to both Microsoft and Amazon, is a potent symbol of the affordable housing crisis that has followed the explosive growth of tech hubs. Now Microsoft, arguing that the industry has an interest and responsibility to help people left behind in communities transformed by the boom, is putting up $500 million to help address the problem.
headline: Microsoft Pledges $500 Million for Affordable Housing in Seattle Area

abstract: A.I. that responds to your voice. Next-generation wireless networks. If this year’s biggest consumer technology trends have a familiar ring, there’s a reason for that.
lead_para: Imagine a future where you are never truly alone. Even when your spouse is on a business trip or your children are away at summer camp, you will always have someone (or something) to talk to. In the morning, you could ask the microwave to heat up a bowl of oatmeal. In your car, you could tell your stereo to put on some ’90s music. And when you walk into the office, you could ask your smartphone, “What’s on my calendar today?”
headline: Devices That Will Invade Your Life in 2019 (and What’s Overhyped)

abstract: Elizabeth Warren’s brushback pitch was aimed at candidates rich enough to self-fund their campaigns. But this kind of binary thinking is a slight to history.
lead_para: What would you do if you could spend a billion dollars a week on any cause, political movement or society-improving innovation of your choice and still have almost $20 billion left over after a year?
headline: Crazy Rich Progressives

abstract: The company is looking to improve its relationships in the city after the mostly disastrous rollout of its plans for a corporate campus in Queens.
lead_para: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]
headline: Amazon Has a New Strategy to Sway Skeptics in New York

abstract: The company said it would increase rates for its 58 million subscribers in the United States 13 to 18 percent, its biggest increase since it started its streaming service 12 years ago.
lead_para: Netflix is raising prices.
headline: Netflix Is Raising Prices. Here’s Why.

abstract: The financial details of the split are sure to be complicated, though the world’s richest man and his wife of 25 years vow to “remain cherished friends.”
lead_para: The Amazon founder Jeff Bezos and the novelist MacKenzie Bezos announced on Twitter on Wednesday that they are getting divorced after 25 years of marriage.
headline: Jeff Bezos of Amazon and MacKenzie Bezos Plan to Divorce

abstract: The online retail giant is taking advantage of what it knows better than anyone: consumers’ online shopping habits.
lead_para: SEATTLE — When a chain of physical therapy centers wanted new patients, it aimed online ads at people near its offices who had bought knee braces recently on Amazon.
headline: Amazon Knows What You Buy. And It’s Building a Big Ad Business From It.

abstract: Under pressure from small merchants, the Indian government is prohibiting Amazon and Walmart from selling products on their own sites.
lead_para: NEW DELHI — On Friday, Indian consumers will wake up to an emptier, more expensive version of Amazon’s shopping service.
headline: Amazon Users in India Will Get Less Choice and Pay More Under New Selling Rules

abstract: Millions of people have a stake in corporate America through mutual funds. But you may be surprised by how those funds are voting on your behalf.
lead_para: When somebody offers something for nothing, I don’t cheer. I reach in my pocket to see if my wallet is still there.
headline: Want a Bigger Say on Corporate Behavior? Move Your Money

abstract: Facebook, Microsoft, Twitter and others are spending millions on video game streaming to compete with Amazon’s Twitch in a fight to court millennials.
lead_para: Microsoft paid millions to lure a top video game streaming star. Facebook signed an exclusive streaming deal with the largest e-sports company in the world. Twitter streamed Fortnite’s collapse into a black hole.
headline: Why Twitch Is Still the King of Live Game Streaming

abstract: The manufacturer could announce its plans today for the troubled plane, which has been out of service since two deadly crashes.
lead_para: (Want this by email? Sign up here.)
headline: Boeing May Suspend 737 Max Production

abstract: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and other critics of an earlier proposal said a move to add offices in Manhattan proved them right.
lead_para: Amazon said on Friday that it would lease office space in Midtown Manhattan for more than 1,500 employees, increasing its presence in New York City less than a year after abandoning plans for a second headquarters in Queens in the face of stiff local opposition.
headline: Amazon Grows in New York, Reviving Debate Over Abandoned Queens Project

abstract: A reporter who has covered the tech industry for more than two decades explains how we may be entering a progressive era of antitrust.
lead_para: Each week, we review the week’s news, offering analysis about the most important developments in the tech industry.
headline: The Week in Tech: How Is Antitrust Enforcement Changing?

abstract: Every month, subscription streaming services add a new batch of titles to their libraries. Here are our picks for December.
lead_para: Watching is The New York Times’s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our twice-weekly newsletter here.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix, Apple TV Plus and More in December

abstract: It was a pretty sleepy week for business news, except for the brisk business done by Amazon, which broke all kinds of records. This coming week looks rather quiet, too, but don’t underestimate the economic fallout of several laws set to take effect on Jan. 1. In the meantime, have a happy New Year.
lead_para: It was a pretty sleepy week for business news, except for the brisk business done by Amazon, which broke all kinds of records. This coming week looks rather quiet, too, but don’t underestimate the economic fallout of several laws set to take effect on Jan. 1. In the meantime, have a happy New Year.
headline: The Week in Business: Amazon Won Christmas

abstract: Because nothing is just a gadget anymore.
lead_para: The optimistic view of the last 10 years of consumer technology is that hundreds of millions of people used unbelievable new devices and services to take part in explosive new economies and cultures.
headline: The Catastrophist’s 2019 Tech Gift Guide

abstract: The 2010s saw a radical shift in the trade balance when it comes to television series. Our critic counts down the finest imports, from “Fleabag” to “Strong Girl Bong-soon.”
lead_para: If streaming was the television story of the decade, then close behind was the explosion of global content that came to American screens to help fill all that new bandwidth. Shows suddenly appeared from all over the world, most noticeably financed or acquired by Netflix but also flooding in through a myriad of other streaming services and cable networks. Americans will read subtitles, it turns out. (I’d prefer to think no one’s choosing the dubbed English soundtracks.)
headline: The 30 Best International TV Shows of the Decade

abstract: Readers discuss how giant online stores like Amazon and rising rents have forced small entrepreneurs out of business.
lead_para: To the Editor:
headline: The Loss of Mom-and-Pop Stores That Can’t Compete With Amazon

abstract: In new tests, Amazon’s system had more difficulty identifying the gender of female and darker-skinned faces than similar services from IBM and Microsoft.
lead_para: Over the last two years, Amazon has aggressively marketed its facial recognition technology to police departments and federal agencies as a service to help law enforcement identify suspects more quickly. It has done so as another tech giant, Microsoft, has called on Congress to regulate the technology, arguing that it is too risky for companies to oversee on their own.
headline: Amazon Is Pushing Facial Technology That a Study Says Could Be Biased

abstract: A small and powerful society of Viners create Amazon’s reality. But is there such a thing as too much free stuff?
lead_para: A U.P.S. driver once said the house set his delivery record: 32 packages in one day. There have been bigger days since, and the burden is now spread across three carriers. Most of it falls to the local postal carriers. They used to make the rounds in a sedan until the sheer volume of packages delivered up the hill each week required them to upgrade to a truck. The boxes have slowed lately, but something arrives almost every day.
headline: The Secret Life of Amazon’s Vine Reviewers

abstract: Amazon and opponents of its new offices appeared to raise the specter that the deal that would bring 25,000 jobs to Queens is not yet finalized.
lead_para: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]
headline: Amazon’s New York Charm Offensive Includes a Veiled Threat

abstract: A British mini-series on Amazon Prime Video centers on a son of Pakistani immigrants whose wit, charm and courage make him a superior snitch.
lead_para: As the television reports a terrorist attack on the continent, Raza Shar, the British-born son of Pakistani immigrants, prepares to go out for a night on the town in London. “Anyone picks on you, don’t be brave,” his father admonishes him. “Tell him you’re a Hindu.” Raza rolls his eyes, nods and recites, “Don’t freak, I’m a Sikh.”
headline: Review: ‘Informer’ Finds a Fresh Take on the Terrorism Thriller

abstract: Even as Facebook, Google and others confronted challenges in 2018, their ambitions were undimmed. After all, so much of life remains undisrupted.
lead_para: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Silicon Valley ended 2018 somewhere it had never been: embattled.
headline: Big Tech May Look Troubled, but It’s Just Getting Started

abstract: Her divorce from the Amazon founder Jeff Bezos has made this novelist, and her private life, a public fascination.
lead_para: In her 25 years of marriage to Jeff Bezos, MacKenzie Bezos has been a loyal ambassador for Amazon, the company that made her and her husband the richest couple in the world.
headline: Who Is MacKenzie Scott?

abstract: Package theft has also soared in cities like Denver and Washington. The increase has frustrated shoppers and led to creative measures for thwarting thieves.
lead_para: Online deliveries to an apartment building in northern Manhattan are left with a retired woman in 2H who watches over her neighbors’ packages to make sure nothing gets stolen.
headline: 90,000 Packages Disappear Daily in N.Y.C. Is Help on the Way?

abstract: TV’s streaming wars are a global contest, and this year India became one of the most hotly contested fronts.
lead_para: With companies like Netflix and Amazon seeking ever larger international customer bases, one thing that distinguishes the streaming wars from previous TV conflicts is the global scale. And in 2019, India became one of the most hotly contested fronts.
headline: In 2019, Netflix and Amazon Set Their Sights on India

abstract: In Campbellsville, Ky., the tech giant’s influences abound. The profits, not so much.
lead_para: CAMPBELLSVILLE, Ky. — In the late 1990s, the town of Campbellsville in central Kentucky suffered a powerful jolt when its Fruit of the Loom textile plant closed. Thousands of jobs making underwear went to Central America, taking the community’s pride with them.
headline: Prime Anchor: An Amazon Warehouse Town Dreams of a Better Life

abstract: After two nonprofits delivered 23,000 signatures to Amazon asking it to remove skin-bleaching products with high levels of mercury, the company listened.
lead_para: Dark skin can be heavy to walk around in. It is not widely represented in movies or television. Black Americans with darker complexions are more likely to say they experience frequent racism. And dark-skinned women around the world are flooded with advertising telling them that white is beautiful.
headline: Fight Against Colorism Takes On Amazon: Beauty ‘Cannot Be One Skin Color’

abstract: The Swedish retailer now lets customers know where nearly every garment it sells is made. Is that enough?
lead_para: The H&M group sells  an estimated three billion articles of clothing per year. Its revenue makes it among the top three fashion retailers in the world.
headline: H&M’s Different Kind of Clickbait

abstract: Giant tech stocks have posted a remarkable year, shrugging off the trade war, bipartisan political hostility and regulatory threats.
lead_para: It was December 2018, and the towering giants of tech were looking wobbly.
headline: Big Tech Is Under Attack, and Investors Couldn’t Care Less

abstract: T. Rowe Price led a new funding round for the start-up, a potential competitor to Tesla that was already backed by Amazon and Ford.
lead_para: Rivian, an electric-vehicle start-up that has drawn an impressive roster of backers, announced Monday that it had received a $1.3 billion investment led by T. Rowe Price, the mutual fund company.
headline: Rivian Gets $1.3 Billion Investment in Electric Truck Venture

abstract: The company gets that many daily submissions to edit descriptions and details about products for sale on its site. How does it keep up?
lead_para: Each week, we review the week’s news, offering analysis about the most important developments in the tech industry.
headline: The Week in Tech: What 5 Billion Means to Amazon

abstract: Algorithms falsely identified African-American and Asian faces 10 to 100 times more than Caucasian faces, researchers for the National Institute of Standards and Technology found.
lead_para: The majority of commercial facial-recognition systems exhibit bias, according to a study from a federal agency released on Thursday, underscoring questions about a technology increasingly used by police departments and federal agencies to identify suspected criminals.
headline: Many Facial-Recognition Systems Are Biased, Says U.S. Study

abstract: Our picks for January, including “Bojak Horseman,” “Uncut Gems” and “True History of the Kelly Gang.”
lead_para: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are our picks for January.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in January

abstract: The new movie, filmed in Cuba with the director Hiro Murai, will start streaming Saturday on Amazon after being shown at Coachella.
lead_para: Headlining the Coachella festival on Friday night apparently is not enough for Donald Glover. The actor and musician, who performs as Childish Gambino, will also release “Guava Island,” a long-rumored movie that Glover and Rihanna filmed over four weeks in Cuba.
headline: Donald Glover and Rihanna’s ‘Guava Island’: Here’s What We Know

abstract: At its heart, privacy is about how data is used to take away our control.
lead_para: This article is part of a limited-run newsletter. You can sign up here.
headline: Privacy Is Too Big to Understand

abstract: Most revenue still comes from website sales, but other services, including cloud computing and advertising, provide an outsize chunk of profits.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon grew into a giant by selling everything under the sun. Its strongest growth lately has been in the cloud.
headline: Amazon Expanding One-Day Prime Shipping as Sales Growth Slows

abstract: Every month, subscription streaming services add a new batch of titles to their libraries. Here are the ones we think are most interesting for April.
lead_para: Watching is The New York Times’s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our twice-weekly newsletter here.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and More in April

abstract: For a decade, value stocks have failed to surge ahead. Investing in them may be a smart move, but it is likely to require patience.
lead_para: In the never-ending tug-of-war between growth and value investing, growth has lately been the strong-armed winner.
headline: In the Stock Market, Value Again Lags Growth

abstract: The musician and TV creator’s new project, a 55-minute film with Rihanna, is available now to stream on Amazon.
lead_para: “Guava Island,” a new 55-minute film starring Donald Glover and Rihanna, was released as a limited-time free stream on Amazon overnight Saturday, during Glover’s headlining set as Childish Gambino at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival.
headline: Donald Glover’s ‘Guava Island’ Debuts After Coachella Set as Childish Gambino

abstract: The romance novelist Cristiane Serruya has been accused of copying passages from dozens of writers.
lead_para: The writer Nora Roberts on Wednesday sued a Brazilian romance novelist for copyright infringement, accusing her of copying or paraphrasing material from 10 of Ms. Roberts’s books.
headline: Nora Roberts Sues Brazilian Writer Who She Says Plagiarized Her Work

abstract: The announcement comes amid a rising backlash to cashless stores, and new laws against them in New Jersey and Philadelphia.
lead_para: The salad chain Sweetgreen said Thursday that it would start accepting legal tender, amid a growing backlash to “cashless” stores around the country. The move came on the heels of Amazon Go’s confirmation this month that it, too, would begin taking cash.
headline: Sweetgreen Scraps Its Cashless Policy as Criticism Grows

abstract: At least 25 prominent researchers are calling on the company to stop selling the technology to law enforcement agencies, citing concerns that it has built-in biases.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — At least 25 prominent artificial-intelligence researchers, including experts at Google, Facebook, Microsoft and a recent winner of the prestigious Turing Award, have signed a letter calling on Amazon to stop selling its facial-recognition technology to law enforcement agencies because it is biased against women and people of color.
headline: A.I. Experts Question Amazon’s Facial-Recognition Technology

abstract: It is a show whose budgets and scale were once unthinkable for television — and now it’s become the gold standard.
lead_para: In the eight years since “Game of Thrones” went on the air, the television industry has been upended. We can thank Netflix for that.
headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Changed TV. Let Us Count the Ways.

abstract: From ‘Veronica Mars’ to ‘Stranger Things,’ 22 new and returning TV shows to put on your calendar.
lead_para: More more more. However you like it, television has it this summer: “Four Weddings and a Funeral” reinterpreted by Mindy Kaling, Meryl Streep joining the beach party on “Big Little Lies,” new adventures from “Stranger Things,” continuing horrors on “The Handmaid’s Tale” and — for those with specialized tastes — a barely recognizable Russell Crowe playing Roger Ailes in “The Loudest Voice.” From more than 50 new and old shows premiering over the next three months, here are 22 to check out, in my own order of anticipation — beginning with a new chapter of a modern classic that made our list of the best dramas since “The Sopranos.” All dates subject to change.
headline: Here’s What to Watch on TV This Summer

abstract: Shareholders are voting on whether to push the tech giant to examine the human rights and financial risks of the surveillance technology.
lead_para: Facial recognition software is coming under increasing scrutiny from civil liberties groups and lawmakers. Now Amazon, one of the most visible purveyors of the technology, is facing pressure from another corner as well: its own shareholders.
headline: Amazon Faces Investor Pressure Over Facial Recognition

abstract: The resolutions, voted on by shareholders, would have pushed the company to reconsider its societal impact.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon said on Wednesday that its shareholders had voted down proposals that would have pushed the company to reconsider its societal impact in two key areas: facial recognition and climate change.
headline: Amazon Investors Reject Proposals on Climate Change and Facial Recognition

abstract: Everything you need to know from Season 1, just in time for the long-awaited Season 2.
lead_para: It’s been a long time since the first season of the dark British comedy series “Fleabag” arrived in the U.S. on Amazon Prime Video — nearly three years, in fact. The creator and star Phoebe Waller-Bridge has been busy in that time, launching the hit thriller “Killing Eve” and reviving the stage version of “Fleabag” for Off Broadway audiences, but the wait is finally over.
headline: ‘Fleabag’ Is (Finally) Back. Here’s a Refresher.

abstract: The algorithms know what we’ll do, but not why we do it. At least not yet.
lead_para: This article is part of a limited-run newsletter. You can sign up here.
headline: The Reason You Hate Online Ads

abstract: The A.C.L.U. of Massachusetts says we should be concerned about violations of privacy.
lead_para: To the Editor:
headline: Amazon’s Facial Recognition Technology

abstract: Children’s groups say the tech giant’s Echo Dot Kids device violated a federal law protecting youngsters’ online privacy. Amazon disagrees.
lead_para: Amazon barreled into the children’s smart-speaker market last year with a brightly colored device called Echo Dot Kids Edition. The tech giant played up the device as a simple way for youngsters to converse with Alexa, the company’s voice-activated virtual assistant, and obtain age-appropriate apps.
headline: Amazon Flunks Children’s Privacy, Advocacy Groups Charge

abstract: Phoebe Waller-Bridge is better than ever in the ribald, rapid-fire, sacrilegious second season of her dark comedy.
lead_para: There’s a “previously on” introduction to Season 2 of Amazon’s “Fleabag,” which you may need given that Season 1 appeared nearly three years ago. But you could also let the title character (Phoebe Waller-Bridge) catch you up, in her usual rapid-fire mode, as she explains to a therapist (Fiona Shaw) why her father asked her to seek counseling:
headline: Review: As She Was Saying, Brilliantly, in a New ‘Fleabag’

abstract: Regulators should take a close look at the iPhone App Store.
lead_para: Of the 17 most popular screen-time and parental-control apps in the App Store, 11 have been removed or restricted by Apple. The app makers believe they are being punished for competing with Apple’s own screen-time control tools, or worse, for weaning people off Apple devices. Many of the apps had more stringent controls than Apple’s in-house alternatives. Apple says that the applications — specifically, the parental-control apps — were removed because of their use of Mobile Device Management, a technology that gave third parties access to information such as “user location, app use, email accounts, camera permissions and browsing history.” In other words, Apple says it removed the apps to protect the privacy of the children and parents who installed them.
headline: Why Does Apple Control Its Competitors?

abstract: Amazon wants to sell ads. Google wants to woo shoppers. Their ambitions are putting the tech giants on a collision course.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — For years, Google and Amazon stuck to their strengths. Google’s search monopoly and universe of online services seemed to present little overlap with Amazon’s web commerce empire.
headline: Attention, Amazon Shoppers: Google Wants Some of Your Spending Money

abstract: Labor groups aiming to organize a Staten Island warehouse were in talks with the company a day before it abandoned plans for a Queens headquarters.
lead_para: When Amazon announced Thursday that it was abandoning plans for an additional corporate headquarters in New York, no one was more surprised than the union leaders who were in talks with the company the day before.
headline: Amazon and New York Unions Had ‘Productive Meeting,’ Then Came a Shock

abstract: In terms of economic, political and cultural impact, the finance industry dominates. But tech is gaining fast, and is where much of the growth is.
lead_para: In terms of economic, political and cultural impact, the finance industry dominates. But tech is gaining fast, and is where much of the growth is.
headline: Even Without Amazon, Tech Could Keep Gaining Ground in New York

abstract: After community backlash, Amazon has decided not to move forward with its plan to open a headquarters in Long Island City, Queens. Here’s a look at what happened.
lead_para: After community backlash, Amazon has decided not to move forward with its plan to open a headquarters in Long Island City, Queens. Here’s a look at what happened.
headline: Why the New York Amazon Deal Fell Apart

abstract: A primer on the players and plot points in a fight that erupted on Thursday in accusations of extortion.
lead_para: A surprise divorce announcement by the world’s richest man, steamy texts, a private investigation, claims of blackmail — and a suspicion that politics are behind it all. These aren’t plot points in a movie coming soon to Amazon Prime. They’re the increasingly surprising events swirling around Jeff Bezos, the Amazon founder.
headline: Jeff Bezos vs. The National Enquirer: How a Tabloid Tale Escalated, and Exploded

abstract: Plus, tax season brings bad news, and the Fed offers more clues about its change of heart.
lead_para: Do you have Presidents’ Day off? I hope so, and that you’re spending it someplace warm and dry, even if that’s just a nest of pillows your living room. The third week of February is the peak of winter drear, in my opinion, and we could all use a break from the gray skies and interminable drama in Washington. Whether you’re heading into a short workweek or not, here’s what to know when it starts, from the latest on President Trump and the wall to the market outlook from the billionaire investor Warren Buffett, and other business and tech news.
headline: The Week in Business: Amazon Breaks Up With New York, and Warren Buffett Takes Stock

abstract: Eric Ulrich, one of two Republicans among 17 candidates for public advocate, may be well positioned to gather votes among those angry at Amazon’s exit.
lead_para: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]
headline: Can a Republican Win a Citywide Race in N.Y.? Maybe, With Amazon’s Help

abstract: Plus, predatory lenders get a boost, and President Trump won’t meet with his counterpart in China — yet.
lead_para: Are you a Valentine’s Day person? If not, welcome to a growing club of detractors. Only 51 percent of Americans plan to celebrate the “holiday” in 2019, according to the National Retail Federation, marking a 12-year downward trend. But if you are an observer, how nice — for your loved ones. Retailers are expecting you to spend a record amount on presents this season (an average of $161.96, up 13 percent from 2018). At least you die-hard romantics are making up for the rest of us. Speaking of gifts, here’s mine to you: All you need to know about the latest business and tech news, gathered into one email that’ll set you up for the week ahead. Chocolates sold separately.
headline: The Week in Business: Jeff Bezos’ Private Texts, and More ‘Fog’ in London

abstract: The region has its act together and knows what it is doing, officials said.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — When Amazon canceled its plans to build an expansive corporate campus in New York City this week, officials more than 200 miles away in Northern Virginia decided to make a statement.
headline: Northern Virginia Is Keeping Amazon’s 25,000 Jobs, and Wants You to Know It

abstract: The governor of New York has called Mr. Bezos and other Amazon executives to persuade them to resurrect their plan to build a campus in Long Island City.
lead_para: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]
headline: Andrew Cuomo Speaks With Jeff Bezos, Hints of ‘Other Ways’ to Clear Path for Amazon’s Return

abstract: A cross-cultural murder mystery pairs John Simm and Anthony Wong, two of their respective film industries most dependable performers.
lead_para: In “White Dragon,” new to Amazon Prime Video on Friday, the hero is a London university lecturer named Jonah Mulray. Since the show is a dark, complicated, tortured-family mystery set in Hong Kong, his name can’t help but call to mind the neo-noir touchstone “Chinatown” and its doomed Mulwrays.
headline: Review: Hong Kong Tourist-Noir in Amazon’s ‘White Dragon’

abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo increased pressure on critics of the planned campus in Queens as executives inside the company chafed at new roadblocks.
lead_para: [Update: Amazon said it was canceling plans to build a corporate campus in New York City.]
headline: Amazon HQ2 Deal Stirs New Tensions in New York

abstract: The director may have a tarnished reputation in the United States, but he has been able to secure funding from a Barcelona-based company for a new project.
lead_para: Just weeks after suing Amazon for canceling a four-movie deal, Woody Allen is working on a new film in Spain.
headline: Woody Allen Is Shooting a New Movie in Spain

abstract: The paper, which has flourished under Mr. Bezos’ ownership, is now reporting on his dispute with another publisher, American Media Inc.
lead_para: Jeff Bezos says owning The Washington Post is a “complexifier” for him. The newspaper could say the same about him.
headline: Washington Post Finds Itself in the Middle of the Jeff Bezos Story

abstract: In Ohio, where companies like FirstEnergy and Goodyear pay no federal corporate taxes, Democrats haven’t figured out how to leverage anxiety over income inequality to defeat President Trump.
lead_para: AKRON, Ohio — Colin Robertson wonders why he pays federal taxes on the $18,000 a year he makes cleaning carpets, while the tech giant Amazon got a tax rebate.
headline: Profitable Giants Like Amazon Pay $0 in Corporate Taxes. Some Voters Are Sick of It.

abstract: The grocery chain’s “Whole Paycheck” reputation doesn’t appear to be threatened.
lead_para: After buying Whole Foods in 2017, Amazon made a couple of bold pronouncements about lowering prices at the grocery chain. It made a third this week, saying that it was offering lower prices on hundreds of items, especially fresh produce, without going into much detail. It is also giving more special discounts to people signed up for Prime, the company’s membership service.
headline: Whole Foods Cut Prices. It Saved Us 5 Cents.

abstract: They say Amazon should stop offering custom cloud computing services that help the oil and gas industry explore for and extract more fossil fuels.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Employees at big tech companies have pushed back against their employers for working with the military and law enforcement offices, and demanded better treatment of women and minorities.
headline: Over 4,200 Amazon Workers Push for Climate Change Action, Including Cutting Some Ties to Big Oil

abstract: Plus, Boeing’s plane problems are adding up, and Facebook prepares for a big fine — or a slap on the wrist?
lead_para: Because nothing heads off the Sunday night blues like feeling prepared to deal with know-it-all co-workers, here’s your weekly catch-up on all the tech and business news you missed, plus the important stuff for the week ahead. Enjoy the rest of your day.
headline: The Week in Business: Tesla’s Driverless Taxis and Uber’s I.P.O.

abstract: Mr. Bezos will keep 75 percent of the couple’s stock in Amazon and all of their ownership of The Washington Post and Blue Origin space company, Ms. Bezos wrote.
lead_para: Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s founder and chief executive, and his wife, MacKenzie Bezos, said on Twitter on Thursday that they had finalized the details of their divorce.
headline: Jeff Bezos, Amazon C.E.O., and MacKenzie Bezos Finalize Divorce Details

abstract: Amazon’s “Made in Heaven” complicates the glamour of wealthy Indian weddings by confronting patriarchy, homophobia and class.

abstract: It’s not Lyft or Didi Chuxing or another ride-hailing firm. Instead, Uber sees itself as the Amazon of transportation.

abstract: Amazon filed a motion saying the company was “justified in terminating its relationship with Allen.”
lead_para: Amazon Studios returned fire on Woody Allen on Wednesday, saying in a court filing that it was “justified in terminating” movie deals with the filmmaker and pointing to his public comments about the #MeToo movement as proof.

abstract: The cloud computing project, known as JEDI, is one of the largest federal information technology contracts in history.
lead_para: The Pentagon said Wednesday that Amazon and Microsoft were the final candidates for a hotly contested $10 billion contract to bring modern cloud computing to the Defense Department.

abstract: Three top-performing funds each racked up returns of more than 25 percent, helped by bets on small- and mid-cap growth stocks.
lead_para: Three of the first quarter’s top-performing mutual funds won big by favoring small- and midcap growth stocks, toting up quarterly returns of 25 percent or more.

abstract: Neighborhood-watch networks are on the rise, even though crime is not. Here’s how to put the data into perspective.

headline: Amazon Will Pay Workers to Quit and Start Their Own Delivery Businesses

abstract: The futuristic Amazon Go faces the city’s notoriously brusque customers, not to mention its shoplifters. Still, the company is hopeful.

abstract: Also: Worries about another war, and the continuing crisis at Boeing.

headline: The Week in Business: A Facial Recognition Ban, and Trade War Blues

abstract: The $575 million investment strengthens one of the biggest overseas rivals to Uber’s food-delivery division, which the ride-hailing company considers a key business.

headline: Amazon to Invest in Deliveroo, a Rival to Uber in Food Delivery

abstract: Virtual helpers that come with female voices by default are perpetuating bias, a Unesco report argues.
lead_para: Why do most virtual assistants that are powered by artificial intelligence — like Apple’s Siri and Amazon’s Alexa system — by default have female names, female voices and often a submissive or even flirtatious style?
headline: Siri and Alexa Reinforce Gender Bias, U.N. Finds

abstract: J. David Goodman, a metro reporter, has chronicled the Google and Amazon invasions. But the most effective technology for reporting on the city is still coffee.
lead_para: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? J. David Goodman, a metro reporter, discussed the tech he’s using.
headline: Tech Is Changing New York, but Not How He Reports on the City

abstract: A bottle opener, a mouse pad and other products displayed images of the Nazi concentration camp.
lead_para: Amazon on Sunday removed from its marketplace holiday ornaments, a bottle opener and other products displaying images of the Nazi concentration camp Auschwitz after the Auschwitz-Birkenau Memorial and Museum in Poland shared images of the products on social media, prompting widespread outrage.
headline: Amazon Removes Holiday Ornaments With Images of Auschwitz After Criticism

abstract: His publicist had blamed a “health crisis” for the actor’s death last month. On Tuesday, the authorities cited fentanyl, heroin, diazepam and cocaine.
lead_para: The death of the “Marvelous Mrs. Maisel” actor Brian Tarantina last month was caused by an accidental drug overdose, the medical examiner’s office in New York said on Tuesday.
headline: Brian Tarantina, ‘Marvelous Mrs. Maisel’ Actor, Died of Overdose, Medical Examiner Says

abstract: Representative David Cicilline doesn’t just want to enforce the laws governing the tech industry. He wants to change them.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — At a hearing this summer about the rising power of the country’s biggest tech companies, Representative David Cicilline zeroed in on Amazon. Unhappy with a response from one of the company’s top lawyers, he delivered a biting retort.
headline: This Man May Be Big Tech’s Biggest Threat

abstract: New York will allow Amazon, DHL and UPS to park cargo bikes in commercial loading zones as a way to get some trucks off the city’s gridlocked streets.
lead_para: Delivery trucks and vans laden with online packages are putting a stranglehold on New York City streets and filling its air with pollutants.

abstract: How two nonprofits took on Amazon and won, hand-clapping games from around the world and wedding websites that promise to stop romanticizing weddings at former slave plantations.
lead_para: Now that Thanksgiving has whizzed by, the holiday shopping season is in full swing, which sometimes means stolen packages. Here’s a look at how many disappear on a regular basis and other stories you may missed from this past week.

abstract: The 118 feature-length movies selected for the indie festival include Julianne Moore as Gloria Steinem and a documentary on Parkland survivors.
lead_para: The Oscar winners Julianne Moore and Alicia Vikander are two of the four actresses who play the feminist activist Gloria Steinem at different ages in “The Glorias,” an unconventional biopic from the director Julia Taymor. The film will be among the 118 feature-length works at the 2020 Sundance Film Festival, the programmers announced Wednesday.
headline: Sundance Gets Real, With a Lineup of Newsy Films for 2020

abstract: The push for quick deliveries from internet retailers has worsened gridlock and pollution. Packages are also luring thieves.

abstract: Twenty years ago, Amazon opened its storefront to anyone who wanted to sell something. Then it began demanding more out of them.
lead_para: SEATTLE — For tens of millions of Americans, it is so routine that they don’t think twice.
headline: Prime Power: How Amazon Squeezes the Businesses Behind Its Store

abstract: Software start-ups have a phrase for what Amazon is doing to them: ‘strip-mining’ them of their innovations.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Elastic, a software start-up in Amsterdam, was rapidly building its business and had grown to 100 employees. Then Amazon came along.
headline: Prime Leverage: How Amazon Wields Power in the Technology World

abstract: In a legal complaint, Amazon said the president had attacked it behind the scenes to harm its C.E.O., Jeff Bezos, “his perceived political enemy.”
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon said in a legal complaint unsealed on Monday that it had lost a $10 billion cloud computing contract with the Pentagon because President Trump used “improper pressure” to divert the contract from the company to harm its chief executive, Jeff Bezos.
headline: Amazon Accuses Trump of ‘Improper Pressure’ on JEDI Contract

abstract: Home innovations like smart microwaves and toilets could lock us into a digital caste system.
lead_para: A few months ago, Amazon invited reporters to its Spheres complex in downtown Seattle. It’s an enormous greenhouse doubling as a work space for employees: a climate-controlled, glass-enclosed, self-contained ecosystem made up of 40,000 species of plants from all over the world. Amazon executives opened the event with a statement worthy of their surroundings: The company had 70 products, services and tools to introduce. Seventy new products?  The journalists in the room responded with gasps and laughter.
headline: Are You an Amazon or an Apple Family?

abstract: Reviled in the ’50s, embraced in the ’60s, the Humphrey Bogart vehicle “Beat the Devil” is still spry at 65.
lead_para: John Huston’s “Beat the Devil,” the Humphrey Bogart vehicle once advertised as a decade ahead of its time, is now an official senior citizen, having opened in New York 65 years ago this month.
headline: ‘Beat the Devil,’ the Bogart Flop That Spawned a Cult

abstract: A host of regulatory issues have slowed the progress of drone-delivery companies but they are making some progress and lots of tests are underway.
lead_para: If you’ve been worrying that drones would be filling the skies over your head, dropping packages off day after day at your neighbor’s house, leaving food on doorsteps or photographing your every move, you can relax a little. At least for now.
headline: Skies Aren’t Clogged With Drones Yet, but Don’t Rule Them Out

abstract: The budget takes up thousands of pages and billions of dollars, and will change the way New Yorkers vote, shop, commute and more. Here is a look at what’s included, what’s not and who is responsible.

abstract: The company wants its voice assistant to become a bigger part of more people’s lives.

headline: Amazon Bets on an Empathetic Alexa

abstract: The creators of a fairy-tale action film expand it into an eight-episode series by removing the fairy tale.
lead_para: “Hanna,” released in 2011, was not a film that called out for a remake or a sequel. It had a singular style, and a delicacy — despite its frequent beatdowns and gun battles — that would suffer from duplication. Bookended by parallel killings, it was a self-contained chronicle of an obsessive and successful quest for revenge that left no important questions unanswered.
headline: Review: Amazon’s ‘Hanna,’ Genetically Modified for Streaming Video

abstract: Amazon often plays politics with a distinctive message: Give us what we want, or we’ll leave and take our jobs elsewhere.
lead_para: SEATTLE — When Texas officials pushed Amazon to pay nearly $270 million in back sales taxes in 2010, Amazon responded by closing its only warehouse in the state and scrapping expansion plans there. Two years later, the officials agreed to waive the past taxes in exchange for Amazon opening new warehouses.
headline: Amazon’s Hard Bargain Extends Far Beyond New York

abstract: Every month, subscription streaming services add a new batch of titles to their libraries. Here are the ones we think are most interesting for March.

abstract: Software looks to be at the heart of the recent Ethiopian Airlines crash. Safety approval of such systems will only get harder as technology advances.

headline: The Week in Tech: Our Future Robots Will Need Super-Smart Safety Checks

abstract: His tweets criticize Facebook and Google, but the Antitrust Division of the Justice Department is making life easier for potential monopolists in Silicon Valley.
lead_para: At his Senate confirmation hearing, Attorney General William Barr signaled an interest in confronting the power of big tech corporations like Facebook and Google. As Mr. Barr put it, a lot “of people wonder how such huge behemoths that now exist in Silicon Valley have taken shape under the nose of the antitrust enforcers.” And since taking office, President Trump has repeatedly attacked America’s biggest technology corporations, especially Amazon, Facebook and Google. Among other accusations, he has charged Amazon with ripping off the Post Office and Google with  censoring conservative users. He recently criticized Facebook, Google and Twitter for “ridiculous” bias in favor of Democrats. By most appearances, Mr. Trump is a foe of big tech.
headline: Trump’s Big Tech Bluster

abstract: Low-income workers seem to want Amazon in New York more than elites do. Amazon should figure out how to give them what they really need.

abstract: If American Media is found to have broken a law, it would be in violation of a deal struck with federal prosecutors in connection to hush money paid to protect Donald Trump.
lead_para: Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon and the owner of The Washington Post, did not become the world’s richest man by refusing to do what it takes to win. And now that he finds himself in a mud fight with the supermarket tabloid that exposed his extramarital affair, he is showing off the same drive that helped him turn a simple idea — selling books on the internet — into an all-purpose, $780 billion powerhouse.

abstract: Huge incentive packages are a burden for taxpayers. Other cities should follow New York’s lead.

abstract: A one-in-a-billion chance: a heroic billionaire.

abstract: Once a generation, Hollywood experiences a seismic shift. It is happening again.
lead_para: LOS ANGELES — Every three decades, or roughly once a generation, Hollywood experiences a seismic shift. The transition from silent films to talkies in the 1920s. The rise of broadcast television in the 1950s. The raucous “I Want My MTV” cable boom of the 1980s.
headline: The Streaming Era Has Finally Arrived. Everything Is About to Change.

abstract: Researchers say computer systems are learning from lots and lots of digitized books and news articles that could bake old attitudes into new technology.

abstract: There is a lot to learn from mistakes that the Continent’s regulators have made, say consumer groups, lawyers and rival companies.

abstract: We may not know our neighbors very well, but video cameras and social platforms can reveal a lot more than any of us suspect.

abstract: Based on the New York Times column of the same name, the Amazon anthology series is the TV equivalent of an Instagrammable latte.
lead_para: It’s fitting that Amazon’s “Modern Love,” which debuts Friday and draws its stories from the New York Times column of the same name, puts forward the best version of itself in the very beginning. No one who has ever dated needs reminding that first impressions can be misleading, but the solid narrative skills and excellent casting on display in the premiere episode help prop up the wispier aspects of this inconsistent but sometimes charming anthology series.
