abstract: “Queer Eye” is back, along with Jack Ryan and a great Canadian sketch comedy series.
lead_para: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every week for new suggestions on what to watch.
headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?

abstract: The company has been investing heavily to keep its giant core businesses growing at the expense of higher profits.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon is back in the business of buying growth.
headline: Amazon’s Profit Falls Sharply as Company Buys Growth

abstract: John Herrman, who writes about the internet, is using many of the same tech tools as a decade ago — but the conversation around how we use them has changed.
lead_para: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? John Herrman, a reporter for the Styles desk who covers the internet, discussed the tech he’s using.
headline: The Tools for Covering Tech Are the Same as in 2009

abstract: It’s time for lawmakers to step back in, carefully.
lead_para: Tech regulation may be the only thing on which a polarized Capitol Hill can agree. “We should be suing Google and Facebook and all that, and perhaps we will,” President Trump recently declared. Senator Elizabeth Warren, a Democratic presidential candidate, has made the breakup of tech companies a central plank of her campaign. Even Silicon Valley-friendly contenders like Pete Buttigieg have called for curbs on the industry’s power.
headline: Letting the Internet Regulate Itself Was a Good Idea — in the 1990s

abstract: The agency said it would look into concerns about anticompetitive behavior by some of the industry’s biggest companies.
lead_para: The federal government has turned its full investigative powers toward examining the world’s biggest technology companies, building on a backlash against the industry that has been growing for over a year.
headline: Justice Department Opens Antitrust Review of Big Tech Companies

abstract: A British regulator ordered that an Amazon-led cash infusion into the food-delivery start-up be paused to study whether it creates competition concerns.
lead_para: LONDON — Britain’s competition regulator said on Friday that it had begun an investigation into a $575 million investment led by Amazon in the London-based food-delivery service Deliveroo, the latest effort by a government to potentially check the reach of a technology giant.
headline: Amazon’s Deliveroo Investment Is Halted for U.K. Scrutiny

abstract: Lawmakers had strong questions and criticism for tech giants yesterday during three hearings on Capitol Hill. Here’s what happened.
lead_para: Good Wednesday. The Elon Musk-backed company Neuralink unveiled its plans to wire your brain to the internet last night — more on that below. (Want this by email? Sign up here.)
headline: DealBook Briefing: Big Tech’s Tough Day in D.C.

abstract: Three of the second quarter’s better-performing mutual funds found winning investments in industries as varied as child care, animal health and banking.
lead_para: Tweets and talk may have recently raged about trade wars and rising interest rates, but that pessimism didn’t hamper three of the second quarter’s better-performing mutual funds. They found winning investments with bets as varied as child care, pet health and banking.
headline: Day Care and Dog Care Helped Plump These Funds’ Returns

abstract: The proposed levies on firms like Facebook and Google are pitting traditional allies against one another and threatening to set off a cascade of tax increases and tariffs.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — For most of the 21st century, wealthy nations have engaged in a race to the bottom on corporate taxes, cutting rates in an effort to poach business activity across borders. Very quickly, that script has flipped.
headline: As Nations Look to Tax Tech Firms, U.S. Scrambles to Broker a Deal

abstract: The master filmmaker’s “Summer Interlude,” “Summer With Monika” and “Smiles of a Summer Night” evoke the transitory happiness of the brief, intense Nordic summer.
lead_para: The fleeting Nordic summer, a respite from the darkness of interminable winter, is “the loveliest time of the year,” the Swedish author Selma Lagerlof wrote, with some understatement, in “The Story of Gosta Berling”: “Everything was beautiful. The road, gray and dusty as it was, had its border of flowers.” Even “the smallest child went on the road with a bunch of lilacs in her hand, and every peasant woman had a little bouquet stuck in her neckerchief.”
headline: Ingmar Bergman’s Summer Movies Raise the Temperature

abstract: Plus, the Trump administration has a big job opening, and there’s a new technology tax.
lead_para: Whether you’re just coming back from a summer vacation, in the midst of one or not taking any time off, you’ve probably been too busy marveling at Megan Rapinoe to stay on top of business and tech news this week. Don’t worry — we’re here to catch you up.
headline: The Week in Business: Amazon Won’t Let the Robots Take Over

abstract: The team behind “Preacher” brings a new comic-book adaptation to Amazon Prime Video. It’s sort of like “Watchmen” with jokes.
lead_para: The team of Evan Goldberg and Seth Rogen (producers) and Garth Ennis (comics writer) has given us AMC’s “Preacher,” the most inventive, audacious and purely entertaining comics-based series of the past few years. With “Preacher” on the way out — its final season begins Aug. 4 — the three are getting right back in the game, with a new show based on an Ennis comic, “The Boys,” coming to Amazon Prime Video on Friday.
headline: Review: ‘The Boys’ Deconstructs the Superhero, With a Light Touch

abstract: The Amazon and Facebook leaders were there for different reasons, but the appearances highlighted their companies’ need to reshape the public debate about their practices.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Two of the technology industry’s leading figures descended on Washington on Thursday as their companies face growing political pressure.
headline: Bezos and Zuckerberg Take Their Pitches to Washington

abstract: Senators at a hearing pushed for assurances that the F.T.C. and Justice Department would provide vigorous oversight of the companies.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Senators pressed top antitrust regulators on Tuesday to aggressively investigate the power of the country’s biggest tech companies, with some lawmakers questioning whether the officials had the will or resources to take on Silicon Valley’s richest businesses.
headline: Lawmakers Urge Aggressive Action From Regulators on Big Tech

abstract: If regulators and lawmakers are serious, they’re going to have to rethink a traditional approach to monopolies.
lead_para: Each week, we review the week’s news, offering analysis about the most important developments in the tech industry.
headline: The Week in Tech: An Emerging Twist on Antitrust

abstract: While Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google have all drawn attention to how they dominate markets, the reasons are as different as the companies.
lead_para: Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google have been the envy of corporate America, admired for their size, influence and remarkable growth.
headline: How Each Big Tech Company May Be Targeted by Regulators

abstract: The retail giant directs the destinations, deadlines and routes for its network of contract delivery drivers. But when they crash, Amazon is held harmless.
lead_para: When she added Gabrielle’s name to the chart in her kitchen, Judy Kennedy could picture the annual ritual. At birthdays she would ask her newest grandchild to stand up straight, heels against the door frame, so she could mark Gabrielle’s height beside that of her other granddaughter in the Maine house the family has lived in since the 1800s.
headline: Amazon Pushes Fast Shipping but Avoids Responsibility for the Human Cost

abstract: A Nobel-winning economist goes to Burning Man. Linda Hamilton is back. Margaret Atwood is, too. And “Friends” is turning 25.
lead_para: With the first week of September in the books, and the exhale of fall ahead of us, take a moment to catch up on some of our great journalism.
headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads

abstract: The University of Chicago has long been associated with the idea that antitrust decisions should be based on prices for consumers, not market dominance. That’s starting to change.
lead_para: Convocation speeches are usually filled with inspiring life lessons or sage advice, but this year’s graduating class at the University of Chicago heard something else: a battle cry against tech monopolies from one of the school’s leading economists.
headline: A Challenge to Big Tech and Antitrust Thinking in a Surprising Place

abstract: House lawmakers asked the companies for information on how their businesses had been affected by Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — House lawmakers have asked more than 80 companies for information about how their businesses may have been harmed by Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google, according to four people familiar with the requests.
headline: Congress Asks More Than 80 Companies for Big Tech Complaints

abstract: Worse, we think there is one.
lead_para: It’s fun, and increasingly fashionable, to complain about technology. Our own devices distract us, others’ devices spy on us, social media companies poison public discourse, new wired objects violate our privacy, and all of this contributes to a general sense of runaway change careening beyond our control. No wonder there’s a tech backlash.
headline: There Is No Tech Backlash

abstract: The landmark show’s “Musicale Finale” is a bizarre Broadway-style goodbye that flattens out some of TV’s most finely shaded characters.
lead_para: “Transparent,” when it arrived on Amazon in 2014, did what great TV does: It made the medium bigger.
headline: Review: ‘Transparent’ and Its Unsettling Technicolor Dream Theater

abstract: The decision to delay a $10 billion computing contract for which Amazon was the favorite reflected both opposition from President Trump and an aggressive campaign by an industry rival.
lead_para: It sounded like the dullest of developments: the award of a big Pentagon I.T. contract was postponed so the new defense secretary could review it.
headline: In Pentagon Contract Fight, Amazon Has Foes in High Places

abstract: A new fantasy series from Amazon Prime Video mixes medieval and Victorian (a little “Game of Thrones,” a little Sherlock Holmes) with a contemporary allegory.
lead_para: “Carnival Row” is a rarity among television fantasies these days because it did not begin life as a comic book, novel, film or other existing property. It’s what’s called an original.
headline: Review: Orlando Bloom Among the Immigrant Beasts in ‘Carnival Row’

abstract: Some critics of the industry want to see the businesses broken up. Others would like to strengthen regulation of Silicon Valley. And there are shades of gray.
lead_para: The Justice Department is investigating them, as is the Federal Trade Commission. Congress and state attorneys general have their sights on the companies, too.
headline: How Should Big Tech Be Reined In? Here Are 4 Prominent Ideas

abstract: In an era of smartphone addiction, a single-purpose device like an e-reader may help you unplug and focus on content that will bring you joy.
lead_para: What if I told you that one of the best ways to fix your smartphone-addicted brain was to buy another gadget?
headline: Amazon Kindle Oasis Review: Now Is the Perfect Time to Buy an E-Reader

abstract: Also: Barneys files for bankruptcy, and more of the week’s top stories in business and tech.
lead_para: It’s been a difficult week of news. So why not catch up quickly on the biggest stories in business and tech and then give yourself a few hours away from the headlines? Put down your phone, eat a lobster roll, read some Toni Morrison and enjoy these final weeks of summer as best you can.
headline: A Financier’s End, and Uber Hits the Skids

abstract: Plus, where should police departments draw the line with facial recognition surveillance?
lead_para: It’s August, which means most people aren’t paying attention to the news — so you get extra Brownie points when you do. Read up on the top stories in business and tech, and feel superior heading into Monday.
headline: The Week in Business: The China Trade War Clobbers the Markets

abstract: Katie Thomas, who covers health care, has chronicled how the technology disruption in her field has raised questions that are still unanswered.
lead_para: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Katie Thomas, who covers health and is based in Chicago, discussed the tech she’s using.
headline: Tech Meets Health Care, Sometimes Shakily

abstract: Amazon is trying, starting with a new Jim Gaffigan set. So is HBO, though it’s more niche with acts like Julio Torres. And don’t count out YouTube.
lead_para: Imagine Netflix died. What happens to stand-up comedy?
headline: Can Netflix, the King of Stand-Up Specials, Be Dethroned?

abstract: As fake and illegitimate texts proliferate online, books are becoming a form of misinformation. The author of “1984” would not be surprised.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — In George Orwell’s “1984,” the classics of literature are rewritten into Newspeak, a revision and reduction of the language meant to make bad thoughts literally unthinkable. “It’s a beautiful thing, the destruction of words,” one true believer exults.
headline: Paging Big Brother: In Amazon’s Bookstore, Orwell Gets a Rewrite

abstract: Plus, WeWork takes steps to go public, and investigations into the Jeffrey Epstein case continue.
lead_para: It has been an eventful week for the stock market, and not in a good way. Catch up on the latest business here, and then head over to the Styles section, where we’re collecting your stories about the weird, awkward world of workplace culture. After all, nothing soothes economic fears quite like lighthearted office gossip.
headline: G.E. Is Accused of Major Fraud, and Stocks Take a Beating

abstract: The cable network won more Emmys than anyone else on Sunday night, but competition is growing and its new leadership has little entertainment experience.
lead_para: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — The champagne was flowing. HBO had just capped off another triumphant night at the Emmys, and it was time to party in the courtyard of the mammoth Pacific Design Center.
headline: As HBO Celebrates a Big Night, Questions About Its Future Loom

abstract: The artists behind the trippy new animated series, from the creator of “BoJack Horseman,” discuss how it all came together.
lead_para: Raphael Bob-Waksberg and Kate Purdy work together on the Emmy-nominated Hollywood satire “BoJack Horseman.” But their latest animated series delivers a narrative that’s even more surreal than the tribulations of a self-loathing talking horse.
headline: How ‘Undone’ Takes Viewers Through the Looking Glass

abstract: With the U.S. unemployment rate near a 50-year low, openings at the company keep piling up as it tries to grow in different directions.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Engineers in the Bay Area. Advertising managers in Chicago. Freight specialists in Arizona. The job listings keep piling up at Amazon, a company that is growing in many directions amid one of the tightest labor markets in memory.
headline: Amazon Has 30,000 Open Jobs. Yes, You Read That Right.

abstract: The company addresses a longtime complaint of audiophiles by offering improved audio for 50 million songs. It will cost $15 a month, $13 for members.
lead_para: Amazon is hoping high-fidelity digital audio will appeal to all kinds of music fans, not just music snobs.
headline: Amazon Offers Millions of Songs in High-Quality Audio. Even Neil Young Approves.

abstract: Margrethe Vestager, whose billion-dollar fines have made her loathed by Silicon Valley, has won new powers that give her unrivaled regulatory reach. President Trump says she “hates the United States.”
lead_para: BRUSSELS — For five years, Margrethe Vestager was the scourge of Silicon Valley, levying billions of dollars in fines and initiating investigations against Google, Apple and Facebook for violating antitrust laws and harming consumers.
headline: E.U.’s New Digital Czar: ‘Most Powerful Regulator of Big Tech on the Planet’

abstract: New devices were introduced on Wednesday to get the digital assistant in your earbuds, in your eyeglasses and in your bathroom.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Alexa has already made herself at home in kitchens and living rooms. Now Amazon is trying to get her in your ears. And on your face. And in your bathroom.
headline: Amazon Wants Alexa to Move (With You) Far Beyond the Living Room

abstract: The superstar took her Savage x Fenty show to the Barclays Center for a night.
lead_para: On Tuesday night in Brooklyn, Rihanna made her bid for global underwear domination.
headline: Rihanna’s Spectacular Sexy Underpants Variety Hour

abstract: Sharpies, auto emissions and the weaponization of policy.
lead_para: Democracies used to collapse suddenly, with tanks rolling noisily toward the presidential palace. In the 21st century, however, the process is usually subtler.
headline: How Democracy Dies, American-Style

abstract: Computer systems need to understand time, space and causality. Right now they don’t.
lead_para: Artificial intelligence has a trust problem. We are relying on A.I. more and more, but it hasn’t yet earned our confidence.
headline: How to Build Artificial Intelligence We Can Trust

abstract: The live-streaming platform, owned by Amazon, has more viewers than many cable channels. But a new ad campaign aims to show it’s good for more than video games.
lead_para: Without video games, Twitch would not be what it is now: a live-streaming platform with millions of devoted viewers and broadcasters, some of them with tattoos of the company’s logo. But the company, which Amazon bought five years ago for more than $1 billion, has ambitions beyond serving fans of Fortnite and World of Warcraft.
headline: Twitch Users Watch Billions of Hours of Video, but the Site Wants to Go Beyond Fortnite

abstract: Humans help train artificial intelligence, so someone may be listening to what you tell Siri, Google Assistant or Alexa. Here’s what to do if you have a problem with that.
lead_para: Many of us ask the digital companions in our homes, whether it’s Amazon’s Alexa, Apple’s Siri or Google Assistant, to handle innocuous tasks like setting a timer and playing music.
headline: Hi, Alexa. How Do I Stop You From Listening In On Me?

abstract: They love working there. It’s great. They love it. It’s great. They love it. It’s great. They love it. It’s great. They love it. It’s great. They love it.
lead_para: On Wednesday evening, a phalanx of Amazon employees known as “FC ambassadors” began tweeting again about how great it is to work at Amazon.
headline: Amazon Uses a Twitter Army of Employees to Fight Criticism of Warehouses

abstract: Top tech companies are rallying around the flag. How opportunistic of them.
lead_para: Not long ago, many leading technologists considered themselves too lofty and idealistic to concern themselves with the petty affairs of government. John Perry Barlow, a lion of the early internet, addressed his “Declaration of the Independence of Cyberspace” to the “governments of the industrial world,” saying that for him and his fellow netizens, these creaky institutions had “no moral right to rule us nor do you possess any methods of enforcement we have true reason to fear.”
headline: The Phony Patriots of Silicon Valley

abstract: The defense secretary said he wants to study the deal, which had been expected to go to Amazon. President Trump had earlier raised concerns.
lead_para: The Pentagon said on Thursday that it was delaying the award of a hotly contested $10 billion contract for a new generation of computing services for the military until the secretary of defense, Mark T. Esper, could review the matter.
headline: Pentagon Delays Award of $10 Billion Cloud Computing Contract

abstract: The move came two months after the cargo delivery giant said it was ending express shipping for the online retailer.
lead_para: Amazon dominates book sales, online shoe purchases and cloud computing. It owns Whole Foods, the high-end grocery chain, and just got involved in home-buying.
headline: FedEx Ends Amazon’s U.S. Ground Deliveries as Retailer Rises as Rival

abstract: The accusation comes at a touchy time for Amazon, with Washington on the lookout for potential anticompetitive behavior.
lead_para: SEATTLE — EBay has accused three Amazon managers of illegally conspiring to poach its sellers, escalating a monthslong feud between two of the country’s largest e-commerce companies.
headline: EBay Accuses Amazon Managers of Conspiring to Poach Its Sellers

abstract: A foodie favorite returns. Or try an Australian family drama fans of  “The Ice Storm” would appreciate.
lead_para: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every week for new suggestions on what to watch.
headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?

abstract: James Daunt fought Amazon and rescued the country’s biggest bookstore chain. Now comes Chapter 2.
lead_para: James Daunt, the man who will soon try to revive Barnes & Noble, once spent weeks in a noisy, arm-waving debate about the ideal angle of tilt for bookstore shelving. His opponent was an Italian showroom designer who argued, in a series of otherwise congenial meals in some of London’s best restaurants, that the shelf should be tilted four degrees.
headline: Can Britain’s Top Bookseller Save Barnes & Noble?

abstract: Every month, subscription streaming services add a new batch of titles to their libraries. Here are the ones we think are most interesting for August.
lead_para: Watching is The New York Times’s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our twice-weekly newsletter here.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and More in August

abstract: Yes, Google, Tesla, Amazon and others are still hiding quirky software surprises in their products, mostly to give you a chuckle.
lead_para: Every car can accelerate, brake and turn. But only the Tesla Model X can put on a three-minute dance performance.
headline: The Secret History of ‘Easter Eggs’

abstract: The decision, while not financially significant for either company, shows how the online retailer has gone from a sought-after customer to a direct competitor of FedEx.
lead_para: It’s unusual when a major corporation boasts about its decision to cut back on doing business with Amazon.
headline: FedEx Says It’s Ending Express Shipping Service for Amazon

abstract: Could Facebook, Google or Apple be considered monopolies? Increased government oversight of the technology giants could consider that possibility.
lead_para: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________
headline: The U.S. Has Its Eye on Big Tech. Will Criminal Inquiries Result?

abstract: The cards, used mainly by consumers who have little credit history or a poor one, haven’t been widely adopted. Amazon is now offering one.
lead_para: Once a little-known option, secured credit cards for people with scant or poor credit are getting more attention.
headline: How Secured Credit Cards Can Build, or Rebuild, Your Credit

abstract: Intense new scrutiny on companies like Google, Apple, Facebook and Amazon could last years and lead to the first overhaul of antitrust rules in decades.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — The federal government is stepping up its scrutiny of the world’s biggest tech companies, leaving them vulnerable to new rules and federal lawsuits. Regulators are divvying up antitrust oversight of the Silicon Valley giants and lawmakers are investigating whether they have stifled competition and hurt consumers.
headline: Antitrust Troubles Snowball for Tech Giants as Lawmakers Join In

abstract: Suddenly regulators’ guns are blazing, but it looks thoughtless and is likely to prove pointless.
lead_para: The techlash has officially arrived.
headline: The People Screaming for Blood Have No Idea How Tech Actually Works

abstract: Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google are all facing federal antitrust inquiries — a potentially long and painful period in their corporate lives.
lead_para: Good Tuesday. (Want this by email ? Sign up here.)
headline: DealBook Briefing: Big Tech Enters Antitrust Purgatory

abstract: For decades, antitrust regulation has focused on the welfare of the consumer. Now a backlash over Big Tech’s power has regulators and scholars trying to reverse years of established doctrine.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — When Americans fear the future, they turn to antitrust action.
headline: To Take Down Big Tech, They First Need to Reinvent the Law

abstract: What will people buy on Prime Day 2019? We look to previous years’ best sellers for clues.
lead_para: Each July for the past four summers, Amazon has held a (made-up) retail holiday called Prime Day, offering some of the deepest discounts of the year on all kinds of things.
headline: Prime Day’s Best Sellers by Year

abstract: Oracle had alleged that Amazon and the Defense Department biased the $10 billion JEDI contract in Amazon’s favor, but was unable to change the Pentagon’s decision.
lead_para: SEATTLE — A federal judge ruled on Friday that Amazon did not unduly influence the shape of one of the largest technology contracts in the Pentagon’s history, setting the stage for the Department of Defense to choose between Amazon and Microsoft for the $10 billion project.
headline: Judge Clears Way for Amazon and Microsoft to Compete for Giant Pentagon Contract

abstract: A machine-dominated workplace can make employees more mechanical themselves. But there is room for initiative, and small acts of rebellion.
lead_para: The last person to touch an item at an Amazon fulfillment center is the packer, whose job is to stick each order in a box and tape it shut.
headline: Inside an Amazon Warehouse, Robots’ Ways Rub Off on Humans

abstract: An engineer in Seattle was charged with stealing the information of millions of customers from Capital One. The incident was surprisingly common.
lead_para: Large financial companies have to thwart hundreds of thousands of cyberattacks every single day. Data thieves have to get lucky only once.
headline: Capital One Breach Shows a Bank Hacker Needs Just One Gap to Wreak Havoc

abstract: The Salt Lake City Police Department found charred human remains in Ayoola Ajayi’s backyard. His book had been about a teenager who witnessed two fiery deaths.
lead_para: A Utah man who the authorities said had the charred remains of a missing university student in his backyard appears to have previously published a book that includes the burning deaths of two people.
headline: Suspect in Mackenzie Lueck Case Wrote a Novel With 2 Burning Deaths

abstract: Phoebe Waller-Bridge also has a big day, while snubs included Chuck Lorre and Julia Roberts.
lead_para: “Game of Thrones” demolished an Emmys record on Tuesday, picking up 32 nominations, the highest total for any show in a single year. The final season of the HBO series beat out “NYPD Blue,” which had 26 nominations in 1994.
headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ and HBO Dominate 2019 Emmy Nominations

abstract: Amazon’s effort could help answer a fundamental question: Will automation be a solution for the great challenges of the 21st century economy, or make those problems worse?
lead_para: As automation technology has leapt ahead, workers increasingly worry about losing their jobs to robots and algorithms. Economists dismiss those concerns, by and large, arguing that workers can grab higher-skilled jobs with better wages.
headline: Amazon’s Latest Experiment: Retraining Its Work Force

abstract: The streaming wars are heating up and the phone giant’s new service will have “Friends” exclusively.
lead_para: After AT&T spent over $80 billion to acquire Time Warner in part to take on Netflix, the phone giant’s new streaming service finally has a name: HBO Max. The company also announced it will debut next spring and will offer 10,000 hours of content, including exclusive access to the hit show “Friends.”
headline: ‘Friends’ to Leave Netflix for HBO Max, AT&T’s New Streaming Service

abstract: A software engineer, facing federal charges in Seattle, was accused of gaining access to 140,000 Social Security numbers and 80,000 bank account numbers.
lead_para: A software engineer in Seattle hacked into a server holding customer information for Capital One and obtained the personal data of over 100 million people, federal prosecutors said on Monday, in one of the largest thefts of data from a bank.
headline: Capital One Data Breach Compromises Data of Over 100 Million

abstract: The video gaming industry is growing but it’s not clear which, if any sectors, are the most promising. Index funds have been a good solution lately.
lead_para: Video gaming has gone from an activity conducted in arcades, dens and rec rooms to a mobile phenomenon where players meet, live and play in virtual space.
headline: Investors Use Indexes to Play in the Video Game Business

abstract: A federal grand jury is looking at partnerships that gave major tech companies broad access to Facebook users’ information.
lead_para: Federal prosecutors are conducting a criminal investigation into data deals Facebook struck with some of the world’s largest technology companies, intensifying scrutiny of the social media giant’s business practices as it seeks to rebound from a year of scandal and setbacks.
headline: Facebook’s Data Deals Are Under Criminal Investigation

abstract: The Massachusetts senator, who is running for president, announced a regulatory plan aimed at breaking up large tech companies and “unwind tech mergers that illegally undermine competition.”
lead_para: Senator Elizabeth Warren, the Massachusetts Democrat who is bidding to be the policy pacesetter in the Democratic presidential primary, championed another expansive idea on Friday evening in front of a crowd of thousands in Queens: a regulatory plan aimed at breaking up some of America’s largest tech companies, including Amazon, Google, Apple and Facebook.
headline: Elizabeth Warren Proposes Breaking Up Tech Giants Like Amazon and Facebook

abstract: The current earnings season shows just how sharply the fortunes of the companies that operate the country’s big stores are diverging.
lead_para: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________
headline: A Stark Divide in America’s Retail Industry Is Coming Into Focus

abstract: “No one is shocked when a paper mill closes anymore. The shocking thing is when one reopens.”
lead_para: COMBINED LOCKS, Wis. — As he watched the No. 7 paper machine hiss and hum for what he thought was the last time, Rick Strick felt a lump well in his throat.
headline: The Great American Cardboard Comeback

abstract: Deap Ubhi has spent his tech career bouncing around. Now he’s tangled up in a little battle over one of the biggest government I.T. contracts in history.
lead_para: Deap Ubhi is a restless guy. At 26, he quit his job in private equity in Northern California, where he had grown up and gone to college, and then moved to India to found Burrp!, a local search site similar to Yelp. He sold the company in 2009 and along with other alums became what they called the Burrp! mafia, seeding and growing other start-ups in India.
headline: Giant Military Contract Has a Hitch: A Little-Known Entrepreneur

abstract: The accusations by Gavin de Becker, Mr. Bezos’ longtime security consultant, are the latest twist in a bizarre situation that has also pulled in the largest U.S. tabloid publisher and The Washington Post.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Jeff Bezos’ security consultant accused the Saudi government of gaining unauthorized access to the Amazon chief executive’s phone, as part of an effort to harm the world’s richest man.
headline: Bezos’ Security Consultant Accuses Saudis of Hacking the Amazon C.E.O.’s Phone

abstract: Antitrust is the nuclear bomb of regulatory moves, but at a moment when nearly everything in America seems contentious, proposals to break up internet giants are gaining support.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — A decade ago, when the greed and carelessness of the financial industry came close to destroying the American economy, the overwhelming response by politicians and the public was: Meh. Almost instantly, all was forgiven and forgotten.
headline: Why a Big Tech Breakup Looks Better to Washington

abstract: No one knows when the special counsel will file his report on Russian interference in the 2016 election, or whether the public will see it. But two publishers aren’t waiting.
lead_para: The legions of reporters and commentators following every move by Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel, do not know when he will finish investigating Russian interference in the 2016 election. And it is unclear whether the report he is expected to file will ever become public.
headline: The Mueller Report Is Already a Hit, Sight Unseen

abstract: The online retailer’s move follows recent efforts by Facebook, YouTube and Pinterest to limit the availability of anti-vaccination and other pseudoscientific material.
lead_para: Amazon has removed the online listings for two books that claim to contain cures for autism, a move that follows recent efforts by several social media sites to limit the availability of anti-vaccination and other pseudoscientific material.
headline: Amazon Pulls 2 Books That Promote Unscientific Autism ‘Cures’

abstract: The first skirmishes have already been fought in what could turn into a tech cold war. “The game is on,” said the Netflix chief executive, Reed Hastings.
lead_para: Apple and Netflix, for better and for worse, have changed how we spend our leisure hours. In the process, the two companies have upended old media habits and created new ones.
headline: Why Netflix Won’t Be Part of Apple TV

abstract: Every month, subscription streaming services add a new batch of titles to their libraries. Here are the ones we think are most interesting for February.
lead_para: Watching is The New York Times’s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and More in February

abstract: It could have answered the concerns of citizens. Instead it bolted.
lead_para: The first word I had that Amazon was about to scrap an agreement to bring 25,000 new jobs to New York City came an hour before it broke in the news on Thursday.
headline: Bill de Blasio: The Path Amazon Rejected

abstract: And what Amazon abandoning New York means for the city — and the country.

abstract: In a report led by Democrats, lawmakers said Apple, Amazon, Google and Facebook needed to be checked and recommended they be restructured and that antitrust laws be reformed.

abstract: Workers have proposed that Amazon let all employees, including warehouse workers, get a paid day off on Election Day.
lead_para: Almost 4,000 tech and corporate workers at Amazon have signed an internal proposal asking the company to give all its workers, including those in its warehouses, a paid day off to vote, according to organizers and screenshots of the effort viewed by The New York Times.

abstract: The four companies known as Big Tech — Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google — now have more than 22,000 employees in the city, with thousands added just this year.

abstract: An unlikely collection of lawyers, activists, economists and academics is fueling the tech backlash, armed with funding from billionaire sponsors.

abstract: Ensuring that the nation can vote by mail is just one of many issues facing the Postal Service, most of which will remain after the election is over.

abstract: Even as the Justice Department sued Google, some antitrust experts wondered whether a different government response would be more effective.

abstract: Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Alphabet reported the latest in a string of enormous quarterly profits on Thursday.

abstract: How did it become a patriotic duty to buy online?

A clerk devoted herself to the customer’s cause, moving through the store with her to select something for each person on her extensive list.

abstract: Life will return to ‘normal,’ but not entirely. Here are some suggestions for investing in a changed world.

Earlier efforts to create a portal for independent booksellers had done little to chip away at Amazon’s market share, and even retailers like Barnes & Noble have struggled to compete.

abstract: Amazon created a retail paradise that protects itself from critics calling for stringent regulation.
lead_para: Amazon is a genie of consumerist wishes, and it keeps growing more irresistible. The company’s online store has always been convenient and plentiful, but in the last year, Amazon significantly increased the speed at which it delivers products, with many items delivered overnight to its Prime members. Investors on Wall Street are used to Amazon’s big spending, and many stock analysts had expected the expensive next-day shipping plan to be another loss leader. But late last month, Amazon released a stunning holiday-season earnings report that proved otherwise: Next-day shipping, the company said, had significantly boosted sales and driven many new sign-ups for Prime, which now has more than 150 million members.
headline: The Trouble With Breaking Up Amazon? Its Online Store Is So Good

headline: Pentagon Asks to Reconsider Awarding Huge Cloud Contract to Amazon

abstract: Runway shows are off. Stores are closed. But we still have TV.
lead_para: There is no live fashion to look at now. No shows; no red carpets; not really any street style. The cruise collections that normally take place in far-flung destinations during May and June have been canceled.
headline: When Fashion TV Becomes an Anthropological Treasure

abstract: We are more dependent on technology than ever. Can it handle the strain?
lead_para: Next week, Bits will be evolving into the On Tech With Shira Ovide newsletter. With a pandemic upon us, the significant effect that technology is having on our families, work, safety and sense of self is even more apparent. What is this reliance on technology doing to us and our communities — and is it good or bad? Shira will be your guide to this constantly changing world, during the coronavirus crisis and beyond.
headline: The Week in Tech: We’re Testing How Much the Internet Can Handle

abstract: Demand for home delivery is rising, and New Yorkers barricaded in their homes are leaning more and more on a largely immigrant work force.
lead_para: Chen Wei’s wife begged him to stop making restaurant deliveries because she feared he might contract the coronavirus from a customer.
headline: The Delivery Workers Who Risk Their Health to Bring You Food

abstract: Prosecutors across the country are investigating exorbitant price increases on hand sanitizer, disinfectant wipes and masks as well as everyday grocery items like chicken, rice and milk.
lead_para: In Florida, one seller was offering 15 N95 face masks on Amazon — for $3,799.
headline: Price Gouging Complaints Surge Amid Coronavirus Pandemic

abstract: Who seems poised to benefit from social distancing? Big Tech.
lead_para: My relationship with social media? It’s complicated, to say the least.
headline: Facebook, Don’t Exploit Us in Our Time of Need

abstract: While we wait for new seasons of TV’s best mafia drama, Amazon Prime Video offers a reasonable facsimile with the globe-trotting thriller “Zerozerozero.”
lead_para: For a certain kind of viewer — raise your hand if you love gritty, operatically scaled gangster melodrama — Seasons 3 and 4 of the Italian drug-gang epic “Gomorrah,” seen in other parts of the world but still missing from North American streaming services, are the Honus Wagner rookie card of television.
headline: Missing ‘Gomorrah’? Watch This

abstract: This city is well ahead of the rest of the nation in the cycle of denial, panic, action.
lead_para: SEATTLE — You relish the little things here in Seattle: Toilet paper is back on some shelves, the hoarders sated for the moment. Instead of making vodka, distilleries are rolling out hand sanitizer. The dreaded daily number of new coronavirus cases shows that while the curve is not yet flat, the rate has gone both down and up on different days this week, carrying our hopes on the bumpy ride.
headline: Seattle Is Living Your Coronavirus Future

abstract: Governments need Big Tech now more than ever.
lead_para: Last month, as the coronavirus started to spread here in the United States, I wrote about a smallish online conferencing company, Zoom Video Communications, saying that we might want to pay attention to it because it makes working from home easier. Well, with the escalating crisis, Zoom is now worth more than four airlines combined — United, Delta, American and JetBlue — with a market cap of just above $44 billion.
headline: Will Our Most Important Industry Survive the Coronavirus?

abstract: The three-week pause, which affects products like consumer electronics, allows the e-commerce company to deal with a surge in demand for household goods.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon is moving to meet a surge in demand for household staples and medical supplies by pulling back on stocking items like consumer electronics and toys.
headline: To Focus on Necessities, Amazon Stops Accepting Some Items in Warehouses

abstract: Online orders have surged for retailers in the pandemic, as curbside pickup helps Americans satisfy their desire to hop in a car and drive to the store.
lead_para: When the pandemic forced Dick’s Sporting Goods to close its hundreds of stores in March, the retailer hustled to set up curbside pickup within two days. Its initial attempt, though, was just this side of a children’s lemonade stand.
headline: Customers Still Like to Shop in Person, Even if They Get Only to the Curb

abstract: Spurred by recent social unrest, many U.S. companies are trying to make it easier for workers, and urging their customers, to cast their ballots.
lead_para: Bank of America is offering employees up to three hours of paid time to vote this year. The spirits company Diageo North America has declared a no-meeting day on Nov. 3. Best Buy is closing stores until noon that day, and PayPal is offering a half day, paid, to workers who volunteer at polling places.
headline: Paid Time Off, Free Fries: How Corporate America Is Getting Out the Vote

abstract: There is heartbreak almost everywhere you look, our columnist says, but the stock market usually rises anyway.
lead_para: In a year of serial crises, solace for many people has come from an unlikely source: the stock market.
headline: For Long-Term Investors, Small Things Like Presidential Elections Don’t Matter

abstract: In this Oscar-nominated documentary, an indomitable matriarch strives to keep her family together while fighting for the release of her incarcerated husband.
lead_para: Fox Rich is a fighter. The entrepreneur, author, and mother of six boys has spent the last two decades campaigning for the release of her husband, Rob G. Rich, who is serving a 60-year sentence at Louisiana State Penitentiary for a bank robbery they both committed in 1997.
headline: Introducing ‘Time,’ a Film From The Times and Amazon Studios

abstract: The picturesque Gard desperately needs more employment. But environmentalists are pushing back at what they see as a looming blight.
lead_para: FOURNÈS, France — On a sultry September morning, Claudie Cortellini headed into the vineyards to survey the grapes that go into her family’s heady Côtes du Rhône wines. In recent years, she has fought to ensure a good harvest as the climate grows warmer. But these days, she is facing an even bigger foe: a giant Amazon sorting center slated for construction near her land.
headline: Are Amazon Jobs Worth 1,400 Loads of Traffic? French Region Is Split

abstract: Lawmakers said they found multiple problems with each of the four giant tech companies.
lead_para: House lawmakers released a scathing report on four of the world’s largest tech companies, accusing them of abusing their market power. The report, which was released on Tuesday and concludes a 16-month investigation into Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google, recommended breaking up the companies and passing the most sweeping reforms to antitrust laws in decades.
headline: 12 Accusations in the Damning House Report on Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google

abstract: How antitrust lawyer Lina Khan is taking on the most powerful men in Silicon Valley.
lead_para: It finally looks as if Big Tech may face some breakups. Lawmakers are interrogating tech C.E.O.s on Capitol Hill while the Justice Department pursues a landmark antitrust case against Google. For decades, tech giants have avoided such scrutiny — hiding behind the idea that their products are free, beneficial, even beloved.
headline: She’s Bursting Big Tech’s Bubble

abstract: A House report on how to limit the reach of Apple, Amazon, Google and Facebook has been delayed as Democrats and Republicans split on remedies.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — For all the divisions in Washington, one issue that had united Republicans and Democrats in recent years was their animus toward the power of the biggest tech companies.
headline: Big Tech Was Their Enemy, Until Partisanship Fractured the Battle Plans

abstract: The move is an escalation of the  pressure being put on executives at the country’s second-largest private employer.
lead_para: Workers at Amazon are calling on groups around the country to help shut down Amazon warehouses temporarily on Halloween if the company does not give all its employees a paid day off to vote.
headline: Amazon workers threaten to shut down warehouses if employees don’t get a day off to vote.

abstract: A damning congressional report about Big Tech helps make the case to break up Jeff Bezos’ empire.
lead_para: We tend to credit Amazon’s enormous reach to its inventiveness. Jeff Bezos has built a logistics operation that rivals UPS and FedEx in the volume of packages it delivers to consumers in the United States. Amazon’s Alexa is the dominant operating system in the new arena of voice-enabled devices and web access.
headline: Don’t Let Amazon Get Any Bigger

abstract: Issues like antitrust and privacy would remain on the agenda as his administration pursued policies to limit the power of the industry’s giants.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — The tech industry had it easy under President Barack Obama. Regulators brought no major charges, executives rotated in and out of the administration, and efforts to strengthen privacy laws fizzled out.
headline: Biden Is Expected to Keep Scrutiny of Tech Front and Center

abstract: Customers and sellers have relied on star ratings for decades, but the review system appears to have met its match: “Yellow Onion (Brands May Vary).”
lead_para: For a business that started as an online bookstore and grew into one of the largest companies in the world, the Amazon of 2020 would feel, to an Amazon customer in 1999, at least a little bit familiar.
headline: What Does Amazon Know About Your Thanksgiving Groceries?

abstract: The company, a subsidiary of Amazon, had to recall 350,000 doorbells following 23 reports of them catching fire.
lead_para: Ring, which sells video doorbells designed to make homeowners feel safer, has recalled more than 350,000 of the devices after nearly two dozen of them caught fire, according to the Consumer Product Safety Commission.
headline: Ring Recalls Video Doorbells After Several Catch Fire

abstract: If the key to Amazon’s success has been to put the customer first, for Shopify the key has been to put the merchant first.
lead_para: In March, the business of Ox Verte, an organic catering company in Manhattan, came to a standstill. Its roster of corporate clients — start-ups that offered free lunches, salespeople with round-table breakfasts — had all implemented work-from-home policies. Events and conferences were canceled for the foreseeable future. If Jessie Gould, the Ox Verte chief executive, hoped to keep her staff employed and her vendors paid, the only path through the pandemic, it seemed, was going to be retail sales. Instead of catering to offices, they would make deliveries to homes. In addition to ready-to-eat meals, they would sell grocery boxes that appealed to health-conscious consumers newly wanting (or forced) to cook. Ox Verte already had a website, but it wasn’t particularly well suited to taking individual orders, so to enable the pivot, the company put up a new online storefront using Shopify, an e-commerce platform based in Canada.
headline: Can Shopify Compete With Amazon Without Becoming Amazon?

abstract: In the pursuit of surveillance as a service, Jeff Bezos is intent on recording even our moods. How much personal data is too much to give to Amazon?
lead_para: Here’s a tip: Don’t get into a car with your family and tell everyone that Jeff Bezos is listening through the device on your wrist.
headline: Amazon Wants to Get Even Closer. Skintight.

abstract: The company has added 427,300 employees in 10 months, bringing its global work force to more than 1.2 million.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon has embarked on an extraordinary hiring binge this year, vacuuming up an average of 1,400 new workers a day and solidifying its power as online shopping becomes more entrenched in the coronavirus pandemic.
headline: Pushed by Pandemic, Amazon Goes on a Hiring Spree Without Equal

abstract: New research shows that we need to be even more skeptical online shoppers.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: How Fake Reviews Hurt Us and Amazon

abstract: On one side: Amazon. On the other: a new alliance of brands and platforms. Who will win?
lead_para: In 2015, the chairman and controlling shareholder of the luxury goods group Richemont, Johann Rupert, took to the stage at an industry conference in Monte Carlo and issued a rallying cry to some of his biggest rivals.
headline: The Luxury E-Commerce Wars Heat Up

abstract: Voice-activated helpers can automate life’s little chores, once you get the hang of them.
lead_para: Apple added its Siri assistant to the iPhone 4S model in 2011, giving users a hand-free way to schedule appointments, play music, look up information and perform other basic tasks. Less than a decade later, digital assistants are in a plethora of digital devices, including computers, smart speakers, dashboards and watches, and they can help you ease into the day and keep the household running smoothly.
headline: Put Alexa and Siri to Work

abstract: Leaders are divided over a global solution to taxing Silicon Valley giants, a fight for big tax dollars that threatens to disrupt global trade.
lead_para: PARIS — The Trump administration and leaders of other wealthy nations remain at odds over how to tax technology companies and other businesses that operate online, negotiators confirmed on Friday, an impasse that threatens to inflame global trade tensions if not resolved by year’s end.
headline: In Talks on Taxing Tech Companies, It’s America vs. the World

abstract: The Amazon founder’s investigation did not find evidence to back his suggestion of a link between Saudi Arabia and the tabloid that gleefully exposed his affair.
lead_para: Almost a year ago, Jeff Bezos hinted that Saudi Arabia had played a role in The National Enquirer’s 11-page exposé of his affair with the Los Angeles television personality Lauren Sanchez. In making the case in a post on the website Medium, Mr. Bezos noted that his newspaper, The Washington Post, had published the Saudi dissident Jamal Khashoggi and had also covered the kingdom’s suspected role in his murder.
headline: Jeff Bezos’ Hack Inquiry Falls Short of Implicating National Enquirer

abstract: It most likely began with a tiny bit of code that implanted malware, which gave attackers access to Mr. Bezos’ photos and texts.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — On the afternoon of May 1, 2018, Jeff Bezos received a message on WhatsApp from an account belonging to Saudi Arabia’s crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman.
headline: How Jeff Bezos’ iPhone X Was Hacked

abstract: “Who’s watching and for what purposes? What kind of information are they scraping off?”
lead_para: This article is part of a limited-run newsletter. You can sign up here.
headline: Why Elizabeth Warren Feels ‘Very Uneasy’ Online

abstract: The maker of home speakers said Google and Amazon stole its technology and abused their power, but it could only risk suing one.
lead_para: SANTA BARBARA, Calif. — In 2013, Sonos scored a coup when Google agreed to design its music service to work easily with Sonos’s home speakers. For the project, Sonos handed over the effective blueprints to its speakers.
headline: Sonos, Squeezed by the Tech Giants, Sues Google

abstract: The announcement applied only to 301 websites, and many Kashmiris said they were still in an information black hole.
lead_para: NEW DELHI — Months after imposing a sweeping communications blackout in Kashmir, the Indian government on Saturday unblocked several hundred websites in the disputed Himalayan region, bringing a tentative end to the world’s longest internet shutdown in a democracy.
headline: India Restores Some Internet Access in Kashmir After Long Shutdown

abstract: An analysis of a phone belonging to Jeff Bezos found malicious code was hidden in a video sent from a WhatsApp account belonging to Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.
lead_para: Each week, we review the week’s news, offering analysis about the most important developments in the tech industry.
headline: The Week in Tech: A Tech Mogul’s Phone and the Saudi Crown Prince

abstract: Until Friday, few executives had complained in public about how Google, Apple, Amazon and Facebook hurt their businesses.
lead_para: For all the criticisms directed at the largest tech companies in the last couple of years, few smaller rivals have been willing to speak up publicly.
headline: Please Stop Big Tech, Small Rivals Tell Lawmakers

abstract: The dollars are adding up fast. So here are some tips for pruning the subscriptions you no longer use.
lead_para: Online subscriptions sure sound cheap, but what do a few bucks a month to watch TV shows, store photos online and stream music add up to?
headline: How Much Are We Paying for Our Subscription Services? A Lot

abstract: Thanks for the flattering commercials, but we’re about to lose our hazard pay.
lead_para: While Amazon may glorify its workers with sentimental commercials, thanking them for their heroic bravery, it has also rolled back some policies designed to keep those very workers safe during this pandemic. And on June 1, it’s getting rid of hazard pay too, even though its facilities continue to see outbreaks of the coronavirus.
headline: We Work in an Amazon Warehouse. We Didn’t Sign Up to Be Heroes.

abstract: Communicating with loved ones is crucial to get through quarantine, and it doesn’t have to be complicated.
lead_para: For most of us, the coronavirus pandemic moved our lives almost entirely inside and online. Staying in touch with loved ones near and far away now relies on a patchwork of phone calls, emails, text messages and an array of video-chat platforms.
headline: 5 Ways to Stay in Touch With Less Tech-Savvy Family and Friends

abstract: It won’t be Amazon or the coronavirus. It will be artificially high rents.
lead_para: Every weekday I drive to my four bookstores, pick up our customers’ orders, wedge them into the back of my car and take them to the Cooper Station post office. My route takes me to Williamsburg to Downtown Brooklyn to the South Street Seaport, and ends at my original store in NoLIta.
headline: What Could Kill My New York Bookstores?

abstract: Amazon and other companies are planning to test workers for the coronavirus. But there is little federal guidance, and some fear it could lead to a false sense of security.
lead_para: As the country reopens, employers are looking into how to safely bring back their workers. One recurring question: Should they be tested for the new coronavirus?
headline: What Role Should Employers Play in Testing Workers?

abstract: After losing some online shoppers to rivals during the pandemic, the retail giant is turning back to faster shipping times and big sales.
lead_para: As millions more Americans turned to online shopping during the pandemic, Amazon struggled to keep up with the demand, and its rivals pounced. Target’s online sales shot up 141 percent last quarter, while Walmart’s rose 74 percent. Etsy’s were up almost 80 percent in April.
headline: Amazon Angles to Grab Back Customers

abstract: Lawmakers want to question Mr. Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive, as part of its antitrust investigation.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — The House Judiciary Committee on Friday called on Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive, to testify before Congress, in a major escalation of its investigation into the country’s largest technology companies.
headline: Congress Calls on Jeff Bezos of Amazon to Testify

abstract: The company said it would be happy to send someone to testify. But it never mentions Jeff Bezos.
lead_para: Amazon responded to lawmakers on Friday who demanded that its chief executive, Jeff Bezos, testify as part of a congressional antitrust investigation.
headline: Amazon Makes No Promises on Bezos Testimony

abstract: The best shopping ideas now are coming from big box stores. Where are Amazon’s innovations?
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Amazon Misses a Shopping Opportunity

abstract: The director Andrew Patterson discusses a sequence from his film, now streaming on Amazon Prime.
lead_para: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series each Friday. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
headline: How ‘The Vast of Night’ Builds Tension With a Strange Sound

abstract: The pandemic briefly brought the Everything Store to its knees — by prematurely bringing about a future it has long been planning for.
lead_para: The pandemic briefly brought the Everything Store to its knees — by prematurely bringing about a future it has long been planning for.
headline: Amazon’s Big Breakdown

abstract: Amazon no longer gets us everything we need and quickly. Will this affect our shopping habits for good?
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Reliable Amazon Isn’t Anymore

abstract: Every month, subscription streaming services add a new batch of titles to their libraries. Here are our picks for April.
lead_para: For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our twice-weekly Watching newsletter here.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix, Amazon and More in April

abstract: Sometimes products are in stock. Sometimes they aren’t. And delivery times vary widely. A virus-fueled surge in orders has created chaos behind the scenes, and confusion for customers.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Exploding Kittens, a game that bills itself as “a kitty-powered version of Russian roulette,” spent years ranked as one of the most popular card games on Amazon’s store. When the coronavirus pandemic hit, sales doubled week after week, as families looked for distraction while hunkering down.
headline: When Even Amazon Is Sold Out of Exploding Kittens

abstract: The move follows a French court order for the U.S. retailer to limit deliveries to essential goods amid controversy over virus safety measures.
lead_para: PARIS — Amazon said Wednesday that it would temporarily halt its operations in France after a court ruled the company had failed to adequately protect warehouse workers against the threat of the coronavirus and that it must restrict deliveries to only food, hygiene and medical products until it addressed the issue.
headline: Amazon to Suspend Operations in France Over Coronavirus Dispute

abstract: Shifting sick-leave policy and communication issues are causing employees to assert themselves after they stayed on the job.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Jonathan Bailey, a 30-year-old Amazon warehouse employee in Queens, has a system for protecting himself from the coronavirus at work. He wears a medical mask with a bandanna tied over it. When he returns to the apartment he shares with his wife, he dumps his mask, work gloves, neon green Amazon safety vest and other clothes into a plastic trash bag.
headline: Gaps in Amazon’s Response as Virus Spreads to More Than 50 Warehouses

abstract: The first quarter was one of the worst in history for many stock markets around the world. The start of the second isn’t looking any better.
lead_para: We are holding a conference call for DealBook readers tomorrow, April 2, at 11 a.m. Eastern. We will go behind the scenes of the Trump administration’s response to the coronavirus and what policy actions may come next. Our special guest will be Maggie Haberman, one of the NYT’s top White House correspondents. You’ll be able to ask Maggie about her reporting during the call, or submit questions in advance to dealbook@nytimes.com. For details about how to join, visit the R.S.V.P. page. This is the first in a weekly series of calls we’re calling the DealBook Debrief, featuring a wide range of experts in conversation with the DealBook team about the business and policy implications of the pandemic. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)
headline: Welcome to the Second Quarter. Brace Yourself.

abstract: Silicon Valley hasn’t suffered from the same financial devastation as other industries. Tech companies still have an agenda to push.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Last month, lobbying groups representing advertising giants like Google and Facebook asked California’s attorney general to wait to enforce the state’s new online privacy rules given the coronavirus ripping around the world.
headline: How Tech’s Lobbyists Are Using the Pandemic to Make Gains

abstract: The retailer said it had redirected shipments of the masks to health care providers and emergency responders.
lead_para: Home Depot has ordered all 2,300 of its stores in North America to stop sales of N95 masks to try to free them up for those on the front lines of the coronavirus emergency response, the company said on Wednesday.
headline: Home Depot Halts Sales of N95 Masks Amid Shortage, Company Says

abstract: The strikes at Amazon and elsewhere over working conditions and low pay have been small, but they may spark a new movement.
lead_para: Class consciousness does not flow automatically out of class identity. Being a worker does not necessarily mean you will come to identify as a worker. Instead, you can think of class consciousness as a process of discovery, of insights derived from events that put the relationships of class into stark relief.
headline: Another Way the 2020s Might Be Like the 1930s

abstract: From the census to the November election, the Postal Service is critical to American democracy.
lead_para: America’s favorite government agency is on the brink of collapse, and Washington policymakers appear too mired in politics to save it.
headline: What’s an Essential Service in a Pandemic? The Post Office

abstract: Lou Ann Dagen, 66, was one of six residents who died from the virus at one nursing home outside Grand Rapids, Mich., a spokesman for the center said.
lead_para: They lived about 20 minutes apart in Michigan, but when a cousin gave the sisters Lou Ann Dagen and Penny Dagen each an Amazon Echo Show last year to make video calls, they would keep each other company for hours on end.
headline: ‘How Do I Get Help?’ Dying Coronavirus Patient Asked Alexa

abstract: Nearly two years in, there has been little enforcement of the General Data Protection Regulation, once seen as ushering in a new era.
lead_para: LONDON — When Europe enacted the world’s toughest online privacy law nearly two years ago, it was heralded as a model to crack down on the invasive, data-hungry practices of the world’s largest technology companies.
headline: Europe’s Privacy Law Hasn’t Shown Its Teeth, Frustrating Advocates

abstract: Digital influencers are shaping our habits, even now and even if we’re clueless about it.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: You Are Being Influenced

abstract: Believing in online hoaxes can be dangerous now. Here’s how we can all help.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: What to Do When Your Uncle Believes Coronavirus Conspiracies

abstract: The internet giant is investing hundreds of millions of dollars in the effort, with its first original game, Crucible, to be released next month.
lead_para: Opening a new front in the campaign to dominate digital entertainment, Amazon is investing hundreds of millions of dollars into becoming a leading creator and distributor of video games.
headline: Amazon Pushes Into Making Video Games, Not Just Streaming Their Play

abstract: Amazon may be bigger than ever, but change is coming for the tech giants, too.
lead_para: On Thursday, Amazon reported blockbuster first-quarter sales. This week Microsoft, Facebook and Google showed robust gains of their own. Supply chain disruptions and slowing ad revenue have put little dent in these cash-rich giants that, together with Apple, account for 20 percent of the S&P 500 index. Amid the biggest economic crisis since the Great Depression, Big Tech is roaring ahead.
headline: The Coronavirus Could Rewrite the Rules for Silicon Valley

abstract: Harry Bosch, in Amazon’s Los Angeles cop procedural, and Doron Kavillio, in Netflix’s Israeli counterterrorism thriller, would have a lot to talk about if they weren’t so laconic.
lead_para: It’s April, so I must be writing about “Bosch.” This is the fifth straight year I’ve taken note of a new season (now the sixth) of Amazon Prime Video’s Los Angeles cop show based on Michael Connelly’s Harry Bosch novels. It’s an indulgence in a time when many worthwhile series go unremarked. This year, I can rationalize it as coronavirus-related: “Bosch” is my comfort show, the one I binge the day it’s available. On Friday I’ll be quarantined in my happy place.
headline: ‘Bosch’ and ‘Fauda’: The Platonic Ideal of the Tough Guy

abstract: Recognized for the hit network sitcoms “The Office” and “Parks and Recreation,” Daniels is breaking his own conventions with a satirical sci-fi show on Amazon.
lead_para: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — The new Amazon series “Upload” was in its final week of shooting last May, and Greg Daniels was chewing on everything he could get his hands on, including his hands. Time was waning, and the set — a convincing facsimile of a claustrophobic Queens apartment — was tricky to navigate. Daniels, the series’s creator, watched a monitor as the crew worked the tight spaces and the director shouted commands.
headline: With ‘Upload,’ Greg Daniels Takes a Leap Into the Great Unknown

abstract: Trillions in stimulus dollars have convinced Wall Street that the government has its back, and investors are seizing on even glimmers of good news about the pandemic.
lead_para: The government said on Wednesday that the U.S. economy had suffered its worst contraction since the last recession. The head of the Federal Reserve later said he didn’t know how bad this downturn would be, or how long it would last.
headline: The Bad News Won’t Stop, but Markets Keep Rising

abstract: Disrobing in the hallway, dodging hugs and fretting over our children’s safety. This is our family’s new normal.
lead_para: “No, honey! You can’t hug Daddy yet!” I frantically tell my 5-year-old son, grabbing him just in time as he runs toward our front door to welcome his father home from work. “He has to wash the bad germs off first, OK?”
headline: My Partner Works in an Amazon Warehouse. I’m Worried — and Proud.

abstract: Like Trump, India is pressuring both of Mr. Bezos’ businesses as its leaders become more nationalistic toward foreign companies and news media.
lead_para: MUMBAI, India — Jeff Bezos’ ownership of The Washington Post has complicated business for his much bigger company, Amazon, in Trump-era Washington.
headline: India Targets Jeff Bezos Over Amazon and Washington Post

abstract: India opened a formal investigation into Jeff Bezos’ Amazon and its leading rival, Flipkart, just before his first visit in five years.
lead_para: MUMBAI, India — Amazon’s founder and chief executive, Jeff Bezos, is visiting India this week for the first time in over five years.
headline: Welcome to India, Mr. Bezos. Here’s an Antitrust Complaint.

abstract: A new story will reveal more about the characters before the Amazon Prime TV superhero series returns this year.
lead_para: “The Boys,” the series about corrupt superheroes which premiered on Amazon Prime TV last year, is returning for a second season  later this year. Before that, however, the characters will return in a comic book mini-series, The Boys: Dear Becky, beginning in April.
headline: The Boys Return to Their Comic Book Roots

abstract: The internet giant posted increases in revenue and profit after shoppers flocked to it during the holiday season.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon sold a lot of things to a lot of people in the last three months of 2019, as speedy shipping shortened the time between “I want it” and “It’s here.”
headline: Amazon Powers Ahead With Robust Profit

abstract: This feels like a good time to watch “Justified.” Otherwise, check out a great new stand-up special or tween show.
lead_para: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every week for new suggestions on what to watch.
headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?

abstract: Algorithms are sending ads by American brands onto Russian disinformation sites.
lead_para: Lenin is sometimes said to have predicted that capitalists would sell Russia the rope with which they would be hanged. Yet not even Lenin could have imagined Vladimir Putin’s success in getting some of the largest Western companies to subsidize his disinformation efforts by advertising on his government-run “news” websites.
headline: How Amazon, Geico and Walmart Fund Propaganda

abstract: Ring offers a front-door view of a country where millions of Amazon customers use Amazon cameras to watch Amazon contractors deliver Amazon packages.
lead_para: There’s always something happening on the porch.
headline: Who’s Watching Your Porch?

abstract: Just a year ago, the world’s richest man seemed to have a pretty low-key life. Times sure have changed.
lead_para: SEATTLE — When Jeff Bezos and his former wife, MacKenzie, celebrated what would be their last anniversary together around Labor Day 2018, they arrived at a Miami nightclub with no fanfare. His table was booked online, which is “totally what tourists do” and “totally dorky,” the club’s celebrity liaison said in an interview at the time.
headline: Jeff Bezos, Tabloid Man

abstract: Investigators said the phone of Jeff Bezos, the Amazon chief, began behaving strangely after he received a video from Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman’s WhatsApp account.
lead_para: SEATTLE — A forensic analysis of Jeff Bezos’ cellphone found with “medium to high confidence” that the Amazon chief’s device was hacked after he received a video from a WhatsApp account reportedly belonging to Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia.
headline: Analysis Ties Hacking of Bezos’ Phone to Saudi Leader’s Account

abstract: Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google will soon have 20,000 workers in New York City, many in offices on the West Side.
lead_para: When Facebook was searching for another New York office, one big enough to fit as many as 6,000 workers, more than double the number it currently employs in the city, it had one major demand: It needed the space urgently.
headline: Silicon Valley’s Newest Rival: The Banks of the Hudson

abstract: Two year-end shows from Amazon and Netflix deliver some laughs, yes, but also serve as veiled ads for the streaming services themselves.
lead_para: At the start of “Death to 2020,” a reporter played by Samuel L. Jackson sits alone in an abandoned office listening to a disembodied voice explain he’s looking back at the past year. “Why would you want to do that?” Jackson responds, with an additional curse for emphasis.
headline: When Is a Comedy Special Also a Corporate Synergy Message?

abstract: U.N. experts lent their weight to allegations that Saudi Arabia’s crown prince hacked the cellphone of Jeff Bezos, owner of The Washington Post, to “influence, if not silence,” its reporting.
lead_para: BEIRUT, Lebanon — United Nations experts broadened the inquiry into Saudi Arabia’s efforts to squelch criticism on Wednesday, accusing its crown prince of personally hacking the cellphone of Jeff Bezos, the billionaire owner of The Washington Post, to “influence, if not silence” the newspaper’s critical coverage of the kingdom.
headline: Bezos Phone Hack Tied to Saudi Crown Prince Puts New Pressure on Kingdom

abstract: We wanted à la carte television, and now we have it — and it costs more than cable. Here’s how to watch your favorite shows without overpaying for a dozen apps.
lead_para: In the old days of cable, you paid one giant price for more TV than you could ever want. It was awful. It was expensive. And who even watches most of this stuff? Now, every media company has its own streaming subscription that you can buy à la carte. And it’s still awful, but in a different way.
headline: How to Navigate a Flood of Streaming TV Subscriptions

abstract: Facebook, Google and other major tech firms were every student’s dream workplaces. Until they weren’t.
lead_para: In 2006, Google bought YouTube for more than $1 billion, Apple was preparing to announce the first iPhone, and the American housing bubble began to deflate. Claire Stapleton, then a senior at the University of Pennsylvania, faced the same question over and over: What did she plan to do with that English degree? She flirted, noncommittally, with Teach for America.
headline: ‘Techlash’ Hits College Campuses

abstract: Puzzles, paintings, ghost brides: plenty to watch this weekend, and our critic has recommendations.
lead_para: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every week for new suggestions on what to watch.
headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?

abstract: The internet juggernaut enjoyed a stunning quarter where nearly every business worked. The results increased Jeff Bezos’ wealth by $13 billion in 15 minutes.
lead_para: Weekend playlist: This new dance number by Elon Musk, if that’s your thing. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)
headline: How Amazon Keeps Defying Gravity

abstract: How investors can use indexes to spot opportunities in global stock markets without adding risk.
lead_para: The buoyant American stock market may be blinding investors to better opportunities abroad.
headline: You Don’t Need to Travel to Profit From International Stocks

abstract: Paying for gas with Amazon’s Alexa or playing table tennis with a robot: Whether the latest tech trends will become fixtures in our lives is an open question.
lead_para: LAS VEGAS — Like it or not, the future is connected.
headline: A Glimpse of Our Connected Tech Future, Courtesy of CES 2020

abstract: Will the proliferation of mobile ordering destroy civic life?
lead_para: For the past few years I have made a habit of going to a particular Starbucks in Brooklyn after I drop my son off at school, a ritual that has given me pleasure way out of proportion to its ordinariness.
headline: What We Lose by Hiring Someone to Pick Up Our Avocados for Us

abstract: My iPhone got hacked once, but the only fallout was that it sent my contacts a bizarre email containing only a fish emoji (really). The billionaire Jeff Bezos apparently wasn’t so lucky — but of course, his phone contents are far juicier than mine. For more on that strange story, and the business and tech news you need to know for the week ahead, read on.
lead_para: My iPhone got hacked once, but the only fallout was that it sent my contacts a bizarre email containing only a fish emoji (really). The billionaire Jeff Bezos apparently wasn’t so lucky — but of course, his phone contents are far juicier than mine. For more on that strange story, and the business and tech news you need to know for the week ahead, read on.
headline: The Week in Business: Beware Mysterious Videos on Your Phone

abstract: Spurred by advances in photomechanical reproduction, forgers are increasingly selling unauthorized copies of famous works on the internet, and elsewhere.
lead_para: In Basel, the Swiss authorities are prosecuting a local art expert who they say sold hundreds of fake prints that he passed off online as the work of Roy Lichtenstein, Andy Warhol, Paul Klee, Pablo Picasso and others over 10 years.
headline: Art Experts Warn of a Surging Market in Fake Prints

abstract: From videoconferencing to fitness apps, the best tech helped us endure a hard year. But there were also low points.
lead_para: To put it lightly, 2020 was rough. More than ever, we turned to our personal tech this year to help find respite, stay healthy and remain connected with the people we care about.
headline: The Tech That Was Fixed in 2020 and the Tech That Still Needs Fixing

abstract: The undisputed heir to “Battlestar Galactica” begins its fifth (and next to last) season on Amazon Prime Video.
lead_para: Every year at this time, I and my colleagues on the television beat publish our lists of the year’s best shows and wait, with much interest and some resignation, to be told what we missed. Our most egregious omissions this year, according to readers, included new shows like Netflix’s “Queen’s Gambit,” Apple TV+’s “Ted Lasso” and HBO’s “How to With John Wilson.”
headline: Review: Catching Up to ‘The Expanse,’ the Space Opera You Love

abstract: The Amazon-owned Zoox is unveiling an electric self-driving vehicle. But are we ready for driverless cars?
lead_para: You know how to Google, how to Uber and how to Netflix and chill. Now, can Jeff Bezos get you to Zoox?
headline: Autonomous Vehicles Take Another Big Leap

abstract: Our streaming picks for December, including ‘The Prom,’ ‘Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom,’ and ‘Your Honor.’
lead_para: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for December.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in December

abstract: The retail giant claims that its health product is extremely precise at scanning body fat. I found otherwise.
lead_para: Many of us are in the same boat these days. With the coronavirus killing more people by the day, we are increasingly stress-eating and drinking more alcohol. At the same time, with gyms shut down, we are sitting around more and glued to screens.
