headline: Amazon Halo Review: The Fitness Gadget We Don’t Deserve or Need

abstract: More than 30 states said that the company downplayed websites that let users search for information in specialized areas.
lead_para: More than 30 states added to Google’s mushrooming legal woes on Thursday, accusing the Silicon Valley titan of illegally arranging its search results to push out smaller rivals.
headline: Google’s Legal Peril Grows in Face of Third Antitrust Suit

abstract: Big tech companies now exert huge influence over what stories get told. The message is clear: Be careful whom you offend.
lead_para: The show was called “Scraper,” but it was clearly about Gawker Media, the network of aggressive, transgressive blogs that created mischief and headaches for America’s powerful until its targets sued the company into oblivion in 2016.
headline: Apple TV Was Making a Show About Gawker. Then Tim Cook Found Out.

abstract: European Union and British authorities released draft laws to halt the spread of harmful content and improve competition.
lead_para: LONDON — Authorities in the European Union and Britain built momentum on Tuesday for tougher oversight of the technology industry, as they introduced new regulations to pressure the world’s biggest tech companies to take down harmful content and open themselves up to more competition.
headline: Big Fines and Strict Rules Unveiled Against ‘Big Tech’ in Europe

abstract: Amazon’s cloud computing business and Apple’s Macs are increasingly using the companies’ homegrown chips.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — For close to a decade, supporters of the chip technology that powers mobile phones vowed to shake up the market for computers. For the most part, they made little headway.
headline: Amazon and Apple Are Powering a Shift Away From Intel’s Chips

abstract: The election, expected early next year, will be one of the few times that employees of the e-commerce giant have had an opportunity to decide whether to join a union.
lead_para: Thousands of workers at an Amazon warehouse near Birmingham, Ala., moved closer this week to holding a vote on whether to form a union, a milestone at the nation’s fastest growing large employer and a coup for organized labor, which has tried for years to make inroads at the e-commerce giant.
headline: Amazon Workers Near Vote on Joining Union at Alabama Warehouse

abstract: The virus outbreak supercharged a continuing shift in the markets, with a few giant companies now exerting the most influence over the direction of stocks since the tech boom.
lead_para: An economic downturn almost always favors giants like Microsoft, Apple and Amazon, the country’s three most valuable companies. But the demand for their shares has only been amplified by a crisis that seems almost tailor-made for their future success.
headline: Investors Bet Giant Companies Will Dominate After Crisis

abstract: A computer with a good internet connection, communication apps and entertainment are the only tech we really need, ever.
lead_para: It has been weeks since the coronavirus brought our lives to a halt, shutting down our schools, offices and gyms. Stuck at home, we have had nothing but time to reflect on the things that matter.
headline: The Virus Revealed Our Essential Tech (and Weeded Out the Excess)

abstract: The ruling is another court victory by French unions against Amazon in a battle over workplace safety.
lead_para: PARIS — Amazon lost an appeal on Friday of a French court decision ordering the e-commerce giant to stop delivering nonessential items in France during the coronavirus crisis to protect workers, raising questions about the immediate future of its business in the country.
headline: Amazon Loses Appeal of French Order to Stop Selling Nonessential Items

abstract: Cargo capacity has been expanding at some airports, disturbing the peace and routines of people who live nearby. Official channels offer scant recourse.
lead_para: The last time Congress approved legislation dealing with airport noise complaints was 30 years ago, when the biggest concern was older, inefficient planes.
headline: As Online Buying Surges, So Do Noisy Cargo Flights

abstract: The attorney general said in a letter that Amazon may have violated laws in firing a Staten Island worker who led a protest against the company.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon may have violated federal worker safety laws and New York State’s whistle-blower protections when it fired an employee from its Staten Island warehouse who protested the company’s response to the coronavirus outbreak, according to a letter the office of the New York attorney general, Letitia James, sent the company last week.
headline: New York Attorney General Scrutinizes Amazon for Firing Warehouse Worker

abstract: Employees want more wipes and less crowding in sanitized warehouses.
lead_para: As if in the darkest children’s fable ever told, the undisputed winner of the current plague turns out to be the man who already had everything, the king whose empire appears intent on consuming the entire map. This week Jeff Bezos, the richest man on earth, saw the year’s first financial quarter close with Amazon stock up more than 5 percent, trading at $1,950 a share, during a period in which the Dow had its worst overall quarter since 1987.
headline: ‘We Didn’t Sign Up for This’: Amazon Workers on the Front Lines

abstract: The chief executive, who had distanced himself from day-to-day management, is closely involved in the company’s response to the pandemic.
lead_para: SEATTLE — At the end of February, Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive, and his girlfriend, Lauren Sanchez, were in France discussing climate change with President Emmanuel Macron at the Élysée Palace and celebrating atop the Eiffel Tower with the designer Diane von Furstenberg. Days later, paparazzi spotted the couple grabbing dinner at Carbone in New York.
headline: Bezos Takes Back the Wheel at Amazon

abstract: Our online habits are changing, likely for good. This could make tech companies even more muscular.
lead_para: We need technology to keep us supplied, connected and informed in this pandemic. And these changes may stick with us. Are we giving too much power to tech companies now — and possibly forever?
headline: The Pandemic Feeds Tech Companies’ Power

abstract: The markets are abuzz about early data from a trial of an antiviral drug, as President Trump unveils guidelines for restarting the U.S. economy.
lead_para: If you couldn’t join us for the DealBook Debrief call with Tom Friedman yesterday, the highlights are at the bottom of the email and the full recording is here. Skip to 9:00 to hear Tom sing a gospel song — we covered a lot of ground in the call. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)
headline: A Prescription for Reviving the Economy

abstract: The agency now says “critical infrastructure workers” who may have been exposed to the coronavirus can stay on the job under certain conditions, instead of isolating.
lead_para: Lisa Harris, a cashier at a Kroger grocery store in Virginia, was surprised last week when a customer offered her a $5 bill as a tip. Ms. Harris, a Kroger employee for 13 years, cited store policy in declining the generous offer.
headline: Food Workers Say C.D.C. Guidelines Put Them at Greater Risk for Infection

abstract: When the most successful companies are anxious, you know we’re in scary times.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Big Tech’s Worries Should Worry You

abstract: Rules and store technology can impede Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program recipients, but a pilot effort to expand access is picking up speed.
lead_para: Whether they need more yeast for stress baking or the comfort of Kraft macaroni and cheese, Americans sequestered by social distancing are shopping for groceries online. But for many low-income households using food stamps, that can happen only in person.
headline: For Most Food Stamp Users, Online Shopping Isn’t an Option

abstract: Tim Bray, an engineer who had been a vice president of Amazon’s cloud computing arm, said the firings were “evidence of a vein of toxicity running through the company culture.”
lead_para: A prominent engineer and vice president of Amazon’s cloud computing arm said on Monday that he had quit “in dismay” over the recent firings of workers who had raised questions about workplace safety during the coronavirus pandemic.
headline: An Amazon Vice President Quit Over Firings of Employees Who Protested

abstract: The pandemic has shown we’ll watch any garbage on TV.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Is ‘Death Diving’ the Future of TV?

abstract: Google, Facebook, Amazon, Capital One and others are extending work-from-home policies to September and sometimes far beyond.
lead_para: Even as President Trump has said “we have to get our country open again,” much of corporate America is in no rush to return employees to their campuses and skyscrapers. The companies are racing not to be the first back, but the last.
headline: White-Collar Companies Race to Be Last to Return to the Office

abstract: The pandemic has intensified the push-pull between labor and the retail giant, which is required by European law to deal with unions — and has prospered anyway.
lead_para: PARIS — Workers at Amazon’s six mammoth French warehouses won some concessions from the company in late March: After hundreds of employees threatened to walk out unless the company better protected them from the coronavirus, the internet giant strengthened social distancing measures, provided masks and hand sanitizer and took employee temperatures.
headline: Amazon’s Showdown in France Tests Its Ability to Sidestep Labor

abstract: Almost 35 million people have HBO. But not all of them can get HBO Max. Here’s what you need to know.
lead_para: AT&T’s new streaming platform HBO Max went live on Wednesday, but for many HBO subscribers, it was not entirely clear whether they had access to the service.
headline: How Do I Get HBO Max if I Already Have HBO?

abstract: The coalition, which includes Amazon, plans to pour $2 million into ads opposing President Trump’s call for higher package delivery rates and pressing for Congress to help the service.
lead_para: A coalition of online retailers backed by Amazon began a seven-figure advertising blitz on Wednesday opposing President Trump’s demand that the beleaguered United States Postal Service ratchet up its package delivery rates to avoid bankruptcy amid the coronavirus crisis, its top lobbyist said.
headline: Online Retailers Spend Millions on Ads Backing Postal Service Bailout

abstract: When the pandemic is over, we most certainly should fear the industry more than ever.
lead_para: If power tends to corrupt, and absolute power corrupts absolutely, how can we best describe the kind of power Big Tech will wield when the coronavirus crisis is over?
headline: The Immunity of the Tech Giants

abstract: Democratic senators sent a letter to the company asking for more details after it fired four employees who raised health concerns about its warehouses.
lead_para: Democratic senators on Thursday questioned whether Amazon retaliated against whistle-blowers when it fired four employees who raised concerns about the spread of coronavirus in the company’s warehouses.
headline: Senators Want to Know if Amazon Retaliated Against Whistle-Blowers

abstract: Workplace safety is now a matter of public health.
lead_para: Shelter-in-place orders are an effective means to slowing the spread of the coronavirus, yet millions of Americans have no choice but to leave home to go to work every day. Deemed essential for their jobs in manufacturing, grocery stores, pharmacies, warehouses, retailing and restaurants, they face daily risks by working alongside colleagues and customers who may be carriers of the coronavirus.
headline: ‘You’re On Your Own,’ Essential Workers Are Being Told

abstract: Jeff Bezos, the chief executive, said the company could spend up to $4 billion to handle the effects of Covid-19.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Online shopping during the coronavirus pandemic drove sales at Amazon far higher, the company said on Thursday. But the cost to deliver those products, and to keep its workers safe, is taking a big bite out of the company’s profits.
headline: Amazon Sells More, but Warns of Much Higher Costs Ahead

abstract: The price of a barrel of oil dropped below zero, reflecting both short-term technical factors and long-term fundamentals. A recovery seems remote.
lead_para: Our next DealBook Debrief call is about the fallout for the retail industry, which has been hit particularly hard by the pandemic. We’ll be joined by Vanessa Friedman, The Times’s fashion director and chief fashion critic, to discuss how the fashion and luxury industries are coping, and the possible lasting effects. We hope you’ll join us on Thursday, April 23, at 11 a.m. Eastern — R.S.V.P. here. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)
headline: You Have to Pay to Give Oil Away

abstract: The investment firm that agreed to buy Victoria’s Secret is now trying to back out. It could embolden others to scrap deals agreed before the pandemic.
lead_para: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.
headline: Victoria’s Secret and Sycamore Partners Play ‘Let’s Break a Deal’

abstract: The tech superpower faces hard questions over how it’s handling worker safety.
lead_para: I’ll be chatting live on Twitter today at 3 p.m. Eastern time with Kara Swisher, a Times contributing opinion writer and a veteran technology journalist.
headline: It’s Now Amazon’s Turn in the Spotlight

abstract: Phoebe Waller-Bridge’s solo stage show comes to Amazon to raise money for the arts and health care charities.
lead_para: Before Phoebe Waller-Bridge’s “Fleabag” became a BBC series, an Emmy winner and a gift to gifs and hot priest memes, it was a solo stage show. A tale of a cheeky, devastated, sexually compulsive London woman, written by and starring Waller-Bridge, it played the Edinburgh Fringe in 2013 and returned last spring for Off Broadway and West End runs.
headline: A Short Recommendation: Watch the Stage Version of ‘Fleabag’ on Amazon Video

abstract: Stacy Mitchell knew that taking on a trillion-dollar company would be a lopsided fight. But the pandemic has not only made Amazon more essential. It has also made it vulnerable.
lead_para: PORTLAND, Maine — A million years ago, Stacy Mitchell was in her office, talking about why Amazon is bad for America.
headline: As Amazon Rises, So Does the Opposition

abstract: Yes, it’s possible.
lead_para: PARIS — Business is booming at Amazon. With a third of the global population now under stay-at-home orders, stir-crazy shoppers have flooded to the site of the world’s largest retailer, to stream, to download and to place orders for everything from coffee makers to toilet paper. The boost has sent Amazon’s share price soaring by more than 40 percent over the past month — and in the process, fattened the pockets of the company’s founder and chief executive, Jeff Bezos, now worth about $140 billion.
headline: How French Workers Took on Amazon in the Middle of a Pandemic and Won

abstract: Kick back with these movies old and new — and gain a new appreciation for artists from Alice Neel to Mark Hogancamp and Sun Ra.
lead_para: You can’t beat art documentaries for sheer relatability. Watch the artists work, watch them succeed or fail, and then listen to their friends sort through the details. The list that follows is hardly an exhaustive introduction to the genre, but it’s a good batch of films guaranteed to transport you out of your living room, whether it’s to the glamour of the Mediterranean coast, to the excitement of a contemporary art auction, to the otherworldly ecstasy of a Sun Ra concert, or even to the squalid claustrophobia of Edvard Munch’s Norwegian adolescence.
headline: 15 Documentaries That Get Inside an Artist’s Head

abstract: Our picks for April, including ‘Community,’ ‘Extraction,’ and ‘Never Have I Ever’
lead_para: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for April.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in April

abstract: With some help from Vogue and the CFDA, the e-commerce giant is opening a new store to showcase independent designers. Does this mark the moment the two worlds finally get hitched?
lead_para: Finally, Jeff Bezos is really in fashion.
headline: Amazon to the Rescue of the Fashion World!

abstract: A warehouse in the foothills of the Poconos has had more known Covid-19 cases than any of Amazon’s others after missing early opportunities to protect workers.
lead_para: Therese Kelly arrived for her shift at an Amazon warehouse on March 27 to find her co-workers standing clustered in the cavernous space. They were awaiting a buildingwide announcement, a rarity at the complex known as AVP1. Over a loudspeaker, a manager told them what they had feared: For the first time, an employee had tested positive for the coronavirus.
headline: ‘Way Too Late’: Inside Amazon’s Biggest Outbreak

abstract: Amazon’s chief said that pandemic-related expenses would consume all profits in the current quarter — and that it was part of a deliberate strategy.
lead_para: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.
headline: Jeff Bezos Doubles Down on Amazon’s Pandemic Response

abstract: The online giant will begin reopening its six warehouses in France following a legal battle over protections for employees.
lead_para: PARIS — ​Amazon has reached an agreement with French unions to reopen its warehouses in France after a lengthy battle over safety measures to protect workers against the coronavirus, capping the most prominent labor showdown the retailer has faced during the pandemic.
headline: Amazon Reaches Deal With French Unions in Coronavirus Safety Dispute

abstract: The intergalactically attuned pop singer and star of films like “Moonlight” and “Hidden Figures” continues to expand her horizons as an actor, playing the lead in the new season of the Amazon thriller.
lead_para: If there is any silver lining to the weeks that Janelle Monáe has spent sheltering in place, it is the opportunity it has afforded her to refocus on the fundamentals of performance and shed some of the excess of what she calls her “p.c.” — that is, “pre-corona” — days.
headline: Janelle Monáe Touches Down in ‘Homecoming’

abstract: Representative Pramila Jayapal of Washington tried to keep her concerns about the company private. Now she’s going public.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Representative Pramila Jayapal was walking a fine line when she arrived at Amazon’s Seattle headquarters on a chilly day last October to meet with some of the company’s top executives.
headline: One of Amazon’s Most Powerful Critics Lives in Its Backyard

abstract: As viewers shelter with screens from the pandemic, more and more TV wrestles with mortality within digital reproductions.
lead_para: “Are we living in a simulation?”
headline: Life Is More Like a Simulation. On These Shows, So Is Death.

abstract: The Amazon series has become a hit in India for its frank depictions of modern Mumbai women and sex, in a country where even kissing has been rare onscreen.
lead_para: When the HBO series “Sex and the City” first arrived on TV screens in 1998, sex had become “the reigning political story,” according to the writer Julie Salamon. The show was a product and a catalyst of a zeitgeist in which financially independent and imperfect women had carved out a space for themselves and their casual, raging sex lives.
headline: With ‘Four More Shots Please!,’ India Gets Its Own ‘Sex and the City’

abstract: As business restrictions are lifted, employees have moved from advocating workplace safeguards to making sure the measures aren’t removed too soon.
lead_para: Riley Breakell, a Starbucks barista in Connecticut, was reassured in mid-March when the company sent a letter announcing expanded catastrophe pay for those absent because of the pandemic. Even though she couldn’t live on the roughly $250 per week she received from Starbucks while her store was closed for a month and a half, she appreciated the company’s effort to do right by its employees.
headline: Reopening Prompts New Agitation Over Workers’ Virus Exposure

abstract: As the pandemic hobbled the real estate industry, several huge deals crossed the finish line, including a record sale at Brooklyn Bridge Park and another Jeff Bezos acquisition in Manhattan.
lead_para: New York City’s real estate market reached new highs in April, even as the coronavirus outbreak threatened future home sales.
headline: A Record Sale in Brooklyn Among April’s Closings

abstract: Every month, subscription streaming services add a new batch of titles to their libraries. Here are our picks for December.
lead_para: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are our picks for some of December’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our twice-weekly Watching newsletter here.)
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, HBO Max, Hulu and More in December

abstract: The former pro football player has pushed himself in acting classes, onstage and in films. His latest drama, “Sylvie’s Love,” also meant returning to an early passion: music.
lead_para: The lead in a romance may seem like a prize for most actors, but the star of the new drama “Sylvie’s Love” had reservations.
headline: For His Second Act, Nnamdi Asomugha Made Preparation His Byword

abstract: For concerned customers, avoiding one of the world’s largest retailers and web service providers is proving harder than expected.
lead_para: Blaze Cromwell, a 24-year-old cashier living in Washington, D.C., doesn’t order from Amazon.com or shop at Whole Foods. He doesn’t watch movies or shows on Prime Video. He doesn’t own a Ring or a Kindle. And he doesn’t use Audible, Twitch or Zappos. He’s about as close as one can get to abstaining from Amazon entirely.
headline: Life Without Amazon (Well, Almost)

abstract: Bryan Fogel’s examination of the killing of the Saudi dissident Jamal Khashoggi had trouble finding a home among the companies that can be premier platforms for documentary films.
lead_para: Bryan Fogel’s first documentary, “Icarus,” helped uncover the Russian doping scandal that led to the country’s expulsion from the 2018 Winter Olympics. It also won an Oscar for him and for Netflix, which released the film.
headline: An Oscar Winner Made a Khashoggi Documentary. Streaming Services Didn’t Want It.

abstract: “She’s disrupting the norms around billionaire philanthropy by moving quickly,” an expert on charities said.
lead_para: In her short career as one of the world’s leading philanthropists, MacKenzie Scott has made a mark through the enormous scale of her giving and also through its speed, donating nearly $6 billion of her fortune this year alone.
headline: MacKenzie Scott Announces $4.2 Billion More in Charitable Giving

abstract: The deal, valued at $300 million, is the latest in a string of acquisitions as streaming platforms expand beyond music and video.
lead_para: Amazon is acquiring Wondery, the company behind podcasts such as “Dirty John,” “Dr. Death” and “The Shrink Next Door,” as the race to grab parts of the audio market continues.
headline: Amazon Buys Wondery as Podcasting Race Continues

abstract: India’s film industry, which relied on theatrical releases, is experimenting with going straight to streaming services such as Amazon, Netflix and Disney’s Hotstar.
lead_para: “Coolie No. 1” has all the hallmarks of a big Bollywood film: colorful costumes, larger-than-life sets, foot-tapping music and a melodramatic story about a man who pretends he has a twin to woo the woman of his dreams.
headline: Bollywood, Reeling From the Pandemic, Shifts to Streaming

abstract: As the power of Google, Apple and other tech giants grows, the companies should do more to explain how they work.
lead_para: This is the last edition of On Tech for 2020. Thank you for reading, please be well and I’ll see you back here on Jan. 4.
headline: Big Tech Should Try Radical Candor

abstract: Silicon Valley is building a powerful influence industry in Brussels, which has “never seen this kind of money” spent this way.
lead_para: A leaked document jolted the European Union capital of Brussels in October, laying out in painstaking detail plans by Google to undermine new legislation that could severely damage its digital advertising business.
headline: Big Tech Turns Its Lobbyists Loose on Europe, Alarming Regulators

abstract: The season is adding pressure on retailers, strained by a pandemic surge in e-commerce and limited by shippers, to deliver gifts on time.
lead_para: E-commerce became a lifeline for consumers and companies during the pandemic. But this holiday season, online shopping will strain the industry as never before: An estimated three billion packages will course through the nation’s shipping infrastructure — about 800 million more than delivered last year.
headline: With 3 Billion Packages to Go, Online Shopping Faces Tough Holiday Test

abstract: Artificial intelligence won’t eliminate every retail job, an economist says, but the future could be grim unless we start planning now.
lead_para: Americans are worried that technology will soon replace much of the work done by humans, and they are right to be.
headline: The Robots Are Coming. Prepare for Trouble.

abstract: I scrolled through the photographs of the two of you, kissing hand-in-hand, the archaeology of your love pieced together in binary code.
lead_para: I scrolled through the photographs of the two of you, kissing hand-in-hand, the archaeology of your love pieced together in binary code.
headline: Alexa, Awake

abstract: The company is unveiling another initiative to compete more effectively with Amazon’s e-commerce business.
lead_para: Google is getting serious about competing with Amazon in online shopping — just as it did in 2013, 2014, 2017 and 2019.
headline: Google Takes Aim at Amazon. Again.

abstract: How Facebook’s most recent crisis started, and what it says about the company’s role in our lives.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Can Facebook Ever Stop the Drama?

abstract: Jeff Bezos of Amazon faced questions from Representative Mary Gay Scanlon about how his company drives up prices through eliminating competition.
lead_para: Jeff Bezos of Amazon faced questions from Representative Mary Gay Scanlon about how his company drives up prices through eliminating competition.
headline: Bezos Grilled About Amazon’s ‘Predatory Practices’

abstract: Jeff Bezos of Amazon, Tim Cook of Apple, Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook and Sundar Pichai of Google will answer questions from House lawmakers about their business practices.
lead_para: Jeff Bezos of Amazon, Tim Cook of Apple, Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook and Sundar Pichai of Google will answer questions from House lawmakers about their business practices.
headline: Watch Live: Tech C.E.O.s Testify Before Congress

abstract: With competitors closing, online retail giants are poised to be the only ones standing after the pandemic.
lead_para: Powell’s, a beloved bookstore chain in Portland, Ore., laid off more than 300 people in mid-March, temporarily closed its five storefronts and issued a dire warning for the years to come. “When we do open our stores again, we expect the landscape of Oregon, and all of our abilities to spend money on books and gifts, will have changed dramatically,” wrote Powell’s chief executive, Emily Powell. “We see the path ahead more clearly: it is dark and scary.”
headline: We Need Amazon During the Coronavirus. That’s a Problem.

abstract: As more films skip theaters and head straight to streaming, we asked our critics to talk openly about what many whisper about: that many of these films are just good enough.
lead_para: In 2015, Tom McCarthy made the journalism drama “Spotlight,” which won the Oscar for best picture. This year his follow-up feature, “Timmy Failure: Mistakes Were Made,” skipped theaters and headed directly to Disney Plus. Best picture it won’t be. As the streaming landscape expands and more movies bypass a theatrical release to land on your welcome screen, we wondered: do these movies have a quality issue? Or should we accept that most streaming-only movies are “good enough”? We put these questions to critics who regularly review these movies for The Times.
headline: This Movie Is Streaming Only. Should We Lower Our Expectations?

abstract: Surging demand for critical products has created an immediate need for more workers, forcing some companies to alter normal hiring practices.
lead_para: The volume of food and paper products passing through a warehouse just outside Los Angeles is up 30 percent from the same time a year ago. Pizza deliveries are surging as people around the country hunker down.
headline: Help Wanted: Grocery Stores, Pizza Chains and Amazon Are Hiring

abstract: With the help of intelligent machines, humans can be nudged to make choices that make workplaces fairer for everyone.
lead_para: — Iris Bohnet, a behavioral economist and professor at the Harvard Kennedy School
headline: Algorithms Learn Our Workplace Biases. Can They Help Us Unlearn Them?

abstract: The Amazon reality series starring Heidi Klum and Tim Gunn is the latest riff on “Project Runway.”
lead_para: I love the print, but the proportions seem wrong. I like the idea, but it feels a little joyless. There’s something very unresolved about the crotch on those pants, and they don’t feel elevated.
headline: ‘Making the Cut’ Is New, but the Pattern Is Familiar

abstract: Our picks for March, including ‘Lost Girls,’ ‘Ozark’ and ‘Making the Cut’
lead_para: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are our picks for March.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in March

abstract: A Tennessee man had planned to sell his stockpile at marked-up prices online. Now he is under investigation for price gouging.
lead_para: A Tennessee man who became a subject of national scorn after stockpiling 17,700 bottles of hand sanitizer donated all of the supplies on Sunday just as the Tennessee attorney general’s office began investigating him for price gouging.
headline: The Man With 17,700 Bottles of Hand Sanitizer Just Donated Them

abstract: Every month, subscription streaming services add a new batch of titles to their libraries. Here are our picks for March.
lead_para: For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our twice-weekly Watching newsletter here.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix, Amazon and More in March

abstract: Amazon is hiring aggressively to meet customer demand. Traffic has soared on Facebook and YouTube. And cloud computing has become essential to home workers.
lead_para: OAKLAND, Calif. — While the rest of the economy is tanking from the crippling impact of the coronavirus, business at the biggest technology companies is holding steady — even thriving.
headline: Big Tech Could Emerge From Coronavirus Crisis Stronger Than Ever

abstract: Amazon cracked down on coronavirus price gouging. Now, while the rest of the world searches, some sellers are holding stockpiles of sanitizer and masks.
lead_para: On March 1, the day after the first coronavirus death in the United States was announced, brothers Matt and Noah Colvin set out in a silver S.U.V. to pick up some hand sanitizer. Driving around Chattanooga, Tenn., they hit a Dollar Tree, then a Walmart, a Staples and a Home Depot. At each store, they cleaned out the shelves.
headline: He Has 17,700 Bottles of Hand Sanitizer and Nowhere to Sell Them

abstract: The iPhone maker, which depends on both factories and consumers in China, could be a bellwether for other big tech companies.
lead_para: Hello, New York Times tech readers. I’m Nellie Bowles, the tech and culture reporter, here now with the roundup of the news.
headline: The Week in Tech: Coronavirus Hits Apple’s Financial Forecast

abstract: Amazon is pointing the finger right at the president over the awarding of the JEDI military contract.
lead_para: What did President Trump know and when did he know it? Whom did he pressure out of self-interest? Are there emails or tapes? And, maybe, let’s call some witnesses.
headline: The Epic Battle Between Trump and Bezos Is On

abstract: The agency ordered Amazon, Apple, Facebook, Alphabet and Microsoft to turn over a decade’s worth of information on small acquisitions.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — The Federal Trade Commission said on Tuesday that it had ordered Amazon, Apple, Facebook, Google’s parent company and Microsoft to turn over information about past acquisitions, broadening its review of the power of big tech companies.
headline: F.T.C. Broadens Review of Tech Giants, Homing In on Their Deals

abstract: How Amazon is causing us to drown in trademarks.
lead_para: Maybe it’s cold, and you need some winter gloves. You know the brand of your favorite coat and remember who made your warmest sweater. Gloves, however, have always just been gloves, purchased without too much thought. So you open up Amazon and search: “winter gloves.”
headline: All Your Favorite Brands, From BSTOEM to ZGGCD

abstract: The Auschwitz Memorial said the show’s human chess scene at a concentration camp was a dangerous caricature, and called for the removal of an anti-Semitic children’s book.
lead_para: Should one be allowed to sell Nazi propaganda online? And is it OK to take creative license with Holocaust atrocities?
headline: Amazon Confronts Criticism Over ‘Hunters’ and Sale of Nazi Propaganda

abstract: The judge ordered work to stop on a cloud-computing contract for the Pentagon until Amazon’s legal challenge was resolved.
lead_para: A federal judge in Washington ordered Microsoft on Thursday to halt all work on a $10 billion cloud-computing contract for the Pentagon, in a victory for Amazon, which had challenged the awarding of the contract.
headline: Judge Halts Work on Microsoft’s JEDI Contract, a Victory for Amazon

abstract: Plus, Bloomberg floods the internet with ads — and the campaign trail with cash.
lead_para: I hope your Valentine’s Day was especially good this year. Americans were forecast to break records with their gifting on Friday, spending an average of $196.31 on their loved ones — a 21 percent increase from last year’s average of $161.96, according to the National Retail Federation. Thanks, and you’re welcome, economy! Here’s the rest of the week’s top news in business and tech.
headline: The Week in Business: Amazon Is Coming for Trump

abstract: Trustbusting advocates like Sarah Miller, who target corporate power, have finally found themselves at the center of the political conversation.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — One night five years ago, Sarah Miller, a former Treasury Department aide, was trying to make sense of an economic recovery that had left the country in the grips of rising inequality.
headline: She Wants to Break Up Big Everything

abstract: Streaming services like Amazon Prime and Spotify offer videos, playlists and narrated books to entertain dogs and cats. But who loves it more: The pets? Or their owners?
lead_para: This is a story about Opie and Karma.
headline: Does Your Pet Really Need Cat TV or a Dog Playlist?

abstract: In a first, videos outnumbered photos in reports to the authorities last year. Facebook found the most imagery, the bulk of it on its Messenger app.
lead_para: The number of reported photos, videos and other materials related to online child sexual abuse grew by more than 50 percent last year, an indication that many of the world’s biggest technology platforms remain infested with the illegal content.
headline: Tech Companies Detect a Surge in Online Videos of Child Sexual Abuse

abstract: Something has to be done about the technology sector. Here’s what to keep in mind.
lead_para: In a rare bit of bipartisanship, Democratic and Republican lawmakers now agree that Big Tech has gotten too big, too powerful, too quickly.
headline: How to Take On the Tech Barons

abstract: “Truth Seekers,” the comedy duo’s first TV collaboration in two decades, is rooted in their own ghost hunting exploits.
lead_para: Simon Pegg and Nick Frost know it’s been a while. Despite being best friends and an acclaimed comic double act in films like “Hot Fuzz” and “Shaun of the Dead,” they have seldom crossed paths, creatively speaking, since 2013’s “The World’s End.” It’s been even longer since they worked together in television — they haven’t co-starred in a series since the British sitcom “Spaced” aired over 20 years ago.
headline: Simon Pegg and Nick Frost Are Back With a British ‘X-Files’

abstract: Sacha Baron Cohen’s pranks involve political figures like Mike Pence and Rudy Giuliani, as well as one unexpected A-list celebrity.
lead_para: This article contains spoilers for “Borat Subsequent Moviefilm.”
headline: The ‘Borat’ Sequel’s 3 Wildest Scenes: Here’s What Happens

abstract: Read the report.
lead_para: Read the report.
headline: The House Antitrust Report on Big Tech

abstract: The team at Wirecutter, a product recommendation site owned by The New York Times Company, combed Amazon to find what’s actually worth buying.
lead_para: The team at Wirecutter, a product recommendation site owned by The New York Times Company, combed Amazon to find what’s actually worth buying.
headline: The Amazon Prime Day Deals Worth Buying

abstract: The bosses of four tech giants are preparing to defend themselves at a congressional hearing against claims of anti-competitive behavior.
lead_para: There is a lot of chatter about David Solomon’s D.J. gig at a packed Hamptons concert over the weekend, where a seeming lack of social distancing has led to an investigation by the New York health authorities. For the Goldman Sachs chief, eyebrows are being raised about his judgment, along with a healthy dose of schadenfreude. More below. (Want this delivered to your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)
headline: Tech’s ‘Big Tobacco’ Moment

abstract: The congressional antitrust hearing showed that concerns about the tech stars aren’t going away.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Big Tech’s Backlash Is Just Starting

abstract: Will you finally let your workers unionize?
lead_para: Covid-19 has created strange bedfellows. Six months ago we, a labor leader and an Amazon vice president, would have been on opposite sides in discussing the future of work at Big Tech in general and Amazon in particular. Then on May 1, one of us, Tim, walked away from a senior role at Amazon Web Services, and potentially millions in compensation, in protest over the firing of workers who spoke out about conditions in the company’s warehouses.
headline: We Have a Question for Jeff Bezos and Other Billionaires

abstract: Tensions between China and the U.S. are higher than ever. Where do we go from here?
lead_para: Breaking: Goldman Sachs has agreed to a $3.9 billion settlement with the Malaysian government over the 1MDB scandal, paying $2.5 billion in cash and returning $1.4 billion in assets linked to the wayward sovereign fund’s bonds. (Want this delivered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.)
headline: The New Tech Cold War

abstract: It’s a tongue twister, but also a strategy. Jeff Bezos, Mark Zuckerberg, Tim Cook and Sundar Pichai appeared before Congress and dressed the part.
lead_para: They didn’t look like titans. They didn’t look like masters of the universe. They didn’t look like “emperors of the online economy,” as Representative David Cicilline, chairman of the antitrust subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee and Democrat from Rhode Island, called them. Nor did they look like “cyber barons,” as Representative Jamie Raskin, a Democrat from Maryland, said.
headline: Titans of Tech Testify in Their Trust-Me Suits

abstract: Technology was supposed to be all about welcoming newcomers. But is it?
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Digital Habits Are Hard to Break

abstract: Bets running from coolers and campers to cloud computing helped three mutual funds trounce the S&P 500 in the second quarter.
lead_para: Returns on some types of mutual funds have been so lofty they look like typos.
headline: Investors Posted Returns So Great They Seemed Wrong

abstract: Tim Bray was a celebrated engineer at Amazon. Now, he is its highest-profile defector.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Tim Bray, an internet pioneer and a former vice president at Amazon, sent shock waves through the tech giant in early May when he resigned for what he called “a vein of toxicity” running through its culture.
headline: The Amazon Critic Who Saw Its Power From the Inside

abstract: The C.E.O.s are likely to argue before Congress that their companies aren’t anticompetitive. Here are the facts.
lead_para: Jeff Bezos of Amazon, Tim Cook of Apple, Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook and Sundar Pichai of Google are set to testify before Congress on Wednesday to make their case about why their companies actually are not that powerful.
headline: A Handbook to Today’s Tech Hearing

abstract: In an era of toilet paper shortages and lines outside of supermarkets, this vintage free-for-all, now on Netflix, feels oddly gratifying.
lead_para: It was an entirely different time in life when there was very, very little to do.
headline: Comfort Viewing: 3 Reasons I Love ‘Supermarket Sweep’

abstract: Amazon, a rival for the $10 billion contract, has complained that President Trump interfered in the process.
lead_para: The Defense Department on Friday reaffirmed its decision to award a massive cloud computing contract to Microsoft, despite protests from Amazon, which had argued that President Trump interfered to prevent it from winning the $10 billion contract.
headline: Pentagon Sticks With Microsoft for Cloud Computing Contract

abstract: The company’s decision comes after thousands of U.S. residents reported receiving unsolicited packets of seed from China, prompting all 50 states to issue safety warnings.
lead_para: Amazon has banned the sale of foreign seeds to its customers in the United States, a move that comes after thousands of U.S. residents received unsolicited packages of seeds over the summer, most of them postmarked from China.
headline: Amazon Bans Sale of Foreign Seeds in the U.S.

abstract: Every month, subscription streaming services add a new batch of titles to their libraries. Here are our picks for October.
lead_para: For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our twice-weekly Watching newsletter here.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Hulu, Amazon and More in October

abstract: And what might we gain and lose from that?
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Can Amazon Conquer the World?

abstract: A number of women working in retail say they are being forced to choose between keeping their jobs and making sure their children can keep up with remote learning.
lead_para: The start of the virtual school year has been a struggle for Patricia Reveles, a pharmacy technician at a CVS in Los Angeles, whose daughter is in fourth grade.
headline: As School Begins, Mothers Working Retail Jobs Feel Extra Burden

abstract: John Mackey, who espouses a high-minded version of capitalism, sold his upscale grocery chain to Amazon.
lead_para: For the better part of the past decade, the Whole Foods founder John Mackey, a libertarian and health food enthusiast, has been preaching the redemptive power of what he calls “conscious capitalism.” As he tells it, when businesses find their true purpose and serve not just investors, but all stakeholders, everyone wins.
headline: Whole Foods Founder: ‘The Whole World Is Getting Fat’

abstract: On social media, people had some concerns about the Ring Always Home Cam. To put it mildly.
lead_para: When Amazon’s chief executive, Jeff Bezos, promised in 2013 that drones would soon be flying everywhere delivering packages, a miniature camera whirring through homes and recording video was probably not what people envisioned.
headline: Amazon Unveils Drone That Films Inside Your Home. What Could Go Wrong?

abstract: The industry is trying to reach customers amid a severe global recession that has brought mass layoffs and plunging sales. Traditional fashion weeks might be out of step.
lead_para: This is usually a busy month for the luxury industry. Not long after glossy fashion magazines publish their all-important September issues, thousands of retail buyers, journalists and clients embark on a tour of New York, London, Milan and Paris.
headline: Can Luxury Fashion Ever Regain Its Luster?

abstract: Republicans and Democrats agree that the U.S. economy could use more stimulus. They can’t agree on how to do it.
lead_para: Want this delivered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.
headline: The Economy Needs Help

abstract: The more Facebook knits together its apps, the harder it becomes for a government to break it up.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: How Facebook Entrenches Itself

abstract: The agency said it had issued a certificate clearing the way for the company to use drones to fly packages to its customers’ doorsteps.
lead_para: Amazon has received federal approval to use drones to deliver packages, bringing the retailer a critical step closer to its goal of shortening delivery times to 30 minutes or less.
headline: Drone Delivery? Amazon Moves Closer With F.A.A. Approval

abstract: Trackers can collect all sorts of information on our health, sleep and fitness. But then what?
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Will More Data Make Us Healthier?

abstract: With deliveries surging during the pandemic, carriers like UPS and FedEx and companies like Amazon are renewing their push toward electric vehicles.
lead_para: Going back years, you might have been able to spot a truck from the likes of FedEx and UPS, and more recently Amazon, that ran on electricity. But most of these were small, short test runs that left the internal-combustion status quo in place.
headline: Soon, the Kitty Litter Will Come by Electric Truck

abstract: While Joe Biden has criticized the largest tech companies, his campaign and transition teams have welcomed allies of Facebook, Google, Amazon and Apple onto its staff and policy groups.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Joseph R. Biden Jr. has been critical of Big Tech, admonishing Facebook for mishandling misinformation and saying internet companies should lose a central legal protection.
headline: Big Tech Makes Inroads With the Biden Campaign

abstract: The F.C.C. approved the company’s 3,236-satellite constellation, which aims to provide high-speed internet service around the world.
lead_para: Welcome to the age of the satellite megaconstellation. Within the next few years, vast networks, containing hundreds or even thousands of spacecraft, could reshape the future of Earth’s orbital environment.
headline: Amazon Satellites Add to Astronomers’ Worries About the Night Sky

abstract: The additional space and workers, envisioned before the pandemic, are a sign of how large tech companies continue to prosper.
lead_para: SEATTLE — The pandemic has upended many companies’ expansion plans. Not Amazon’s.
headline: Amazon Sticks With Office Expansion Plans in New York and Elsewhere

abstract: The most patriotic thing that companies could do is make democracy work better.
lead_para: I recently wrote that Mark Zuckerberg is the most powerful unelected man in America. His and Facebook’s efforts to try to combat election-related disinformation on its platform, however comforting, were merely “an admission of a great power that should make Americans uncomfortable,” I said.
headline: America’s Tech Billionaires Could Help Protect the Election. If They Wanted To.

abstract: As the rapid pace of change mixes with national security issues, Europe’s role as a global regulator is increasingly tested — and may not be enough.
lead_para: BRUSSELS — Lacking a powerful technology sector of its own, the European Union has instead tried to carve out a space in the digital economy as the world’s regulatory superpower, leading the charge on privacy rights and data protection by leveraging its enormous single market against Goliaths like Google and Facebook.
headline: Europe Feels Squeeze as Tech Competition Heats Up Between U.S. and China

abstract: Our streaming picks for October, including ‘Rebecca,’ ‘The Haunting of Bly Manor,’ and ‘Welcome to the Blumhouse’
lead_para: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for October.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in October

abstract: With a shift to online resources well underway, “the most trusted civic institutions” are in a good position to deal with the changing future.
lead_para: Many companies and public institutions were unprepared for the pandemic and the ensuing lockdown. There was one notable, perhaps even surprising, exception: the nation’s public libraries.
headline: Beyond the Pandemic, Libraries Look Toward a New Era

abstract: U.S. lawmakers are digging into questions about how to steer technology to make our lives better.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Hooray (Mostly) for the Government!

abstract: With “Utopia,” the best-selling novelist makes her debut as a TV showrunner. But anyone who knows her from “Gone Girl” or “Sharp Objects” might be surprised by what they see.
lead_para: Gillian Flynn grew up surrounded by comics. Her father, a film professor and an avid comic book collector, would spend weekends taking her to flea markets and garage sales, explaining the various eras and artists she should know, which strip was loosely based on a Ray Bradbury story, and so on.
headline: Gillian Flynn Takes Her Paranoia to Television

abstract: A day after the S&P 500 had its worst performance in months, stocks mostly reversed their steep early losses on Friday, but still closed the week 4.3 percent off their latest high.
lead_para: The searing monthslong rally in the stock market has been a clear sign that investors expected the country’s giant tech firms to help lead the pandemic-hit economy out of the doldrums.
headline: Stocks Slide Again as a Promising Week Turns South

abstract: The S&P 500 dropped 3.5 percent on Thursday, the biggest single-day fall since June 11, as big tech companies weighed on it heavily.
lead_para: The S&P 500 had its worst day on Thursday since June 11, falling 3.5 percent, and the same big tech companies that have driven the recent rally were the culprits.
headline: Wall Street Has Its Worst Day in Months

abstract: Our streaming picks for September, including ‘Away,’ ‘I’m Thinking of Ending Things' and ‘Enola Holmes’
lead_para: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for September.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in September

abstract: New films, and classics, just keep coming, but you don’t have to drill down to find the finest selections to stream. We’ll do the heavy lifting. You press play.
lead_para: Sign up for our Watching newsletter to get recommendations on the best films and TV shows to stream and watch, delivered to your inbox.
headline: The Best Movies on Amazon Prime Video Right Now

abstract: E-commerce is not a purely online activity. It affects our real world, too, in both constructive and potentially harmful ways.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Amazon Is So Much Bricks and Mortar

abstract: Investors have cast the nearly relentless drumbeat of bad news aside to focus on any signs that the worst of the coronavirus pandemic might be over.
lead_para: Widespread economic devastation, severe unemployment and a grim prognosis for recovery have not stopped the stock market’s exuberance. And on Tuesday, that undying optimism propelled the market to a new high, pushing it past a milestone reached only six months ago, when the coronavirus was just beginning its harrowing journey across the United States.
headline: ‘This Market Is Nuts’: S&P 500 Hits Record, Defying Economic Devastation

abstract: As the economy contracts and many companies struggle to survive, the biggest tech companies are amassing wealth and influence in ways unseen in decades.
lead_para: American tech titans flew high before the coronavirus pandemic, making billions of dollars a year.
headline: Big Tech’s Domination of Business Reaches New Heights

abstract: As Amazon signals its growth in India with its office in Hyderabad, its largest in the world, local business owners are pushing back.
lead_para: The austere building is hardly distinguishable in the landscape of glass and concrete buildings making up Asia’s Silicon Valley, as Hyderabad, India, is known. It is one of Amazon’s latest developments, the online retailer’s largest office building in the world.
headline: In South India, Amazon Builds Its Largest Office Yet

abstract: Our picks for August, including ‘Project Power,’ ‘Doctor Sleep’ and ‘Portrait of a Lady on Fire.’
lead_para: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for August.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in August

abstract: Theatrics distracted from the real payoff of the congressional hearings: the subpoenaed documents.
lead_para: The spectacle of the chief executives of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google’s parent testifying before Congress last week made for good TV drama. Yet the theatrics of the showdown distracted from the real payoff of the hearings: the accompanying cache of subpoenaed emails and texts from the past decade and a half. These documents provide compelling evidence — long rumored but seldom established — that the companies, especially Facebook and Amazon, in their rise to dominance did not always play by the rules and apparently violated antitrust laws.
headline: What Years of Emails and Texts Reveal About Your Friendly Tech Companies

abstract: The fight over a rezoning plan in Brooklyn has pitted progressives and mainstream Democrats against each other.
lead_para: A plan to bring tens of thousands of jobs to an overlooked corner of the city just outside Manhattan has become another battleground for New York City leaders. Progressives are attacking mainstream Democrats about their competing visions for the city. A powerful business is on the defensive.
headline: Progressives Killed Amazon’s Deal in New York. Is Industry City Next?

abstract: Amazon said it was rebranding Twitch Prime, in another attempt to crack the video game market after a big-budget game effort failed.
lead_para: BERKELEY, Calif. — Amazon stumbled as it worked to break into the lucrative video game industry. Now it’s trying again.
headline: After a Flop, Amazon Makes Another Foray Into Video Games

abstract: Netflix, Apple and the rest must figure out what bundles we love, and which we’ll grow to hate.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: A Steal Might Actually Be a Raw Deal

abstract: Mr. Wilke, who has been a key lieutenant to Jeff Bezos, is departing after building the e-commerce business for two decades.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Jeff Wilke, the chief executive of Amazon’s vast consumer business, said on Friday that he planned to retire early next year after more than two decades with the company, in a rare changing of the guard at the top of the e-commerce giant.
headline: Jeff Wilke, Amazon’s Chief of Consumer Business, Will Retire Next Year

abstract: Many companies are retreating. But Amazon, Apple, Facebook, Google and Microsoft are placing bets to get even bigger.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Even as Facebook grappled this month with an internal revolt and a cascade of criticism over its refusal to take action on President Trump’s inflammatory posts, the social network was actively making other bets behind the scenes.
headline: The Economy Is Reeling. The Tech Giants Spy Opportunity.

abstract: Every month, subscription streaming services add a new batch of titles to their libraries. Here are our picks for June.
lead_para: For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our twice-weekly Watching newsletter here.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix, Amazon and More in June

abstract: Since the 1980s, profit-sharing has declined. It deserves to make a comeback.
lead_para: After the bruising crises we’re now going through, it would be wonderful if we could somehow emerge a fairer nation. One possibility is to revive an old idea: sharing the profits.
headline: When Bosses Shared Their Profits

abstract: The Amazon-owned site, known for showing video game play, has become a hub for airing the sit-ins and marches over racial inequality.
lead_para: When Shawn Whiting began documenting the protests over George Floyd’s death late last month, he started by posting photos and videos on Twitter and livestreaming marches on the social media service.
headline: Where Black Lives Matter Protesters Stream Live Every Day: Twitch

abstract: A great comedy on Showtime returns after having its season cut short by the pandemic. A chill animated favorite is back, too, based on a popular series of children’s books.
lead_para: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, our TV critic Margaret Lyons offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.
headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?

abstract: The region’s lawmakers and regulators are taking direct aim at Amazon, Facebook, Google and Apple in a series of proposed laws.
lead_para: LONDON — European Union leaders are pursuing a new law to make it illegal for Amazon and Apple to give their own products preferential treatment over those of rivals that are sold on their online stores.
headline: ‘This Is a New Phase’: Europe Shifts Tactics to Limit Tech’s Power

abstract: A grilling on the power of digital giants in the internet age.
lead_para: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
headline: The Big Tech Hearing

abstract: Even though the tech industry’s four biggest companies were stung by a slowdown in spending, they reported a combined $28 billion in profits on Thursday.
lead_para: A day after lawmakers grilled the chief executives of the biggest tech companies about their size and power, Amazon, Apple, Alphabet and Facebook reported surprisingly healthy quarterly financial results, defying one of the worst economic downturns on record.
headline: The Economy Is in Record Decline, but Not for the Tech Giants

abstract: As lawmakers debate whether Apple, Google, Facebook, and Amazon are monopolies, a reporter recalls her attempt to avoid interacting with the companies.
lead_para: The chief executives of Amazon, Facebook, Google and Apple were called before a House antitrust committee this week, ostensibly to answer questions about whether they have too much power and whether that hurts consumers.
headline: I Tried to Live Without the Tech Giants. It Was Impossible.

abstract: The chiefs of Amazon, Apple, Google and Facebook faced withering questions from Democrats about anti-competitive practices and from Republicans about anti-conservative bias.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — The chief executives of Amazon, Apple, Google and Facebook, four tech giants worth nearly $5 trillion combined, faced withering questions from Republican and Democratic lawmakers alike on Wednesday for the tactics and market dominance that had made their enterprises successful.
headline: Lawmakers, United in Their Ire, Lash Out at Big Tech’s Leaders

abstract: Apple said on Tuesday its devices would be carbon-neutral by 2030, making it the latest tech giant to ramp up voluntary climate targets.
lead_para: The titans of the tech industry like to think of themselves as solvers of big world problems, and, lately, they’re tripping over themselves to show that they are working to solve a problem for which they, too, are culpable: climate change.
headline: Big Tech Has a Big Climate Problem. Now, It’s Being Forced to Clean Up.

abstract: Members of Congress will be able to grill tech C.E.O.s at a hearing. Let’s hope they don’t waste the opportunity.
lead_para: Amid the coronavirus pandemic, Congress’s attention will turn briefly to another matter: world domination. On Wednesday, the chief executives of Facebook, Amazon, Apple and Google’s parent company, Alphabet, will appear together to defend themselves in a continuing inquiry into their market power by the congressional subcommittee focused on antitrust.
headline: Four of the World’s Wealthiest Men Are Preparing for Battle

abstract: The hearing this month would be a central moment in the continuing backlash against the power of Amazon, Facebook, Alphabet and Apple.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — The chief executives of four of the world’s biggest technology companies will appear before Congress this month as part of its sweeping antitrust investigation into their market power, according to the committee running the inquiry, setting up a high-profile face-off between the companies and skeptical lawmakers.
headline: Four Top Tech C.E.O.s Will Testify in Antitrust Inquiry, Panel Says

abstract: Congress was once filled with “Atari Democrats.” This week's hearings showed their transformation into trust busters.
lead_para: On Wednesday, Representative David Cicilline, Democrat of Rhode Island and chairman of the House Judiciary Committee’s antitrust subcommittee, opened a half-virtual hearing on “Online Platforms and Market Power” with a combative opening statement: “Our founders would not bow before a king. Nor should we bow before the emperors of the online economy.”
headline: The Last Days of the Tech Emperors?

abstract: Big tech companies reported bumper profits in the shadow of congressional scrutiny over their outsize market power.
lead_para: You won’t want to miss our next DealBook Debrief call, where we will discuss racial injustice and corporate America with special guest Nikole Hannah-Jones, The Times’s domestic correspondent and creator of The 1619 Project. What more is needed from the business community to produce lasting change? Join us on Thursday, Aug. 6 at 11 a.m. Eastern to find out. R.S.V.P. here. (Want this delivered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.)
headline: They Made How Much?

abstract: The deadly disease has arrived in some offices, and employers are figuring out how to adapt.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — At Facebook on Thursday, the questions from spooked employees came thick and fast.
headline: Workplace vs. Coronavirus: ‘No One Has a Playbook for This’

abstract: Technology from Amazon, Apple, Google, IBM and Microsoft misidentified 35 percent of words from people who were black. White people fared much better.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — With an iPhone, you can dictate a text message. Put Amazon’s Alexa on your coffee table, and you can request a song from across the room.
headline: There Is a Racial Divide in Speech-Recognition Systems, Researchers Say

abstract: Workers for Instacart and Amazon staged walkouts, fearing coronavirus exposure on the job.
lead_para: Want this delivered to your inbox each morning? Sign up here.
headline: A Revolt Over Safety and Pay

abstract: The two companies are the latest targets of labor action by groups fearing virus exposure on the job.
lead_para: Signaling both growing anxiety and growing solidarity brought on by the coronavirus pandemic, workers in a variety of occupations across the country are protesting what they see as inadequate safety measures and insufficient pay for the risks they are confronting.
headline: Strikes at Instacart and Amazon Over Coronavirus Health Concerns

abstract: The shift to battery power has inspired a wave of new companies to challenge the automotive dinosaurs.
lead_para: FRANKFURT — For most of the last century the auto industry has been known more for shutdowns than start-ups. Brands like Saab, Pontiac and Plymouth disappeared and not much took their places.
headline: Tesla Isn’t the Only Start-Up Disrupting the Car Business

abstract: The retailer is trying to do two contradictory things: Ban hate literature but allow free speech.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon quietly banned Adolf Hitler's manifesto “Mein Kampf” late last week, part of its accelerating efforts to remove Nazi and other hate-filled material from its bookstore, before quickly reversing itself.
headline: Amazon Bans, Then Reinstates, Hitler’s ‘Mein Kampf’

abstract: “We’re going to operate like a pizza takeout place,” one independent bookstore owner said.
lead_para: Danny Caine, owner of The Raven Book Store in Lawrence, Kan., thought the store had weathered the worst of obstacles when it managed to stay in business after a giant Borders bookstore moved across the street. Then came the threat from Amazon’s domination of the book-selling business.
headline: Curbside Pickup. Bicycle Deliveries. Virtual Book Discussions. Amid Virus, Bookstores Get Creative.

abstract: Mr. Jones, who has used his radio show and website to promote conspiracy theories, is falsely claiming his products can fight the virus.
lead_para: The New York State attorney general has issued a cease-and-desist order to Alex Jones, the conservative radio host, alarmed by false claims on his website that his diet supplements and toothpaste could be used to fight the coronavirus.
headline: Alex Jones Is Told to Stop Selling Sham Anti-Coronavirus Toothpaste

abstract: The crisis is forcing a tech boomtown to hit pause.
lead_para: SEATTLE — There is a strange in-betweenness to life in the nation’s coronavirus capital. Classes continue on the University of Washington’s campus, some half-empty, others completely full. I have been teaching here 13 years, and faculty members have been getting detailed, palpably anxious instructions from administrators on how to teach online and on hand-washing and social distance, and reminders that no one on our 46,000-student campus has tested positive for the coronavirus that causes Covid-19. For now.
headline: Life in Seattle, America’s Coronavirus Capital

abstract: A bipartisan House bill aims to stem the flow of fake goods from China by putting pressure on companies like Amazon.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — A group of bipartisan House lawmakers on Monday outlined a plan to stem the flow of counterfeit products from China and other countries into the United States by making e-commerce companies such as Amazon legally liable for fake goods sold on their websites.
headline: Lawmakers Propose Making E-Commerce Companies Liable for Counterfeits

abstract: Michael Sanchez says he was trying to protect his sister in a lawsuit complaint.
lead_para: The brother of Jeff Bezos’s girlfriend has filed a lawsuit accusing Mr. Bezos and his security consultant of defaming him in connection with a 2019 National Enquirer story revealing Mr. Bezos’s extramarital affair.
headline: Jeff Bezos Is Sued by His Girlfriend’s Brother

abstract: Battling a troubled move and loss of shoppers’ trust, the New York online grocery service now contends with increased competition.
lead_para: About a year and a half ago, longtime patrons of the pioneering grocery delivery service FreshDirect started complaining that orders were arriving hours late. There were broken eggs and spoiled fruit. One customer reported that she had paid $200 for groceries — only to receive nothing but seltzer and a loaf of bread.
headline: FreshDirect, After Broken Eggs and Angry Customers, Stages a Comeback

abstract: So far, the Everything Store has dodged some of the scrutiny dogging Google and Facebook.
lead_para: SEATTLE — The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, with its 1.4 million truck drivers, warehouse workers and other transportation laborers, does not represent any Amazon workers, nor is it organizing them. But the union keeps butting into the e-commerce giant, which ships billions of packages a year.
headline: Unions Push F.T.C. to Study if Amazon Warps the Economy

abstract: Despite regulatory scrutiny and pressure from lawmakers, the industry’s wealthiest are continuing to grow at remarkable speeds for big companies.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — When Google’s parent company, Alphabet, said on Monday that revenue at the company soared past $161 billion last year, it was a stark reminder of the widening gap between tech’s wealthiest outfits and the rest of the industry.
headline: The Gap Between the Haves and Have-Nots of Tech Widens

abstract: The European Union outlined proposals to bolster its digital economy and keep it from being overly reliant on foreign companies, while cracking down on those companies.
lead_para: LONDON — Across the digital economy, Europe has been missing.
headline: Europe, Overrun by Foreign Tech Giants, Wants to Grow Its Own

abstract: The Pentagon said it “strongly opposes” the request from the internet giant, which is challenging the awarding of a defense contract to Microsoft.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon has asked a federal court to let it depose President Trump and Defense Secretary Mark Esper, arguing that hearing from them is essential to determining if they intervened against the internet company when the Pentagon awarded a multibillion-dollar contract to a competitor.
headline: Amazon Looks to Question Trump in Pentagon Contracting Case

abstract: The actor’s new Amazon series about renegade Nazi hunters is loosely inspired by actual events but has more in common with comic books and ’70s action flicks.
lead_para: When Logan Lerman was offered the lead in “Hunters,” he did what all actors do: He cast about for inspiration.
headline: In ‘Hunters,’ Al Pacino Stalks Nazis Into New Territory

abstract: The world’s richest man unveiled a fund to help climate scientists and activists, an escalation of his philanthropic efforts.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive and the world’s richest man, said on Monday that he was committing $10 billion to address the climate crisis in a new initiative he called the Bezos Earth Fund.
headline: Jeff Bezos Commits $10 Billion to Address Climate Change

abstract: The retailer once said it would sell “the good, the bad and the ugly.” Now it has banished objectionable volumes — and agreed to erasing the swastikas from a photo book about a Nazi takeover.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon is quietly canceling its Nazis.
headline: In Amazon’s Bookstore, No Second Chances for the Third Reich

abstract: Microphones and cameras lurk everywhere. You may want to slip on some privacy armor.
lead_para: Last year, Ben Zhao decided to buy an Alexa-enabled Echo speaker for his Chicago home. Mr. Zhao just wanted a digital assistant to play music, but his wife, Heather Zheng, was not enthused. “She freaked out,” he said.
headline: Activate This ‘Bracelet of Silence,’ and Alexa Can’t Eavesdrop

abstract: Included in the breach was a list that purportedly showed how much money each of the platform’s streamers had earned in the past two years.
lead_para: Twitch, the live-video site popular with gamers, said on Wednesday that it had endured a data breach that security researchers believe may have provided sweeping insight into the platform’s computer code, security vulnerabilities and payments to its content creators.
headline: A ‘potentially disastrous’ data breach hits Twitch, the livestreaming site.

abstract: The company, which is backed by Amazon and Ford, is seeking to sell shares in one of the biggest initial public offerings of the year.
lead_para: Rivian, an electric truck maker backed by Amazon and Ford Motor, on Friday revealed huge losses and a voracious need for cash as it headed into one of the most anticipated initial public offerings of the year.
headline: Rivian, an Electric Vehicle Start-Up, Reveals Large Losses in Its I.P.O. Filing

abstract: Give any social media platform long enough, and it turns into a mall.
lead_para: In three short years, TikTok has grown in the public imagination from an app for dancing teens into an all-purpose cultural powerhouse, driving trends in music, food, news and politics, and changing the way people communicate online. In the process, it’s also become something else: a place where people buy things. Lots of them.
headline: Will TikTok Make You Buy It?

abstract: The announcement was a further retreat from the rigid stance the tech giant had taken earlier this year.
lead_para: Amazon told employees on Monday that it was loosening its plans to force workers to return to their offices, further retreating from a more rigid approach it had taken earlier this year.
headline: Amazon expands flexibility for some employees to work from home indefinitely.

abstract: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of October’s most promising new titles.
lead_para: (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, HBO, Hulu and More in October

abstract: Why are DoorDash and Instacart letting businesses buy their way to the top of search results?
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
headline: New Digital Companies, Old Ad Habits

abstract: Despite an overall decline in office leasing in the United States, technology companies gobbled up more space in the Seattle area than they had the previous year.
lead_para: The pandemic was a disaster for commercial real estate markets. In the Seattle area, it was a boon.
headline: As Big Tech Grows in the Pandemic, Seattle Grows With It

abstract: Unlike any other streamer, Amazon brings hundreds of billions of dollars in revenue and the power of a vast network of other lines of business to the fight.
lead_para: In the 1930s and ’40s, five major Hollywood studios dominated the film industry and tried to lock up distribution and exhibition channels as well by taking over movie theaters across the country. Courts and regulators saw that allowing studios so much power up and down the film supply chain posed grave threats to the integrity of the industry and to viewer choice.
headline: Don’t Let Amazon Eat the Film Industry

abstract: A bipartisan group told the company that they were considering referring their concerns to the Justice Department for a potential criminal inquiry.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan group of lawmakers pressed Amazon’s chief executive on Monday to respond to allegations that its executives provided a congressional inquiry with false answers to questions about its house-brand products.
headline: Lawmakers question whether Amazon executives, including Jeff Bezos, misled Congress.

abstract: A knot of problems with Amazon’s system for handling paid and unpaid leaves has led to devastating consequences for workers.
lead_para: A year ago, Tara Jones, an Amazon warehouse worker in Oklahoma, cradled her newborn, glanced over her pay stub on her phone and noticed that she had been underpaid by a significant chunk: $90 out of $540.
headline: Inside Amazon’s Worst Human Resources Problem

abstract: Many companies do not account for the emissions from their supply chains, which can be a significant majority of their contributions to greenhouse gases.
lead_para: For nearly 30 years, the pharmaceutical giant Bristol Myers Squibb has proclaimed it’s been setting and meeting ambitious targets around energy and greenhouse gas emissions. These days, those goals include being “carbon neutral” by 2040.
headline: Corporate Climate Pledges Often Ignore a Key Component: Supply Chains

abstract: Hosting relatives for the holiday weekend? Here are some great films and series that will appeal to all ages.
lead_para: The holiday weekend is here! We want to help by taking one thing off your plate. We’ve gone through Netflix, Hulu, Amazon Prime Video and Disney+ to find the best titles that are suitable for the entire family.
headline: Here Are 5 Family-Friendly Things to Stream This Weekend

abstract: For years merchants have complained about transaction fees that eat into their revenue, but having Amazon take up the fight may ratchet up the pressure. The change will go into effect Jan. 19.
lead_para: Amazon will stop accepting Visa credit cards issued in Britain from mid-January, the company said on Wednesday.
headline: Amazon, railing against high fees, will stop accepting Visa credit cards issued in Britain.

abstract: Sean O’Brien scored a decisive victory among union members after criticizing the current leadership as too timid in UPS talks and Amazon organizing.
lead_para: Sean O’Brien was a rising star in the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in 2017 when the union’s longtime president, James P. Hoffa, effectively cast him aside.
headline: A Hoffa Ally, Then a Foe, and Soon the Teamsters President

abstract: If ever an issue cried out for some lawmaking guidance, this is it.
lead_para: Facebook, oops, Meta — boy, this is going to take some getting used to — announced this week that it would end its decade-old facial recognition system and delete the face data of over a billion users, prompting the cybersecurity reporter Kashmir Hill of The New York Times to tweet, “My jaw dropped to the floor.”
headline: Is Meta’s Facial Recognition Retreat Another Head Fake?

abstract: The gift was the largest yet for the foundation and was among several splashy donations in recent months by Mr. Bezos, one of the world’s richest people.
lead_para: Former President Barack Obama’s private foundation announced on Monday that it had been promised $100 million from the Amazon founder Jeff Bezos.
headline: Jeff Bezos gives $100 million to the Obama Foundation.

abstract: Signing bonuses, higher wages, even college tuition. Companies are using perks to entice new employees in an industry that has been battered by the pandemic.
lead_para: Macy’s is offering referral bonuses of up to $500 for each friend or family member that employees recruit to join the company. Walmart is paying as much as $17 an hour to start and has begun offering free college tuition to its workers. And some Amazon warehouse jobs now command signing bonuses of up to $3,000.
headline: Retailers Scramble to Attract Workers Ahead of the Holidays

abstract: Amazon, racing to get products from factories to our homes, lures merchants with chartered cargo ships.
