lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
headline: Amazon on the High Seas

abstract: The judgment, which is subject to court approval, is in line with a “right to know” law that was designed to keep workers safe in the pandemic.
lead_para: Amazon has agreed to pay $500,000 to help enforce California’s consumer protection laws after the company was accused of concealing Covid-19 case numbers from its workers, officials said on Monday.
headline: Amazon agrees to pay $500,000 in California over claims that it hid Covid-19 cases from workers.

abstract: Competing with SpaceX, OneWeb and others, the e-commerce titan will rely on small rockets to get prototypes of its satellite constellation into space.
lead_para: Amazon is getting ready to go to space.
headline: Amazon to Launch First Two Internet Satellites in 2022

abstract: A reader says the congresswoman’s diligence and talent will prevail. Also: Treating chickens humanely; Jeff Bezos and Amazon workers; climate-friendly policies.
lead_para: To the Editor:
headline: Republican Attacks on A.O.C.

abstract: Facebook groups spread conspiracy theories and shield abuse. Here are ways to make them less toxic.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: How to Fix Facebook Groups

abstract: With several films competing for Golden Globes on Sunday and a number of high-priced movies coming this year, the streaming service has altered its reputation in Hollywood.
lead_para: [Follow live updates from the 2021 Golden Globes and analysis.]
headline: Amazon Moves From Film Industry’s Margins to the Mainstream

abstract: Andy Jassy, the chief of Amazon’s cloud computing division, will become chief executive, while Mr. Bezos, the company’s founder, will become executive chairman.
lead_para: SEATTLE — When Jeff Bezos founded an online bookseller named Amazon in 1994, he said the question that he was asked most frequently was “What’s the internet?”
headline: Jeff Bezos to Step Down as Amazon C.E.O.

abstract: After being cut off by Amazon and other tech giants, Parler worked for weeks to find a way to get back on the internet.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Parler, the social network that drew millions of Trump supporters before disappearing from the internet, is back online a month after Amazon and other tech giants cut off the company for hosting calls for violence around the time of the Capitol riot.
headline: Parler, a Social Network That Attracted Trump Fans, Returns Online

abstract: An expert calls for “meaningful data protection.” Also: No worries about a baby bust; organized labor at Amazon; dancing in the pandemic.
lead_para: To the Editor:
headline: The Need for a Strong Privacy Law

abstract: The president’s support for the rights of unionizing Amazon workers delighted political organizers in Alabama who are hoping to build long-term Democratic momentum in a reliably red state.
lead_para: BESSEMER, Ala. — The first time Darryl Richardson tried to start a union, he was 23 years old and virtually alone in the effort. It failed, he lost his job, and he remembers the lasting fears of other employees who worried they would suffer a similar fate.
headline: How Biden Is Trying to Help Working-Class Voters in Red-State Alabama

abstract: The vote can often involve a painstaking process that will be closely scrutinized by representatives from the union and the retail giant.
lead_para: The counting of votes that will determine whether a union can form at an Amazon warehouse in Bessemer, Ala., begins Tuesday. But the results of the union election, one of the most consequential in recent memory, may not be known until later this week or early next week because the vote can often involve a painstaking process that will be closely scrutinized by representatives from the union and Amazon.
headline: The Amazon union vote: What happens next.

abstract: The animated version of the comic book series cocreated by Robert Kirkman — with mayhem, destruction and gore — is now on Amazon Prime Video.
lead_para: “Invincible” is not like other animated superhero series.
headline: In ‘Invincible,’ a Young Hero Arrives for a Mature Audience

abstract: New research suggests that when big companies increase wages, they drive up pay in the places where they operate — without a notable loss in jobs.
lead_para: Amazon has embarked on an advertising blitz this winter, urging Congress to follow the company’s lead and raise the federal minimum wage to $15 an hour. American workers “simply can’t wait” for higher pay, the company said in a recent blog post.
headline: When Amazon Raises Its Minimum Wage, Local Companies Follow Suit

abstract: Around 6,000 workers at an Amazon warehouse in Bessemer, a former steel town outside of Birmingham, are voting over the next week on whether they want to be represented by a union.
lead_para: President Biden expressed solidarity with workers attempting to unionize an Amazon facility in Alabama in a video released Sunday that emphasized his broad support of the labor movement — without explicitly backing their cause or naming the company itself.
headline: Biden expresses solidarity with Alabama workers attempting to unionize an Amazon warehouse.

abstract: Yes, tech companies are hiring. Here’s why they want you to notice.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Big Tech Wants Points for Jobs

abstract: Amazon Live is a prominent example of how interactive video shopping, popularized by TV networks like QVC, has moved online.
lead_para: Matt Granite had been working for years as a consumer journalist filming segments that were syndicated on American television stations and sharing additional videos on his YouTube channel, The Deal Guy.
headline: Livestreaming, Still Niche, Grows as a Tool for Retailers

abstract: The founder of the e-commerce giant steps down as C.E.O. in two days. Then what?
lead_para: Jeff Bezos founded Amazon 27 years ago. He steps down as C.E.O. two days from now. His successor, Andy Jassy, will take over the e-commerce giant on July 5.
headline: Amazon After Bezos

abstract: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are our picks for some of July’s most promising new titles.
lead_para: (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our twice-weekly Watching newsletter here.)
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, HBO, Hulu and More in July

abstract: The Amazon founder and three others lifted off in Blue Origin’s New Shepard spacecraft, fulfilling a goal more than 20 years in the making.
lead_para: VAN HORN, Texas — Jeff Bezos, the richest human in the world, went to space on Tuesday. It was a brief jaunt — rising more than 65 miles into the sky above West Texas — in a spacecraft that was built by Mr. Bezos’ rocket company, Blue Origin.
headline: Bezos Launches to Space, Aiming to Reignite His Rocket Company’s Ambitions

abstract: The discovery of multiple nooses has set off heated debates about the responsibility of companies and the ability of workers to speak their mind.
lead_para: WINDSOR, Conn. — The town of Windsor has developed a niche in the world of warehouses and manufacturing, taking advantage of wide open spaces and crisscrossing interstates in nearby Hartford. Walgreens has a large facility here, as does Dollar Tree.
headline: Nooses, Anger and No Answers: Inside the Uproar Over a Future Amazon Site

abstract: A trade group representing Google, Facebook, Amazon, Apple and others said changes to a Hong Kong privacy law could stop firms from providing services in the city.
lead_para: An industry group representing the largest American internet companies warned Hong Kong’s government that changes to the city’s data-protection laws could impact companies’ ability to provide services in the city.
headline: American Internet Giants Hit Back at Hong Kong Doxxing Law

abstract: An inherent flaw in government purchasing of technology: Budget cycles take forever, tech changes fast.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Government Tech Moves Too Slooowly

abstract: A recent Times project that examined how the tech giant manages its workers took months of reporting and hundreds of interviews.
lead_para: Last summer, amid a hiring spree at Amazon so gigantic it left historians struggling for comparisons, Karen Weise, a Times reporter who covers the company from Seattle, brought up a puzzling question to her editors. Approaching the million-worker mark, Amazon was on track to becoming the largest private employer in the United States. Yet, in spite of solid wages and generous benefits, it was quickly cycling through employees. Why?
headline: Investigating Amazon, the Employer

abstract: Now they will be pursued in federal court, a significant retreat from a strategy that often helps companies avoid liability.
lead_para: Amazon told customers this week that it would no longer require them to resolve their legal complaints involving the technology giant through arbitration, a significant retreat from a strategy that often helps companies avoid liability.
headline: Amazon Ends Use of Arbitration for Customer Disputes

abstract: Readers take sides pro and con on a controversial question. Also: Proof of vaccination at cultural venues; Black colleges; student loan forgiveness; decluttering; Amazon’s business model.
lead_para: To the Editor:
headline: Should Big States Be Broken Up?

abstract: Even as businesses have reopened, many people continue to do their shopping online, and much of that business continues to go Amazon’s way.
lead_para: Amazon on Thursday followed a trend among the country’s biggest tech firms. The company said it made more money in the latest quarter compared with last year — a lot more money.
headline: Amazon’s quarterly profit jumps to $7.8 billion.

abstract: Some developers are sick of Apple being a dictator. Apple says it’s protecting us. Let’s dissect this.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Why All the Fury at Apple?

abstract: The American company sees big potential in the country’s nascent e-commerce market. Both sides view a troubled grocery store chain as the key to success.
lead_para: NEW DELHI — Amazon and one of the world’s richest men are engaged in a multibillion-dollar, politically fraught clash over Rani Pillai’s favorite place to buy groceries.
headline: Why Amazon Is Confronting the Richest Man in India

abstract: Amazon relishes mastering the impossible. But it hasn’t put the same energy into managing its work force.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Amazon Is Brilliant. Why Not at H.R.?

abstract: A bipartisan group of House members introduced five bills targeting Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — House lawmakers on Friday introduced sweeping antitrust legislation aimed at restraining the power of Big Tech and staving off corporate consolidation. If passed, the bills would be the most ambitious update to monopoly laws in decades.
headline: Lawmakers, Taking Aim at Big Tech, Push Sweeping Overhaul of Antitrust

abstract: Our streaming picks for June, including ‘Sweet Tooth,’ ‘Good on Paper’ and ‘Eden'
lead_para: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for June.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in June

abstract: Why Google thought twice about restoring your privacy.
lead_para: There is a saying in Silicon Valley that when a product is free, the user is the product.
headline: Google’s Privacy Backpedal Shows Why It’s So Hard Not to Be Evil

abstract: House lawmakers have gotten serious. A package of bills poses existential threats to the tech giants.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: What Congress Wants From Big Tech

abstract: Delegates will vote on a resolution pledging “all resources necessary” for efforts to unionize the retail giant.
lead_para: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which represents over one million workers in North America in industries including parcel delivery and freight, will vote on whether to make it a priority to organize Amazon workers and help them win a union contract.
headline: The Teamsters consider a new emphasis on organizing Amazon workers.

abstract: French soccer teams could face economic disaster after a television partner said it would refuse to honor its contract. Transfers, salaries and budgets hang in the balance.
lead_para: French soccer’s new television deal was supposed to save the league and its clubs from a financial meltdown.
headline: As France Chases Title at Euros, Its League Faces a $400 Million Hole

abstract: The persistence of bogus reviews raises big questions for Amazon.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Amazon’s Open Secret

abstract: As the fortunes of Amazon and its founder have increased, their public images have cratered.
lead_para: The latest creation from the technology giant Amazon occupies two floors in a shopping district in central London: a hair studio. Inside the 1,500-square-foot Amazon Salon, customers can visualize potential new hairstyles on the company’s tablets, buy shampoos and conditioners not available in drugstores, and order up things like a children’s haircut ($20), a roots tint ($62) or a thermal cut with heated scissors ($166).
headline: The Jeff Bezos Paradox

abstract: With the failure of the union campaign in Bessemer still fresh on their minds, labor organizers are looking to retool their strategy.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Prime Day, Amazon’s annual summer shopping bonanza, lasted not one but two days this June. The company advertised it incessantly on social media and especially to subscribers of Amazon Prime, a group that includes close to half of the U.S. population. In the many warehouses in and around the company’s hometown, thousands of workers showed up to their packing and sorting stations for a mandatory, extra-long shift.
headline: Amazon Transformed Seattle. Now, Its Workers Are Poised to Take It Back.

abstract: The Group of 20 gathering begins a crucial stretch in yearslong negotiations.
lead_para: VENICE — The world’s top economic leaders convened on Friday to hash out crucial details of what would be the largest overhaul of the international tax system in a century, kicking off a three-month race to finish a deal by the end of the year.
headline: Finance Ministers Meet in Venice to Finalize Global Tax Agreement

abstract: The gap keeps widening between the super rich tech superstars and the merely super. There’s one possible explanation.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Big Tech Has Outgrown This Planet

abstract: An unusual number of vice presidents are leaving for prominent jobs at public companies or high-growth start-ups.
lead_para: SEATTLE — When Andy Jassy is elevated to chief executive of Amazon on Monday, taking the reins from its founder, Jeff Bezos, it will be one of the most closely watched executive handoffs in years.
headline: Bezos’ Exit Is One of Many Among Amazon’s Top Ranks

abstract: The company has hired a law firm to look into allegations at Amazon Web Services.
lead_para: Amazon has hired a law firm to investigate claims of widespread gender discrimination in part of its cloud computing division, the company said in an email to employees late last week.
headline: Amazon will investigate gender bias claims in its cloud division.

abstract: The latest jobs report was good, consumer confidence is back and stocks are at record highs.
lead_para: Happy Fourth of July. Between strong jobs growth in June, rising consumer confidence and a record-high stock market, there’s much to celebrate in the economy. So fire up the grill, watch the fireworks and enjoy the long holiday weekend. — Charlotte Cowles
headline: The Week in Business: Start With a Bang

abstract: Newly released emails show particular praise of Amazon among top Defense Department officials during the Trump administration as technology firms competed for a $10 billion award.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — As the Defense Department prepares to solicit bids for cloud-computing work that could yield billions of dollars for Amazon, members of Congress are raising new questions about the company’s efforts to win a $10 billion contract during the Trump administration.
headline: G.O.P. Lawmakers Question Amazon’s Connections on Pentagon Contract

abstract: New data shows Netflix, long the king of streaming, is losing attention as subscribers shift to competitors like Disney+ and Amazon Prime Video.
lead_para: The cracks are showing in Netflix’s worldwide dominance.
headline: Disney is chipping away at Netflix’s dominance.

abstract: The world’s richest man thanked Amazon employees and customers for making his flight to space possible.
lead_para: From groceries and streaming subscriptions to web servers and Alexa, Amazon has become one of the most powerful economic forces in the world. And after Jeff Bezos returned from his brief flight to space on Tuesday in a rocket built by his private space company, Blue Origin, he made remarks that drew attention to the vast wealth the company had created for him.
headline: Bezos thanks Amazon workers and customers for his vast wealth, prompting backlash.

abstract: Executives, lobbyists, and more than a dozen groups paid by Big Tech have tried to head off bipartisan support for six bills meant to undo the dominance of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — In the days after lawmakers introduced legislation that could break the dominance of tech companies, Apple’s chief executive, Tim Cook, called Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other members of Congress to deliver a warning.
headline: Tech Giants, Fearful of Proposals to Curb Them, Blitz Washington With Lobbying

abstract: Not since the government sued to break up Microsoft in the late 1990s has there been greater demand for people who know the ins and outs of corporate competition law.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Lawyers at Kellogg, Hansen, Todd, Figel & Frederick, a top corporate law firm, were abuzz on Monday as they grappled with a federal judge’s rulings about antitrust cases related to their client: Facebook.
headline: Boom Times for Lawyers as Washington Pursues Big Tech

abstract: But he is not the only politician who shows which way the wind is blowing.
lead_para: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I was hoping to pick up where we left off last week, with the New York City mayoral primary and our new ranked-choice voting system. Assuming Eric Adams holds on to his lead, what do you think his win says about the state of the city — and of the Democratic Party?
headline: The Mike Pence Saga Tells Us More Than We Want to Know

abstract: Amazon said that if Ms. Khan played a role in antitrust investigations of Amazon, it would violate federal ethics rules and the firm’s right to due process.
lead_para: Amazon demanded on Wednesday that Lina Khan, the new chair of the Federal Trade Commission and an avowed critic of the company, recuse herself from any antitrust investigation into the e-commerce giant.
headline: Amazon says the new F.T.C. chair, Lina Khan, should recuse herself from investigations.

abstract: A committee took its first vote in the early afternoon, advancing a bill that would increase the money companies pay government agencies when getting some mergers approved.
lead_para: House lawmakers on Wednesday began the process of considering a legislative package that would overhaul the nation’s antitrust laws in an attempt to rein in the power of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google.
headline: House Lawmakers Are Considering 6 Bills Aimed at Big Tech

abstract: We’re interested in learning as much as possible about how Amazon manages its work force.
lead_para: Amazon and its founder, Jeff Bezos, have pioneered news ways of mass-managing people through technology, relying on a maze of systems that minimized human contact to grow unconstrained.
headline: Are You a Current or Former Amazon Employee?

abstract: Margrethe Vestager is the European regulator trying to do something audacious: get companies like Apple, Amazon and Facebook to play fair and pay taxes.
lead_para: Margrethe Vestager and Kara Swisher have something in common: They both have made it their job to keep watch on Jeff Bezos, Tim Cook, Mark Zuckerberg and the other titans of tech. Vestager does this from her post as the head of the European Commission’s antitrust division. And while Swisher may regularly opine on what drives tech C.E.O.s, Vestager says she isn’t interested in “soul-searching” their motives. She’s focused on catching them in the act — whether companies are sliding from “aggressive tax planning into tax avoidance” or they are moving from content moderation into censorship.
headline: Meet Big Tech’s Tormenter in Chief

abstract: The tech giant deserves credit for taking on big issues, but what matters is that it follows through to the end.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Amazon Wants a Lot of New Laws

abstract: Outsiders see a business success story for the ages. Many insiders see an employment system under strain.
lead_para: An Amazon worker tries to return from a Covid-related leave and is mistakenly fired. A wife panics as disability benefits halt for her gravely ill husband. An employee is fired for having a single underproductive day.
headline: Power and Peril: 5 Takeaways on Amazon’s Employment Machine

abstract: Four people will be aboard the New Shepard, the Blue Origin rocket named for the first American in space, when it is set to launch.
lead_para: An auction winner paid more than $28 million for an 11-minute ride into space alongside Jeff Bezos, on a reusable rocket launched by his space company, Blue Origin.
headline: Winning Bidder Paid $28 Million for Ticket to Space With Jeff Bezos

abstract: New hotel quarantines in Britain.
lead_para: New arrivals to England from South Africa, Brazil and 31 other countries deemed to be hot spots for coronavirus variants are now required to spend 10 days quarantining in a government-sanctioned hotel at a cost of nearly $2,500 for an adult. Travelers from elsewhere are required to quarantine at home for 10 days.
headline: Your Tuesday Briefing

abstract: Officials are looking for signs of manipulation behind the recent market frenzy.
lead_para: Keith Gill’s cheerleading of GameStop stock made him an icon among Reddit-based traders during the recent meme-stock rally, and may have minted him a fortune — on paper at least. But Massachusetts authorities are now looking at whether he broke securities rules, The Times’s Matthew Goldstein reports, as regulators there and at the federal level investigate possible market manipulation in the trading frenzy.
headline: It’s Memes vs. Regulators

abstract: Mr. Jassy, who will become Amazon’s chief this summer, has spent more than two decades absorbing lessons from Mr. Bezos.
lead_para: SEATTLE — In 2002, Andy Jassy, a young executive at Amazon, began closely shadowing Jeff Bezos, the founder of the online bookstore.
headline: How Andy Jassy, Amazon’s Next C.E.O., Was a ‘Brain Double’ for Jeff Bezos

abstract: The company said the attorney general, Letitia James, had overstepped her authority in investigating workplace safety.
lead_para: Amazon sued New York’s attorney general, Letitia James, on Friday in an attempt to stop her from bringing charges against the company over safety concerns at two of its warehouses in New York City.
headline: Amazon Sues New York Attorney General to Block Covid-19 Charges

abstract: The Amazon founder started his private rocket company in 2000, but its busiest phase could just now be starting.
lead_para: For most of its two decades of existence, Blue Origin was like Willy Wonka’s chocolate factory in the children’s book by Roald Dahl.
headline: Jeff Bezos Renews Focus on Blue Origin, Which Has Been Slower to Launch

abstract: The celebrated editor is ending his tenure at the helm of a very different newspaper than the one he originally signed on to run.
lead_para: On July 30, 2013, Martin Baron left The Washington Post building and crossed 15th Street for an extremely rare happy hour drink.
headline: How Marty Baron and Jeff Bezos Remade The Washington Post

abstract: The Federal Trade Commission said Amazon secretly lowered hourly delivery wages and tried to mask the smaller wages by using customer tips to cover for the smaller hourly pay.
lead_para: Amazon agreed on Tuesday to pay $62 million to the Federal Trade Commission to settle charges that it withheld tips to delivery drivers over a two-and-a-half year period, in a case that highlights the federal government’s increased interest in gig-economy workers.
headline: Amazon agrees to $62 million settlement for withholding tips to delivery drivers.

abstract: The Amazon founder is stepping down as C.E.O. but will continue to exert a lot of influence at the e-commerce giant.
lead_para: On Feb. 22-23, DealBook will convene some of the sharpest minds in business and policy for our DealBook DC Policy Project. Join us from anywhere in the world, free of charge. Register today.
headline: What Jeff Bezos Does Next

abstract: Our streaming picks for February, including ‘Parks and Recreation,’ ‘News of the World’ and ‘Bliss.’
lead_para: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for February.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in February

abstract: A big question about the future of commerce is how local businesses will succeed online.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Who Wins the (Online) Corner Store?

abstract: The company has always opposed efforts by its workers to organize, but its regulatory fate rests largely with Democrats in Washington.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Amazon is aligned with the Biden administration on several fronts.
headline: Amazon Walks a Political Tightrope in Its Union Fight

abstract: The unionization struggle at a year-old warehouse in Alabama will help shape the future of work.
lead_para: For a few minutes on Sunday night, President Biden sounded a little like a union leader. “Unions put power in the hands of workers,” he said in a video statement of support for the union drive at an Amazon fulfillment center in Bessemer, Ala. “They level the playing field. They give you a stronger voice for your health, your safety, higher wages, protections from racial discrimination and sexual harassment. Unions lift up workers, both union and nonunion, but especially Black and Brown workers.”
headline: Biden Is Saying Things Amazon Doesn’t Want to Hear

abstract: The vote in Alabama is a temperature check on beliefs about Amazon and labor unions in the United States.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Why Amazon’s Union Vote Matters

abstract: New York reaches a deal to legalize marijuana, and China strikes back against sanctions.
lead_para: Good morning and happy Passover. Here’s what you need to know in business and tech news for the week ahead. — Charlotte Cowles
headline: The Week in Business: A Big Win for Marijuana

abstract: A former school librarian recalls feeling panicked by an active-shooter drill that “felt all too real.” Also: Beach erosion on the Outer Banks; Amazon and organized labor.
lead_para: To the Editor:
headline: ‘A Country That Values Guns More Than Children’

abstract: In “Fulfillment,” Alec MacGillis tours America to understand how one company’s culture and capitalistic impulses are seeping into our way of life.
lead_para: FULFILLMENTWinning and Losing in One-Click AmericaBy Alec MacGillis
headline: What Is Amazon Doing to Our Country?

abstract: Coupang, a start-up founded by a Harvard Business School dropout, helped transform e-commerce in South Korea, one of the world’s fastest-growing markets for online shopping.
lead_para: SEOUL, South Korea — The small white delivery trucks zip down streets all over South Korea. The uniformed workers send photos of safely delivered packages to impatient customers. Workers can move so fast, their employer promises, that it calls the service “rocket delivery.”
headline: South Korea’s Answer to Amazon Debuts on Wall Street

abstract: The unionization effort, which began last summer, is the largest and most viable organizing campaign among Amazon workers in the United States.
lead_para: The most closely watched union election in recent history is underway in Alabama, where almost 6,000 workers at an Amazon warehouse near Birmingham are voting on whether they want to form a union. The election has attracted attention from President Biden, National Football League players and Hollywood actors, making it a high-stakes test of whether a union has a role in one of the country’s biggest employers.
headline: The Amazon Unionization Vote: What to Know

abstract: Google presents itself to independent sellers as cheaper and less restrictive. But it is not clear whether it can change people’s habits of going straight to Amazon.
lead_para: OAKLAND, Calif. — Google tried to copy Amazon’s playbook to become the shopping hub of the internet, with little success. Now it is trying something different: the anti-Amazon strategy.
headline: Google Aims to Be the Anti-Amazon of E-Commerce. It Has a Long Way to Go.

abstract: Labor leaders are effusive in praising the new president, but experts worry that he may be powerless to reverse unions’ long-term decline.
lead_para: Two months into the new administration, labor leaders are proclaiming Joseph R. Biden Jr. to be the most union-friendly president of their lifetime — and “maybe ever,” as Steve Rosenthal, a former political director for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said in an interview.
headline: Biden May Be the Most Pro-Labor President Ever; That May Not Save Unions

abstract: The operators of Climate Pledge Arena, home to the N.H.L.’s newest team, the Seattle Kraken, plan to reduce and offset its entire planet-warming footprint. They still have a lot to prove.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Fans of the Seattle Kraken, who joined the N.H.L. this season as the league’s 32nd team, had a lot to take in at the club’s first-ever home game last Saturday. There were new players on the ice to cheer, new seats to find and new concession stands to seek.
headline: An Arena Where the Goal Is ‘Net Zero’ Carbon Emissions, Even From Fans

abstract: After the Blue Origin crew set down, science fiction met reality.
lead_para: A half-century ago, a television show told young people that space travel would be the coolest thing ever. Some of them were even inspired to work toward that goal. Science fiction met reality on Wednesday as one of those fans, now one of the richest people in the world, gave the show’s leading actor a brief ride up into the ether.
headline: Back on Earth, Shatner and Bezos have a Kirk-Spock moment.

abstract: The organizers say they will have enough signatures by Monday to file for an election with the National Labor Relations Board. The company is pushing back.
lead_para: Tucked in four plastic tubs in a tent by a Staten Island bus stop are stacks of cards with valuable autographs: the signatures of more than 1,700 hourly Amazon workers.
headline: Amazon Workers on Staten Island Aim for Union Vote

abstract: The congressman discusses the future of his party and why he’s teaming up with Democrats on a bipartisan effort that could break up big tech.
lead_para: Representative Ken Buck has joined forces with the Democratic congressman David Cicilline and others to push through a package of antitrust legislation that could prove damning to companies like Amazon, Apple, Google and Facebook. “As a conservative, I don’t think big is bad. I think big is great,” he says. But at the same time, he is quick to clarify that Silicon Valley isn’t the land of “benevolent monopolists” and that leaders like Jeff Bezos need to be more transparent about their business practices.
headline: Why Republican Ken Buck Believes in Antitrust and Doesn’t Believe in the ‘Big Lie’

abstract: The company’s profit was lower, largely because of higher labor costs and huge investments in its delivery network.
lead_para: Amazon on Thursday posted its slowest sales growth in almost seven years as the pandemic-fueled surge in online shopping eased.
headline: Amazon sales growth slows and costs rise.

abstract: The outcome could bring a second unionization vote at an Amazon warehouse in less than a year.
lead_para: A fledgling union of employees at four Amazon warehouses on Staten Island demonstrated on Monday that they had enough worker interest to hold an election to form a union, the National Labor Relations Board said. The agency’s determination lays the groundwork for the second unionization vote at an Amazon warehouse in less than a year.
headline: Amazon workers on Staten Island show they have enough support to hold a union election.

abstract: The agreement comes as more than 130 countries agreed this month to an overhaul of the international tax system that will see nations adopt a global minimum tax of 15 percent.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — The United States reached an agreement on Thursday with Austria, France, Italy, Spain and Britain that will terminate the threat of American tariffs on certain goods from those countries in exchange for the eventual removal of digital services taxes that they had imposed on companies like Facebook, Amazon and Google.
headline: U.S. agrees to drop tariffs on countries that imposed digital services taxes as a global tax overhaul moves ahead.

abstract: When the tech giants splurge on big-ticket investments, it’s great for them but hard for others to keep up.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
headline: Spending Is Big Tech’s Superpower

abstract: Our picks for October, including ‘Colin in Black & White,’ ‘Poltergeist’ and ‘Diana: The Musical’
lead_para: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for October.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in October

abstract: The company hopes a new court show starring the straight-talking judge will help turbocharge its free, ad-supported streaming platform, IMDb TV.
lead_para: CULVER CITY, Calif. — And you thought Amazon’s ambitions in Hollywood were limited to a single streaming service.
headline: Why Amazon Is in Business With Judge Judy

abstract: You loved TikTok leggings. Will you ever buy them again?
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
headline: The Internet Broke Brand Loyalty

abstract: The workers had spent months collecting signatures to call for an election.
lead_para: Workers at four Amazon warehouses on Staten Island have withdrawn their request for a union vote, throwing into doubt the future of an organizing push that could have led to the second election at an Amazon workplace in less than a year.
headline: Amazon Staten Island Workers Withdraw Request for Union Vote

abstract: Three years ago, the company walked away from a Defense Department project after employees objected to it. Now the company is working on a new proposal for the Pentagon.
lead_para: Three years after an employee revolt forced Google to abandon work on a Pentagon program that used artificial intelligence, the company is aggressively pursuing a major contract to provide its technology to the military.
headline: Google Wants to Work With the Pentagon Again, Despite Employee Concerns

abstract: The electric-vehicle maker, backed by Amazon and Ford, ended its first day of trading valued at $86 billion, though its deliveries so far total 156.
lead_para: Rivian, an electric-vehicle maker that has been around for over a decade, finally got around to delivering a product this year — 156 pickup trucks — and nearly all went to its employees.
headline: Rivian I.P.O. Is Embraced by Investors Looking for Another Tesla

abstract: Rising Covid cases have spurred a return to mask-wearing in the U.S. and overseas, at a time when flawed KN95s from China continue to dominate e-commerce sites.
lead_para: The N95 mask, arguably the most essential and coveted piece of pandemic protective gear, is no longer a rare commodity, thanks to the return of Chinese imports and a resurgence in U.S. domestic production.
headline: Counterfeit Covid Masks Are Still Sold Everywhere, Despite Misleading Claims

abstract: Sean O’Brien said he would be more aggressive than the incumbent, James P. Hoffa, in his approach to Amazon and UPS.
lead_para: The head of a Boston local who urged a more assertive stand toward employers like the United Parcel Service — and an aggressive drive to organize workers at Amazon — declared victory Thursday in his bid to lead the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
headline: Critic of Teamsters leader claims victory in race to succeed him.

abstract: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are our picks for some of November’s most promising new titles.
lead_para: (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, HBO, Hulu and More in November

abstract: Amazon’s ambitious fantasy adaptation is bursting with magic and monsters, but it’s no heir to the “Thrones.”
lead_para: There is a great wheel that turns and turns, and history turns with it. When it completes its circuit, the departed souls from the previous age return in new forms.
headline: Review: This ‘Wheel of Time’ Goes Nowhere Fast

abstract: Amazon said in August that it intended to appeal to the national labor board if it did not prevail at the regional level, but it did not say Monday whether it would follow through.
lead_para: A regional office of the National Labor Relations Board on Monday ordered a new union election at an Amazon warehouse in Alabama, upholding a union challenge to a vote that the company won decisively.
headline: Union Vote at Amazon Warehouse in Alabama Is Overturned by Regional Labor Office

abstract: Satellite internet is exciting, but it needs to be part of a bigger effort to get more people online.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
headline: Satellite Hopes Meet Internet Reality

abstract: The Trump era spurred them to collective action. But the work has just begun.
lead_para: This month, Big Tech pulled the plug on the loudest man on the internet. The decisions by Facebook and Twitter to remove Donald Trump coincided with a growing public concern about the power of tech platforms to invade privacy, monopolize markets and swing elections. Bipartisan political actions, including major antitrust suits, are also underway. But as tech executives prepare for these battles, they also face an adversary closer to home: the militant white-collar tech worker.
headline: Silicon Valley Workers Have Had Enough

abstract: A Norwegian group filed a complaint with regulators, saying Amazon had deliberately made it difficult to end memberships to its Prime service. Groups in Europe and the U.S. back the effort.
lead_para: LONDON — Those who have tried ending a membership in Amazon Prime, the technology giant’s digital subscription service, may be familiar with the multi-click process: warnings that cancellation will mean losing “exclusive benefits,” and prompts to reverse course, or switch to an annual membership instead.
headline: Consumer Groups Target Amazon Prime’s Cancellation Process

abstract: The app has renewed a debate about who holds power over online speech after the tech giants yanked their support for it and left it fighting for survival. Parler went dark early on Monday.
lead_para: From the start, John Matze had positioned Parler as a “free speech” social network where people could mostly say whatever they wanted. It was a bet that had recently paid off big as millions of President Trump’s supporters, fed up with what they deemed censorship on Facebook and Twitter, flocked to Parler instead.
headline: How Parler, a Chosen App of Trump Fans, Became a Test of Free Speech

abstract: Connecticut’s top law enforcement official said on Wednesday that he was conducting an antitrust investigation into how Amazon runs its e-books business.
lead_para: Connecticut’s top law enforcement official said on Wednesday that he was conducting an antitrust investigation into how Amazon runs its e-books business.
headline: Connecticut is investigating Amazon’s practices in the e-books market.

abstract: Microsoft, Starbucks and Amazon are among the companies offering the government assistance with logistics and operations.
lead_para: Amazon wrote to President Biden on Thursday offering to assist with communication and technology. Microsoft is opening up its largely empty office campus as a vaccination center as part of a broader partnership with the State of Washington. Starbucks is assigning workers from its operations and analytics departments to help design vaccination sites, donating the labor to the same state while continuing to pay employees.
headline: Help With Vaccination Push Comes From Unexpected Businesses

abstract: Biden started off his presidency with a flurry of economy-focused executive orders. Netflix’s budget broke even — for the first time. And Parler won’t be back online anytime soon.
lead_para: All eyes are on President Biden right now. Here’s how his new policies will affect companies and households struggling to weather the pandemic economy — plus more of the week’s top business and tech news. Stay safe, everyone. — Charlotte Cowles
headline: The Week in Business: Biden Gets Down to Business

abstract: Faced with boycotts and criminal complaints, the director of “Tandav” made the edits this week. But that did not appear to satisfy some of the show’s critics, who called for him to be jailed.
lead_para: ARPORA, India — The director of a big-budget Amazon web series has bowed to pressure from Hindu nationalists and cut several scenes that they had deemed offensive, demonstrating the sway of a powerful political movement that strives to reshape Indian society.
headline: Director of Amazon India Drama Cuts Scenes Amid Outcry From Hindu Nationalists

abstract: The 1978 novel, which Amazon recently removed from its site, depicts a right-wing assault on the Capitol. Scholars say the parallels with last week’s insurrection are clear and chilling.
lead_para: In “The Turner Diaries,” a group of white supremacists attacks the Capitol in an effort to overthrow the U.S. government. Dozens are killed in the assault, including members of Congress and their staffers. But in the insurrectionists’ view, the greater victory is symbolic.
headline: How ‘The Turner Diaries’ Incites White Supremacists

abstract: Tech giants were right to ban the president. We still need to break them up.
lead_para: In the days after Donald Trump whipped up a mob to overrun the Capitol in a desperate attempt to stop the certification of his defeat, many conservatives have voiced their outrage over the true victims of the failed putsch.
headline: The Scary Power of the Companies That Finally Shut Trump Up

abstract: Airports across the United States are devoting more space to freight shipments as online shopping surges in the pandemic.
lead_para: HEBRON, Ky. — Since the pandemic started nearly a year ago, 15,000 fewer people arrive and depart daily from the Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky International Airport, known as CVG. Yet the 60 percent drop in passenger traffic is not so apparent on the airport’s four runways, which are handling a record amount of air cargo — nearly 4,000 tons a day.
headline: Air Cargo Construction Is Booming, Thanks to Amazon

abstract: Evictions of some popular products tell us a lot about untrustworthy internet reviews.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Amazon’s Great Purge

abstract: Our streaming picks for May, including ‘Puberty Blues,’ ‘RuPaul’s Drag Race: Down Under’ and ‘The Underground Railroad’
lead_para: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for May.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in May

abstract: How Barry Jenkins and his band of indie filmmakers made television’s most ambitious take on American slavery since “Roots.”
lead_para: ATLANTA — There was only one time when he seriously thought about quitting. The project, a 10-episode series for Amazon, had just been announced, in the fall of 2016. Within hours of the news — BARRY JENKINS TO ADAPT HOT NOVEL ‘UNDERGROUND RAILROAD’ — the tweets had arrived.
headline: The Epic Journey to ‘The Underground Railroad’

abstract: A small activist investment fund scored a huge win.
lead_para: Exxon Mobil suffered a stunning loss at its annual shareholder meeting yesterday, as a small new activist investor focused on climate change, Engine No. 1, won at least two seats on its 12-member board. To corporate America, the upset was a clear sign that company boards and leaders need to pay attention to environmental, social and governance issues (known as E.S.G.) — or suffer rebukes.
headline: Wall Street Rebels Against Exxon

abstract: A plan aimed at the nation’s largest cluster of warehouses is designed to spur electrification of pollution-spewing diesel trucks and could set a template for restrictions elsewhere.
lead_para: Southern California is home to the nation’s largest concentration of warehouses — a hub of thousands of mammoth structures, served by belching diesel trucks, that help feed America’s booming appetite for online shopping and also contribute to the worst air pollution in the country.
headline: E-Commerce Mega-Warehouses, a Smog Source, Face New Pollution Rule

abstract: The time to debate the power of voice technology is now. (Before Alexa starts suggesting comfort foods.)
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Should Alexa Read Our Moods?

abstract: The District of Columbia said in a lawsuit that Amazon had stopped merchants that use its platform from charging lower prices for the same products elsewhere online.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — The District of Columbia sued Amazon on Tuesday, accusing it of artificially raising prices for products around the web by abusing its monopoly power, a sign that regulators in the United States are increasingly turning their attention to the company’s dominance across the economy.
headline: D.C. Accuses Amazon of Controlling Online Prices

abstract: The lawmakers said that the companies limited the reach of conservative voices.
lead_para: A group of seven House Republicans said on Wednesday that they would no longer take donations from major tech companies or their top executives, a sign of the growing distance between some conservatives and big business.
headline: Seven House Republicans pledge to take no donations from major tech companies.

abstract: A year ago even the tech giants were anxious. Now they have so much money it’s awkward.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: How Big Tech Won the Pandemic

abstract: A new report says millions of dollars in wages have been withheld from garment workers around the world by factories contracted by major fashion brands.
lead_para: Over a crackling phone line, Ashraf Ali, a 35-year-old father in Bangladesh, described feeling suicidal and desperate to feed his family. Sokunthea Yi, in Cambodia,  said she spends sleepless nights worrying about how she will pay off loans she took out to build her house. And at only 23, Dina Arviah in Indonesia said she was hopeless about her future as there were no longer any jobs in her district.
headline: Garment Workers Who Lost Jobs in Pandemic Still Wait for Severance Pay

abstract: QAnon adherents and other far-right influencers are making thousands of dollars broadcasting election and vaccine conspiracy theories on the streaming site.
lead_para: Terpsichore Maras-Lindeman, a podcaster who fought to overturn the 2020 presidential election, recently railed against mask mandates to her 4,000 fans in a live broadcast and encouraged them to enter stores maskless. On another day, she grew emotional while thanking them for sending her $84,000.
headline: Extremists Find a Financial Lifeline on Twitch

abstract: The retail giant defeated the closely watched drive to unionize its warehouse in Bessemer, Ala.
lead_para: Amazon beat back the unionization drive at its warehouse in Bessemer, Ala., the counting of ballots in the closely watched effort showed on Friday.
headline: Here is how the Amazon unionization vote broke down.

abstract: Seth Aaron Pendley was arrested on Thursday and charged with plotting to blow up an Amazon data center in Virginia, prosecutors said.
lead_para: A Texas man who boasted that he was at the United States Capitol when a pro-Trump mob stormed the building in January has been charged with plotting to blow up an Amazon data center in Virginia, the Justice Department said on Friday.
headline: Man Who Boasted He Was at Capitol Riot Is Charged in Bomb Plot

abstract: The high volume of orders during the pandemic has let Amazon operate more efficiently.
lead_para: With the pandemic shifting sales online and consumers flush with stimulus checks, Amazon on Thursday reported $108.5 billion in sales in the first three months of the year, up 44 percent from a year earlier. It also posted $8.1 billion in profit, an increase of 220 percent from the same period last year.
headline: Amazon’s profit soars 220 percent as pandemic drives shopping online.

abstract: What’s good for the online giant might be very bad for free competition and national cohesion.
lead_para: In 1986 an item in the New Republic decreed that “Worthwhile Canadian Initiative,” a headline that appeared on this very Op-Ed page, was “possibly the most boring headline ever written.” Seeking a different sort of reaction, I briefly considered titling this Op-Ed “Worthwhile Josh Hawley Initiative,” a headline that I suspect would elicit fury rather than boredom from many readers of this page.
headline: America’s Amazon Problems

abstract: The dictionary doesn’t have enough superlatives to describe what’s happening to the five biggest technology companies, raising uncomfortable questions for their C.E.O.s.
lead_para: In the Great Recession more than a decade ago, big tech companies hit a rough patch just like everyone else. Now they have become unquestioned winners of the pandemic economy.
headline: ‘A Perfect Positive Storm’: Bonkers Dollars for Big Tech

abstract: The two employees had publicly pushed the company to reduce its impact on climate change and address concerns about its warehouse workers.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon illegally retaliated against two of its most prominent internal critics when it fired them last year, the National Labor Relations Board has determined.
headline: Amazon Illegally Fired Activist Workers, Labor Board Finds

abstract: The company’s decisive victory deals a crushing blow to organized labor, which had hoped the time was ripe to start making inroads.
lead_para: Amazon workers at a giant warehouse in Alabama voted decisively against forming a union on Friday, squashing the most significant organizing drive in the internet giant’s history and dealing a crushing blow to labor and Democrats when conditions appeared ripe for them to make advances.
headline: Amazon Workers Vote Down Union Drive at Alabama Warehouse

abstract: Tech executives wanted to change the world, and they did. Of course we’re now questioning them.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Why Is Big Tech Under Assault? Power.

abstract: Our system of labor law and regulations has too strongly tilted the playing field in favor of companies and against unions.
lead_para: Labor activists had great hopes for the attempt to organize the Amazon warehouse in Bessemer, Ala., and the effort by the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union attracted national attention.
headline: Why the Amazon Workers Never Stood a Chance

abstract: What the tech barons think matters. But imagine if those working in the trenches had a bigger voice.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: To Understand Tech, Look Beyond the C.E.O.s

abstract: Wish, the ultra-budget e-commerce app, is about as online as shopping gets. What happens when it comes to your neighborhood?
lead_para: At MRK Computing Solutions, in the Crown Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn, Marc Anglade helps customers with technological needs: computer repair; web and app design; CCTV installation; printing, faxing, scanning. Mr. Anglade, 34, described his small business, which has earned many positive reviews on Google and Yelp, as “a neighborhood Staples.”
headline: The Not-Quite-Everything Store

abstract: Pay, benefits and an aggressive anti-union campaign by the company helped generate votes at a warehouse in Alabama.
lead_para: When Graham Brooks received his ballot in early February, asking whether he wanted to form a union at the Amazon warehouse in Alabama where he works, he did not hesitate. He marked the NO box, and mailed the ballot in.
headline: Why Amazon Workers Sided With the Company Over a Union

abstract: With about half the ballots counted late Thursday, votes against unionization had a more than 2-to-1 advantage, according to a tally by The New York Times.
lead_para: With about half the ballots counted late Thursday, votes against unionization had a more than 2-to-1 advantage over those in favor, according to a live broadcast of the counting that was tallied by The New York Times. When the counting paused, there were 1,100 votes against unionization and 463 in support.
headline: Partial tally in Amazon union drive favors ‘No’ votes.

abstract: If they really wanted to help the working class, there is plenty they could do.
lead_para: The Republican Party may not have much of an agenda to sell to the public right now, but it does have an enemy with which to rally its troops: “woke capital,” or those corporations that have adopted progressive rhetoric on social issues and used their platforms to support voting rights or back movements like Black Lives Matter.
headline: Republicans’ Fake War Against ‘Woke Capital’

abstract: Amazon must become a leader in reducing single-use packaging.
lead_para: The year 2020 may have been heartbreaking for most humans, but it was a good one for Jeff Bezos and Amazon. His company’s worldwide sales grew 38 percent from 2019, and Amazon sold more than 1.5 billion products during the 2020 holiday season alone.
headline: This Peeler Did Not Need to Be Wrapped in So Much Plastic

abstract: Stuart Appelbaum, president of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, said Amazon workers voted against forming a union over fear that they might lose their job.
lead_para: Stuart Appelbaum, president of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, said Amazon workers voted against forming a union over fear that they might lose their job.
headline: Amazon Workers Felt Intimidated, Labor Leader Says

abstract: Our streaming picks for January, including ‘Cobra Kai,’ ‘Bump’ and ‘One Night in Miami …’
lead_para: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for January.
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in January

abstract: Artists say officials tied to the country’s ruling party use pressure to stem criticism. Streaming services hoping to tap the Indian market’s potential have been caught in the middle.
lead_para: NEW DELHI — Bollywood once again has fallen into the cross hairs of India’s Hindu nationalist ruling party — and major Western streaming services like Amazon and Netflix increasingly find themselves caught in the middle.
headline: Amazon Web Drama Draws the Wrath of India’s Hindu Nationalists

abstract: Merchandise with phrases like “Battle for Capitol Hill Veteran” could still be purchased on major e-commerce sites, a sign of how the platforms have struggled to remove the goods.
lead_para: The day after the violent attack on the Capitol, Shopify declared that it had removed e-commerce sites affiliated with President Trump, including his official campaign store. The sites had violated a policy that prohibited the support of groups or people “that threaten or condone violence to further a cause.”
headline: Why T-Shirts Promoting the Capitol Riot Are Still Available Online

abstract: Big banks are sending mixed signals.
lead_para: America’s biggest banks have all now released their financial results for the past year, data that reflect the strange economic situation facing President Biden and his new administration. Parts of the economy are booming, others are at a standstill and the outlook is extraordinarily uncertain.
headline: How Wall Street Reflects the Economy Biden Inherits

abstract: IBM doesn’t donate to politicians. Perhaps others shouldn’t, either.
lead_para: [Read more on Trump and Pence.]
headline: Getting Corporate Cash Out of Politics

abstract: The social network, which had fast been gaining right-wing users, said that Amazon had conspired with Twitter, but did not provide any direct evidence.
lead_para: Hours after it went offline on Monday, the social media start-up Parler filed a lawsuit in federal court accusing Amazon of violating antitrust law and asking for a temporary restraining order to prevent the tech giant from blocking access to cloud computing services.
headline: Parler Accuses Amazon of Breaking Antitrust Law in Suspending Hosting Services

abstract: And it wouldn’t require legislation.
lead_para: The recent controversy over stock trading by lawmakers like Senator Kelly Loeffler of Georgia, who avoided significant losses by selling some shares after key meetings early in the pandemic, revived concerns about how Congress polices its members’ portfolios. In his first column of the year, Andrew proposes a simple way to stop politicians’ trading in individual stocks.
headline: A Cure for Politicians’ Stock Trades

abstract: Workers at a warehouse in Bessemer, Ala., are to vote next month on whether to unionize, the largest and most viable effort of its kind involving the technology giant.
lead_para: The largest, most viable effort to unionize Amazon in many years began last summer not in a union stronghold like New York or Michigan, but at a Fairfield Inn outside Birmingham, in the right-to-work state of Alabama.
headline: Amazon Union Drive Takes Hold in Unlikely Place

abstract: A website called Not Amazon was created to drive sales to more than 4,000 independent stores in four cities. The initiative aims to keep expanding.
lead_para: TORONTO — The snow was falling outside Ali Haberstroh’s apartment in late November when the idea came to her.
headline: A Canadian ‘Buy Local’ Effort Fights Amazon on Its Own Turf

abstract: The blaze that killed the former Zappos chief executive may have been caused by “carelessness or even an intentional act,” Connecticut fire and police officials said.
lead_para: Tony Hsieh, who developed Zappos into a billion-dollar internet shoe store and formulated an influential theory about corporate happiness, deliberately locked himself in a shed moments before it was consumed by the fire that would kill him.
headline: Tony Hsieh’s Fatal Night: An Argument, Drugs, a Locked Door and Sudden Fire

abstract: Selections from the current Weekend section, including a review of “West Side Story.”
lead_para: Selections from the current Weekend section, including a review of “West Side Story.”
headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend

abstract: Aerial footage by a local news outlet showing damage caused by severe weather to an Amazon warehouse in Edwardsville, Ill. Officials said there were “confirmed fatalities” after a roof collapsed at the warehouse.
lead_para: Aerial footage by a local news outlet showing damage caused by severe weather to an Amazon warehouse in Edwardsville, Ill. Officials said there were “confirmed fatalities” after a roof collapsed at the warehouse.
headline: Video Shows Tornado Destruction at Amazon Warehouse in Illinois

abstract: At least six people died after a tornado tore through an Amazon warehouse in Edwardsville, Ill., on Friday.
lead_para: At least six people died after a tornado tore through an Amazon warehouse in Edwardsville, Ill., on Friday.
headline: Images Show Amazon Warehouse Before and After Tornado

abstract: The company, Haven, had promised to disrupt the way large corporations deliver benefits to their employees.
lead_para: A joint venture formed by Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan Chase to explore new ways to deliver health care to their employees is disbanding, according to a short statement on its website. The company, Haven, will cease operations at the end of February — three years after its arrival sent shock waves through the health care industry.
headline: Amazon, Berkshire and JPMorgan Will End Joint Health Care Venture

abstract: Rivian, which has raised another $2.65 billion, plans to sell a pickup truck and S.U.V. it has worked on for more than a decade.
lead_para: PLYMOUTH, Mich. — It’s hard to imagine any company matching Tesla’s rocketlike rise. But if any electric car start-up could aspire to be the “next Tesla,” it would be Rivian.
headline: The Next Tesla? Investors Bet Big on Electric Truck Maker Rivian

abstract: Deplatforming President Trump showed that the First Amendment is broken — but not in the way his supporters think.
lead_para: In the months leading up to the November election, the social media platform Parler attracted millions of new users by promising something competitors, increasingly, did not: unfettered free speech. “If you can say it on the streets of New York,” promised the company’s chief executive, John Matze, in a June CNBC interview, “you can say it on Parler.”
headline: Why Is Big Tech Policing Speech? Because the Government Isn’t

abstract: In East Africa, too much Facebook has been awful. So has too little Facebook.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: What Internet Censorship Looks Like

abstract: The social network, popular with President Trump’s supporters, went offline last week after it was kicked off Amazon’s servers.
lead_para: Parler, the social network popular with Trump supporters, is trickling back to life.
headline: Parler Tries to Survive With Help From Russian Company

abstract: The everything store wants its workers to vote on unionization in person, in the middle of a pandemic.
lead_para: A battle over voting by mail is again being waged in an electoral contest. But now it’s Amazon that opposes a mail-ballot election in order to thwart a unionization effort at an Alabama fulfillment center.
headline: Amazon’s Cynical, Anti-Union Attack on Mail Voting

abstract: A toy company finds that selling goods on Amazon is both key to its success and super fraught.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: One Tale From an Amazon Seller

abstract: How did a case meant to lower prices instead possibly lead to higher prices?
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: When Tech Antitrust Failed

abstract: The judge said forcing Amazon to allow the social media app back onto its cloud computing platform would not be in the public interest.
lead_para: A federal judge declined on Thursday to force Amazon to resume hosting the social networking app Parler on its cloud computing platform, saying that doing so would not be in the public interest.
headline: A judge declines to force Amazon to resume hosting Parler.

abstract: Social media platforms have raced to bar organizers of the attack on the Capitol. Will that make a repeat less likely, or just harder to prevent?
lead_para: After the attack on the Capitol, social media platforms sprang into action. On Facebook and Twitter, accounts — including President Trump’s — were suspended and the pages of whole groups were taken down. Parler, a fringe platform that had become popular among Trump fans, was pulled by Amazon.
headline: Is More Violence Coming?

abstract: Central banks in the United States, Britain and the European Union took measures to address rapidly rising prices.
lead_para: The Federal Reserve signaled on Wednesday that it would take more serious measures to address rapidly rising inflation. The central bank said it would speed up its plans to ease pandemic support measures, by ending its bond-buying program in March. In a new set of economic projections, Fed officials said they expected to raise interest rates three times next year. The Fed is one of several central banks to announce they would tweak their monetary policy in response to high inflation this week: The European Central Bank announced on Thursday that it would also end its pandemic-era bond-buying program in March, and the Bank of England voted to raise its interest rate.
headline: The Week in Business: Taking On Inflation

abstract: President Biden is set to visit Kentucky, which was hard-hit when storms swept across six states late last week.
lead_para: A tornado outbreak tore through six states on Friday night: Arkansas, Illinois, Kentucky, Mississippi, Missouri and Tennessee.
headline: What to know about the deadly tornado outbreak.

abstract: After deadly tornadoes hit a facility owned by Amazon, concerns were raised about its safety practices and business model.
lead_para: An Amazon delivery center in Edwardsville, Ill., was one of the buildings in the path of tornadoes that ripped though six states on Friday night, leaving at least 90 dead, including six at the facility. A tornado that formed in the parking lot caused about half of the 40-foot-tall structure to collapse. A candle factory in Mayfield, Ky., that had also been operating at full tilt ahead of the holiday season was leveled, trapping workers.
headline: A New Focus on Amazon Warehouses

abstract: “I don’t think we’ll have seen damage at this scale, ever,” said Gov. Andy Beshear of Kentucky in the wake of the devastating tornadoes on Friday.
lead_para: MAYFIELD, Ky. — Darryl Johnson didn’t know what his sister did at the Mayfield Consumer Products factory or why she worked nights; he knew only that her husband dropped her off on Friday evening and that they never heard from her again.
headline: In Kentucky, Tallying the Grim Scale of Destruction

abstract: The disasters that struck in Kentucky and Illinois cannot be separated from the overall political economy of the United States.
lead_para: For a vast majority of Americans, democracy ends when work hours begin.
headline: This Is What Happens When Workers Don’t Control Their Own Lives

abstract: In an investigation into how the e-commerce giant gains an advantage over competitors, regulators said third-party vendors paying for Fulfillment by Amazon received special perks.
lead_para: Amazon on Thursday was fined nearly $1.3 billion by Italian regulators who accused the company of breaking antitrust laws by giving special perks to third-party merchants who use Amazon’s warehouse and delivery system.
headline: Amazon is fined $1.3 billion in Italy over antitrust violations.

abstract: Fears that a disrupted supply chain could wreak havoc on the logistics industry over the holiday turned out to be wrong as many Americans ordered early and shopped in stores.
lead_para: The warnings started to stream in early this fall: Shop early or you may not get your gifts on time.
headline: Why Christmas Gifts Are Arriving on Time This Year

abstract: Organizers are aiming to form a new union, the Amazon Labor Union.
lead_para: Labor organizers at an Amazon warehouse on Staten Island said they had submitted more than 2,500 worker signatures to the National Labor Relations Board in a petition to hold a union election.
headline: Labor organizers at Amazon’s Staten Island warehouse refile petition for a union election.

abstract: Tech executives and engineers are quitting Google, Meta, Amazon and other large companies for what they say is a once-in-generation opportunity with crypto.
lead_para: OAKLAND, Calif. — When Sandy Carter left her job as a vice president of Amazon’s cloud computing unit this month, she announced in a LinkedIn post that she was joining a crypto technology company. She included a link for open positions at the start-up.
headline: The New Get-Rich-Faster Job in Silicon Valley: Crypto Start-Ups

abstract: “I felt like the floor was coming off the ground,” said a delivery driver who escaped. The tornado caused the walls of the building to fall inward and the roof to collapse.
lead_para: At least six people were killed at an Amazon warehouse in Illinois after a direct hit from a tornado caused a major portion of the building to collapse on Friday night, officials said.
headline: At least six people died after an Amazon warehouse in Illinois took a direct hit.

abstract: Customers can start telling Jeff Bezos to treat his workers like human beings.
lead_para: Here are some of the ways that people who have worked inside Amazon’s warehouses describe the experience: “The job crushed my spirit and crippled my body.” “The lowest point in my life.” An “isolating colony of hell.” “They’re killing people mentally and physically.” “I began to hate my day-to-day life.” “The way Amazon pushes people is not moral.” “I had whole days where I didn’t talk to anyone.” “The systematic devaluing of human bodies.”
headline: The Force That Can Help Amazon’s Workers? Amazon’s Shoppers.

abstract: They will receive 50 cents to $3 more an hour, the company said.
lead_para: Amazon will increase pay between 50 cents and $3 an hour for half a million workers in its warehouses, delivery network and other fulfillment teams, the company said on Wednesday.
headline: Amazon to raise pay for 500,000 workers.

abstract: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are our picks from May’s new titles.
lead_para: (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our twice-weekly Watching newsletter here.)
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, HBO, Hulu and More in May

abstract: Amazon was built on an underdog philosophy, but its workers are finding a voice. That presents a problem for the company that goes far beyond the union vote in Alabama.
lead_para: It has been Day 1 at Amazon ever since the company began more than a quarter-century ago. Day 1 is Amazon shorthand for staying hungry, making bold decisions and never forgetting about the customer. This start-up mentality — underdogs against the world — has been extremely good for Amazon’s shoppers and shareholders.
headline: Amazon’s Clashes With Labor: Days of Conflict and Control

abstract: Created by Little Marvin and produced by Lena Waithe, the new series uses genre-style horror to unearth a racist and lasting relic from America’s past.
lead_para: Want to hear a scary story? Here’s one: A family reckoning with a senseless, pervasive horror flees home to what they hope will be a place of safety and prosperity, only to find themselves pursued by that same demented presence.
headline: In ‘Them,’ a Black Family Is Haunted by Real-Life Monsters

abstract: Corporate America keeps squeezing the humanity out of the workplace.
lead_para: It is easy to imagine that Amazon executives popped champagne corks over the weekend after quashing the union drive in Bessemer, Ala. After a bruising fight, workers at the warehouse, in a suburb of Birmingham, rejected joining a union by more than a two-to-one ratio, chilling future union organizing efforts at the nation’s second-largest private employer.
headline: Amazon’s Big Win Over the Little Guy

abstract: Republicans are mad at big business, but not mad enough to raise taxes.
lead_para: Senator Marco Rubio is extremely mad at corporations for “bending a knee to woke progressive craziness,” and he’s going to do, well, something about it.
headline: Marco Rubio’s ‘Woke Capital’ Tantrum

abstract: How a small group of workers in Alabama are taking on one of the most powerful companies in the world.
lead_para: Since its earliest days, Amazon has been anti-union, quashing any attempt by workers to organize.
headline: A Union Drive at Amazon

abstract: Amazon workers in Alabama voted down the biggest push for unionizing in the company’s history.
lead_para: Good morning. Here are the top stories in business and tech to know for the week ahead. — Charlotte Cowles
headline: The Week in Business: Amazon Defeats the Union

abstract: Unions aren’t obsolete, and we need to get them back.
lead_para: Labor activists hoped that the unionization vote at Amazon’s Bessemer, Ala., warehouse would be a turning point, a reversal in the decades-long trend of union decline. What the vote showed, instead, was the continuing effectiveness of the tactics employers have repeatedly used to defeat organizing efforts.
headline: America Needs to Empower Workers Again

abstract: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, while diminished, commanded a premium price, with Amazon seeking to bolster its crucial Prime membership offering.
lead_para: LOS ANGELES — In the ultimate symbol of one Hollywood era ending and another beginning, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, home to James Bond, “Thelma & Louise” and Rocky, finally found a buyer willing to pay retail: Amazon.
headline: James Bond, Meet Jeff Bezos: Amazon Makes $8.45 Billion Deal for MGM

abstract: In “Amazon Unbound,” his second book about the company, Brad Stone focuses on its singular C.E.O.
lead_para: AMAZON UNBOUNDJeff Bezos and the Invention of a Global EmpireBy Brad Stone
headline: To Understand Amazon, We Must Understand Jeff Bezos

abstract: People are eager to return to grocery stores, but Amazon seems to be missing the opportunity.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
headline: Stores Still Matter. Where’s Amazon?

abstract: The decision-making theatrics of Amazon, Facebook and other tech companies underscore the need for government to play a larger role.
lead_para: Philadelphia spent almost half a million dollars wooing Amazon’s HQ2 campus in a 2018 competition that the company billed as merit-based. So city leaders probably weren’t thrilled to read in a new book that one of the company’s top executives frowned on its bid because he couldn’t abide the Eagles, the city’s football team.
headline: Companies Write Their Own Rules and Make a Mockery of Democracy

abstract: In Barry Jenkins’s dreamlike adaptation of the Colson Whitehead novel, the railway is real and so is the pain.
lead_para: In Barry Jenkins’s transfixing adaptation of Colson Whitehead’s “The Underground Railroad,” Martin (Damon Herriman), a white man smuggling Cora (Thuso Mbedu) as she escapes slavery, rouses her before dawn to witness something ghastly. Along the road they’re traveling, grimly called “The Freedom Trail,” the trees are hung with lynched corpses. “You need to see this,” he tells her.
headline: Review: ‘The Underground Railroad’ Weaves an Epic Vision

abstract: The Windsor Police Department said it was investigating what it called “potential hate crime incidents” after a seventh noose was found at a future fulfillment center.
lead_para: Amazon said it had temporarily stopped construction of a new fulfillment center in Windsor, Conn., after seven ropes that appeared to be nooses were found on the site since April 27.
headline: Amazon Pauses Construction at Connecticut Site After Nooses Are Found

abstract: Two-thirds of characters reflect stereotypes, and just 3.4 percent of movies had leads or coleads who were Asians or Pacific Islanders, the study of 1,300 movies found.
lead_para: Of the 1,300 top-grossing films released from 2007 through 2019, just 44 featured an Asian or Pacific Islander character in a leading role — and one-third of the roles went to a single actor, Dwayne Johnson, a study has found.
headline: Stereotypes Are Rife Among Asian and Pacific Islander Film Roles, Study Finds

abstract: A deal would add Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer’s 4,000 films to Amazon’s streaming library, including the James Bond, Rocky and “Legally Blonde” franchises.
lead_para: LOS ANGELES — Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has been in talks to sell itself to Amazon, according to three people briefed on the matter. If completed, a deal would turbocharge Amazon’s streaming ambitions by bringing James Bond, Rocky, RoboCop and other film and television properties into the e-commerce giant’s fold.
headline: MGM Looks to Amazon as the Hollywood Studio Tries to Find a Buyer

abstract: The e-commerce giant’s European retail business had record sales in 2020, but its headquarters on the continent reported a $1.4 billion loss.
lead_para: Amazon had a record-breaking year in Europe in 2020, as the online giant took in revenue of 44 billion euros while people were shopping from home during the pandemic. But the company ended up paying no corporate tax to Luxembourg, where the company has its European headquarters.
headline: Amazon Had a Big Year, but Paid No Tax to Luxembourg

abstract: Driven by a combination of anxiety and murky information about new virus variants, some New Yorkers aren't letting their guard down.
lead_para: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
headline: Wearing Masks, Even After Getting Vaccinated

abstract: Bookstore or Amazon? Curbside pickup or delivery? We answer common questions readers might have.
lead_para: The last year has seen expanded options for buying books online, as more bookstores have developed websites, and e-commerce sites like Bookshop.org gain traction. But massive retailers like Amazon continue to dominate the bookselling business, and readers may be torn between the desire to support local bookstores and the convenience and price of online delivery giants. Here, booksellers and literary agents offer advice on how to evaluate your book buying options.
headline: Where Should You Buy Your Books?
