headline: The Country That Wants to ‘Be Average’ vs. Jeff Bezos and His $500 Million Yacht

abstract: A gay man gets trapped in a web of lies after his overeager best friend concocts an artificial relationship for him on social media.
lead_para: The real villain of “My Fake Boyfriend,” from the director Rose Troche, is New York City dating culture. Everyone seems perpetually ready to move onto the next hottie or hookup app that grabs their attention.
headline: ‘My Fake Boyfriend’ Review: Deepfake Dating

abstract: Sales of the emergency contraceptive surged after the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.
headline: Women on Why They’re Stocking Up on the Morning-After Pill

abstract: The agreement comes after a three-year deal the former president and first lady had with Spotify lapsed.
lead_para: Higher Ground, the production entity led by former President Barack Obama and Michelle Obama, the former first lady, has signed an exclusive, multiyear production deal with Audible, the audio arm of Amazon, just two months after a similar agreement with Spotify ended.
headline: Higher Ground, the Obamas’ production company, signs multiyear deal with Amazon’s Audible.

abstract: The company’s consumer and operations business has experienced a significant shake-up in recent weeks.
lead_para: Two of Amazon’s most senior Black executives are departing the company, according to four people familiar with the change, leaving Amazon without any Black leaders on its senior leadership team, which includes more than two dozen executives responsible for running the company.
headline: Senior Black Executives Depart Amazon as It Names New Consumer Boss

abstract: Dave Clark, who was also the architect of the company’s sprawling warehouse operations, said he would depart after 23 years.
lead_para: Dave Clark, the chief executive of Amazon’s consumer business, who was the architect of its massive warehouse operations, announced on Friday that he would leave the company after 23 years. He did not say what he would do next, and the company did not immediately name a successor.
headline: The chief executive of Amazon’s consumer business is leaving.

abstract: Paige Thompson’s lawyers said she had been looking for cracks so they could be fixed. A jury found her guilty of wire fraud and hacking charges.
lead_para: A former Amazon engineer who was accused of stealing customers’ personal information from Capital One in one of the largest breaches in the United States was found guilty of wire fraud and hacking charges on Friday.
headline: Ex-Amazon Worker Convicted in Capital One Hacking

abstract: In an interview, the chair of the Federal Trade Commission laid out some of her plans now that she has a Democratic majority at the agency.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Nearly a year into her job as chair of the Federal Trade Commission, Lina Khan hasn’t quite made the splash that many expected.
headline: Lina Khan, a Big Tech Critic, Tries Answering Her Own Detractors

abstract: The streaming service is reportedly talking to Comcast and Google as it seeks to create an ad-supported offering.
lead_para: Reed Hastings, Netflix’s co-founder, once dismissed the idea of putting ads on the streaming service as a nonstarter. Then, this year, the company posted its first subscriber loss in more than a decade, causing its stock to nosedive. Now, the company is talking to Comcast and Google to help it with the details of a plan to bring an ad-supported offering to its service, The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday.
headline: Netflix Needs Some Help With Ads

abstract: The technology is hard and the economics of mass deliveries may never make sense.
lead_para: Jeff Bezos said Amazon drones would be bringing toothpaste and cat food to Americans’ homes within four or five years. That was nearly nine years ago. Oops.
headline: Where Are the Delivery Drones?

abstract: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are our picks for some of June’s most promising new titles.
lead_para: (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to HBO, Hulu, Apple TV+ and More in June

abstract: Members of the Judiciary Committee accused Amazon of obstructing its inquiry into how the company treats third-party sellers.
lead_para: A House committee asked the Justice Department on Wednesday to investigate Amazon and some of its executives for criminal obstruction of a congressional investigation that included the e-commerce giant.
headline: A House panel calls for a criminal investigation into Amazon.

abstract: The e-commerce giant, which also turned a profit in its latest quarter, indicated sales in the holiday period might rise at their lowest level since 2001.
lead_para: For much of this year, Amazon’s growth slowed and losses mounted as it faced high costs and changes in people’s shopping habits with the ebbing of the coronavirus pandemic.
headline: Amazon Returns to Growth but Signals Slowness Ahead

abstract: Employers are taking a variety of approaches to union campaigns.
lead_para: There has been a surge in labor organizing among baristas at Starbucks, warehouse workers at Amazon and retail workers at Apple and Trader Joe’s. They have made their voices heard, though only a fraction of each group has joined a union, and some have rejected unionization.
headline: How Is Your Company Responding to Labor Organizing? We Want to Hear.

abstract: A series of quarterly earnings reports is showing that even Silicon Valley’s most powerful companies are feeling the impact of inflation and rising interest rates.
lead_para: Google this week reported a steep decline in profits. Social media companies such as Meta said that advertising sales — the heart of their businesses — have rapidly cooled off. And Microsoft, perhaps the tech industry’s most reliable performer, predicted a slowdown through at least the end of the year.
headline: Tech’s Biggest Companies Are Sending Worrying Signals About the Economy

abstract: Investors sent the electric vehicle maker’s shares down sharply in after-hours trading after the company warned about uncertain customer demand.
lead_para: Investors punished Tesla for cutting its growth forecast on Wednesday, sending shares tumbling nearly 6 percent lower in premarket trading, despite Elon Musk’s efforts to play down worries about slowing demand amid broader worries about the economy and growing competition.
headline: Tesla Optimists Are in Retreat

abstract: Chegg, a homework help app, exposed the data of 40 million users, including details about some students’ sexual orientation and religion, regulators said in a legal complaint.
lead_para: The Federal Trade Commission on Monday cracked down on Chegg, an education technology firm based in Santa Clara, Calif., saying the company’s “careless” approach to cybersecurity had exposed the personal details of tens of millions of users.
headline: F.T.C. Accuses Ed Tech Firm Chegg of ‘Careless’ Data Security

abstract: Several dozen night-shift employees at a Staten Island site that recently voted to unionize had refused to work amid safety concerns.
lead_para: Amazon on Tuesday suspended more than two dozen employees at a large warehouse on Staten Island who had refused to work their shift the previous evening, hours after a cardboard compactor at the site had caught fire.
headline: Amazon Suspends Workers After Protest Over Warehouse Fire

abstract: Patrick McKay and J.D. Payne have had to thread a difficult needle, satisfying Tolkien die-hards and average viewers. The finale gave everyone plenty to mull.
lead_para: This interview includes spoilers for the Season 1 finale of “The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power”
headline: ‘The Rings of Power’: The Showrunners Unpack That Twisty Finale

abstract: It is the latest tech company to pump the brakes on hiring amid growing economic concerns.
lead_para: Amazon is freezing corporate hiring in its retail business for the rest of the year, according to an internal announcement obtained by The New York Times, making it the latest company to pull back amid the economic uncertainty.
headline: Amazon Freezes Corporate Hiring in Its Retail Business

abstract: By a 2-to-1 ratio, the group had its second defeat since a surprise victory in April on Staten Island.
lead_para: Workers at an Amazon facility near Albany, N.Y., have voted decisively against being represented by the upstart Amazon Labor Union, denting efforts to expand unionization across the giant e-commerce company.
headline: Amazon Labor Union Loses Election at Warehouse Near Albany

abstract: On the whole, the N.F.L.’s Thursday night games aren’t statistically worse than the rest of the schedule and draw more viewers than “Young Sheldon.” So why do they get such a bad rap?
lead_para: Watching Amazon’s “Thursday Night Football” is not merely as boring as watching paint dry. It’s also as unpleasant as smelling paint dry.
headline: The Existential Horror of Thursday Night Football

abstract: The Amazon founder, estimated to be worth $124 billion, suggested in an interview on CNN that he would donate most of his money to charity in his lifetime, the first time he had made such a pledge.
lead_para: Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, said he would give away most of his money to charity, making him the latest billionaire to pledge to donate his vast fortune during his lifetime.
headline: Jeff Bezos Says He Will Give Away Most of His Fortune

abstract: He said that the company has a panel that reviews content that might be objectionable, but that cases were not always “straightforward.”
lead_para: Appearing at the DealBook Summit on Wednesday, Amazon’s chief executive, Andy Jassy, said the e-commerce giant had no immediate plans to remove — or add a disclaimer — to the antisemitic film that the Brooklyn Nets guard Kyrie Irving drew attention to on the Amazon website last month.
headline: Andy Jassy says Amazon will allow the antisemitic film that Kyrie Irving tweeted to remain on sale for now.

abstract: The job cuts of approximately 10,000, which would start as soon as this week, would focus on the company’s devices organization, retail division and human resources.
lead_para: Amazon plans to lay off approximately 10,000 people in corporate and technology jobs starting as soon as this week, people with knowledge of the matter said, in what would be the largest job cuts in the company’s history.
headline: Amazon Is Said to Plan to Lay Off Thousands of Employees

abstract: A new Amazon series puts an unlikely alliance at the heart of an unconventional tribute to the classic American western.
lead_para: The new Amazon series “The English” bears all the external signs of the classic westerns of yore, with scenes that could have been pulled straight from a 1950s Technicolor epic. There are horseback riders silhouetted against retina-singeing vistas, desolate outposts appearing like sunbaked hallucinations, and low-angle shots that magnify people into mythic figures.
headline: ‘The English’: Emily Blunt and Chaske Spencer Saddle Up

abstract: The deal to stream Overtime Elite’s games to Prime Video comes as top male players consider the league an option instead of traditional high schools and colleges.
lead_para: ROSELLE, N.J. — On a recent Friday evening, Naasir Cunningham was back home in New Jersey doing what he does best: flying up and down a basketball court, deftly floating in baskets and hitting an array of jump shots from various angles.
headline: Overtime Elite Gets Media Deal With Amazon Prime Video

abstract: It promises to be unpredictable, with retailers and consumers still figuring out how much will be spent and on what kinds of goods.
lead_para: No one quite knows what to make of this year’s holiday shopping season. But billions of dollars are riding on it.
headline: Billions of Dollars Are at Stake in a Puzzling Holiday Shopping Season

abstract: Entire forests and enormous factories running 24/7 can barely keep up with demand. This is how the cardboard economy works.
lead_para: Before it was the cardboard on your doorstep, it was coarse brown paper, and before it was paper, it was a river of hot pulp, and before it was a river, it was a tree. Probably a Pinus taeda, or loblolly pine, a slender conifer native to the Southeastern United States. “The wonderful thing about the loblolly,” a forester named Alex Singleton told me this spring, peering out over the fringes of a tree farm in West Georgia, “is that it grows fast and grows pretty much anywhere, including swamps” — hence the non-Latin name for the tree, which comes from an antiquated term for mud pit. “See those oaks over there?” Singleton went on. “Oaks are hardwood, with short fibers. Fine for paper. Book pages. But not fine for packaging, because for packaging, you need the long fibers. A pine will give you that. An oak won’t.”
headline: Where Does All the Cardboard Come From? I Had to Know.

abstract: With the collapse of the giant cryptocurrency exchange, investors are asking whether regulators or the venture capitalists who funded FTX, are at fault.
lead_para: Andrew here. Over dinners and text messages this weekend, financiers on Wall Street and Silicon Valley, and policymakers in Washington, debated whether the multibillion-dollar collapse of FTX, the crypto exchange founded by the wunderkind Sam Bankman-Fried, should be compared to the fall of Enron, Lehman Brothers, Bernie Madoff or MF Global.
headline: Who Bears Blame for FTX’s Failure?

abstract: Markets expect another big interest rate increase on Wednesday. But investors are also anxious about the central bank’s coming moves.
lead_para: Wednesday is the final meeting of the Fed’s Open Market Committee before next week’s midterm elections, and the central bank’s move on interest rates looks like a foregone conclusion.
headline: Investors Await the Fed’s Next Move

abstract: Andrew will interview Janet Yellen, Volodymyr Zelensky, Mark Zuckerberg, Andy Jassy, Ben Affleck and many more.
lead_para: Follow our live updates of the DealBook Summit.
headline: Top Questions for Today’s DealBook Summit Speakers

abstract: The series, “The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power,” will take place thousands of years before the events of the “Lord of the Rings” trilogy.
lead_para: Amazon Prime Video’s long-gestating “Lord of the Rings” series, which will make its debut on the streaming platform in September, officially has a name: “The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power.”
headline: Amazon unveils the title for its big-budget ‘Lord of the Rings’ streaming series.

abstract: The company plans to open Amazon Style later this year in Glendale, Calif., that will incorporate customers’ physical browsing behavior and preferences on the Amazon Shopping app.
lead_para: Amazon, which has posed formidable challenges to booksellers, big-box chains and grocers, has a new kind of retailer in its sights: physical clothing stores.
headline: Amazon plans a new rival for retailers: a physical clothing store.

abstract: U.S. antitrust leaders said they would focus on the tech industry’s free services as they strengthened the review process for corporate consolidation.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Top federal antitrust officials on Tuesday announced a review of how they approve mergers and acquisitions, in a broad effort to strengthen enforcement and clamp down on a surge of corporate consolidation, particularly in high tech.
headline: Regulators aim to rewrite rules for big mergers.

abstract: For many Americans, it has become hard to imagine online shopping without Prime.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
headline: Amazon Prime: Loved at Almost Any Price

abstract: Most autistic characters have been played onscreen by neurotypical actors. A new series bucks the trend, starring three leads who are on the spectrum.
lead_para: In the new Amazon series “As We See It,” Violet, a 25-year-old cashier at Arby’s, desperately wants a boyfriend, but she is looking for love in all the wrong places (namely, Arby’s). Violet’s needs are simple. She wants someone cute, someone to go on fun dates with. Most of all, she wants someone normal.
headline: ‘As We See It’ Is Not a Typical Portrayal of Autism

abstract: Cloud computing is slowly changing how Wall Street banks handle their business, but concerns with security remain.
lead_para: Michael W. Lucas made big plans to take a trip around the world in March 2020. He arranged to travel from his home in Detroit to Tokyo, then attend conferences in Hong Kong and Bangalore, India, before making a final stop in Paris.
headline: Banks Tiptoe Toward Their Cloud-Based Future

abstract: Companies must now decide whether to proceed with planned mandates without cover from the federal government.
lead_para: A requirement that large companies mandate vaccines or weekly testing for workers was blocked by the Supreme Court on Thursday, leaving the often fraught choice up to employers.
headline: Businesses are whipsawed again as the Supreme Court blocks OSHA’s vaccine mandate.

abstract: The National Labor Relations Board has scheduled a mail-in election to start Feb. 4 for workers in Alabama after throwing out the results of a vote last year.
lead_para: Amazon workers in Alabama will have another shot at voting to form a union this winter, as the National Labor Relations Board scheduled a mail-in election to start Feb. 4.
headline: A timeline is set for a new unionization vote at an Amazon warehouse.

abstract: The company has big plans to turn its delivery fleet green. But very few of the vehicles are made right now.
lead_para: In the fall, Jeff Bezos tweeted praise for Rivian, a start-up under contract to make 100,000 electric delivery vans for Amazon, and its founder, R.J. Scaringe, calling him “one of the greatest entrepreneurs I’ve ever met.”
headline: Can Anyone Satisfy Amazon’s Craving for Electric Vans?

abstract: The S&P 500 fell 1.4 percent, while the Nasdaq composite slid 2.5 percent, losses that wiped out gains made by both benchmarks over the past two days.
lead_para: Stocks tumbled on Thursday in a late sell-off led by shares of technology companies, ending two days of relative calm on Wall Street.
headline: Stocks drop as turbulence continues on Wall Street.

abstract: Readers discuss whether a high school coach had the right to kneel and pray after games. Also: Genocide in Ukraine; Amazon’s response; Republican lies.
lead_para: To the Editor:
headline: Prayer on a School Football Field: Awaiting a Supreme Court Ruling

abstract: A debate on how unions build power today and whether politicians — particularly Democrats — are still behind them.
lead_para: From Amazon and Starbucks to large media companies, unionization has become a siren call for workers — white- and blue-collar — fighting for rights and fair wages. But in 2022, after two years of a pandemic, how have our ideas about unions changed? And are Democrats, the so-called party of the unions, still allies in the fight for workers’ rights?
headline: From Amazon to Starbucks, America Is Unionizing. Will Politics Catch Up?

abstract: The company’s crackdown on a worker protest in New York backfired and led to a historic labor victory.
lead_para: In the first dark days of the pandemic, as an Amazon worker named Christian Smalls planned a small, panicked walkout over safety conditions at the retailer’s only fulfillment center in New York City, the company quietly mobilized.
headline: How Two Best Friends Beat Amazon

abstract: The meetings are a common response by companies like Amazon and Starbucks to union drives among workers. The full labor board will make the decision.
lead_para: The general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board issued a memo on Thursday arguing that the widespread employer practice of requiring workers to attend anti-union meetings is illegal under federal law, even though labor board precedent has allowed it.
headline: N.L.R.B. counsel calls for a ban on mandatory anti-union meetings.

abstract: As subscriber growth slows, Netflix and others show less resistance to introducing ads.
lead_para: Later today, Netflix will report its latest quarterly earnings. Analysts do not have high expectations. The streaming service’s profits are expected to drop by more than 20 percent.
headline: The Next Big Thing in Streaming

abstract: The new surcharge is in addition to fee increases for sellers in November that went into effect in January.
lead_para: Facing rising costs, Amazon said on Wednesday that it was adding its first “fuel and inflation surcharge” to the fees it charges sellers whose inventory it warehouses and delivers to customers, according to an announcement on its website.
headline: Amazon adds a fuel and inflation surcharge to the fees it charges to sellers.

abstract: The company listed a series of complaints against an upstart union’s organizing efforts. Both Amazon and another union noted objections to another vote in Alabama.
lead_para: Amazon objected on Friday to a landmark union election at its Staten Island fulfillment center, saying an upstart union’s unorthodox tactics there crossed legal lines, according to a copy of its filing to the National Labor Relations Board obtained by The New York Times.
headline: Amazon says landmark Staten Island union vote should be thrown out.

abstract: The balloting will take place this week and could produce the second union at an Amazon facility in the United States.
lead_para: About 1,500 workers at an Amazon sorting center on Staten Island will be eligible to vote this week in an election that could produce the second union at the company in the United States.
headline: Union Vote Begins at Another Amazon Facility on Staten Island

abstract: Why a pro-union vote at Amazon may be a big deal.
lead_para: I grew up in a relatively equal society, at least as far as incomes were concerned. Obviously there were class differences in 1974, the year I graduated from college; some jobs paid much better than others, some people were rich while others were desperately poor. But for most Americans these differences were much narrower than they are today.
headline: A Small Earthquake on Staten Island

abstract: Executives at Netflix, Disney+ and other top streaming services, chasing ever bigger subscription numbers, are having a change of heart about commercials.
lead_para: The two titans of the video streaming wars — Netflix and Disney+ — have long resisted commercials, showing a reluctance to have premium series like “Stranger Things” or “The Mandalorian” run alongside commercials hawking dish soap, soda and medications.
headline: And Now, a Word From Your Streaming Sponsor …

abstract: Amazon benefited from the coronavirus pandemic as people flocked to online shopping. Now, shoppers’ behavior has shifted.
lead_para: In the face of a pandemic that appears to be receding and the highest levels of inflation in four decades, Amazon on Thursday posted its slowest quarterly growth in years and its first quarterly loss since 2015.
headline: Amazon reports slowing sales growth and indicates slowdown may continue.

abstract: The British actor plays an enigmatic interloper in this new science fiction Western on Amazon. “The trickery of it is what made it so fun,” she said.
lead_para: When Imogen Poots arrives in the premiere of “Outer Range,” a trippy new science fiction Western series, the first impression is of an ingénue.
headline: Imogen Poots Keeps Everyone Guessing in ‘Outer Range’

abstract: Despite heavy lobbying by the company, workers at the facility voted by a wide margin for a union. It was seen as a rebuke of the company’s treatment of its employees.
lead_para: It was a union organizing campaign that few expected to have a chance. A handful of employees at Amazon’s massive warehouse on Staten Island, operating without support from national labor organizations, took on one of the most powerful companies in the world.
headline: Amazon Workers on Staten Island Vote to Unionize in Landmark Win for Labor

abstract: In a new show on Prime Video, Claire Foy plays a British aristocrat whose sex life became the subject of salacious tabloid stories in the 1960s.
lead_para: LONDON — Everybody loves a sex scandal, and a posh one is even better. The great and the good brought down in disgrace: That’s a story people want to hear.
headline: A Duchess Brought Low by ‘A Very British Scandal’

abstract: A fortune of $172 billion is almost impossible to fathom. For the magazine’s Money Issue, the artist Mona Chalabi came up with some extremely original comparisons.
lead_para: A fortune of $172 billion is almost impossible to fathom. For the magazine’s Money Issue, the artist Mona Chalabi came up with some extremely original comparisons.
headline: 9 Ways to Imagine Jeff Bezos’ Wealth

abstract: It turns out, one can live in America and not have an Amazon Prime account.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
headline: How I Quit Prime and Survived

abstract: Ahead of a major five-city show, the artist reflects on the evolution of her practice and her distrust of Amazon.
lead_para: This past December, I met the abstract artist Rochelle Feinstein at her studio — a 900-square-foot space in an industrial office building in Queens, N.Y. — to discuss her upcoming exhibition, “You Again,” a survey of her work that will be displayed simultaneously in six independent galleries in Paris, Zurich, New York, Miami and Los Angeles, beginning this month at Bridget Donahue and Candice Madey in Manhattan. Unlike many painters, the ineffability of personal experience concerns Feinstein less than the cultural conditions that create it. What interests her is, “How can I enter that cultural condition and how can I enter it right now?”
headline: Rochelle Feinstein Makes Work That Is Purposefully Hard to Define

abstract: An Amazon program guaranteed sellers a minimum price while offering a potential upside if an algorithm determined that customers were willing to pay more
lead_para: Amazon settled a price-fixing investigation by the Washington State attorney general’s office on Wednesday, agreeing to pay $2.25 million and end a program that gave it control over the prices of products supplied by third-party sellers on its marketplace.
headline: Amazon pays $2.25 million to settle a price-fixing investigation.

abstract: The states argue that Google reached a deal with Facebook to have the social network join its effort in an effort to “kill” a competing ad network.
lead_para: Google’s chief executive approved an agreement with Facebook at the heart of an antitrust lawsuit that 16 states and Puerto Rico have lodged against the search giant, according to a portion of the complaint revealed on Friday.
headline: Google’s chief executive signed off on deal at center of antitrust case, states say.

abstract: With midterm elections approaching, a vote taken on Thursday could be the first of several that Congress takes on bills aimed at the industry.
lead_para: Lawmakers on Capitol Hill are readying a major push on bills aimed at restraining the power of the country’s biggest tech companies, as they see the window of opportunity closing quickly ahead of the midterm elections.
headline: Efforts to Rein In Big Tech May Be Running Out of Time

abstract: Approval of unions in the U.S. is the highest it’s been in decades, while participation in them has steadily fallen.
lead_para: Approval of unions in the U.S. is the highest it’s been in decades, while participation in them has steadily fallen.
headline: The U.S. Labor Movement Is Popular, Prominent and Also Shrinking

abstract: After years of breakneck growth, the number of scripted TV series orders made by networks and streamers is in decline.
lead_para: American television viewers have become accustomed to it: Dozens of premieres every month, hundreds of shows every year, a guarantee from Hollywood that there’s always going to be something new to watch.
headline: Streaming’s Golden Age Is Suddenly Dimming

abstract: Ever experienced buyer’s remorse? Of course you have. But there are ways to prevent it.
lead_para: The limited edition SpongeBob Funko Pop was calling to Jason Grioua.
headline: You Bought the Thing. Now You Regret the Thing.

abstract: The title will be the first major single-player game for Amazon. It is a coup for the retail giant, which has struggled to gain traction with its video game business.
lead_para: Amazon said on Thursday that it would publish the next iteration of the popular video game franchise Tomb Raider, a coup for the tech giant’s video game business.
headline: Amazon to Publish the Next Tomb Raider Video Game

abstract: Tech’s biggest companies — Apple, Amazon and YouTube’s owner, Google — have been pursuing the rights to the football package.
lead_para: Google’s YouTube is nearing a deal to acquire the rights to the National Football League’s Sunday Ticket package of games, according to three people with knowledge of the talks, a deal that would bring a staple of traditional television into the streaming realm.
headline: YouTube in Advanced Talks for N.F.L. Sunday Ticket

abstract: A conversation with the warehouse workers who created an e-commerce giant’s first union against all odds.
lead_para: This week, The Daily is revisiting some of our favorite episodes of the year and checking in on what has happened in the time since they first ran.
headline: How Two Friends Beat Amazon and Built a Union: An Update

abstract: The e-commerce giant avoided a fine, but will make a variety of changes regulators believe will help independent merchants who had raised alarms about Amazon’s tactics.
lead_para: Amazon has agreed to a settlement with European Union regulators that will force the company to make significant changes to its business practices but also allows the e-commerce giant to avoid a drawn out legal fight and billions of dollars of potential fines, according to three people with knowledge of the deal.
headline: Amazon Agrees to Change Some Business Practices in E.U. Settlement

abstract: The company and its new union share the same problem.
lead_para: Last Wednesday, Derrick Palmer clocked in for his 7:15 a.m. shift at Amazon’s giant warehouse on Staten Island and spent the day packing boxes with board games, iPhones and mini vacuum cleaners. The following morning, he boarded a train to Washington, D.C., where more experienced labor leaders hailed him and his best friend, Christian Smalls, for doing what had once seemed impossible: unionizing an Amazon facility.
headline: Amazon vs. the Union

abstract: The judge said the worker was “unlawfully” fired two years ago after a pandemic safety protest at a company warehouse.
lead_para: A judge ruled on Monday that Amazon must reinstate and pay lost wages to a worker the company “unlawfully” fired two years ago after a protest at its fulfillment center on Staten Island, the same warehouse that recently voted in a landmark election to unionize.
headline: A judge ruled that Amazon must reinstate a Staten Island worker who was fired.

abstract: It’s the biggest victory for organized labor in a generation. Was it a fluke or the start of a new era of labor activism?
lead_para: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.
headline: Does the Amazon Union Win Portend a Comeback for Organized Labor?

abstract: The company’s rewiring of retail puts customers at risk.
lead_para: When Carey Gartner ordered a TV remote on Amazon in 2017, it arrived promptly at his home in Texas, most likely in one of those standard brown boxes with the company’s logo: an arrow tilting up in a half-smile. A year later, the battery cover popped off the remote, exposing a lithium battery, and Gartner’s 19-month-old swallowed it, severely burning and permanently damaging her esophagus, according to allegations in a court filing. His wife, Morgan McMillan, sued Amazon on their daughter’s behalf.
headline: What You Don’t Know About Amazon

abstract: The successful organization of a warehouse in Staten Island offers a real glimmer of hope for the American working class.
lead_para: Faced with an unexpectedly strong organizing campaign by workers at one of its Staten Island warehouses, Amazon initially turned to one of the oldest tricks in the anti-union playbook: a little bit of racism.
headline: Amazon Tried One of the Oldest Tricks in the Book, and It Backfired

abstract: The strike at an Alabama coal mine is one of the longest in U.S. history. To make ends meet, some striking miners have picked up work at an Amazon warehouse. It’s the same warehouse where workers are trying to unionize.
lead_para: BROOKWOOD, Ala. — Braxton Wright is a second-generation coal miner, a die-hard union supporter and, until recently, a staunch Republican. He is named after his uncle, a Korean War veteran, who was fatally crushed between two rail cars while working at the Pullman train factory near Birmingham.
headline: What One ‘Brotherhood’ of Coal Miners Learned From a Year Above Ground

abstract: “By the way, Amazon, here we come. Watch,” the president said. But the White House quickly said his remarks did not mean the government would get formally involved.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Days after warehouse workers on Staten Island defied Amazon and successfully formed a labor union, President Biden on Wednesday threw his support behind the workers and championed their cause.
headline: Biden Appears to Show Support for Amazon Workers Who Voted to Unionize

abstract: The Digital Services Act would force Meta, Google and others to combat misinformation and restrict certain online ads. How European officials will wield it remains to be seen.
lead_para: The European Union reached a deal on Saturday on landmark legislation that would force Facebook, YouTube and other internet services to combat misinformation, disclose how their services amplify divisive content and stop targeting online ads based on a person’s ethnicity, religion or sexual orientation.
headline: E.U. Takes Aim at Social Media’s Harms With Landmark New Law

abstract: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are our picks for some of April’s most promising new titles.
lead_para: (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to HBO, Hulu, Apple TV+ and More in April

abstract: The success of an independent drive has organized labor asking whether it should take more of a back seat.
lead_para: After the stunning victory at Amazon by a little-known independent union that didn’t exist 18 months ago, organized labor has begun to ask itself an increasingly pressing question: Does the labor movement need to get more disorganized?
headline: Amazon Workers Who Won a Union Their Way Open Labor Leaders’ Eyes

abstract: Workers had accused the companies of unlawful behavior during recent union campaigns.
lead_para: In a sign that federal labor officials are closely scrutinizing management behavior during union campaigns, the National Labor Relations Board said Friday that it had found merit in accusations that Amazon and Starbucks had violated labor law.
headline: Labor regulators find merit in accusations by unions at Amazon and Starbucks.

abstract: Company officials said the terminations were the result of an internal review, while the fired managers saw it as a response to the recent union victory.
lead_para: After Amazon employees at a massive warehouse on Staten Island scored an upset union victory last month, it turned the union’s leaders into celebrities, sent shock waves through the broader labor movement and prompted politicians around the country to rally behind Amazon workers. Now it also appears to have created fallout within Amazon’s management ranks.
headline: Amazon Abruptly Fires Senior Managers Tied to Unionized Warehouse

abstract: Titus Welliver returns as the old-school detective Harry Bosch on Amazon’s Freevee, though he never really went away.
lead_para: A show called “Bosch: Legacy” starts this week, and it is labeled Season 1. Fans of the show’s grumpy namesake and his original series can rest easy, though. In everything but name, it’s an eighth season of “Bosch.” They knew better than to mess with Harry.
headline: ‘Bosch: Legacy’ Review: More of the Same (Good) Thing

abstract: Leaving room for disagreement is gracious, not timid.
lead_para: I want to take up a language peeve I hear a lot about: The uptick in (often younger) people prefacing their opinions with “I feel like”: “I feel like it’s a matter of duty,” “I feel like people are ignoring the consequences” and so on.
headline: I Think It’s Fine to Say ‘I Feel Like.’ I Reckon Others Do, Too.

abstract: Why has the union campaign spread so much further at the coffee chain than at the e-commerce giant?
lead_para: Roughly six weeks after successful union votes at two Buffalo-area Starbucks stores in December, workers had filed paperwork to hold union elections in at least 20 other Starbucks locations nationwide.
headline: A Union Blitzed Starbucks. At Amazon, It’s a Slog.

abstract: Nations are accelerating efforts to control data produced within their perimeters, disrupting the flow of what has become a kind of digital currency.
lead_para: Every time we send an email, tap an Instagram ad or swipe our credit cards, we create a piece of digital data.
headline: The Era of Borderless Data Is Ending

abstract: Twitch, the livestreaming site owned by Amazon that is popular with gamers, said it had taken the channel offline.
lead_para: Follow our live coverage of the mass shooting in Buffalo.
headline: The gunman broadcast the attack on a livestreaming site.

abstract: The results were a setback for the upstart Amazon Labor Union, which won a landmark victory last month at a larger Amazon warehouse nearby.
lead_para: The growing labor organizing efforts at Amazon were dealt a blow on Monday when workers voted by a wide margin to reject joining a union at a warehouse on Staten Island, just weeks after the union won a landmark victory at a larger facility nearby.
headline: Amazon Union Loses Vote at Second Staten Island Warehouse

abstract: Flush with cash, Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Microsoft and Google are positioned to emerge from a downturn stronger and more powerful. As usual.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple, Amazon, Microsoft and the parent companies of Facebook and Google have lost $2.7 trillion in value so far this year, about the annual gross domestic product of Britain.
headline: Big Tech Is Getting Clobbered on Wall Street. It’s a Good Time for Them.

abstract: Looking for something new to watch? Here’s a roundup of the most promising titles coming to most major U.S. streaming services (except Netflix) this month.
lead_para: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of May’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to HBO Max, Hulu, Apple TV+ and More in May

abstract: Since the Great Recession, the college-educated have taken more frontline jobs at companies like Starbucks and Amazon. Now they’re helping to unionize them.
lead_para: Over the past decade and a half, many young, college-educated workers have faced a disturbing reality: that it was harder for them to reach the middle class than for previous generations. The change has had profound effects — driving shifts in the country’s politics and mobilizing employees to demand fairer treatment at work. It may also be giving the labor movement its biggest lift in decades.
headline: The Revolt of the College-Educated Working Class

abstract: Apple and Google are pushing privacy changes, but a shift in digital tracking is giving some platforms a bigger advertising advantage.
lead_para: The internet industry shuddered last year when Apple introduced privacy measures for the iPhone that threatened to upend online tracking and cripple digital advertising. Google pledged similar privacy actions.
headline: You’re Still Being Tracked on the Internet, Just in a Different Way

abstract: How much should the middleman get?
lead_para: This week, thousands of people who sell goods on Etsy are going on strike to protest the company’s climbing fees. And what seems to be a fight over a small corner of the internet is really one of the most enduring battles over our digital world.
headline: Etsy and the Sameness of Internet Fights

abstract: Amazon workers on Staten Island have created the company’s first union. The government needs to make it easier for others to follow.
lead_para: Two years ago, Amazon fired Christian Smalls after he organized fellow workers at a warehouse on Staten Island to protest pandemic working conditions. On Friday, after a campaign the company bitterly opposed, the government announced that those workers had voted to unionize, and Mr. Smalls, their leader, popped open a bottle of champagne.
headline: The People, United, Must Fight Hard or Be Defeated

abstract: Federal privacy bills, security legislation and antitrust laws to address the power of the tech giants have all failed to advance in Congress, despite hand wringing and shows of bipartisan support.
lead_para: In just the last few years, Europe has seen a sweeping law for online privacy take effect, approved far-reaching regulations to curb the dominance of the tech giants and on Saturday reached a deal on new legislation to protect its citizens from harmful online content.
headline: As Europe Approves New Tech Laws, the U.S. Falls Further Behind

abstract: Michael De Luca and Pamela Abdy, brought on to ready MGM for a sale, announced their departures one month after its acquisition by Amazon.
lead_para: The two top executives at Metro Goldwyn Mayer — Michael De Luca and Pamela Abdy — announced their impending departures on Wednesday, one month after Amazon closed its $8.5 billion acquisition of the film studio.
headline: One month after Amazon takeover, two top MGM executives announce their departures.

abstract: Readers discuss a Bret Stephens column about whether or not Vladimir Putin miscalculated. Also: The Amazon union vote; treatment for sex offenders.
lead_para: To the Editor:
headline: What Is Putin Really After in Ukraine?

abstract: A tornado that hit a delivery station in Illinois last year will be a focus of the inquiry.
lead_para: The House Committee on Oversight and Reform has opened an investigation into Amazon’s labor practices during severe weather events, according to a letter members sent to Andy Jassy, Amazon’s chief executive.
headline: House committee opens investigation into Amazon’s labor practices.

abstract: Karen Weise, a technology correspondent, shares how she covers Amazon and its far-reaching businesses.
lead_para: Karen Weise is a technology correspondent based in Seattle who has covered Amazon, which is headquartered there, for The Times since 2018. With its e-commerce operation, line of web services and grocery businesses, Amazon maintains a vast reach across American society. The company has been on a hiring spree in recent years, including a large push during the pandemic, which has brought its role as a major U.S. employer into sharper focus.
headline: Reporting From Amazon’s Hometown, and Seeing the Company Everywhere

abstract: Big technology companies are set to report earnings starting Tuesday. The S&P 500 has dropped nearly 8 percent this month, its worst monthly showing since March 2020.
lead_para: Stocks slid on Tuesday, adding to a losing streak that has April shaping up to be Wall Street’s worst month in two years.
headline: Stocks drop 2.8%, led lower by tech, as April’s slump continues.

abstract: Chinese merchants have been huge on Amazon. But now we’re seeing the trend reverse.
lead_para: One essential ingredient for Amazon’s success is the explosion of businesses based in China that sell products through its vast digital mall.
headline: An American Comeback on Amazon

abstract: New York City tenants have been tossed out of their homes in more than 500 cases since the eviction moratorium was lifted.
lead_para: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at another sign that New York City is moving back to its prepandemic routines: Housing courts are hearing eviction cases again. We’ll also look at book publishing and its role in the city’s economy.
headline: In Housing Court, Tenants Are Being Evicted Again

abstract: The White House visit by rank-and-file union members was an unusual show of support by an administration of either party.
lead_para: President Biden, Vice President Kamala Harris and Labor Secretary Martin J. Walsh met Thursday at the White House with several union organizers involved in successful campaigns at companies including Amazon and Starbucks.
headline: Biden and Harris meet with labor organizers from Amazon and Starbucks.

abstract: A new documentary explains the undersung Canadian troupe’s brilliance, and a new season of its sketch show confirms it.
lead_para: The Kids in the Hall were very nearly not the Kids in the Hall. As Mark McKinney recalls in the two-part documentary “The Kids in the Hall: Comedy Punks,” he pushed for the Audience, the name of the group that he had performed in previously with Bruce McCulloch. “Thank God I didn’t win that fight,” he says.
headline: The Kids in the Hall Have Gotten Old. Their Comedy Hasn’t.

abstract: Anger, sadness and other reaction to the story about the former mayor. Also: An L.G.B.T.Q. bill; Amazon and unions; young people and change; unopened letters.
lead_para: To the Editor:
headline: A Portrait of Ed Koch’s Secret Gay Life

abstract: Most tech jobs are now in mainstream industries like health care, banking and retail, which are increasingly in need of workers with digital skills.
lead_para: Priya Natarajan, a seasoned software engineer, was restless this year and looking for her next career move. She wanted two things: a job where her technical skills would be put to good use in a field that could make “a big impact on the world,” she said.
headline: As Silicon Valley Retrenches, a Tech Talent Shift Accelerates

abstract: The online retail giant avoided a major fine but agreed to changes that have long been sought by merchants who depend on Amazon to reach customers.
lead_para: Amazon has agreed to give merchants operating in the European Union more access to valuable real estate on its website, the European Commission said Tuesday, in a deal that ends antitrust investigations by regulators who said the company had used its size and power to stifle competition in the bloc.
headline: Amazon and E.U. Reach Deal to End Antitrust Investigation

abstract: NetChoice, whose members include Amazon, Google, Meta and TikTok, said the new law could cause online services to limit important content for minors.
lead_para: A tech industry trade association sued the State of California on Wednesday in an effort to halt a new children’s online safety law, a legal challenge that comes at a moment of intensified public concern over the risks that content on popular platforms like Instagram and TikTok could pose to younger users.
headline: Tech Trade Group Sues California to Halt Children’s Online Safety Law

abstract: Contracts that could total $9 billion were awarded to Amazon, Google, Microsoft and Oracle. An earlier effort, won by Microsoft, was scrapped after rivals objected.
lead_para: The Defense Department said Wednesday that it had awarded lucrative cloud-computing contracts to four companies: Amazon, Google, Microsoft and Oracle. The contracts run through 2028 and could be valued as high as $9 billion, the Pentagon said in a news release.
headline: Pentagon Divides Big Cloud-Computing Deal Among 4 Firms

abstract: A new reality is setting in for students and recent graduates who spent years honing themselves for careers at the largest tech companies.
lead_para: Ever since she was a 10th grader in Seattle, Annalice Ni wanted to develop software for a prominent tech company like Google. So she went to great lengths to meet the internship and other résumé criteria that make students attractive hires to the biggest tech firms.
headline: Computer Science Students Face a Shrinking Big Tech Job Market

abstract: In challenging times, choosing the direction of a company can be a lot like shifting pieces of a puzzle — with sometimes staggering consequences.
lead_para: Last week at the DealBook Summit, I interviewed some of the world’s most influential leaders, among them Janet Yellen, the Treasury secretary of the United States; President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine; Mark Zuckerberg, chief executive of Meta; and Andy Jassy, the chief executive of Amazon.
headline: At the DealBook Summit, Untangling the Now — and the Future

abstract: We want to hear about the creative or surprising ways your household uses digital assistants. Find Alexa creepy? Tell us about that, too.
lead_para: Amazon has not figured out how to get customers to buy stuff with Alexa, its digital assistant, which is largely a disappointment for the company. But while Alexa has underperformed as a product for Amazon, we want to know how it’s performing for the people who really matter: us.
headline: Tell Us How Your Family Uses Alexa

abstract: Crypto, the economy, China, streaming wars, Elon Musk and other big topics dominated this year’s DealBook Summit.
lead_para: DealBook held its annual conference in New York yesterday, a packed day of high-level discussions with leaders from the world of politics, business and culture. Speakers included:
headline: What We Learned From Sam Bankman-Fried, Mark Zuckerberg, Reed Hastings and More

abstract: Business and policy leaders from around the world joined us at our annual event. Here’s what happened.
lead_para: Sam Bankman-Fried spoke about the collapse of FTX. In his first live interview since FTX filed for bankruptcy, the former C.E.O. of the cryptocurrency exchange repeatedly said he had not known the extent of its financial troubles and had not knowingly committed fraud or commingled funds. Bankman-Fried blamed the collapse on a “massive failure of oversight and said he was “deeply sorry for what happened.” Read the full transcript, and watch the video here.
headline: Did You Miss the DealBook Summit?

abstract: The winter storm system that is sweeping much of the United States has complicated the delivery of last-minute gifts. Amazon and other companies say they’re doing their best to prepare.
lead_para: Holiday shoppers scrambling to order last-minute gifts, and those already patiently waiting for their packages to arrive, have another concern to check off their lists: The winter storm sweeping much of the United States could have a negative effect on shipping.
headline: Holiday Shoppers and Shipping Companies Are Keeping a Close Eye on the Storm

abstract: Netflix, Amazon Prime and other studios are snapping up soundstages in Britain and building more, drawn by an experienced labor pool and alluring tax incentives.
lead_para: LIVERPOOL, England — For two decades, the Littlewoods building in Liverpool, a long, low-slung and cavernous space built to house a betting and mail-order company in the 1930s, sat abandoned. No one wanted to take on this crumbling hulk looming on the outskirts of the city.
headline: A Hollywood Production (Made in Liverpool)

abstract: The company said it expected to produce only 25,000 electric vehicles this year, adding a new cloud to its outlook only months after a hot I.P.O.
lead_para: Rivian, which has had a rocky ride in the stock market after a blockbuster initial public offering, cast a further shadow over its outlook on Thursday, reporting that supply chain problems could severely constrain its production of electric vehicles.
headline: Rivian Pares Delivery Targets for 2022, Citing Supply Problems

abstract: A judge ordered construction of the development in Cape Town to be halted, saying that the developer had not properly consulted Indigenous South Africans.
lead_para: JOHANNESBURG — A plan to build African headquarters for the tech giant Amazon in Cape Town is in peril after a judge on Friday ordered construction to stop, arguing that the developers had not properly consulted Indigenous South Africans.
headline: Plan for Amazon Headquarters in South Africa in Peril After Court Order

abstract: The policy change for Amazon Web Services started over the weekend but was not publicly announced until Tuesday.
lead_para: Amazon has quietly stopped letting customers in Russia and Belarus open new cloud computing accounts.
headline: Amazon Web Services blocks new sign-ups from Russia and Belarus.

abstract: The new policy will take down channels that persistently lie about vaccines and election fraud, as well as Russian state-run media.
lead_para: Twitch, the livestreaming site beloved by video gamers that has become a key internet communications service, said on Thursday that it had created new rules aimed at clamping down on egregious purveyors of misinformation.
headline: Twitch Says It Will Bar Chronic Spreaders of Misinformation

abstract: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are our picks for some of March’s most promising new titles.
lead_para: (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to HBO, Hulu, Apple TV+ and More in March

abstract: The attorney general for the District of Columbia said Amazon made merchants on its site sell at the lowest price they charged on the web, resulting in higher prices overall.
lead_para: A court on Friday threw out what was thought to have been the first government lawsuit in the United States arguing that Amazon had broken antitrust laws.
headline: D.C. Suit Accusing Amazon of Controlling Prices Is Thrown Out

abstract: The National Labor Relations Board approved the voting at a warehouse next to JFK8, where another election is in progress.
lead_para: The National Labor Relations Board has approved a union election at a second Amazon warehouse on Staten Island, opening a new front in the growing challenges to the company’s labor model.
headline: A Second Amazon Site on Staten Island Will Have a Union Election

abstract: Under pressure from investors and consumers, many Western companies are unwinding their investments, closing stores and pausing sales in Russia.
lead_para: After the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, ordered the invasion of Ukraine on Feb. 24, multinational companies have been forced to re-examine their ties with Russia. Some, like McDonald’s, PepsiCo and Shell, had built relationships with the country over decades and were faced with untangling complicated deals.
headline: Companies Are Getting Out of Russia, Sometimes at a Cost

abstract: TV-themed itineraries are on the rise, taking travelers on adventures with familiar shows during a time of uncertainty.
lead_para: With 70 percent of Americans watching more TV in 2021 than they did in 2020, binge-watching has skyrocketed during the pandemic. Now, as borders reopen, restrictions ease and travel restarts, tour advisers are fielding an increasingly popular request: immersive, TV-themed itineraries that allow travelers to live out their favorite shows’ story lines.
headline: ‘Bridgerton’ Tea, ‘Outlander’ Castles and Lodges in Yellowstone: Favorite TV Shows Inspire Trip Ideas

abstract: For the workers who haven’t joined the Great Resignation, this moment has inspired a new wave of organizing — and a brutal pushback.
lead_para: In 1996, Manuel Miranda, a second-generation Filipino American from Kent, Wash., graduated from Evergreen State College. He had majored in literature and got a job in Seattle, taking care of people with cerebral palsy for $9 an hour. The city was “post-grunge” but being transformed by tech, Miranda told me. There was a lot of excitement about Amazon, the online bookseller.
headline: Do Today’s Unions Have a Fighting Chance Against Corporate America?

abstract: A newly revamped store in Washington shows how thoroughly Amazon has woven itself into the grocery shopping experience.
lead_para: “Would you like to sign in with your palm?”
headline: Here Comes the Full Amazonification of Whole Foods

abstract: The retailer said it was taking action after governors from Connecticut to California ended mask mandates recently.
lead_para: Walmart said on Friday that fully vaccinated employees would no longer have to wear masks unless state or local rules required it. The change is effective immediately, the giant retailer said in a memo to its staff.
headline: Walmart says vaccinated workers no longer have to wear masks in most states.

abstract: The combination of next-day delivery, Ring surveillance footage and TikTok has put a spotlight on Amazon drivers. But it’s also created a new main character: the package itself.
lead_para: The TikTok video begins with a fish-eye view of a porch. Beyond it lies a sunny footpath, a yard planted with a sapling, a homogeneous subdivision. We are amid the suburban dream, and yet the view is foreboding: We are peering out from a hidden surveillance camera, and a stranger is approaching the house. We watch him execute a slow variation on the electric slide and deposit a package at the door. Then, in the manner of a servant capitulating to the whims of his liege, he curtsies toward the lens. He does this because, as the TikTok user explains by way of an automated robotic voice-over, “I asked my Amazon driver to do a dance before he delivers my package.”
headline: Dance, I Said — Dance! And Leave the Package on the Porch.

abstract: Even as grieving families tried to warn Amazon and other e-commerce sites of the danger, there were more purchases and more deaths.
lead_para: The pleas to Amazon were explicit. A food preservative sold by the online retailer and other e-commerce sites was being used as a poison to die by suicide.
headline: Lawmakers Press Amazon on Sales of Chemical Used in Suicides

abstract: Five superpower companies — yes, even Facebook after recent news — are completely enmeshed in our world.
lead_para: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
headline: What Big Tech’s Riches Mean for Our Future

abstract: Citing a competitive labor market, the online retailer raised the cap on cash compensation for salaried workers to $350,000, from $160,000.
lead_para: Amazon has told its corporate employees that it is raising its cap on base cash compensation to $350,000, more than double the previous amount, citing “a particularly competitive labor market,” according to an internal announcement viewed by The New York Times.
headline: Amazon doubles its cap on base salaries for corporate employees.

abstract: Amazon, Apple, Google and Microsoft are expanding their reach over the rest of the economy.
lead_para: The stock market has lately soured on the technology industry. Stock prices of many of the largest companies are down this year, some slightly — shares of Apple and Google have fallen more than 6 percent — and some stupendously: Facebook's parent company, Meta, and Netflix have lost about a third of their value since the New Year. Because surging tech stocks drove a big part of the stock market’s rise in 2021, their decline has contributed much to the market’s fall. The S & P 500 is down by about 7 percent in 2022.
headline: The Rise of Big Tech May Just Be Starting

abstract: Investors took the strong jobs showing as a reason for the Federal Reserve to move quickly as it starts to raise interest rates this year.
lead_para: Stocks on Wall Street rose on Friday, as an unexpectedly strong jobs report scrambled investors’ expectations for coming interest rate increases and as the latest round of earnings reports offset some fears about declining corporate profits.
headline: Stocks climb as investors weigh a surprising jobs report and Amazon earnings.

abstract: Online shopping was supposed to give consumers more power and freedom. Instead, costs are so fluid that household goods fluctuate almost like Bitcoin.
lead_para: When a holiday toy catalog from Amazon arrived in the mail in late October, Krista Hoffmann noticed something amiss.
headline: Does Anyone Know What Paper Towels Should Cost?

abstract: Speaking at The New York Times’ DealBook summit, Andy Jassy said that Amazon’s legal fight over a union election in Staten Island could end up in federal courts.
lead_para: Speaking at The New York Times’ DealBook summit, Andy Jassy said that Amazon’s legal fight over a union election in Staten Island could end up in federal courts.
headline: Amazon Will Challenge Staten Island Union Election, C.E.O. Says

abstract: Owners of the league’s teams met to discuss N.F.L. business, including the payment of a $790 million settlement over the Rams’ relocation.
lead_para: The fate of the Washington Commanders owner Daniel Snyder dominated the reports of the N.F.L. owners’ meeting in Manhattan on Tuesday, after the Indianapolis Colts owner Jim Irsay broke ranks with his peers and told reporters there was merit to forcing Snyder to sell his team.
headline: Dan Snyder Wasn’t on the N.F.L. Owners’ Meeting Agenda. Here’s What Was.

abstract: Or do they make our lives easier?
lead_para: We have a love-hate relationship with middlemen. We hate them — brokers or other intermediaries — because they can seem like profit-making parasites who needlessly insert themselves between customers and the people who actually make and do stuff. We try to get around middlemen by shopping at farmers’ markets, buying homemade goods straight from the makers on sites such as Etsy and directly supporting inventors and entrepreneurs by throwing money at them via GoFundMe.
headline: Are Middlemen Really Profit-Making Parasites?

abstract: The e-commerce site said the groups targeted its sites in the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Spain and Japan.
lead_para: Amazon filed a lawsuit against the leaders of over 10,000 Facebook groups it accused of publishing fake reviews on the e-commerce site, the company announced on Tuesday.
headline: Amazon sues leaders of more than 10,000 Facebook groups it says churn out fake reviews.

abstract: Diversely casting fantasy series like “The Rings of Power” isn’t a betrayal of the story. It’s also just one step in opening up the genre.
lead_para: Emilia Clarke does not have purple eyes. Her character in HBO’s “Game of Thrones,” Daenerys Targaryen, is described in the source novel by George R.R. Martin as having “violet” eyes, a distinctive feature of her family. The producers decided against using colored contact lenses. Somehow, millions of viewers were able to suspend disbelief.
headline: Guess Who’s Coming to Mordor

abstract: National Labor Relations Board officials said the company had applied its workplace rules unfairly, and asked it to change or scrap the regulations.
lead_para: Federal labor regulators have moved to force Amazon to scrap a rule that governs employees’ use of nonwork areas, accusing the company of illegally singling out union supporters in enforcing the policy.
headline: Regulators Accuse Amazon of Singling Out Union Organizers for Discipline

abstract: The U.S. wants to stop Penguin Random House from buying Simon & Schuster. The elephant in the room is Amazon.
lead_para: Amazon isn’t on trial in a big books lawsuit. But its power is.
headline: The Books Merger That’s About Amazon

abstract: The retail giant is exploring bundling a streaming service into its Walmart+ membership program.
lead_para: Walmart has held discussions with major media companies about including streaming entertainment in its membership service, according to three people with knowledge of the conversations, part of an effort to extend its relationship with customers beyond its brick-and-mortar stores.
headline: Walmart Ponders Streaming Deal With Paramount, Disney and Comcast

abstract: The acquisition of iRobot Corp., maker of the robot vacuum, will add to Amazon’s roster of smart home devices, which includes the Alexa virtual assistant and Ring doorbells.
lead_para: Hey, Alexa, tell Roomba to vacuum the bedroom.
headline: Amazon to Buy Maker of the Roomba for $1.7 Billion

abstract: Noteworthy premieres include new seasons of buzzy hits (“Abbott Elementary,” “The Handmaid’s Tale”), reboots and revivals (“Quantum Leap,” “Willow”) and more.
lead_para: The fall television season got off to an early start this year with the arrival of the dueling franchise extensions and hopeful blockbusters, “House of the Dragon” on HBO and “The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power” on Amazon Prime Video. But TV’s vast landscape offers a lot more than expensively produced, effects-laden fantasy. From the relatable delights of “Abbott Elementary” to the highly specific hilarity of “Documentary Now!,” here are some noteworthy fall premieres, arranged in chronological order.
headline: 40 TV Shows to Watch This Fall

abstract: Amazon’s expensive fantasy saga finally debuts on Thursday night. What do the critics think? Read on.
lead_para: Practically since it was announced several years ago, Amazon’s expensive “Lord of the Rings” prequel series, “The Rings of Power,” has had many people predicting its doom. Indeed the series’s quest seems fraught with peril: It must win over a general audience and live up to the beloved Peter Jackson film trilogy of the early 2000s. And it must also satisfy grumpy Tolkien readers who have debated this material for decades. Stray but a little, as Galadriel might say, and it will fail.
headline: ‘The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power’: The Reviews Are In

abstract: In Shira Ovide’s last On Tech newsletter, she looks back at how the past two and a half years have shifted her thinking on technology.
lead_para: I’ve had the opportunity to write the On Tech newsletter for the past two and a half years, and now that time has come to an end. This is my last edition.
headline: A Goodbye to Readers and a Reflection

abstract: Data mining plus streaming can target political ads household by household, largely unregulated.
lead_para: Over the last few weeks, tens of thousands of voters in the Detroit area who watch streaming video services were shown different local campaign ads pegged to their political leanings.
headline: This Ad’s for You (Not Your Neighbor)

abstract: Rob Bonta, California’s attorney general, said the retailer punishes companies that offer lower prices on other websites.
lead_para: California’s attorney general filed an antitrust lawsuit against Amazon on Wednesday, claiming the retailer stifles competition and increases the prices that consumers pay across the internet.
headline: California Files Antitrust Lawsuit Against Amazon

abstract: Amazon’s “The Rings of Power” will struggle to recreate the magic of Middle-earth, a world not fit for “cinematic universe” treatment.
lead_para: In the months leading up to its premiere this Friday, Amazon Prime’s “The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power” has prompted both excitement and concern among fans at the expansion of J.R.R. Tolkien’s world in the era of the “cinematic universe.”
headline: Please Don’t Make a Tolkien Cinematic Universe

abstract: The labor official concluded that Amazon’s objections to the election should be set aside and that the Amazon Labor Union should be certified to represent workers at the warehouse.
lead_para: A federal labor official who presided over Amazon’s challenge to a union victory at a Staten Island warehouse has recommended that the challenge be rejected, the National Labor Relations Board said on Thursday.
headline: Labor Board Official Says Amazon Effort to Overturn Staten Island Warehouse Election Should Be Rejected

abstract: Amazon’s pricey, gorgeous fantasy spectacle delivers what fans expect, but it could thrive by giving them what they don’t.
lead_para: What does several hundred million dollars buy?
headline: ‘The Rings of Power’ Review: Shiny, Not Yet Precious

abstract: Self-checkout systems are intended to make shopping convenient, but they also can lead to more thefts, experts said.
lead_para: Citing losses, the supermarket chain Wegmans announced that it had halted the use of its self-checkout app in which customers scanned their groceries as they shopped.
headline: Wegmans Discontinues Self-Checkout App, Citing Losses

abstract: Which has the better dragons? Which has the better swords? Now that we’ve seen a few episodes of each, here’s an early comparison.
lead_para: Comparisons between HBO’s “House of the Dragon” and Amazon’s “The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power” — both new epic fantasies, both prequel series, both with huge budgets and ready-made fan bases — were probably inevitable. And indeed the internet has already been more than happy to oblige.
headline: Fantasy Face-Off: ‘The Rings of Power’ vs. ‘House of the Dragon’

abstract: To truly rule the television world, the two fantasy series need to borrow from each other’s strengths.
lead_para: The past 25 years of American television, like the history of J.R.R. Tolkien’s Middle-earth, can be usefully divided into several ages. First came the age of Prestige TV, dominated by auteurs and antiheroes, 1970s-style reimaginings of classic cinematic genres, think pieces about Dickensian storytelling, Sunday-night appointments with HBO. It was succeeded by the age of Peak TV, in which proliferating streaming platforms competed to produce as much content as possible, in a repetitive churn dominated by B+ knockoffs of the prestige era’s biggest hits.
headline: With ‘House of the Dragon’ and ‘The Rings of Power,’ We’ve Entered the Age of Blockbuster TV

abstract: The deal, which will help expand distribution of its stationary bikes, comes in the middle of a turnaround effort by the company’s new chief executive.
lead_para: Peloton said on Wednesday that it had reached a deal with Amazon to sell exercise equipment, accessories and apparel on the retailer’s U.S. website, as the maker of stationary bikes tries to reinvigorate sales.
headline: Peloton will sell fitness equipment and apparel on Amazon.

abstract: Last month, the company said it planned to acquire One Medical, a much larger competitor to its own health care business.
lead_para: Amazon told employees in an email on Wednesday that it is shutting down Amazon Care, its in-house foray into providing primary and urgent health care. The move comes a month after Amazon announced plans to buy a much larger competitor, One Medical, in a $3.9 billion deal.
headline: Amazon says it will shut down Amazon Care, its primary and urgent health care business.

abstract: What Braxton Wright has learned by participating in one of the longest work stoppages in U.S. history.
lead_para: For more than 500 days, coal miners in rural Alabama have been on strike. Around 900 workers walked off the job in April 2021, and they haven’t been back since.
headline: A Coal Miner’s Political Transformation

abstract: Jacobson cocreated and stars in this new Amazon series, which expands the story told in Penny Marshall’s 1992 film.
lead_para: Abbi Jacobson really can play baseball, she insisted. Just not when the cameras are rolling. “I fully get the yips when someone is watching me,” she told me.
headline: In ‘A League of Their Own,’ Abbi Jacobson Makes the Team

abstract: The dream was to sell directly to customers. Now Peloton is on Amazon, Casper is in a furniture shop, and it’s awkward.
lead_para: Earlier this summer, I bought an online mattress — in a boring, conventional store.
headline: Why Peloton Is Selling on Amazon

abstract: The former syndication star and top-flight interviewer is rebuilding his daily show on Amazon’s new app, Amp.
lead_para: LOS ANGELES — One afternoon in June, Zach Sang was curled into an improvised studio nook at the top of a staircase in a warehouse in Hollywood. The setup was ramshackle — right downstairs was the fallow set for Hailey Bieber’s YouTube series “Who’s in My Bathroom?” — but Sang didn’t let the scrappy conditions get to him.
headline: Zach Sang, the Ryan Seacrest of the Youth, Wants to Save Radio

abstract: A new version of the women’s baseball tale, best known from the 1992 movie, incorporates stories about queer identity and race.
lead_para: A subset of TV’s seemingly endless crop of reboots adapt well-known properties from yesteryear but with more thoughtful or thorough approaches to race or gender, or both. The 1960s are different when “The Wonder Years” centers on a Black family. There’s more to gossip about on “Gossip Girl” without the rigid do-si-do of a gender binary.
headline: Review: ‘A League of Their Own’ Broadens the Field

abstract: A sweeping bill that would enact the strongest restrictions on Big Tech companies in the United States has been stalled in the Senate.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Critics of the country’s largest tech companies branded the last few months “Hot Antitrust Summer” because they hoped that Congress would vote on new regulations for Amazon, Apple, Google and Facebook.
headline: Clock Running Out on Antitrust Bill Targeting Big Tech

abstract: The maker of electric pickup trucks, vans and sport utility vehicles affirmed its production forecast for the year.
lead_para: Rivian, a fledgling electric-vehicle manufacturer, said Thursday that it lost $1.7 billion in the second quarter.
headline: Rivian Reports $1.7 Billion Quarterly Loss as Supply Chain Problems Persist

abstract: Mr. Carney, who was press secretary to President Barack Obama, joined Amazon in 2015.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Jay Carney, who was press secretary for President Barack Obama, is leaving the top policy and public communications job at Amazon to join Airbnb.
headline: Jay Carney, Amazon’s Top Policy Executive, Will Join Airbnb

abstract: Amazon has ordered 100,000 trucks to cut its carbon dioxide emissions, but Rivian will take years to deliver.
lead_para: Nearly three years ago, Amazon announced that it would buy 100,000 custom-made delivery vehicles from Rivian, a fledgling maker of electric vehicles. On Thursday, after some delays, the companies said hundreds of the vans were finally on the road.
headline: Amazon Wants 100,000 Electric Vans. Can Rivian Deliver?

abstract: Growth has slowed from its pandemic highs as people return to shopping in-person and pull back on spending in an uncertain economy.
lead_para: Amazon’s growth continued to come down from its pandemic highs, the company said on Thursday, signaling a new normal as online shopping resets amid a tumultuous economy.
headline: Amazon posts 7.2 percent increase in revenue, the slowest growth rate in two decades.

abstract: The $3.9 billion deal is Amazon’s latest acquisition in the health care industry. In 2018, it acquired PillPack, an online pharmacy.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Just two months ago, Andy Jassy, almost a year into his reign as Amazon’s chief executive, told investors that driving down costs was a “really big area of focus,” after the company produced its worst quarterly earnings in years. But that didn’t mean he wasn’t open to a deal.
headline: Amazon to acquire One Medical clinics in latest push into health care.

abstract: “Net-zero emissions” sounds like an ambitious goal, but for most corporations, it’s just kicking the can down the road.
lead_para: In what seems like a rapid shift of gears, corporations are finally jumping into action on climate change.
headline: New Climate Promises, Same Old Global Warming

abstract: Many companies are navigating tough times better than investors had feared.
lead_para: When the president, the treasury secretary and other Biden administration officials insisted this week that the American economy is not currently in a recession, they were mocked for weaseling out of bad news on a technicality. The Commerce Department announced on Thursday that the broadest measure of economic activity, gross domestic product, fell for a second quarter in a row — meeting a widely held, though unofficial, definition of recession. It is true, as the Biden folks argued, that the nation’s official recession arbiter, the National Bureau of Economic Research, has yet to call one, because it relies on many more signals. Still, it sure sounded as if the Biden team was splitting hairs.
headline: Recession? Not for Big Tech.

abstract: Maybelle Blair is still dedicated to including women and girls in baseball. And she still loves the “clicketyclack” sound of baseball cleats on her feet.
lead_para: Maybelle Blair walked into a sporting goods store in her early 90s with a mission: to try on a pair of spikes.
headline: She Inspired ‘A League of Their Own.’ At 95, She’s Far From Done.

abstract: The retail giant said it would stop collecting nonpublic data on rivals and give merchants more ways to reach customers.
lead_para: Amazon tried on Thursday to end a three-year investigation by antitrust regulators in the European Union by offering to make a series of changes to its business practices and give rival merchants an easier way to reach customers on its website.
headline: Amazon Moves to End a Long-Running Antitrust Case in Europe

abstract: The e-commerce giant planned to build an airport cargo center, hire 1,000 workers and invest hundreds of millions of dollars over 20 years.
lead_para: For the second time, plans by Amazon to substantially expand its presence in the New York area have been abandoned after labor and community groups mobilized in opposition.
headline: Amazon Hub in Newark Is Canceled After Unions and Local Groups Object

abstract: As the first Arab Muslim lead in a comic book adaptation, the Egyptian American actor lists the things guiding him as he steps into the spotlight.
lead_para: Growing up in Pasadena, the actor Abubakr Ali never thought he’d play many lead roles. Even after coming up through the acting program at New York University and then the Yale School of Drama — where he graduated alongside the playwright Jeremy O. Harris and “The Gilded Age” actress Louisa Jacobson, the daughter of Meryl Streep — he’d become used to a world in which an Egyptian-born Arab American like himself would be relegated to the margins.
headline: Abubakr Ali Gets a Boost From Whale-Watching and Eid Fashions

abstract: The region is home to the largest concentration of online shoppers in the country. The facilities, key to delivering packages on time, are reshaping neighborhoods.
lead_para: An e-commerce boom turbocharged by the pandemic is turning the New York City region into a national warehouse capital.
headline: Warehouses Transform N.Y.C. Neighborhoods as E-Commerce Booms

abstract: The company has held hundreds of meetings with workers to discourage them from supporting a union in two upcoming elections.
lead_para: On Staten Island, Amazon supervisors often refer to them as “training.” At an Amazon warehouse in Alabama, supervisors refer to them ambiguously as “meetings.” Amazon says they’re officially “small group meetings.”
headline: Mandatory Meetings Reveal Amazon’s Approach to Resisting Unions
