lead_para: When the celebrity-backed media company Religion of Sports — founded by Tom Brady, Michael Strahan and Gotham Chopra — debuted in 2018, getting into the rapidly expanding podcast business seemed like a no-brainer.
headline: Podcast Companies, Once Walking on Air, Feel the Strain of Gravity

abstract: Christoph Waltz plays a very, very bad boss in a dark tech-industry satire from Amazon Prime Video.
lead_para: “The Consultant,” an amusing trifle on Amazon Prime Video that burns through most of its dark-comic capital before its eight episodes are up, is set during a critical moment at a tech company: when new, “competent” management takes over for the brilliant but callow founder.
headline: ‘The Consultant’ Review: When Your Start-Up Goes to Hell

abstract: With the exception of Apple, eight tech giants are no longer “pure growth” stocks, while Exxon and Chevron are, a new study says. Our columnist says: Buyer, beware.
lead_para: It is impossible even to talk about the long bull market that ended in January 2022 without saying high-growth tech stocks propelled the market higher.
headline: Value Stocks? Growth Stocks? Markets Last Year Turned Everything Topsy-Turvy.

abstract: Looking for something different to stream? We have options for you.
lead_para: This month’s suggestions for the hidden gems of your subscription streaming services cut a wide swath of genres and styles, including a piercing psychological thriller, a moody marital drama and a buck-wild sex comedy, with a handful of first-rate documentaries to keep you anchored in reality.
headline: ‘Black Bear,’ ‘Sharp Stick’ and More Streaming Gems

abstract: Rescuing movie viewers from endless browsing — and introducing them to hidden gems — is satisfying to a Times critic.
lead_para: The phrase “service journalism” is a loaded one, particularly among arts critics, who are constantly worrying that their thoughtful and nuanced criticism is being reduced to a yes or no binary — fresh or rotten fruit, if you will. Am I contributing to the cultural conversation, we worry, or merely serving as a consumer guide? But as the writer who curates the New York Times lists of the best movies to watch on Netflix and on Amazon Prime Video, and the best movies and TV shows to see on Hulu, I’ve come not only to accept the label of service journalism, but to embrace it.
headline: A Film Critic Who Embraces His Role as a Guide

abstract: After more than a year of delays and adjustments, the big-budget adaptation of a best-selling novel about music, love and fame hopes to become this year’s irresistible streaming series.
lead_para: It was the 36th day of what was supposed to be a 30-day shoot in New Orleans, but the cast and crew of the rock drama “Daisy Jones & the Six” were still at it.
headline: ‘Daisy Jones & the Six’ and the Ballad of Making Rock ’n’ Roll TV

abstract: The company indicated the reduced growth and tight margins would continue in the first three months of this year.
lead_para: Amazon on Thursday reported almost no profit in the latest quarter, with unexpected weakness in its big cloud computing businesses helping to slow overall sales growth to one of its lowest levels in decades.
headline: Amazon Reports Almost No Profit and Slowing Growth

abstract: Seven years ago, I showed that Facebook sold discriminatory ads. Its system is still broken.
lead_para: I still remember the shock I felt when I was able to buy a Facebook ad aimed only at white house hunters — something the Fair Housing Act was designed to prevent — in just minutes. But even more shocking is that it took six years after my test for Meta, Facebook’s parent company, to comply with the act. As of today, the company still has not fully fixed its discriminatory ad system.
headline: It’s Time to Tear Up Big Tech’s Get-Out-of-Jail-Free Card

abstract: Apple, Amazon and Alphabet all reported disappointing quarterly results, as they emphasized efforts to cut costs in the face of an economic slowdown.
lead_para: Shares in tech companies are in retreat after investors got sobering news on Thursday about three of the industry’s giants — Alphabet, Amazon and Apple — including slowing demand for everything from iPhones to digital ads to cloud services.
headline: Tech Earnings Give a Wake-Up Call to Investors

abstract: The race for the White House is deadlocked, but business leaders aren’t taking chances, reaching out to the former president to rebuild relations.
lead_para: As the presidential race nears its end next week, the most notable public sound from many C.E.O.s and businesses on the election has been silence — and Donald Trump’s camp is increasingly interpreting that as a sign that corporate America may be preparing for him to win.
headline: Corporate America Hedges on Trump 2.0

abstract: As this documentary by Brett Story and Stephen Maing chronicles, the efforts to unionize a warehouse in New York were successful — but also a grind.
lead_para: When employees at an Amazon warehouse on Staten Island voted to unionize in 2022, the result was seen as a major victory for organized labor. A year earlier, the documentarians Brett Story (“The Hottest August”) and Stephen Maing (“Crime + Punishment”) got on the ground with the workers and the organizers; in their engrossing new film, “Union,” they show how the vote’s outcome was hardly assured.
headline: ‘Union’ Review: A Labor Fight to the Finish at Amazon

abstract: The tech giant’s cloud computing business picked up steam and its retail business showed resiliency.
lead_para: Amazon reported record profits on Thursday, as cloud computing sales picked up steam and its retail business showed resilience.
headline: Amazon Reports Record $15.3 Billion Profit

abstract: A plan to revive U.S. chip manufacturing rests partly on a company that is firing workers and delaying factories, even as the government pushes for the opposite.
lead_para: At an annual gathering of tech executives and billionaires in Sun Valley, Idaho, this past July, Gina Raimondo commandeered a table near a duck pond and tried to exert her influence as the U.S. secretary of commerce to help rescue an ailing national champion.
headline: The White House Bet Big on Intel. Will It Backfire?

abstract: A new docudrama recounts the conflicts and controversy surrounding “Loft Story,” a French twist on “Big Brother” that divided critics and generations.
lead_para: The behind-the-scenes French docudrama “Culte” (in French, with subtitles), available on Amazon Prime Video, captures the birth of reality TV in France. And like many births, it’s a messy and emotional process, with plenty of screaming and crying from multiple parties, some unhelpful meddling from the families, fits of doubt and unknown reservoirs of determination.
headline: ‘Culte’ Is a Fascinating Romp Through the Dawn of French Reality TV

abstract: Large technology companies are investing billions of dollars in nuclear energy as an emissions-free source of electricity for artificial intelligence and other businesses.
lead_para: Technology companies are increasingly looking to nuclear power plants to provide the emissions-free electricity needed to run artificial intelligence and other businesses.
headline: Hungry for Energy, Amazon, Google and Microsoft Turn to Nuclear Power

abstract: Companies like Amazon have required a return to the office five days a week despite findings showing benefits to employers that allow some remote days.
lead_para: Amazon’s C.E.O., Andy Jassy, made waves last month when he demanded that all employees return to the office five days a week. The proclamation seemed to validate similar demands made by executives like JPMorgan Chase’s Jamie Dimon and Goldman Sachs’s David Solomon. And it naturally raised the question of whether others might follow suit. (It appears some have.)
headline: Executives and Research Disagree About Hybrid Work. Why?

abstract: The push by Pinduoduo to lower prices has helped it become one of China’s fastest-growing e-commerce apps, and epitomizes a broader force plaguing the economy.
lead_para: When Lin Yunyun started selling diapers two years ago on Pinduoduo, China’s fast-growing e-commerce site, she was not prepared for the relentless nagging about prices.
headline: How E-Commerce Is Making China’s Deflation Worse

abstract: Amazon’s delivery system depends on third-party companies. But labor regulators have challenged that model, possibly opening the way for unionization.
lead_para: Vans marked with Amazon’s arrow logo have become ubiquitous on residential streets, a symbol of the nearly instantaneous delivery that has transformed online shopping.
headline: Amazon Could Be Forced to Treat Drivers as Employees

abstract: The billionaire made splashy purchases of The Washington Post and a mansion in Washington. But his status as a power player in the nation’s capital was never realized.
lead_para: A decade ago, Jeff Bezos was expected to make a splash in Washington.
headline: Mr. Bezos Went to Washington. But He Never Arrived.

abstract: Margrethe Vestager, the European Union’s antitrust regulator, who put technology’s harms on the global agenda, reflected on a decade of taking on the biggest companies and what comes next.
lead_para: Margrethe Vestager, the European Union antitrust enforcer who has been the world’s foremost critic of the tech industry, recently walked through her Brussels office wondering what to do with the stuff she had accumulated during a decade in that role, which ends late this month. At one point, she paused to lift a sculpture of a hand holding up its middle finger.
headline: The World’s Pioneering Tech Cop Is Making Her Exit

abstract: Eight years ago, workers loudly protested White House policies. This time around, the companies are trying to keep a lid on activism.
lead_para: If any industry could have said its workplaces were politicized, it was tech.
headline: Big Tech’s Hotbeds of Employee Activism Quiet After Trump’s Victory

abstract: The world’s two richest men are longtime business rivals, but now one of them has the ear of the next president of the United States.
lead_para: A few months ago, a three-post exchange between Jeff Bezos and Elon Musk on Mr. Musk’s X would have passed for petty sniping between billionaire rivals.
headline: Three Short Posts Show a New Power Dynamic Between Musk and Bezos

abstract: Another Trump presidency will be good for crypto and Elon Musk, but every big tech company may not benefit from a more hands-off approach to antitrust.
lead_para: Donald Trump has won the 2024 presidential election. Follow live updates here.
headline: What a Trump Victory Means for Tech

abstract: The executives of tech’s biggest companies largely ignored Donald Trump before the 2016 election. This time around, they’re far more friendly.
lead_para: When Donald J. Trump first campaigned for president eight years ago, tech executives largely ignored him. They later atoned for their disregard by making a televised walk through the lobby of Trump Tower in New York for a 90-minute meeting with the president-elect.
headline: Before the Election, Tech C.E.O.s Were Quietly Courting Trump

abstract: Consumers are seeking deals and being choosier about their spending in the crucial final weeks of the year, executives say.
lead_para: Shoppers are heading into the Black Friday weekend unsure how wide to open their wallets, retailers say, with many still feeling the squeeze of inflation and also worried that tariffs could make things even more expensive if they wait too long to buy.
headline: Holiday Shopping Season Separates Winning Retailers From Losers

abstract: Since last September, the tech giant has pumped $8 billion into the artificial intelligence start-up, a sign of intense competition in developing tools that are reshaping the tech sector.
lead_para: Amazon said on Friday that it would invest another $4 billion in Anthropic, a start-up that competes with OpenAI and Google in the increasingly competitive field of artificial intelligence.
headline: Amazon Invests $4 Billion in Anthropic, Deepening Its A.I. Ties

abstract: The ruling, stemming from a complaint against Amazon, bars companies from compelling workers to attend meetings on unionization’s downsides.
lead_para: The National Labor Relations Board ruled on Wednesday that companies may not compel workers to attend meetings on the downsides of unionization, a tactic that unions say stifles worker organizing.
headline: N.L.R.B. Says Employers Can’t Hold Mandatory Anti-Union Meetings

abstract: The machines can load and unload trucks, move goods and do other repetitive tasks but are stymied by some, like picking items from a pile.
lead_para: In the outbound dock of an Amazon warehouse near Nashville, a robotic arm named Cardinal on a recent day stacked packages, Tetris-style, into six-and-a-half-foot-high carts. Then Proteus, an autonomous platform, moved the carts to the loading bay, flashing electronic eyes designed to make the robot more appealing to human colleagues.
headline: Robots Struggle to Match Warehouse Workers on ‘Really Hard’ Jobs

abstract: Like Christmas shows? So does Hallmark+. Like horror? Dare to try Shudder. And British shows? There’s BritBox and more.
lead_para: Executives from the Hallmark Channel made a curious decision this fall: They started a new streaming service.
headline: The Streaming Wars Didn’t Kill the Little Guys. In Fact, They’re Thriving.

abstract: Netflix and Amazon are driving a small bump in the market for TV shows after a major slowdown.
lead_para: It has been nearly seven months since Hollywood resolved its strikes, but momentum still hasn’t taken hold in the entertainment industry. “Survive till ’25” has become an informal slogan among entertainment workers.
headline: Signs of Life Appear in TV Show Purchases

abstract: The Amazon Labor Union has been divided over strategy and governance issues after winning a representation vote at a Staten Island warehouse in 2022.
lead_para: A dissident group has won control of the Amazon Labor Union, the only union in the country that formally represents Amazon warehouse workers, election results on Tuesday showed.
headline: Dissident Group Wins Amazon Union Leadership Vote

abstract: California officials cited failures to disclose productivity requirements at two locations. The company said it would appeal.
lead_para: A California labor regulator said on Tuesday that it had fined Amazon nearly $6 million for thousands of violations of a safety law that took effect in 2022.
headline: Amazon Is Fined Nearly $6 Million Over Warehouse Work Quotas

abstract: In the best ways, this endearing and very bingeable British show feels as if “Breaking Bad” were happening to “Bob’s Burgers.”
lead_para: “Some of this might have happened,” “The Curse” declares at the top of each episode. The show is loosely inspired by the 1983 Brink’s-Mat robbery in London, when robbers stole a mountain of gold bullion from a vault and largely evaded capture. As with many plundered caches, though, those bricks came at a cost, and where money led, misery followed.
headline: ‘The Curse’ Is a Pulpy and Self-Aware Heist Series

abstract: The soaring electricity demands of data centers and A.I. are straining the grid in some areas, pushing up emissions and slowing the energy transition.
lead_para: A few weeks ago, I joined a small group of reporters for a wide-ranging conversation with Bill Gates about climate change, its causes and potential solutions. When the topic turned to the issue of just how much energy artificial intelligence was using, Gates was surprisingly sanguine.
headline: A.I.’s Insatiable Appetite for Energy

abstract: Online sales appear to be compounding threats from climate change and habitat loss, according to new research.
lead_para: Some of the bright orange bats were framed in shadow boxes, their boldly striped wings spread wide. Others were mounted in miniature coffins with shiny fittings. A few were promoted as Halloween or Christmas gifts.
headline: Bats Were Already Struggling. Now They’re Selling on EBay.

abstract: The agreements, set to begin after next season, could potentially pay the league about $76 billion over 11 years.
lead_para: The National Basketball Association’s Board of Governors has approved a set of agreements for the rights to show the league’s games, Commissioner Adam Silver said on Tuesday, moving one step closer to completing deals that would reshape how the sport is watched over the next decade.
headline: N.B.A. Board Backs TV Rights Deals, but Steps Remain

abstract: The company is trying to make the league accept its match of Amazon’s bid to broadcast games starting with the 2025-26 season.
lead_para: Warner Bros. Discovery sued the National Basketball Association on Friday in an attempt to force the league to accept its offer to match Amazon’s bid to broadcast games.
headline: Warner Bros. Discovery Sues N.B.A. Over Rights Deal

abstract: The league rejected a bid by Warner Bros. Discovery to match Amazon’s offer.
lead_para: The National Basketball Association announced new rights agreements with Disney, Comcast and Amazon on Wednesday after rejecting a rival bid by Warner Bros. Discovery that would have kept games on its TNT network, which has broadcast the N.B.A. since the 1980s.
headline: N.B.A. Announces Lucrative Rights Deals With Disney, Comcast and Amazon

abstract: “Batman: Caped Crusader,” a new animated series, is not concerned with making its hero likable — either to the citizens of Gotham or to its audience.
lead_para: The story of Batman has been told in comic books and onscreen many times. But if there’s one person who should get the chance to tell it again, it is Bruce Timm.
headline: A New Batman Is Less a Dark Knight Than a ‘Weird and Creepy’ One

abstract: Inspired by the very (very) brief reign of Queen Jane, the Amazon series has fun rewriting Tudor history — complete with magical creatures.
lead_para: “My Lady Jane,” whose eight-episode first season is available now, on Amazon, seems to be in the vein of “The Great” or “Bridgerton,” irreverent historical fiction with aggressively contemporary mores and scores. But it is perhaps better understood as a fantasy comedy because not only does it break with history, it breaks with reality: It is Tudor palace intrigue with shape-shifting, a joyful and breathless more-more-more. A lot of “Jane” adheres, happily, to genre conventions, but it is done with a well-pitched playfulness. Even the stained glass in so many of the backgrounds has a funfetti color scheme.
headline: ‘My Lady Jane’ Is a Sly and Sassy Historical Comedy

abstract: The deal, a vote in favor of the future of brick-and-mortar retail on the high end, could reshape the retail landscape.
lead_para: In a move that would further consolidate the luxury retail market, the parent company of Saks Fifth Avenue has agreed to acquire Neiman Marcus in a $2.65 billion deal, creating the ultimate high-end department store behemoth, the companies announced on Wednesday.
headline: $2.65 Billion Saks-Neiman Marcus Acquisition Will Create a Luxury Retail Giant

abstract: “Pop Culture Jeopardy!” is expected to begin production in August and will stream only on Amazon Prime Video.
lead_para: If you have enjoyed Colin Jost’s dispatches from Tahiti for the Olympics surfing events and are hoping to see more of him, you’re in luck: On Wednesday, Sony Pictures Television announced that he will be host of the new game show “Pop Culture Jeopardy!”
headline: Colin Jost Will Host the New ‘Jeopardy!’ Pop Culture Spinoff

abstract: The company said it effectively got all of the electricity it used last year from sources that did not produce greenhouse gas emissions. Some experts have faulted the company’s calculations.
lead_para: Amazon announced on Wednesday that effectively all of the electricity its operations used last year came from sources that did not produce greenhouse gas emissions. But some experts have criticized the method the company uses to make that determination as being too lenient.
headline: Amazon Says It Reached a Climate Goal Seven Years Early

abstract: Who will survive? Die? Thrive? And how? We talked to nearly a dozen top media executives and asked them to predict what lies ahead.
lead_para: When the media titans Brian Roberts, John Malone and Barry Diller cast off in early February on Mr. Diller’s 156-foot, two-masted yacht, named Arriva, the waters off the coast of Jupiter, Fla., were placid.
headline: The Future of Streaming (According to the Moguls Figuring It Out)

abstract: The visual effects supervisor, hurt in one of three recent accidents on Amazon film sets, has sued, but the company says it is not to blame.
lead_para: In March 2023, the producers of Amazon’s holiday movie “Candy Cane Lane,” starring Eddie Murphy, were determined to set a 15-foot fir aflame for a scene, according to court papers filed in a recent lawsuit.
headline: Film Crew Veteran, Injured in an Accident, Faults Amazon for His Pain

abstract: A fantastical series about the very short-term 16th century queen Lady Jane Grey takes historical liberties in the name of reclamation — and fun.
lead_para: Lady Jane Grey is generally considered a tragic heroine, the teen queen of England and Ireland for nine days in 1553 before her foes manipulated her into an early death by execution. As the cheeky narrator of the Amazon series “My Lady Jane” puts it, “History remembers her as the ultimate damsel in distress.”
headline: ‘My Lady Jane’ Asks: ‘What if History Were Different?’

abstract: An affiliation agreement between the Amazon Labor Union and the 1.3 million-member Teamsters signals an escalation in challenging the online retailer.
lead_para: After years of organizing Amazon workers and pressuring the company to bargain over wages and working conditions, two prominent unions are teaming up to challenge the online retailer.
headline: How the Teamsters and a Homegrown Union Plan to Take On Amazon

abstract: The actress in the hit superhero satire mulled her role in an age of online bullying and token feminism: “Thank God there are characters like this.”
lead_para: Erin Moriarty just stopped a stranger in his tracks. But it wasn’t because he recognized her as a star on one of TV’s most popular shows, or because he was taken by her charm.
headline: Erin Moriarty Is a Woman Among ‘The Boys’

abstract: There were more than 100 reports of breakage involving the JoyJolt Declan single-wall glass mug, resulting in 56 injuries, the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission said. Some required surgery and stitches.
lead_para: A recall has been issued for about 580,000 glass coffee mugs after the manufacturer received more than 100 reports that they broke when filled with hot liquids, resulting in nearly five dozen injuries, the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced on Thursday.
headline: 580,000 Glass Coffee Mugs Are Recalled After Hot Liquid Causes Some to Break

abstract: The leading companies are co-opting Silicon Valley’s traditional cycle of disruption.
lead_para: Silicon Valley prides itself on disruption: Start-ups develop new technologies, upend existing markets and overtake incumbents. This cycle of creative destruction brought us the personal computer, the internet and the smartphone. But in recent years, a handful of incumbent tech companies have sustained their dominance. Why? We believe they have learned how to co-opt potentially disruptive start-ups before they can become competitive threats.
headline: How Big Tech Is Killing Innovation

abstract: They’ll be replaced in North America with paper packing, eliminating some 15 billion pillows a year. Plastic film is a major pollutant.
lead_para: They’re a familiar sight in Amazon packages: The plastic air pillows designed to keep products safe in transit, but that also end up in landfills by the billions.
headline: Amazon Says It Will Stop Using Puffy Plastic Shipping Pillows

abstract: Major U.S. entertainment companies are hiring a former top F.B.I. official and renewing a push for federal legislation to combat online thievery overseas.
lead_para: In recent years, Hollywood has become much better at hunting pirates. Just last week, five men were convicted of operating Jetflicks, an illegal streaming site that federal prosecutors said offered a stolen lineup of TV shows and movies that was larger than the combined catalogs of Netflix, Hulu and Amazon’s Prime Video.
headline: Hollywood Sharpens Aim at Online Pirates

abstract: The company’s TNT channel and the N.B.A. have long been inextricably linked, but that may end after next season. Plus, Charles Barkley is retiring.
lead_para: Warner Bros. Discovery executives thought they had given the National Basketball Association a proposal it would accept.
headline: As N.B.A. TV Deal Nears, Warner Bros. Discovery Is on the Outside

abstract: Big tech companies say A.I. can help solve climate change, even as it’s driving up their emissions and raising doubts about their climate goals.
lead_para: Cleaning up the technology industry was supposed to be easy.
headline: The A.I. Power Grab

abstract: Some members of Congress have expressed concerns that stores will monitor customers and raise prices. Business experts say the technology has not raised customers’ grocery bills.
lead_para: Members of Congress are raising the alarm about new technology at supermarkets: They say Kroger and other major grocery stores are implementing digital price tags that could allow for dynamic pricing, meaning the sticker price on items like eggs and milk could change regularly.
headline: Kroger and Walmart Deny ‘Surge Pricing’ After Adopting Digital Price Tags

abstract: The series is the third production linked to the author to face turmoil after allegations made by five women surfaced this summer.
lead_para: “Good Omens,” a series based on a novel by the author Neil Gaiman written in collaboration with Terry Pratchett, will return for a third and final season, but it will consist of only one episode, Prime Video announced on Friday.
headline: ‘Good Omens’ Season 3 Cut Short Amid Allegations Against Gaiman

abstract: Eight people were taken to hospitals, three of them with serious injuries, in a crash on the set of “The Pickup” in April. A federal investigation found no health or safety violations.
lead_para: An investigation into a crash that injured several crew members on the set of the movie “The Pickup” this year found no safety violations, federal officials said.
headline: Investigation of Georgia Movie Set Crash Finds No Violations

abstract: The world’s richest men have their own rocket fleets, their own media and their own schemes to succeed with Donald J. Trump.
lead_para: Entrepreneurs become legends when they make big bets on technology that pay off in a huge and dramatic way. Elon Musk is now applying that all-or-nothing philosophy to a presidential election, tying his reputation and perhaps his future to a win by Donald J. Trump.
headline: Jeff Bezos, Elon Musk and the Billions of Ways to Influence an Election

abstract: The tech giant has been increasing live programming on its streaming service, but this will be its first test with news.
lead_para: Amazon is dipping its toe into the news business, with a familiar face.
headline: Amazon Enters News With Live Election Coverage From Brian Williams

abstract: It is the shopping phenomenon of our times, and now it’s an Amazon store.
lead_para: In mid-November, as election post-mortems focused on inflation worries and the holiday shopping season began to pick up steam, Amazon introduced a new storefront.
headline: I Haul, Therefore I Am

abstract: Within the boundaries of the crime-solving genius genre, “Cross” represents the dark yin and “The Lincoln Lawyer” the bright yang.
lead_para: On the page, Alex Cross, the embittered psychologist created by James Patterson, leads his fellow fictional crime solver Mickey Haller, the flamboyant lawyer created by Michael Connelly, 32 novels to seven. On the small screen, the tables turn: The Haller series “The Lincoln Lawyer” debuted its third season last month on Netflix while the first season of “Cross,” announced nearly five years ago, finally arrives Thursday on Amazon Prime Video.
headline: ‘Cross’ and ‘The Lincoln Lawyer’ Offer Different Spins on the Same Formula

abstract: Its shows have moved to Amazon Prime, where they will remain free.
lead_para: Amazon is folding Freevee, its ad-supported streaming service, into Prime Video, where its shows will remain free to viewers who don’t subscribe to Prime.
headline: Amazon Is Phasing Out Its Freevee Streaming Service

abstract: Mr. Bezos, who also owns The Washington Post, recently quashed the newspaper’s endorsement of Vice President Kamala Harris.
lead_para: Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon and the owner of The Washington Post, on Wednesday congratulated President-elect Donald J. Trump on his victory, a sign of a potential thawing between Mr. Trump and the billionaire tech mogul.
headline: Jeff Bezos Congratulates Trump on Victory

abstract: “Last One Laughing,” an Amazon Prime show in which contestants try not to crack up, has spawned spinoffs in more than a dozen countries — though not the United States.
lead_para: In early 2016, James Farrell, then the head of content at Amazon Studios for Japan, was looking for original programming that could help the streamer gain a foothold in the region.
headline: On This Comedy Show, You’d Better Not Laugh

abstract: Chafing at their dependence, Amazon, Google, Meta and Microsoft are racing to cut into Nvidia’s dominant share of the market.
lead_para: In September, Amazon said it would invest up to $4 billion in Anthropic, a San Francisco start-up working on artificial intelligence.
headline: Nvidia’s Big Tech Rivals Put Their Own A.I. Chips on the Table

abstract: The explosion of the e-commerce economy has created an opportunity for thieves — and a conundrum for the railways.
lead_para: Of all the dozens of suspected thieves questioned by the detectives of the Train Burglary Task Force at the Los Angeles Police Department during the months they spent investigating the rise in theft from the city’s freight trains, one man stood out. What made Victor Llamas memorable wasn’t his criminality so much as his giddy enthusiasm for trespassing. He was a self-taught expert of the supply chain, a connoisseur of shipping containers. Even in custody, as the detectives interrogated him numerous times, after multiple arrests, in a windowless police-station room in the spring of 2022, a kind of nostalgia would sweep over the man. “He said that was the best feeling he’d ever had, jumping on the train while it was moving,” Joe Chavez, who supervised the task force’s detectives, told me. “It was euphoric for him.”
headline: The Great Freight-Train Heists of the 21st Century

abstract: Amazon walked away from the $1.7 billion acquisition of iRobot as it faces questions from regulators in the European Union and United States.
lead_para: Amazon said on Monday that it was abandoning plans to buy iRobot, the maker of the self-driving Roomba vacuum, after regulators raised concerns the deal would hurt competition.
headline: Amazon Scraps Deal to Buy Maker of Roomba Amid Regulatory Scrutiny

abstract: Vivienne Medrano’s animated musical series went from middle-school sketches to YouTube to a series streaming on Amazon.
lead_para: On Oct. 28, 2019, the animator and YouTube personality Vivienne Medrano celebrated a milestone: the release of “Hazbin Hotel,” a 30-minute pilot for an animated musical-comedy about a rehabilitation program that aspires to help Hell’s repentant demons get to Heaven.
headline: ‘Hazbin Hotel’ Is a Childhood Dream Streamed Out to the World

abstract: The festival, seen as a barometer for the overall health of the film industry, featured several movies and documentaries snatched up by studios and streaming services.
lead_para: Talk of the demise of the Sundance Film Festival as an incubator for audience-friendly independent films appears to have been greatly exaggerated.
headline: After a Slow Start, Sundance Finishes With Plenty of Sales

abstract: The agency is concerned that transactions including Microsoft’s $13 billion investment in OpenAI could hinder competition and innovation.
lead_para: Tech giants like Microsoft, Amazon and Google have sought an edge in the artificial intelligence race by investing in innovative start-ups like OpenAI and Anthropic.
headline: The F.T.C. Takes on A.I. Deals

abstract: The agency plans to scrutinize Microsoft, Amazon and Google for their investments in the A.I. start-ups OpenAI and Anthropic.
lead_para: The Federal Trade Commission opened an inquiry on Thursday into the multibillion-dollar investments by Microsoft, Amazon and Google in the artificial intelligence start-ups OpenAI and Anthropic, broadening the regulator’s efforts to corral the power the tech giants can have over A.I.
headline: Federal Trade Commission Launches Inquiry Into A.I. Deals by Tech Giants

abstract: As its second season ends, our contributor considers the broad appeal of Amazon’s big, brawny hit.
lead_para: The first season of Amazon’s “Reacher” was one of the streamer’s biggest hits, drawing critical acclaim and a massive audience. The second season, which concludes on Jan. 19, is an even bigger sensation. It became Prime Video’s most streamed title of 2023.
headline: Why ‘Reacher’ Is More Than Just ‘Peak Dad TV’

abstract: Ring, a maker of internet-connected cameras that is owned by Amazon, said the police could no longer ask people to share video recordings using the company’s app, Neighbors.
lead_para: Ring, a home security camera company owned by Amazon, said that it would stop letting police departments request users’ footage in its app amid longstanding concerns from privacy advocates about the company’s relationship with law enforcement.
headline: Ring to Stop Allowing Police to Request Videos From Security Cameras

abstract: The first two episodes of the show, which was filmed during the city’s pandemic restrictions, were released last week but were not available there.
lead_para: At the height of Hong Kong’s Covid restrictions, the government gave Nicole Kidman and several others a rare exemption from the weeks of hotel quarantine required for travelers so that they could film a series about the malaise of privileged expatriates.
headline: Amazon Filmed ‘Expats’ in Hong Kong, but People There Can’t Watch It

abstract: Our TV critic on the joy and melancholy of “Northern Exposure.”
lead_para: “Northern Exposure” premiered on CBS in 1990. Over the next six years, it drew millions of viewers, won a raft of Emmys and adorned the cover of multiple issues of TV Guide. But despite its success decades ago, “Northern Exposure” wasn’t widely available on streaming platforms until recently. Our TV critic Margaret Lyons considers how being out of circulation affected the show’s legacy, and the joys of rediscovering this classic series.
headline: A Beloved ’90s TV Show Finally Comes to Streaming

abstract: The layoffs add to a growing number of cuts in the tech industry this past year.
lead_para: Amazon is laying off hundreds of employees at its studio division as well as its subsidiary Twitch to reduce costs, the latest in a wave of new job cuts hitting the tech industry.
headline: Amazon Cuts Hundreds of Jobs at Studios and Twitch

abstract: Amazon, Google, Microsoft and other tech companies have been on a layoff spree this month, with the latest cuts differing from last year’s mass reductions.
lead_para: Last year, Mark Zuckerberg declared 2023 to be a “year of efficiency.” His company, Meta, soon laid off a third of its employees. Amazon, Google and Microsoft also cut tens of thousands of workers.
headline: Focused Cuts and Fewer Layers: Tech Layoffs Enter a New Phase

abstract: Various companies have used the term to describe job cuts, but some criticize the language as opaque.
lead_para: Various companies have used the term to describe job cuts, but some criticize the language as opaque.
headline: Why Are So Many Companies ‘Rightsizing’?

abstract: See how a handful of stocks have had an outsize impact on the performance of the S&P 500
lead_para: See how a handful of stocks have had an outsize impact on the performance of the S&P 500
headline: These Seven Tech Stocks Are Driving the Market

abstract: Seven tech stocks, including Meta, Nvidia and Apple, have accounted for roughly 90 percent of the S&P’s gains over the past 12 months.
lead_para: Seven tech stocks, including Meta, Nvidia and Apple, have accounted for roughly 90 percent of the S&P’s gains over the past 12 months.
headline: The S&P 500 Through the Prism of a ‘Magnificent 7’

abstract: After mass layoffs and a pivot to A.I., the tech industry has been scaling back on the splashy and quirky benefits it had become known for.
lead_para: A deep-tissue massage. Housekeeping and laundry services. A haircut after lunch.
headline: What Is (or Was) ‘Perks Culture’?

abstract: Many Haitian immigrants work at an Amazon warehouse near Springfield, packaging thousands of holiday gifts. But after Donald Trump won the election, some worry about their future.
lead_para: In a vast Amazon warehouse in central Ohio, the stress might seem to be all about the work. It’s the holidays, and like every other Amazon fulfillment center, the one in West Jefferson is under the gun. Hundreds of employees are working 12-hour shifts, racing to sort and pack thousands upon thousands of items destined to land in living rooms before Christmas and Hanukkah.
headline: Haitians in Ohio Work to Keep the Holidays on Track. But They Wonder: Can They Stay?

abstract: Mr. Altman and OpenAI have recently hired key executives who previously worked for the Clinton, Obama and Biden administrations.
lead_para: OpenAI said on Friday that its chief executive, Sam Altman, was planning to donate $1 million to President-elect Donald J. Trump’s inaugural fund, joining a number of tech companies and executives who are working to improve their relationships with Mr. Trump.
headline: OpenAI’s Sam Altman to Donate $1 Million to Trump’s Inaugural Fund

abstract: The Amazon founder said he saw signs of a “calmer” Donald J. Trump on the eve of his return to the White House.
lead_para: Does Jeff Bezos fear President-elect Donald J. Trump? Quite the contrary.
headline: Jeff Bezos, a Past Trump Foe, Is Optimistic About a Second Term

abstract: The retail giant said it expected its operations to be largely unaffected by the strike of some drivers at contracting firms Amazon uses to deliver packages.
lead_para: Workers who deliver packages from seven Amazon facilities across the country went on strike Thursday morning, according to the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the union that represents them.
headline: Amazon Delivery Drivers at Seven Hubs Walk Out

abstract: During an interview at the DealBook Summit on Wednesday, Jeff Bezos, the Amazon and Blue Origin founder, said President-elect Donald J. Trump was calmer and more confident now.
lead_para: During an interview at the DealBook Summit on Wednesday, Jeff Bezos, the Amazon and Blue Origin founder, said President-elect Donald J. Trump was calmer and more confident now.
headline: Bezos Is ‘Very Optimistic’ About a Second Trump Term

abstract: Listen to our interview with Jeff Bezos.
lead_para: DealBook Summit includes conversations with business and policy leaders at the heart of today’s major stories, recorded live at the annual DealBook Summit event in New York City.
headline: From Amazon to Space — Jeff Bezos Talks Innovation, Progress and What’s Next

abstract: The billionaire founder of Amazon spoke with Andrew Ross Sorkin at the DealBook Summit.
lead_para: Jeff Bezos, the billionaire founder of Amazon and the owner of The Washington Post, defended his decision to end presidential endorsements at The Post and expressed optimism about a second Trump administration at the DealBook Summit on Wednesday. But he also delved into his personal philosophy in his discussion with Andrew, including how he approaches entrepreneurship and leadership.
headline: Why Jeff Bezos Likes ‘Messy’ Meetings

abstract: Remote work is increasingly a privilege enjoyed by the most affluent Americans.
lead_para: When it comes to remote work, executives want workers to do as they say, not as they do.
headline: Packed Cubicles, Empty Corner Office: Remote Work Is Increasingly a Right of the Rich

abstract: Amazon, Advanced Micro Devices and several start-ups are beginning to offer credible alternatives to Nvidia’s chips, especially for a phase of A.I. development known as “inferencing.”
lead_para: On the south side of Austin, Texas, engineers at the semiconductor maker Advanced Micro Devices designed an artificial intelligence chip called MI300 that was released a year ago and is expected to generate more than $5 billion in sales in its first year of release.
headline: The Furious Contest to Unseat Nvidia as King of A.I. Chips

abstract: It was a week of frenzied activity, as Silicon Valley billionaires and their companies brandished checks and compliments for the President-elect.
lead_para: The $1 million donations came gradually — and then all at once.
headline: In Display of Fealty, Tech Industry Curries Favor With Trump

abstract: Decades after mega retail centers became a shorthand for bland suburbia, there may be some hope for them yet.
lead_para: Recently, a retail mirage of sorts appeared just off the Hempstead Turnpike on the Queens-Long Island border, next to the Belmont horse racetrack and the UBS arena, home of the New York Islanders hockey team and the occasional Harry Styles concert.
headline: What Do We Want From the Mall?

abstract: A recent visit to the company’s overhauled drone delivery program in Arizona left me impressed by the drones, but skeptical that the public will welcome them.
lead_para: Over the past few weeks, concerned New Jersey residents have craned their heads skyward to track the movements of what appeared to be mysterious drones overhead, formulate theories about their origins and strategize about how to get rid of them.
headline: Are Amazon’s Drones Finally Ready for Prime Time?

abstract: Powerful Americans have lost the will to resist Trump.
lead_para: At a press conference at Mar-a-Lago on Monday, Donald Trump described recent visits from Tim Cook, C.E.O. of Apple, Sergey Brin, a co-founder of Google, and other tech barons. “In the first term, everyone was fighting me,” he said. “In this term, everyone wants to be my friend.” For once, he wasn’t exaggerating.
headline: The Great Capitulation

abstract: A staff report by the Senate labor committee, led by Bernie Sanders, uncovered evidence of internal concern about high injury rates at the e-commerce giant.
lead_para: For years, worker advocates and some government officials have argued that Amazon’s strict production quotas lead to high rates of injury for its warehouse employees. And for years, Amazon has rejected the criticism, arguing that it doesn’t use strict quotas, and that its injury rates are falling close to or below the industry average.
headline: Amazon Disregarded Internal Warnings on Injuries, Senate Investigation Claims

abstract: Comcast and Warner Bros. Discovery are rearranging their businesses for mergers and acquisitions. Experts say the next year could transform the media industry.
lead_para: The people in charge of the world’s biggest media companies are setting the stage for a flurry of deal making.
headline: Media Moguls Set the Stage for Deal Mania

abstract: It’s got a great cast. It looks cinematic. It’s, um … fine. And it’s everywhere.
lead_para: A few years ago, “Atlanta” and “PEN15” were teaching TV new tricks.
headline: The Comfortable Problem of Mid TV

abstract: Video of a collision during the filming of “The Pickup” shows an armored truck and an S.U.V. veering off a road before the truck flips onto the smaller vehicle.
lead_para: Eight crew members, including two who were ejected from a vehicle, were taken to hospitals after a crash on the set of the movie “The Pickup,” the authorities said on Thursday.
headline: Crew Members Were Ejected From Vehicle in Movie Set Crash, Police Say

abstract: Galena, a 6-year-old shorthair, was found in an Amazon warehouse a week after she climbed into a 3-by-3-foot cardboard box at her owner’s home.
lead_para: When Carrie Clark got a phone call on April 17 from a veterinarian in California informing her that her cat, which had vanished from her Utah home a week earlier, had been found some 500 miles away, her first reaction was disbelief.
headline: Stowaway Cat Gets From Utah to California in Amazon Returns Package

abstract: The spending that the industry’s giants expect artificial intelligence to require is starting to come into focus — and it is jarringly large.
lead_para: If 2023 was the tech industry’s year of the A.I. chatbot, 2024 is turning out to be the year of A.I. plumbing. It may not sound as exciting, but tens of billions of dollars are quickly being spent on behind-the-scenes technology for the industry’s A.I. boom.
headline: In Race to Build A.I., Tech Plans a Big Plumbing Upgrade

abstract: In theory, getting deliveries can be more efficient than driving to the store. But you may still want to think before you add to cart.
lead_para: The convenience of online shopping is hard to beat. But it uses a lot of energy and resources and can lead to more waste.
headline: Is Online Shopping Bad for the Planet?

abstract: TV’s latest big-ticket video game adaptation, from the creators of “Westworld,” takes a satirical, self-aware approach to the End Times.
lead_para: The scream was just right — bloodcurdling, if also very funny — and the practical effects crew had finally found the proper volume and trajectory of the water cannon. The idea was to film what might happen if you ripped a man from the throat of a mutant salamander, exploding its guts like a giant water balloon.
headline: ‘Fallout’ Finds the Fun in an Apocalyptic Hellscape

abstract: For years, federal lawmakers have tried to pass legislation to rein in the tech giants. The TikTok law was their first success.
lead_para: The swift passage this week of legislation to force the sale or ban of TikTok was the first time a federal tech law has been approved in years.
headline: TikTok Broke the Tech Law Logjam. Can That Success Be Repeated?

abstract: The Federal Trade Commission is sending payments to customers who had certain Ring home security cameras and accounts during a particular time period, the agency said.
lead_para: The Federal Trade Commission said this week that some people who had bought certain home security cameras made by Ring, which is owned by Amazon, would be eligible for refunds for their purchase. The payments, totaling more than $5.6 million, are part of a settlement between Ring and the F.T.C. over claims that the company failed to protect customer accounts.
headline: How to Claim Your Part of a $5.6 Million Ring Settlement

abstract: The war-scarred ghouls and bulky power armor seen in three decades of video games arrive in the new TV show “Fallout.”
lead_para: The new TV series “Fallout” on Prime Video is based on a gargantuan video game universe of warring factions, world-changing stakes and irradiated monsters. Although the show has an original plot and viewers do not need to be experts on the source material, you may prefer to watch with some level of fluency.
headline: Welcome, Vault Dwellers: A Guide to the Fallout Universe

abstract: The company also reported that profit more than tripled, to $10.4 billion, topping Wall Street expectations.
lead_para: Amazon reported its highest first-quarter profit on Tuesday as it continued to wring efficiencies out of its retail business and recharge growth in its cloud computing operations.
headline: Amazon Reports $143.3 Billion in Revenue for First Quarter of 2024

abstract: The Teamsters union has made little headway in organizing workers at Amazon and FedEx despite wage and other gains it secured at UPS last year.
lead_para: Last year, two unions representing workers at three large automakers and UPS negotiated new labor contracts that included big raises and other gains. Leaders of the unions — the United Automobile Workers and the Teamsters — hoped the wins would help them organize workers across their industry.
headline: The Delivery Business Shows Why Unions Are Struggling to Expand

abstract: The second season of this Amazon series, all of which is available now, cranks up both the time-travel and the outrageous soapiness.
lead_para: Season 1 of “Outer Range,” on Amazon, was intriguing and unsatisfying — lush, expansive and compelling, but also marred by abundant faux-deep nonsense and a total lack of resolution. It’s a “this is my family’s land, grumble grumble” ranch drama ostensibly starring Josh Brolin, but the real star of the show is a big hole. And not just any hole — a magic hole! A hole that transports you through time! Sometimes people disappear. Sometimes the hole disappears.
headline: ‘Outer Range’ Is a Dizzying Sci-Fi Drama, With Buffalo

abstract: As the Justice Department’s case against Google nears an end, the federal government has more suits in the pipeline trying to rein in Big Tech.
lead_para: The U.S. government’s landmark antitrust trial against Google’s search business is nearing its conclusion. But the parade of major federal cases challenging Big Tech’s power is just getting going.
headline: U.S. Antitrust Case Against Google Is Just the Start

abstract: Ads are here, there — almost everywhere — on streaming services now.
lead_para: Not long ago, streaming TV came with a promise: Sign up, and commercials will be a thing of the past.
headline: What Happened to Our Ad-Free TV?

abstract: Tech giants are building power-hungry data centers to run their artificial intelligence tools. The costs of that demand surge are becoming clearer.
lead_para: The boom in artificial intelligence has minted billions in (paper) wealth for tech giants like Microsoft and Amazon. But there’s an overlooked set of winners as well: utilities and energy companies.
headline: How Bad Is A.I. for the Climate?

abstract: Expectations are sky-high for the chipmaker’s latest earnings report. The company is at the center of Wall Street’s focus on artificial intelligence.
lead_para: Despite concerns about stubbornly high inflation, elevated interest rates and ballooning U.S. debt, the S&P 500 is trading at a record on Wednesday, having soared 27 percent over the past year.
headline: Testing the Nvidia Boom

abstract: The workers’ union hopes that adding employees at the Staten Island warehouse to a protest started by delivery drivers will increase pressure on Amazon.
lead_para: Signaling an escalation in a labor campaign that began at seven Amazon delivery hubs on Thursday, workers at the company’s largest Staten Island warehouse began a protest there at midnight on Saturday.
headline: Amazon Warehouse Workers in New York City Join Protest

abstract: Just a few years ago, media executives thought theatrical releases didn’t benefit their streaming services. Now, many of them think the opposite.
lead_para: Amazon Studios spent $250 million to make “Red One,” a comedic holiday action film starring Dwayne Johnson and Chris Evans. Then the company pushed the film into more than 4,000 theaters, spending tens of millions more to market it.
headline: Here’s a Hollywood Twist: Streaming Success Runs Through Theaters

abstract: We flew to Arizona to test the recently debuted service ourselves.
lead_para: This week, we took a field trip to the Phoenix suburbs to see Amazon’s newest iteration of drone delivery service in action. We toured the facility where these drones are in operation, spoke with the vice president and general manager of Prime Air, David Carbon, and watched from a local backyard as our own order dropped from the sky.
headline: Is Amazon’s Drone Delivery Finally Ready for Prime Time?

abstract: The move follows Meta’s donation of the same amount to the fund earlier this week.
lead_para: Amazon said on Thursday that it was planning to donate $1 million to President-elect Donald J. Trump’s inaugural fund, part of a pattern in which tech companies and their leaders are taking steps to repair their relationships with Mr. Trump.
headline: Amazon Plans $1 Million Donation to Trump’s Inaugural Fund

abstract: For many remote communities in the sparsely populated nation, Canada Post is the only parcel delivery option. Even Amazon relies on it.
lead_para: Every Christmas season, Elizabeth Teasdale sets aside an entire room in her house on Cape Breton Island in Nova Scotia to store presents for her family’s large holiday gathering. By now, 20 to 30 packages should be stashed away.
headline: A Postal Strike Means Fewer Gifts Under Canadian Christmas Trees

abstract: Retailers like Amazon, Walmart and Target have figured out that if they get you your online order today, you will probably spend more tomorrow.
lead_para: One day in early November, I ordered an emotional support pickle. The image on Amazon showed a green crocheted prolate vegetable, with a pink bow fixed on top and two black button eyes. It held a sign that read, “Emotional Support Pickle: I will always be around to let you know that you are a BIG DILL.”
headline: You Want That Gift to Arrive Today? This Is What It Takes.

abstract: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration agreed to withdraw citations at nine of 10 warehouses where it had flagged violations; the company agreed to a $145,000 penalty.
lead_para: Federal health and safety regulators announced a corporatewide settlement with Amazon on Thursday, bringing an end to cases involving accusations of safety violations at 10 warehouses in several states.
headline: Amazon Reaches Settlement to Resolve Federal Safety Accusations

abstract: The District of Columbia’s attorney general said the company deliberately outsourced Prime member deliveries in certain ZIP codes.
lead_para: The attorney general of the District of Columbia sued Amazon on Wednesday, accusing it of violating consumer protection laws by making slower deliveries to Prime members in historically lower-income neighborhoods.
headline: Amazon Sued Over Slow Deliveries to Low-Income Areas

abstract: A new rocket from Mr. Bezos’ company Blue Origin and a satellite system from Amazon could heat up competition with SpaceX, owned by Mr. Musk.
lead_para: Elon Musk and Jeff Bezos have become the two wealthiest men in the world thanks to their breakthrough technology companies. But Mr. Musk, through SpaceX, has long held a big lead in the pursuit closest to their hearts: colonizing space.
headline: Jeff Bezos Prepares to Close the Gap in His Space Race With Elon Musk

abstract: The new Amazon series isn’t reinventing the TV mystery, but it is a fun and clever watch, buoyed by a few well-timed and energetic twists
lead_para: The Australian dramedy “Population 11,” on Amazon Prime Video, is like a lot of recent shows: It is loosely inspired by a true story; it puts a quirky, relatively lighthearted spin on violence and suffering; it is set in a small town where everyone has strong murderer energy; and one of the characters is an aspiring podcaster, collecting evidence alongside the audience. Let’s spin the wheel, friends! This week we’re going to … Australia! For a show where there is a … missing long-lost father! You might recognize these performers from … “Superstore” and “Wentworth”! It is not particularly original, but it is fun.
headline: ‘Population 11’ Is a Peppy Small-Town Outback Mystery

abstract: “The Hammer” offers portraits of organizing efforts from around the country at a time when the future of union power has reached an inflection point.
lead_para: In 2022, after being elected president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the biggest federation of unions in the United States, Liz Shuler stood before a crowd of union officials gathered in a large ballroom in Philadelphia and announced a new goal: “In the next 10 years, we will organize and grow our movement by more than one million people!”
headline: The Labor Movement Hasn’t Taken Off. A New Book Explains Why.

abstract: Residents rarely learn how data centers and their noise and energy and water use may affect their lives until it’s too late.
lead_para: The revolution in artificial intelligence that promised us breakthroughs in medical research and corporate productivity seems to be running a little behind. But already A.I. has become something of a nightmare for the Americans who happen to live near one of the more than 5,000 data centers that power it and keep the cloud above our digital world running.
headline: Noisy, Hungry Data Centers Are Catching Communities by Surprise

abstract: This taut and serious Amazon series chronicles the time when Prince Andrew was interviewed on TV about his relationship with Jeffrey Epstein.
lead_para: “A Very Royal Scandal,” available now on Amazon Prime Video, tells — retells — the story of when the BBC journalist Emily Maitlis interviewed Prince Andrew on television in 2019 about his relationship to Jeffrey Epstein. The very first thing he says in the interview is that “there is no good time to talk about Mr. Epstein and all things associated.” Welp …
headline: ‘A Very Royal Scandal’ Is a Juicy British Drama

abstract: A group of people who participated in the reality competition show this summer are suing MrBeast’s production company.
lead_para: A group of contestants who participated in “Beast Games,” the reality competition show hosted by Jimmy Donaldson, better known online as MrBeast, are suing Mr. Donaldson and the production companies behind the show, accusing them of exposing participants to “dangerous circumstances and conditions.”
headline: ‘Beast Games’ Contestants File Lawsuit Claiming ‘Dangerous Conditions’ on Set

abstract: The Motion Picture Association has been wooing the company for years. The addition gives the group a lot more muscle.
lead_para: Hollywood’s top lobbying group, the Motion Picture Association, has a powerful new member: Amazon.
headline: Amazon Joins Hollywood’s Top Lobbying Group

abstract: The internet giant told employees on Monday that it expected them to return to the office full-time in January.
lead_para: Amazon told its corporate employees on Monday that they had to return to working in the company’s offices five days a week starting in January.
headline: Amazon Tells Corporate Workers to Be Back in the Office 5 Days a Week

abstract: From hurricanes to wildfires, a new generation of technologies could help utilities better plan for the risk of extreme weather to their electric grid.
lead_para: More than 4 million people were without power on Friday morning after the enormous ring of wind and rain known as Hurricane Helene made landfall in Florida and moved north.
headline: Extreme Weather Is Taxing Utilities More Often. Can A.I. Help?

abstract: “They should have just called it Strawberry. At least that’s delicious.”
lead_para: Last week, OpenAI released a preview of its hotly anticipated new model, o1. We discuss what it has excelled at and how it could accelerate the timeline for building superintelligence. Then, we explain why Meta is making teenagers’ Instagram accounts private by default. And, finally, we chat with the New York Times reporter Karen Weise about why Amazon is forcing its corporate employees to go back to working in the office five days a week and whether other companies will follow suit.
headline: OpenAI’s Reasoning Machine, Instagram Teen Changes and Amazon R.T.O. Drama

abstract: Under pressure from Chinese competitors, Amazon, Walmart and other U.S. retailers have been exploring ways to avoid tariffs. Could a new Biden administration rule change that?
lead_para: Major American retailers including Amazon and Walmart have been quietly exploring shifting toward a business model that would ship more goods directly to consumers from Chinese factories and require fewer U.S. workers in retail stores and logistics centers.
headline: New Tariff Rules Could Reverse a ‘Paradigm Shift’ in Retail

abstract: The chipmaker, which has been struggling, said on Monday that it obtained a new government grant, signed a contract with Amazon and would pause some initiatives.
lead_para: Intel, a Silicon Valley giant that has struggled after a series of stumbles, said on Monday that it had signed new contracts and made further belt-tightening plans as it tries to cope with a deep slump in its business.
headline: Intel, Aiming to Reverse Slump, Unveils New Contracts and Cost Cuts

abstract: The federal government has more lawsuits in the pipeline trying to rein in the tech giants, including another antitrust case against Google that goes to trial next month.
lead_para: The U.S. government’s landmark antitrust trial against Google’s search business concluded on Monday with a federal judge’s ruling that the company acted illegally to maintain a monopoly. But the parade of major federal cases challenging the power of the tech giants is just getting going.
headline: After Google Antitrust Ruling, Here’s Where Other Big Tech Cases Stand

abstract: The e-commerce giant reported a profitable second quarter, but warned that the third quarter will be harder to predict.
lead_para: Political violence. The Olympics. An unpredictable presidential election. A chaotic summer of news has distracted consumers, making it hard to know how they will spend, Amazon said Thursday.
headline: Amazon Cautions That When the News Gets Nutty, People Shop Less

abstract: “Maybe this actually is a chance to press the reset button on the internet.”
lead_para: This week, a federal judge ruled that Google acted illegally to maintain a monopoly in online search. David McCabe, a New York Times reporter, joins to discuss what happens next. Then, are we in an A.I. bubble? We weigh in on the wild market swings that started the week and consider the argument that A.I. is overhyped. And finally, it’s time for our new segment: We bat around some of the weirdest recent tech drama — including a MrBeast competition that went awry and a founder who dropped a diss track aimed at a rival. All aboard the Hot-Mess Express.
headline: Google’s Monopoly Money + Is the A.I. Bubble Popping? + The Hot-Mess Express

abstract: Google, Microsoft and Amazon have made deals with A.I. start-ups for their technology and top employees, but have shied from owning the firms. Here’s why.
lead_para: In 2022, Noam Shazeer and Daniel De Freitas left their jobs developing artificial intelligence at Google. They said the tech giant moved too slowly. So they created Character.AI, a chatbot start-up, and raised nearly $200 million.
headline: The New A.I. Deal: Buy Everything but the Company

abstract: He pioneered the bookstore-as-superstore, a retail behemoth that dominated the industry before Amazon overtook it with its online reach.
lead_para: Leonard Riggio, the brash, charismatic and literary-minded businessman who, in founding the giant Barnes & Noble retail chain, transformed the business of selling books as thoroughly as the rise of the paperback once did — and who was cast as both a hero and a villain for doing so — died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 83.
headline: Leonard Riggio, 83, Dies; Founded Barnes & Noble and Upended Publishing

abstract: Big technology companies show no signs of slowing their spending on artificial intelligence, even though a payoff still looks a long way away.
lead_para: Mark Zuckerberg, Meta’s chief executive, started 2023 by declaring it the “year of efficiency.” Like several of its big tech peers, Meta cut jobs and mothballed expansion plans.
headline: Tech Bosses Preach Patience as They Spend and Spend on A.I.

abstract: The contestants in the internet star’s “Beast Games” expected outlandish challenges and signed contracts that acknowledged risks of serious injury and death. Still, few were prepared for the conditions on set.
lead_para: Jimmy Donaldson is the internet’s fairy godmother.
headline: Willing to Die for MrBeast (and $5 Million)

abstract: The hedge fund mogul has been bankrolling a European patent fight against Intel, Dell, Amazon and other tech giants.
lead_para: A small computer chip design company, R2 Semiconductor, has been notching wins in a potentially big patent fight against Intel over the past few months — a dispute that could force Intel to stop selling several chip lines in Europe.
headline: Dan Loeb Enters the Chip Wars

abstract: Just when we thought the feud was cooling off, OpenAI pulled out the receipts.
lead_para: OpenAI responded to Elon Musk’s lawsuit this week, with a blog post that included emails dating to 2015. We talk about whether the lawsuit could have any impact on the company, and who stands to benefit from it. Then, will the European Union’s Digital Markets Act make the tech industry a more competitive environment for entrepreneurs? We look at how some of the biggest tech giants are changing their services to comply with the law. And finally, Kevin Roose and the Wall Street Journal reporter Joanna Stern compare notes on using the Apple Vision Pro.
headline: Musk vs. OpenAI, Europe’s Tech Crackdown and a Month With the Vision Pro

abstract: Washington’s crackdown on Big Tech is coming for Apple.
lead_para: Last week, the Justice Department took aim at Apple, accusing the company of violating competition laws with practices intended to keep customers reliant on their iPhones.
headline: The United States vs. the iPhone

abstract: For years, Apple, Google, Meta and others operated unfettered. But new laws and regulations have finally compelled them to make major shifts to their products and businesses.
lead_para: By Thursday, Google will have changed how it displays certain search results. Microsoft will no longer have Windows customers use its Bing internet search tool by default. And Apple will give iPhone and iPad users access to rival app stores and payment systems for the first time.
headline: Forced to Change: Tech Giants Bow to Global Onslaught of Rules

abstract: The latest investment brings Amazon’s total stake in the San Francisco company to $4 billion.
lead_para: Amazon said on Wednesday that it had added $2.75 billion to its investment in Anthropic, a start-up that competes with companies like OpenAI and Google in the race to build cutting-edge A.I. systems.
headline: Amazon Adds $2.75 Billion to Its Stake in the A.I. Start-Up Anthropic

abstract: Marc Lore, the entrepreneur behind Diapers.com and Jet.com, would like to disrupt food delivery. But he really wants to build a brand that actually lasts.
lead_para: When Marc Lore, the e-commerce billionaire, left his position as the chief executive of Walmart.com in 2021, he began to dabble in a variety of long-odds attempts to change the world. He backed a nuclear fusion start-up, and another designing flying taxis. Frustrated with the current state of capitalism, he embarked on plans to build, from scratch, a Bjarke Ingels-designed city of five million in the American West.
headline: He’s Not Just Looking to Make a Quick Billion

abstract: For years, Apple, Google, Meta and other tech giants operated unfettered. Now, regulators are taking steps to compel them to make major shifts to their products and businesses.
lead_para: For years, Apple, Google, Meta and other tech giants operated unfettered. Now, regulators are taking steps to compel them to make major shifts to their products and businesses.
headline: Five U.S. Cases Targeting Big Tech

abstract: Once again a juggernaut thanks to artificial intelligence, Microsoft has worked to shed its strong-arm image. Is there a catch?
lead_para: The December day in 2021 that set off a revolution across the videogame industry appeared to start innocuously enough. Managers at a Wisconsin studio called Raven began meeting one by one with quality assurance testers, who vet video games for bugs, to announce that the company was overhauling their department. Going forward, managers said, the lucky testers would be permanent employees, not temps. They would earn an extra $1.50 an hour.
headline: Why Microsoft Has Accepted Unions, Unlike Its Rivals

abstract: The company raised $7.3 billion over the last year, as the lure of artificial intelligence changes Silicon Valley deal-making.
lead_para: Last May, Anthropic, one of the world’s hottest artificial intelligence start-ups, raised $450 million from investors including Google and Salesforce. It was the beginning of an astonishing funding spree.
headline: Inside the Funding Frenzy at Anthropic, One of A.I.’s Hottest Start-Ups

abstract: The tech giant introduced the Rufus chatbot. It has lagged behind others on introducing consumer-facing generative artificial intelligence.
lead_para: Amazon entered the consumer chatbot fray on Thursday, announcing a new artificial intelligence personal shopping assistant as the company races to catch up with other tech giants.
headline: Amazon Enters Chatbot Fray With Shopping Tool

abstract: Books — often riddled with gross grammatical and factual errors — are appearing for sale online soon after the death of well-known people.
lead_para: After Joseph Lelyveld, a former executive editor of The New York Times, died last month, his brother Michael Lelyveld went online to see how he was being remembered. He found obituaries in major news outlets, as expected. But he also found other, unexpected portraits of his brother.
headline: A Celebrity Dies, and New Biographies Pop Up Overnight. The Author? A.I.

abstract: Companies like Meta that could tout their work in the fast-growing field saw a benefit in their fourth-quarter results — and won praise from eager investors.
lead_para: Earlier this week, Mark Zuckerberg of Meta endured a grilling on Capitol Hill and publicly apologized to relatives of victims of online abuse. Little more than a day later, he had a lot to crow about, as his business delivered some of its best quarterly earnings in years.
headline: A.I. Promises Give Tech Earnings a Jolt

abstract: Profits are up and the economy is strong. But the tech industry faces two challenges — dealing with a frenetic work force expansion in the pandemic and building A.I.
lead_para: After a year of big layoffs, job cuts at the tech industry’s largest companies trickled into the first month of 2024.
headline: Why Is Big Tech Still Cutting Jobs?

abstract: The company made the novel claim, echoing arguments by SpaceX and Trader Joe’s, in a legal filing while fighting a case.
lead_para: In the latest sign of a growing backlash within corporate America to the 88-year-old federal agency that enforces labor rights, Amazon argued in a legal filing on Thursday that the National Labor Relations Board was unconstitutional.
headline: Amazon Argues Labor Board Is Unconstitutional

abstract: New York magazine’s money columnist wrote about being conned out of $50,000 by crooks pretending to be from Amazon and government agencies. We asked the company and agencies for comment.
lead_para: When New York magazine’s finance advice columnist dropped an article that went viral on Thursday about falling victim to a $50,000 scam, my heart skipped a beat.
headline: What Amazon, the F.T.C. and C.I.A. Won’t Say When You’ve Been Scammed

abstract: The index is up TK percent this year.
lead_para: Stocks rose on Friday, with the S&P 500 index closing above 5,000 for the first time amid a rally fueled by better-than-expected earnings reports.
headline: Tech Rally Lifts S&P 500 Above 5,000 Mark

abstract: Canceling is simple. The tough part is remembering to do it.
lead_para: The dream of streaming — watch what you want, whenever you want, for a sliver of the price of cable! — is coming to an end.
headline: Streaming Prices Keep Going Up. Here’s How to Manage Subscriptions.
